name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements in preparation for the European Council on 22 and 23 June (2017/2625 (RSP)).

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, President Juncker, Commissioner, honourable Members, the 28 Heads of State and Government will be meeting in Brussels next week. They have a very dense agenda which will be spread over two days. The first item on the agenda is migration. The Eastern Mediterranean route and the Western Balkans route are largely under control. The most pressing issue today is the Central Mediterranean route. In February, leaders agreed on a list of measures to address the situation. Member States and institutions have followed up on this guidance and significantly increased their engagement. Still, the magnitude of the crisis and the harrowing numbers of lives lost at sea remind us every day that more is needed – more efforts and more coordination to implement what has been decided. The European Council will review the state of play and look at how to improve the effectiveness of our action. Leaders will also revert to the reform of the Common European Asylum System. The European Council is expected to give a steer for further work to continue under the Estonian Presidency. Second on the agenda is security and defence. In the light of recent tragic attacks, notably in Manchester and London, leaders will again speak out firmly against terrorism, hatred and violent extremism and will look at what more the EU can do. As concerns external security and defence, leaders established a comprehensive work programme in December. Since then more progress has been achieved than in the last ten years. Building on this new momentum, leaders will discuss further steps on some issues, for instance, permanent structured cooperation, EU battle groups or the industrial dimension of EU defence. Turning now to jobs, growth and competitiveness, which is the third item on the agenda, a year ago leaders set the deadline of 2018 to complete the Single Market in all its dimensions. They will therefore look at what has been achieved, and where we are lagging behind. This deadline should remain a strong driver to make headway at all levels, including in interinstitutional negotiations. Furthermore, in the light of recent developments, the European Council will return to trade policy. Leaders are expected to reaffirm the EU strong commitment to our trade policy. They will also discuss how the EU can make sure trade remains free and fair for all. To conclude, I would like to mention two other important topics. First, leaders will show their strong and continued support to the Paris Agreement on climate change. This is an important point, and we will discuss this here later on in the morning and I think that we should expect some strong language on this issue. Second, in preparation for the Estonian Presidency, leaders will encourage a broader outlook on the digital dimension of Europe. As demonstrated by recent cyber attacks, digital issues go beyond the Digital Single Market. They have a bearing on many if not all other EU policies. So for now, I thank you for your attention.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President of the Commission. - Mr President, Minister, honorable Members, since we last met here one month ago, Europe has again seen its way of life attacked through cowardly acts of terrorism. In Europe, determination will always triumph over fear. These attacks will not undermine our resilience. They do, however, bring into sharper focus the discussions on defense and security that we will have at this month’s European Council. Europeans expect their Union to keep them safe from threats, whether they be from within or without, and whatever their nature. That was recognized by EU leaders in Bratislava and in Rome when they pledged to step up their defense cooperation. They highlighted defense as one of the key issues for our Union when moving forward. To support that, and faithful to what I told this Parliament last September in the State of the European Union speech, the Commission last week published a reflection paper on the future of European defense, showing how far we can go depending on the level of ambition and political will of our Member States. We have all the tools we need in the Treaties to make it happen, including permanent structured cooperation, the sleeping beauty of the Lisbon Treaty. But now is the time to decide, and this House must play a full role in that debate. Whichever road we go down, our ever closer partnership with NATO will remain the cornerstone of Europe’s defense and security. On defense, the European Union and NATO are like twins. We are part of the same family, and rivalry is not an option. Within NATO there is a great deal the European Union can do to improve its own cooperation. The simple truth is that no European country alone can tackle the scale and complexity of the challenges we face, nor can we rely on any foreign power to do it for us. We cannot outsource our own security. That starts with the need to invest in a more efficient way. The United States already spends twice as much as all European countries combined, while Russia and China have dramatically stepped up their defense budgets in recent years. And 90% of the money we invest in defense, research and technology in Europe is spent without any kind of coordination at all. That leads to inefficiencies and duplication that could easily be avoided. That is why the European Defense Fund that the Commission proposed last week will support Member States' budgets and facilitate cooperation on joint research and purchasing of equipment and technology. We have earmarked EUR 590 million to support defense by 2020, and have proposed to allocate at least EUR 1.5 billion each year after that. The fund is both an investment boost to our industry and a statement of intent to our citizens, who expect us to do more to protect them. I was encouraged to see already vocal support for our proposals at last week's high-level conference on security and defense which I hosted with Prime Minister Sobotka in Prague, but also the Franco-German announcement for the development of a European drone program and the joint training of officers. We are not talking about the militarization of the European continent. It is about doing more together for the stability and peace of our continent. Monsieur le Président, Mesdames et Messieurs, il est normal que l’Union européenne s’implique fortement dans tout ce qui relève de la sécurité et de la défense. Mais la sécurité mondiale exige bien plus que les seuls efforts en matière de dépenses militaires. La stabilité européenne comme la stabilité mondiale dépendent aussi de nos efforts dans les domaines de la coopération au développement et de la lutte contre les changements climatiques, dont nous savons à quel point ils redessinent notre planète et sont source d’instabilité. Notre terre et tous ses peuples en subiront les effets. La montée des eaux n’a jamais été aussi rapid: elle menacera la côte du Bengale, comme la côte de Floride et certaines côtes européennes. Tous les peuples ne sont pas égaux face aux conséquences des changements climatiques. La partie la plus pauvre du monde, qui n’est responsable que de 7% of emissions from CO2, est la plus vulnérable. Cette fois-ci, nous ne pourrons pas prétendre que nous ne savions pas. À travers le monde, le nombre des catastrophes naturelles liées au climat a plus que triplé depuis le début des années 60. Chaque année, ces catastrophes ont provoqué plus de 60 000 decès, principalement, mais non exclusivement, dans les pays en développement. Les épisodes de sécheresse deviennent de plus en plus nombreux et de plus en plus graves, provoquant de véritables situations de famine, comme c’est actuellement le cas en Afrique de l’Est. Réduire les budgets de l’aide au développement ou remettre en cause les engagements pris à la COP 21, c’est porter une lourde responsabilité en nuisant gravement à la stabilité mondiale. Ce message, l’Union européenne doit continuer et continuera à le porter. Vous pouvez compter sur moi et le monde comptera sur nous. Nous avons connu, ces dernières années, le plus important afflux de réfugiés depuis la Deuxième Guerre mondiale, mais nous devons aujourd’hui prévenir une crise bien plus grave encore. Agissons sans perdre un seul instant, car ne pas tenir aujourd'hui les engagements de l'accord de Paris, c'est risquer de jeter, d'ici à 2050, jusqu'à 250 millions de réfugiés climatiques sur les routes de l ' exile. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! We have actually already taken on a pioneering role in reforming the European asylum and migration system. Even if public and public opinion often claim that the European Union is not making headway in the refugee crisis, this is not entirely true. This is proven by our current migration package, which the Commission sent to the European Council yesterday. We see more solidarity than before, but we don't see enough solidarity yet. And we see ours External borders are better protected than ever before. The Union and the Member States support Greece and Italy; we have redistributed 20,000 refugees from these two countries. This shows: where there is a will, there is a way. And we have set up central reception centers on site, to which we have sent EU officials, staff from EU agencies and experts from all Member States. At the same time, we have made the protection of our common external borders our responsibility. Thanks to the European Border and Coast Guard, we can now better secure the most endangered sections of the border. At the moment there are already 1,600 European border guards on duty - but nobody says it - to support the national border guards: 967 in Greece, 402 in Italy, 168 in Bulgaria and 65 in Spain. In addition, a pool of 1,500 border guards is immediately ready for action. We show solidarity not only within the Union, but also towards those states that take in a large proportion of the refugees. This includes Turkey. At my most recent meeting with President Erdoğan at the end of May, we both confirmed that we wanted to continue working on the successful implementation of the EU-Turkey refugee agreement. The EU is true to its word, and Turkey is also true to its word. Because today 98% fewer refugees come from Turkey to Greece than was the case before the agreement. But of course we will not rest on what we have achieved. Our reports clearly show where there are still shortcomings and where the Member States need to make further efforts. This is about very practical questions, such as the lack of equipment for European border and coastal protection. But it is also about fundamental questions, namely how Member States implement EU law. After a total of twelve reports in which we have repeatedly warned that some countries must do more to improve their There are still three countries - Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic - which have either not accepted a single refugee from Italy and Greece or have not accepted any refugees for over a year. That leaves us with no choice but to start infringement proceedings against these countries today. I would like to underline this: this is not about sanctions, it is about making it clear that the decisions made are applicable law, even if one has voted against it. The Commission is the guardian of the Treaties and we must do our duty, as we are doing today in 137 other infringement cases against a total of 27 Member States. We should stop arguing that initiating infringement proceedings equates to sanctions. This is about compliance with European law, and anyone who insists that European law be complied with does not sanction. (Applause) European solidarity cannot be a one-way street; traffic has to move in both directions. I am not giving up hope that the European spirit, European reason and our European values ​​will ultimately prevail and that we will not have to resolve this question of solidarity before the Court of Justice. European solidarity issues do not have to be resolved in court, but cry out for an immediate political response. Solidarity, however, cannot be enforced with a crowbar; it has to come from the heart, especially when it comes to human life. I will remind the Member States intensely of this at the next European Council. (Applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I want to start with a topic which is not officially on the agenda next week, but which will surely overshadow the whole debate – namely, the general election in the UK. Let me start with a frank analysis from our side: I do not think it is a good result, because we were asking London for clear orientation and stability, and what we see today is a situation of disorientation – some are calling it a chaotic situation – in London. Theresa May gambled and she lost, and the country is deeply divided. Twelve months after the Brexit result, when we look at the political landscape all over Europe, we now see clear leadership in France, Spain is stable, Italy is stable, Germany is stable, and so is Dublin. So Europe is united, but we are seeing a lot of problems on the table in London. So the main message for people in the European Union is that it is better to reform the European Union, if needed, than to destroy it or to leave it. (Applause) One inspiring element of this election is that the youth is back. They abstained in the Brexit decision, and now they have gone to vote and have taken their destiny into their own hands. That is a very promising thing, because they are in favour of partnership and in favour of Europe. A hard Brexit was what Theresa May offered, and I have to say that there is no majority for this option. In Great Britain, people are rethinking their priorities, and today they are mainly discussing jobs: that is what we should also focus on. Let us talk about jobs, let us talk about the economy, and about people’s daily lives. That is one thing.  The second thing is the official agenda: there, the most important thing is that we have had enough papers on the table and we have had enough talks on the issues. It is now time to act. That is what people all over Europe expect from our leaders. On defence, it is obvious we have the Commission’s very good papers – Jean—Claude Juncker’s papers – on the table, and we have the Bratislava decision on the table. So let us now start with cyber war, with drones, and with action in the Sahel Zone. It is now up to us simply to do it, and that is what we expect from the Council. On migration, for the EPP Group, the precondition for all further measures was always that we need strong border control. We have to protect our borders. When we listen to our Commission President, this is now much better organised and works much better than it has done in recent years. Now we can go a step further. I want to underline that on the question of solidarity it is not Europe which is failing, because Brussels – I should say the Commission – is offering a clear proposal, and we in Parliament have a clear majority in favour of practicing solidarity in the European Union. It is not Europe that is failing, but for the moment it is national egoism which is failing and not bringing results. That is why we should move. Let us go on and let us show leadership. With Brexit in mind, the most convincing thing that our leaders can do now is act. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before giving the floor to President Pittella, I wanted to tell you that today it will not be possible to grant "blue card" questions because times are very tight and we have two important guests who will participate in our working day.I also wanted to send a message of solidarity from the European Parliament to the city of London for the serious fire that is destroying a skyscraper in which there are injured and missing.So we are close to the city of London, once again hit by a dramatic event.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a dedication to Mrs May with one sentence: whoever wants to win big is always on the verge of losing everything. And thanks to the leader of the British Labor Party Jeremy Corbyn for the great victory obtained, which is a victory of courage in the political and programmatic proposal and also a victory of a just conception of Brexit, neither hard nor soft but right and fair. A joke about terrorism: if we want to be serious, the first thing we have to do is to strengthen the cooperation of the intelligence services, the rest is propaganda. With regard to refugees and immigration, the surveillance of the external borders is good and the infringement procedures are good, albeit late, because some Member States have been blocking the refugee relocation scheme for some time. I am sorry - I must say this to the Council and not to the Maltese Presidency, whom I thank very much - that the European Commission's proposal on the revision of the Dublin system lies in the Council like a closed book and not even leafed through. It is serious and shameful that that proposal was not even worthy of an opening for discussion, while Parliament has worked hard and is working hard. The problem is not just that of refugees, President Juncker, you know this well and Commissioner Avramopoulos knows it too. There is a big problem concerning the flows of irregular immigrants and we have to put one thing in our heads: if we want to reduce the irregularity of the flows we must guarantee the legality of the flows, that is, open legal channels for immigration. This is the main road, together with the other one that of a serious partnership with Africa, not bartering - we give some money, a few, to Africa and in exchange they accept return, repatriation - but a true partnership. political, economic and social that makes it possible to solve the great challenges facing Africa. Juncker talked about it, with reference to climate change, to the theme of education and to the theme of democracy.As long as Africa is the prey ground of multinationals that pocket gigantic revenues and give no return to African citizens, as long as there is no democracy and we do not help them build a democratic system and an autonomous and indigenous development, we do notwe will resolve the issue of irregular immigrants, because there they have two paths: either they come to us or they go with the terrorists of Boko Haram, there is no other path for those young people, for those girls.We have to offer perspective.If we offer this perspective to Africa, we also offer a better perspective to Europe.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the agenda for this Summit highlights some of the big challenges ahead: security, migration and asylum, Turkey, as well – as others have said – as some discussions on the Brexit negotiations. Topics we have discussed before and no doubt topics that we will discuss again; but each time we have to ask ourselves: are we any closer to solutions and real action? If you will allow me, let me start with the British general election. An election in which the Conservative party lost seats but not enough to lose power, and where the opposition gained seats but not enough to gain power and ended up 56 seats behind, and just as in any other country, for example the Netherlands at the moment, the largest party will seek to form a government with support from a smaller party. But the UK Government expects to begin negotiations later this month, for we have kept you waiting long enough.  Just as in this Parliament, the largest party will need to build wider coalitions in order to pass legislation. Now if that means addressing concerns over civil liberties while drafting new laws to tackle the threat of terrorism, to my mind a wider coalition is not necessarily a bad thing.  Can I also take this opportunity to thank colleagues from across the political spectrum for their messages of condolences and solidarity after the recent terrorist attacks in both Manchester and my home city of London. We may be divided on our politics but we are united in not wanting to allow the terrorists to win. (Applause) I hope the Council will understand the importance of tackling terrorism at different levels. At the international level: military cooperation without undermining NATO, better data sharing between national law enforcement agencies; at the national level: upholding the rule of law, our shared values and the security of our citizens, as well as making sure that any shared intelligence is actually acted upon; and at a local community level: encouraging local projects to tackle radicalisation at its roots.  But security is just one of the issues facing us. The migration crisis continues as does the EU-Turkey deal, and the ECR believes that the EU should focus on a new relationship based not on the false promise of membership, but on an honest relationship based on cooperation. Because while the deal with Turkey appears to be holding for now, the Council must seek consensus from all Member States to effectively tackle the migrant crisis, in case that agreement breaks down, by getting the basics right – processing asylum applications quickly and efficiently, returning those who do not qualify to their country of origin, agreeing clear criteria for qualification, based on the Geneva Convention – and by not continuing to pursue a struggling relocation scheme without the full support of all Member States.  Our discussions on the challenges will continue way beyond this Summit and future ones, but how many times do we have to discuss them before our voters see real progress? While others will call for new rules, the ECR Group calls for the EU to make what we already have work better. While others will call for more agencies, the ECR Group calls for more action and while others will call for further political integration, the ECR Group calls for political cooperation for a reformed EU which does less, but does it better.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, for once I have to contradict Manfred Weber. He said that there is at least one positive outcome of the British election: the disappearance of UKIP and of those who want not only Britain out of Europe, but who want to destroy the European Union from inside. I think that it is true that there will be a lot of items on the agenda in the European Council next week, but the main point on the agenda is whether we can now start the negotiations on Brexit. It is three years since the start of the debate, a year since the outcome of the British referendum and three months since the triggering of the notification, and we are not still not in a position to start negotiations, because there is – for the moment anyway – no clear position from the new government in the United Kingdom – if there is already a new government, because every day I read that there is a deal, but then six hours later there is no deal and they are still discussing it. But there are five pressing questions that need to be answered on a short—term basis. Mr Kamall, maybe you can help the government to respond to them. First: is the British position still that of the letter of 29 March, or will the new government take into account the outcome of the election, which was a little different from the hard talk of the letter of the 29th? The second question is: will it be the opinion of the Tories or the position of the whole nation? Party interest or national interest? Because this is not about the Tories leaving the European Union but about the UK leaving the European Union. The third question: what about the Good Friday Agreement? What is the proposal so that the Good Friday Agreement can be kept in place and that no hard border will be created between the Republic on the one hand and Northern Ireland on the other hand? The fourth question: will the British government – as we do on the European side – one hundred per cent guarantee the current rights of EU citizens living in Britain, like we are ready to guarantee the current rights of British citizens living on the continent? Finally, the fifth question: is it still the opinion of the UK government to leave the single market and the customs union? Is the populist illusion of limiting free movement in Europe really more important than the prosperity and fortune of British workers, British industry, British companies and the British economy? Because let us face reality. This Brexit has already had a negative impact on everybody in Europe, and especially on Britain. Zero growth in the first quarter in Britain; for the moment it is three times less than in the last quarter of last year. And because of what? Because of the uncertainty that has been created. So I think the time is now right for us to receive from the British side clear answers to these five questions so that these negotiations can start. I know that yesterday Emmanuel Macron, the new French President, spoke about an open door. He said that, if Britain is changing its mind, it will find an open door. I do not disagree with him but, like in Alice in Wonderland, all doors are now the same. It will be a brand new door with a new Europe: a Europe without rebates, without complexity, with real power and with unity. That is the door towards Europe. For me, Jean-Claude, the most important thing now is the reform of our Union, and for this reform not to be bogged down in these Brexit talks. Brexit talks for the moment look more like the Echternach Procession – you are from Luxembourg and maybe you can explain to everybody what the procession of Echternach is – namely two steps forward and one step back. That is typical Echternach. I am very grateful to the Commission for the different reflection papers that they have put on the table, but the Commission is more than a think tank. I think the moment is now there, when we start these Brexit talks, to have also legislative proposals on the reform of the European Union, on defence – as you have done – and on economic and monetary union. But not only reflection papers: we also need legislative proposals. Do not leave the space open for the Council. It is not for the Council to fill in the space; it is the Commission that will have to do it with legislative proposals. We have now a new president in France who is pro-European, and we will have German elections. That is the moment to go forward. We always say do not waste a good crisis. Well, do not waste a good election cycle either.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! In my opinion, there are three topics that are very topical and that must certainly play a role both officially and unofficially at the Council meeting: On the one hand, there is the migration crisis, which I will come back to in a moment, the Brexit, but also the situation in Greece. I would like to ask you for the Council, too, to take a position with a view to the upcoming meeting of creditors and euro area finance ministers, in order to make it clear that we must finally put an end to blackmail. Now finally money has to be paid. But now negotiations on a haircut must finally begin. How do you want to talk about jobs and growth on the radio if you just let parts of the European Union break away and don't ensure that conditions arise there that make jobs and growth possible in the first place? That's the one point. I would just like to make one comment about Brexit because a lot has already been said: Theresa May is getting the support of the DUP. I would like to draw your attention once again to the fact that this fact alone violates the mandate's requirement that all parts of the Good Friday Agreement must be observed. The British government is committed to neutrality and impartiality between the two ruling forces in Northern Ireland. I really ask for your attention here. When it comes to addressing the issue of the migration crisis, I would like to remind you once again: Please ensure that legal and safe channels are opened! The dead in the Mediterranean do not allow us to continue shirking this decision. In my view, they do not allow us as the European Union to organize deals with Sudan and Libya. Both are regimes - some of them are failed states. We finance forces directly in Sudan that were among those who took massive action against migrants from other regions, from other countries in Africa, deport them again or are responsible for inhuman treatment, for torture, for theft, for everything. We know that the Libyan coast guard is on the move, for example to impede sea rescue. We know the letter that “Sea-Watch” and “Doctors Without Borders” wrote to the Federal Chancellor, in which they asked her to finally put a stop to it, to finally ensure that we get this money - for example the 140 Millions to Sudan to finance the fact that Sudan is holding back the refugees with its forces - kindly put in the countries from which the refugees come. We must finally give concrete and long-term help to all those countries in Africa; Otherwise, the demands for closed borders are simply inhumane, because they lead us to keep putting people back. You, Mr Juncker - and this is my last request here today - spoke of the Union helping Greece and Italy: Please go to the hotspots! Yes, there is help, but on the other hand there are also efforts to hinder family reunification, for example, and also to return migrants to Greece and Italy. We can't let that happen. Solidarity is not voluntary in the European Union. You are right about that, and we will support you there. Infringement proceedings against those who do not participate are correct. Sanctions in the sense that funds are cut - that's not the point. It is really about making solidarity a compulsory part of the European Union.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I share the calls of some of our colleagues for more solidarity on the refugee issue. I think it is super disappointing that the Council has dropped any progress on the issue of solidarity from the agenda, and I am afraid that if you cannot even solve that task, then I really have a hard time imagining how there can be progress in other areas – at least not in a way that will be satisfactory. I think the reason for that is that for solving problems you would actually need to tackle their root causes. You would have to look at the root cause for why people have to flee, and do something about that. You would have to look at the root causes for conflict and not just spend more money, and also look at the root causes of radicalisation and terror. Your answer to conflicts and violence worldwide is just to push for more military spending. You want to actually take money away from SME funding and from structural funds and put it into the weapons industry. But I do not really think that that particular industry really needs that extra bit of help, but what we are actually doing here – or what we would be doing here – is actually to make a 29th or 28th sort of defence policy. But rather than doing that and wasting a lot of money, we should make pooling and sharing the rule, and not the exception. This sort of cooperation could actually save us something like EUR 100 billion every year: money that is actually urgently needed to tackle all the root causes of conflicts, for example, in the world.  On terrorism we also urgently need answers, but I do not think that your recipe of simply collecting more and more data is going to do it. Rather, we need more policewomen and policemen on the ground. We need to strengthen the exchange of data on actual suspects and unknown risk persons, so that the tools that we already have today actually serve the security of our citizens. And yes, of course we need to prosecute those who pose a real threat to us and our way of life – absolutely – but we also need to look further into the root causes of radicalisation so that fewer people become a threat to our security and to our freedom. I wish the Presidency good luck with their discussions, and I hope that it will defy my low expectations and actually dare to look into the root causes and come up with solutions that actually solve something.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I know that a lot of the people here are very pleased with the result of the UK general election and view it as a victory for the EU. Let me give you a sense of perspective: in the 2015 general election, just 13% of voters voted for parties – namely UKIP, which was the only one – that wanted to leave the European Union. Last Thursday, over 85% of British voters voted for parties on a manifesto not just of leaving the European Union, but of leaving the single market as well. In fact, on the morning of the general election, 70% of the British public – whichever way they had voted in the referendum – simply wanted the government to get on and complete and conclude Brexit.  I know that Theresa’s terrible campaign has cast a bit of doubt on this, and I saw that Emmanuel Macron yesterday – a call echoed by Mr Verhofstadt this morning – said that there is still time for the United Kingdom to change its mind; that it does not have to leave. Let me tell you that the only certainty in this mess is that we will be leaving. But that has not stopped a parade of former prime ministers and of former European Commissioners from lining up and attempting to get the British Government to backslide on its commitments. There is now a big push, a big drive, for us to opt for a Norway-style option, and I have to confess that your chief negotiator, Mr Barnier, is right: it took Theresa May nine months to trigger Article 50, and by the time the talks start it will be nearly four months since it was triggered, so I do accept that we go into this, as a British Government, with a British Prime Minister in a very weak position. And she is caught in a bit of a pincer movement, because the political class would like us to stay in the customs union and to stay in the single market, but the people have made it perfectly clear they want us to leave both of those things. And I would say this: that unless Theresa May – and it is difficult for her, because she never really believed in Brexit – stands up at the summit next week, in those negotiations, and makes it absolutely clear that she is not giving an inch – that we are leaving the single market – then her own party will get rid of her, and then yet more time will be lost in the Article 50 process.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.- On 22 June, the Council will discuss, among other things, EU defense, Brexit and migration.Let me be clear right away.On EU defense: we do not want an EU army, but cooperation of sovereign states within NATO.That got us through the Cold War.There is no need for a bureaucratic, money-consuming EU army.About Brexit: England is leaving the EU because the EU is a failed project developing into a second Soviet Union.So I don't want a billion dollar bill for England.The EU must stop and make way for economic cooperation between sovereign states.On migration: the EU appears unable to stop NGOs that have already picked up tens of thousands of migrants from Libya with rented boats instead of dragging them back.I hereby express my support for Hungary and the other Visegrad countries in their fight against Islamization.Let the Council follow this example.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Mr President, colleagues, citizens in Europe and overseas, I am also asking for solidarity, but in this case solidarity with my homeland: Hungary. As you all know, we resist mass migration and we keep defending our borders and the borders of Europe. The European Union wants to push us on our knees. Now they started infringement proceedings against us; they want to punish us hard, they want to weaken our economy, and I ask for your solidarity and support around the world. Please write letters of dissent to this odd, strange man Mr Juncker, and moreover make Hungary and Hungarian goods and services trendy. Lots of you are now deciding where to go for a holiday: come to our safe country which is still European, come to Hungary; we have fantastic thermals spas, you can get your health back; we have a fantastic beautiful capital – Budapest; buy Hungarian products; if you go to see friends, bring a bottle of Hungarian wine or some good Hungarian food; show that you support Hungary and we will not give up.

name: Herbert REUL
text: - Gentlemen Presidents, dear colleagues! We have just heard from someone like that about how great Brexit is. The result of Brexit is plain and simple: there is a government here that is no longer able to negotiate, people are sliding into an uncertain future, and there is more enthusiasm for Europe in the rest of Europe. That's the truth, that's the result. I think we must now use the result as an opportunity for ourselves and seize the opportunity. And here the Council - which in recent years has not always been able to act as we would have liked - to seize the opportunity to make the best of it now. Incidentally, this also means, Madam, that rules that have been agreed upon are observed by everyone. If they are not adhered to, then you get criticism. That's the way it is in life. If I park incorrectly, I get a problem too. Rules are there to ensure that they are adhered to, in all questions - in all questions, including national debt. The second point is that if the Council meets now and wants to seize the opportunity, then I think that the Commission's presentation, especially in the area of ​​security and defense, is extremely interesting and good. Just take two or three things out of it - you don't have to do everything - take two or three things out of it and put a first point and show the people in Europe who are now back on the streets and say: “Europe is great, is valuable “: We can solve that, we take care of the problems that arise, and we also create very specific concepts. More cooperation - specifically, not generally, but practically doing something in the field of cybercrime, doing something in the field of drones, implementing it, delivering realities. This is the very best. And in this respect, Commission President Juncker has just made something important. Maybe we explain this far too little.Of course, Ms. Keller has not finished the refugee issue.Who thinks that?But we can at least say: We still have a lot of work to do, but we have also achieved a lot.It is true that these agreements with Turkey were successful, even if I do not like everything that is happening in Turkey.But the results aren't that bad.The numbers have fallen, relocations are working - far too little, but in part.It doesn't work for all states to participate, yes.I can also tell everything that doesn't work.But wouldn't it be intelligent now, at a time when people in Europe are having fun, hope and interest in Europe again, to report on their successes?I invite you: just take part!

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – (inaudible) version just suffered a big blow: the 27 are, in fact, more united in implementing the roadmap adopted in Rome. And, once and for all, the European Union needs to assert itself as a political entity and a strong pillar of the multilateral system. So the defence package just presented by the Commission is certainly a very important move, and we need to be prepared to have that discussion about the package, but we know that lasting peace also depends a lot on permanent systemic action for development worldwide, starting with Africa. We know this very well. We also need to be prepared to open a new generation of trade agreements, pushing for sustainable development all over the world. At the same time, we also need to build much more powerful instruments to cope with citizens’ concerns.  There is a lot of hard work to be done. We have just now the revision of the European Fund for Strategic Investments and we need to make sure that this fund will become more powerful, pushing for real, additional, strategic investment projects. We need to make sure that the upcoming pillar of social rights will prepare the labour market in Europe to provide better jobs, particularly for young people, and we need to make sure that our eurozone will start working for real convergence. So this is a very demanding internal agenda.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: - The European Council will shortly review the problem of irregular migration of economic migrants from Libya to Italy. In addition to the 200 million euros that we are investing in humane reception in Libya and the surrounding area, it is time to work on a return policy from the EU, based on our experiences with the EU-Turkey deal. This deal resulted in swift asylum procedures in Greece so that all refugees who were already safely in Turkey could be returned to that country. With this we got the flow of refugees under control. I wonder what we are waiting for to establish the same kind of cooperation with all the countries in North Africa. Why should we stick to that one EU-Turkey deal? After all, it is legal to return migrants to a safe harbor. According to the Commission itself, this is a place where human lives are not threatened, where basic needs are met and where transport can also be arranged. Outside of Turkey, other North African countries are certainly eligible for this. I therefore call on all European leaders to investigate what legal options there are, for example, to reach an EU-Libya deal. This is the only way to avoid fatal tragedies at sea.

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, I have just noticed something and wondered if everybody else had noticed the same thing: that all the leaders today are speaking in English. They do not normally speak in English. This is extremely strange, and I thought my good friend President Jean Claude Juncker here had said that English was no longer the language of the European Parliament. Is there something I have missed here, ladies and gentlemen?

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thanks but it's not under the regulation.Excuse me.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: –Mr President, I was thinking of talking about the outsourcing of immigration and asylum controls, a process that dilutes responsibilities in favor of an imprecise legal framework and weak or no democratic controls, a process that has irresponsible consequences. But I have listened carefully to Mr Juncker and, although I do not expect a change in policy, I would like to urge him to be careful with the terminology. What message do we send to society when we insist on the idea of ​​better defending our borders? We allude, without mentioning it, to a danger from which we must defend ourselves, to an enemy; And, ladies and gentlemen, that enemy are people who simply need, seek and deserve a future for their children. This terminology is not innocent, because it feeds xenophobic and far-right messages and positions. Ladies and gentlemen, let's look at the central Mediterranean, please: many more people are dying than we think and very serious events are taking place, such as maydays launched by NGOs twelve miles off the Libyan coast that are not being answered or attended by European ships.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Italy is paying dearly for the failure of the European management of migratory flows. There were 181 436 arrivals in 2016 and around 64,000 since the beginning of 2017. For immigration, Italy has foreseen 4.6 billion spending this year, one billion more than in 2016. European Union are negligible: the last allocation of 58 million corresponds to about 3% of the 4.6 billion. Therefore a mortification to the principle of fair sharing of responsibilities provided for by the treaties, even though Italy is a net contributor, that is to say that Italy gives the European Union more than it receives. The Dublin regulation, despite having been declared dead, still forces us to send more migrants back to Italy than were relocated by Italy to other Member States. The Council's willingness to block its review thus provides the bleak picture of a Europe unable to find effective and shared solutions. If the Council continues to be an expression of national selfishness, it will not only be the reform of the common European asylum system but the whole European project that will fail.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the next European Council will be moving towards more immigration, one should say migratory submersion.The newly elected French president seems to want to impose one of his most harmful fads, namely the common European right of asylum.It is a safe bet that this is intended to replace national legislation.The right of asylum, since the origin of States, has been an exclusive prerogative of the latter.As whether or not to grant asylum must be considered on a case-by-case basis.We totally reject such a drift which would further accentuate the migratory pressure on our countries, furthermore depriving them of any possibility of decision-making.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, today in this Chamber the political elites are gloating and cheering. They have overseen the resistance parties failing to take power in Austria and France, UKIP decimated and a Conservative Brexit government weakened. Political elitism is a doctrine of servitude, but its forces are strong, determined and well financed and it is attacking and destroying its enemies one by one.  They infiltrated UKIP; they isolated, ignored and removed true conservative party Brexiteers; they attacked and removed the voices of resistance from our radio and TV stations. They attack and abuse the President who was elected in the United States of America, yet celebrate the globalist placeman they installed in France. Those who love freedom: patriots, Democrats, Brexiteers, must say no more. We must regroup and return fire. We must fight for a true Brexit, not a fake Brexit.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! The agenda of the European Council currently includes issues that determine the credibility of the European Union: migration control, sense of security, reduction of terrorist threats, Brexit. These are hot topics in the European debate today. This is where human fears are born, and from these fears the anti-European populism draws its power, which further fuels them. It is indeed a test of the European Union's causative power and utility in the eyes of ordinary citizens. Regarding migration, the obvious challenge today is the route through Libya and the Mediterranean, due to the collapse of the Libyan state and the emergence of an organized human smuggling industry. The commitments already adopted should be implemented, there is no time for declarations (Manfred Weber spoke about it). The Maltese declaration must be implemented and the European asylum system reformed. As if these challenges weren't enough, this is the first time we have an unpredictable partner on the other side of the Atlantic, and therefore it makes sense to organize our own European insurance policy. However, while it will be difficult to find a common language with the president of the United States in matters of climate or world trade, the defense dimension of the European Union should be created in full synergy with NATO, because I do not exclude that President Trump will confirm American commitments in Poland, where he will come on 6 July. The joint declaration of the European Union and NATO adopted last year in Warsaw should also serve as an inspiration.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: - Every summit deals with migration, but people still cannot count on us. Countries are not fulfilling their obligations to relocate asylum seekers from Greece and Italy. President Juncker, you mentioned the hundreds of millions of climate refugees that could result from the non-implementation of the climate agreement. Unfortunately, even in this house, there is no ear for the introduction of clear criteria that would enable international protection for climate refugees. In the letter, my colleagues and I drew the attention of European government leaders to the drama of unaccompanied children. I came back from Greece. Without an ambitious Dublin reform, the situation in Greece and Italy will be unmanageable. Debates in the Council are radically moving away from positions in Parliament. We are building security at Europe's borders, colleagues, but we are not building security where people are fleeing. And with inhuman Schengen measures at the borders, with internal control between, for example, Slovenia and Austria, where there have been no illegal crossings for months, we will not actually be able to solve this situation. And much more attention should be paid to the fight against criminal organizations that smuggle people, against violence against women and children. In short, it is our responsibility, dear colleagues, to resolve this situation. Citizens expect this.

name: Franck PROUST
text: - Mr President, the message we must send to Heads of State or Government ahead of the next European Council must be the following: the time for clarity has come. Major political events, from Brexit to the United States' exit from the Paris Agreement, with Donald Trump's unconscious decision, offer us a unique opportunity to be clear about who we are and what we are. let's defend. Europe is changing and its future is being built every day, in our work and on priorities: a social and fair Europe, with the revision of the directive on the posting of workers, which did not wait for voluntarism. recent from France for MEPs to take up the issue; strengthening of the economic and monetary zone; Europe of defense; trade policy in the service of fair trade and the protection of our economic interests and our jobs. European leaders must have the courage to be firm and above all the will for unity. Firmness with Turkey, for example, which must finally understand that no membership in our Union is possible. Unity, then, to show Mr. Trump's United States or Mr. Putin's Russia that Europe is back to build a bloc that protects its citizens and is strong on the international stage. Unity, finally, so that the twenty-seven Member States are united in the Brexit negotiations alongside the Commission and Michel Barnier. It will be necessary to make understand to Mrs May, clearly weakened by the recent elections in the United Kingdom, that one cannot win on all the tables and that belonging to our community of destiny or the exit of this community is not and will never be a simple game.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Mister President! If one compares the situation in the Union with that of a year ago, there is no doubt that there are signs of stabilization. Not only is the economic situation improving, we have also gained confidence after Brexit and Trump. In the area of ​​migration and refugee policy, however, the situation is much more complicated. The numbers have declined significantly, but we still haven't managed to set the long-term course: reforming the Dublin system or creating legal immigration opportunities. And the relocation process is still not completed, tens of thousands of people are still stuck in Greece and in the Western Balkans and are becoming a security problem for the region. And we are still not able to provide sufficient funds for the regions of origin in good time. A new tragedy is already preparing in connection with the liberation of Mosul and Rakkas.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: - Mr President, I want to start by remembering the victims of the latest attacks in England, especially the young Spaniard Ignacio Echeverría, who died helping the police fighting with his skateboard. We share the same principles. That's why they attack us, not because of our passport. They do not attack us because of our borders but because we share the same values. And we share them. Values ​​unite us. In the latest attacks in England, the victims were not only from the United Kingdom. They were also from Australia. They were also from Canada, from France. They were also from Spain. We are not alone in the face of terrorism. No country in the European Union can face the challenges of globalization alone. No one is smarter or better than others to find solutions for himself, without everyone collaborating against what attacks us, against what awaits us in the future. That is why Brexit is a step backwards. Brexit is walking on your back. And yesterday we were precisely celebrating the anniversary of the Erasmus program, which is the opposite of Brexit: four million young Europeans moving - two hundred thousand Britons through the European Union and practically the same number of young people from the rest of the European Union through the United Kingdom, among them my daughter María—; almost a million children born to Erasmus, children who have four mother tongues, the first generation of Europeans in history. The Erasmus program shows that Europe is made from our differences. Our difference and our tolerance is our advantage. For this reason, between Erasmus and Brexit we always choose Erasmus, because Erasmus means generosity, and Brexit, selfishness.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: - Mr. president. I think it is important to highlight that there is a more positive horizon for the European Union, more optimistic than a few years ago: there is economic growth, there is job creation and populisms are being defeated politically. It seems important to highlight this horizon. Secondly, I would like to recall that, yesterday, the French President, Mr Macron, announced his favorable position that the tax on financial transactions could be established in the European Union. It seems to me an idea that we should consider, because we need our own financial resource for the European Union, to address as many problems as we have ahead. We have, of course, a financial need for migration; we need financing for security and defense against terrorism because, for the first time in the history of the European Union, internal security depends on external security; and we have important needs to put in place the social pillar or to put in place climate change, as Mr Macron proposed. We are going to move in that direction, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to tell my colleagues that last Sunday millions of Italians went to the polls to elect their mayor and that it happened, for example, that the mayor of Lampedusa, who had become the symbol of hospitality, awarded by Unesco and taken by Renzi to the Obama White House, she lost the elections, and like her many other mayors. So what happens? Do we have to say that Italians are no longer in solidarity? No, the Italians are in solidarity, they are the people you applaud for their generosity and hospitality, and we must continue to do so. However, to explain what is happening, I use the words of Carlo Nordio, an Italian magistrate who has been through all the moments, even the dark ones, of our country since the 1970s. He says that it seems that the inexorable logic of numbers has finally been discovered, which goes beyond the utopian aspirations of solidarity. When a room is full, nobody can enter it anymore. And this is what is happening in Italy. Therefore, the overwhelming majority of the municipalities refused a new reception, regardless of the political affiliation of the administrators. He then adds that this migratory phenomenon, now banally defined as epochal, is in reality the result of a strategy developed at the table by criminal organizations, and therefore asks that an organic and unitary, clear, serious and severe policy be put in place to deal with this situation. I hear too much useless and empty rhetoric from these benches, which risks becoming solidarity for these criminal organizations of traffickers of human beings. That's enough!

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I express solidarity with the mayor Giusi Nicolini. There are many items on the agenda of the next European Council. I will limit myself to a few observations on the migration phenomenon. The Maltese Presidency recalled the drama that occurs every day on the Central Mediterranean route and President Juncker illustrated the results achieved on migration issues, which were made possible thanks to the role of Parliament's co-legislator, calling all Member States to their responsibilities, under penalty of the infringement procedure, which has already been launched against three Member States. The punitive measures must be accompanied by forward-looking political initiatives such as the partnership with Africa. The Maltese Presidency must remind the European Council of the procedure that applies to the reform of the Common European Asylum System, namely the ordinary legislative procedure. I therefore hope that European leaders will discuss the legislative proposals on which our committees are working with a great sense of responsibility. There is no room for imagination. There is no room for alternative solutions.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, at next week’s Council there will be a new Irish face around the table – and a new face of Ireland, perhaps. Today, the taoiseach Enda Kenny hands over that office to Leo Varadkar, and I take this opportunity to wish our new taoiseach, our new party leader, well in his work ahead, and also to acknowledge the great work of Enda Kenny as leader of our country in very difficult times. Yesterday there were tributes paid to him, and the most remarkable comments were the simplest and nicest ones – about his sunny disposition, his optimism in dark times, and how that is so needed in politics today. That disposition was undented by six years in office, as I say, in very difficult times. He spoke about the honour that he had of leading our country, and I hope that our new leader will carry that same optimistic disposition and work for a united Europe. His last call was to Theresa May to warn her about a Brexit that would damage the Good Friday Agreement. We should honour his words, his commitment to peace and his commitment to Europe. I salute his work, and I wish our new leader every success.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Mr. president. Telegraphically. Security and fight against terrorism. Tribute to Echevarría. Ignacio Echevarría, a Spanish hero fallen in a savage act of terrorism in London, defending with dignity the contribution of European citizens to the cause of European values. Defending. It is not a question of more spending, but of coordination and solidarity between the Member States. Pooling of defensive resources. It would make a change and a phenomenal difference in the defensive capacity of the whole European Union. Migratory routes. I have heard that they are under control. And are the grossly non-compliant Member States under control? Not only infringement procedures, but also, and above all, sanctions. And finally, climate change. Single voice of the entire European Union against the absurd and populist decision of President Trump to withdraw the United States from the COP 21 agreements, ignoring the fate of 60,000 annual victims of climate displacement and the 500 million displaced expected in the next thirty years as a result of drought, desertification and rising sea levels.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman! Today, President Juncker has once again blamed the disastrous mistakes of his own policy on the countries of Central Europe - Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. But the solidarity he talked about is not about responsibility for other people's mistakes. Solidarity is about helping in no fault of need. If you have a bad policy, you really have to learn from it. President Juncker talks about the law. The right is also political responsibility. These European Union authorities should resign, because even the declarations about the fight against illegal smuggling of people have not been fully implemented. We all appreciate what our seafarers are doing in the SOPHIA operation. This is saving people at sea. But in fact, the illegal immigration industry is still operating and destroying Europe, and those who have watched it passively are lecturing those who do not take the consequences of this situation.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, since the United Kingdom voted to leave the European Union, the response from the EU has been ‘more Europe’. It has announced its intention to speed up the Capital Markets Union. It has increased the size of the Juncker fund by a staggering EUR 185 billion and announced the formation of a common defence fund. There are also suggestions that EU funding in the future will be contingent upon national acceptance of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office and that non-eurozone members will have to adopt the single currency.  This is staggering authoritarianism and control-freakery in terms of a political system. It is all very well suggesting that the so-called populist parties across Europe are now in demise; I would suggest and ask the EU to very, very seriously consider whether some of the announcements that they have made and the demands that are now being placed on Member States will actually be counterproductive to what they want to do in terms of stopping populism.

name: Diane JAMES
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you so much for this useful exchange which I will convey to the President of the European Council.  Let me use these concluding remarks to make a more general comment. Recently, a tangible sense of unity, urgency and responsibility has been added to our actions. This should also encourage us, Parliament and the Council to deliver results more rapidly, united by the same objective and showing that we are able to meet the challenges that the EU is facing. The Presidency needs your ideas and your energy. It needs your flexibility and your sense of responsibility to deliver on the guidance provided by the European Council. We have had many achievements in the past five months, but there is much more work to be done ahead of us. So let us keep this sense of urgency alive.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The discussion is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing.- We are probably on the eve of the turning point Council!On the agenda of the summit, for the umpteenth time, the burning issues of current affairs, which are immigration, security and defense.But this time we hope that the fruitless discussions and the backward steps on integration will finally be followed by a qualitative leap.The revision of the asylum system and the overcoming of the Dublin Treaty are now essential decisions.Solidarity and foresight are needed.National selfishness has failed and this Parliament has already proved it.There is a strong majority that establishes a common defense and security among the European states.The Union must finally equip itself with an intervention capacity and its own fund, from which to draw for military spending.Next week's Council cannot ignore citizens' expectations on these issues, which await a new concrete impetus from Europe.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing. - The withdrawal of the United States from the Paris agreement recalls the primacy of national sovereignty and concretizes a campaign commitment by the candidate for the White House. We deplore it nonetheless, as sustainable development must unite across partisan divisions. The consequences of this decision, which would not take effect until 2020, that is to say in the wake of the next American presidential election, must be qualified, especially given the weight of 14% of the United States in emissions. global. In contrast, China accounts for 29% and is, nevertheless, subject to less stringent obligations by this agreement. For the Europeans, the American withdrawal opens a breach. China, which has dethroned the Europeans since 2015, especially Germany, in the photovoltaic sector, cannot have sole control of innovation in the field of renewable energies. Through protectionist measures in the event of unfair competition and through support for research and development, sustainable European industries must regain their place as world leaders. Beyond the industrial project, it is about keeping the promises made to Europeans on the subject of the energy transition: those of a new economic model, promising growth and jobs.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: signed up.- Next week's Council meeting has many items on the agenda.Here many speeches referred to migration, security, defense.These are important points of course.I want to refer to the issue of jobs, growth, competitiveness.Madam Minister, you have said that you will discuss trade policy, how it remains free and fair.I would like these points not to be overlooked.Europe will be strong if we really ensure fair trade, not as it is now, without effective defense policies.It will be strong if young people do not leave for a better life in the USA.We need to increase jobs through a policy of reindustrialisation and fair trade agreements.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written. - Although the horizon for the European Union in economic matters and job creation is more positive and more optimistic than a few years ago and that populisms are being defeated politically, the concern about migration issues and those related to security and defense against terrorism continues to increase. For the first time in the history of the Union, internal security depends on external security and the pooling of defensive resources and greater coordination are more than ever necessary. Furthermore, in the area of ​​immigration, it is necessary to face in solidarity the enormous existing challenges and move from infringement procedures to sanctions for those Member States that do not comply with their commitments to the distribution of refugees. In relation to climate change and Trump's decision to withdraw the United States from the COP 21 agreements, we must assume world leadership not only on environmental issues, but also on trade and social rights. Finally, the States concerned must give the final push necessary for the approval of the tax on financial transactions as a new public resource to face all these emergencies.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: in writing. - Mr Juncker, in your speech today, you referred several times to the importance of European solidarity and compliance with the European Treaties. Nevertheless, on May 25, 2017, in your meeting with Erdogan, you handed over a document with a roadmap of EU commitments to Turkey, which includes the start of negotiations for the modernization of the Turkish Customs Union at the end of the year and for a new EU Summit. Turkey for spring 2018. This roadmap with commitments was given without the consent of the Member States, bypassing the European Council as the competent body. Is this your attitude of respect for the EU Treaties? At the same time, Turkey is violating the sovereignty of an EU member state and threatening European citizens of Cyprus, but your solidarity does not apply to European Cyprus? As an elected MEP, I represent European citizens to whom I would just like to explain the reasons for your behavior.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: written. - The meeting includes major issues on which I would like to comment briefly on the common security and defense policy. I wholeheartedly support European defense cooperation and believe that the meeting must reflect on its new directions, both in principle and in concrete terms. In this global political situation, EU countries are each other's best security. Pooling & amp; sharing would free up funds where the most important security work for the EU is done: threat prevention. EU-wide defense cannot be organized on the same principle as nation-state defense, so a new way of thinking is needed, not an EU army imitated by nation-states. Modern security enhancements are needed, for example, to improve cybersecurity, and that is not cheap either. Here, too, the member states have a concrete added benefit from cooperation! The mandatory increase in defense spending is not suitable for Finland, as it is not for many other countries. Similarly, the idea of ​​500 million earmarked money for research use in the arms industry is impossible to justify to citizens and the scientific community. Good, effective, European security cooperation is the best way to prepare for both external and internal threats.

name: Sergei STANISHEV
text: in writing. – The EU asylum system is currently in shambles. The Dublin regulation is legally alive but politically dead. The terms we all so commonly use – ‘solidarity’ and ‘shared responsibilities’ – have lost their meaning. Meanwhile, Council is dragging its feet. Now, more than ever, we need commitment and real actions. Because, let’s not forget, as somebody recently pointed, a vision without actions is simply a hallucination. Being a Member State is not a matter of cherry picking. it is not just about benefiting from European funds or protecting your national interests, but also contributing to collective efforts for tackling common challenges. It was Greece, Portugal and Spain who were most affected by the economic crisis. Today it is Greece and Italy struggling to cope with the migration inflow to Europe. Shall we just ‘duck and hide’ today and expect a helping hand tomorrow when the next crisis hits? Solidarity is a two-way street. The recipe for success is simple: listen to the European citizens. And what the vast majority want is common solutions to the migration crisis, joint approach to security and defence and shared efforts on the social dimension.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - Although the current meeting of the EiT includes several important issues that will determine the future of the EU, such as the European Semester or the Common Security Policy, this time the European citizen still expects the refugees to resolve the refugee crisis. An agreement on a lasting, workable system of rules for the reception of refugees can no longer be postponed, and this responsibility can no longer be shirked by the political leaders of the Member States. In my view, the most important elements of this are: ending human trafficking and the disasters in the Mediterranean, ensuring that refugees are treated in a humane, promising future, and that migrants arriving at the EU's borders are treated, received, diverted or returned in accordance with humane, uniform and transparent rules. At least as urgent - and can only be done at the level of top leaders - is to bring the basic idea of ​​solidarity back into the legal order and practice of EU migration policy. They must face a common challenge with governments that refuse a commonly agreed system of refugee distribution, above all Orban. The astonishing development that Orbán attacked the existence and basic values ​​of the Union in his last parliamentary speech, stating that "the EU is on the side of terrorists" because many people have objected to the ten-year imprisonment of refugees protesting at the Hungarian border, including is. In this connection, I expect Mr President to make a firm statement in his speech at the EiT of the EP's almost unanimous position.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - In 2015, in the EU28, a recent UNICEF report found that 27% of children and young people, 25.3 million, live in poverty. EU austerity policies have imposed on Member States cuts in support and social benefits with families and children and in substitutive benefits for work earnings, when they were most needed. Right-wing and austerity policies imposed cuts in health, education, and other public services, while imposing cuts in wages, unemployment, degradation of labor relations, increasing inequalities and poverty. These are policies of exploitation and poverty in the EU that feed the reality that cannot be hidden today in countless countries: thousands of children flagged in hungry schools, basic needs such as clothing, housing and health care to be provided, children victims of abandonment and school failure, child labor, begging, youth prostitution, abandonment. Unfortunately, none of these issues will be discussed at the next Council. The EU has no solution but to dissolve it to give way to a new model of cooperation.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. - Over the past year, we have come much closer to the European Union becoming an important tool for increasing spending on defense technology research, as well as improving the capabilities of the armed forces of the Member States. The Commission's proposals for the European Defense Fund, as well as the establishment of, inter alia, Military Planning and Conduct Capability (MPCC), which is designed to plan and conduct non-offensive military missions, are steps in the right direction. However, while some actions are proposed by the European institutions, concrete and tangible decisions are the responsibility of the Member States. The European Parliament has repeatedly reaffirmed its support for strengthening defense and security cooperation. It was a place of constructive discussions in this regard. However, it is up to the Member States to confirm their willingness to act collectively. Time for concrete action. The plans are ready. Ideas analyzed. I don't think any more calls to action are needed. The only thing missing is political will. I hope that this will will finally be unequivocally expressed at the next European Council summit.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on President Trump’s decision to withdraw the US from the COP 21 Climate agreement (2017/2729(RSP)). The Paris Agreement has been a historic achievement of the international community, the first ever global commitment to address climate change and its consequences. While we regret the decision taken by the United States of America’s administration to withdraw from this agreement, our long-standing commitment and determination to lead global action on climate change must not relent. We Europeans will not miss the opportunity that the Paris Agreement represents for our citizens, for our planet and for our economy. Tackling this global challenge also entails working with our industry for new investments, new technologies and more sustainable growth and jobs. The European Parliament has been at the forefront of climate action within the European Union, and today there is an important vote on this. Our overwhelming vote in favour of this agreement made possible its ratification and entry into force. We must be proud of this achievement and we must also continue to work with the United States, its companies, states and cities on this and other fronts. We have set ourselves the most ambitious target in the world. We have the most advanced legislation, which we are strengthening now, showing our continuous commitment. We were fundamental to this global agreement, as we were able to forge a strong alliance between developing and developed countries. This multilateral spirit was fundamental to the success of the COP 21, and for this I want to thank Commissioner Cañete and the Commission for their strong engagement in this issue in which the nations of the world, big and small, united to defend a higher cause. Today we have the honour to have with us Mrs Hilda Heine, President of the Republic of the Marshall Islands and Chair of the High Ambition Coalition. Madam President, you know very well the effects that climate change can have, especially on the most vulnerable. Your testimony today is of the utmost importance for us. Madam President, you have the floor.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President of the Marshall Islands. – Mr President, I bring warm greetings from the people and government of the Republic of the Marshall Islands. It is indeed a great honour and privilege to address you today. I come from a country whose beauty is as breathtaking as its vulnerability. Our ancestors refer to our islands as ‘jolet jen Anij’ or ‘Gifts from God’. Midway between Australia and the United States, the Marshall Islands comprises more than 1 000 islands dotted within 29 different atoll chains, often no wider than a road. While our territory, mostly ocean, is vast, our population is about 50 000 – far smaller than this beautiful city.  It would seem that my country and yours could hardly be further apart or more different but there is much that we have in common. On a personal level, some of my ancestry is European, German to be specific. On a national level, we are strongly committed to liberal democracy, to human rights and the rule of law. Like the European Union, my country also believes deeply in a multilateral approach to solving global problems. The gravest of these is the battle against climate change. We are all vulnerable to climate impact. No one can escape, but the Marshall Islands is on the front-line. Wherever you stand in my country you see the ocean. With an average elevation of two metres above sea level, we have nowhere to run and nowhere to hide. King tides and droughts have become more regular and frequent with disaster often hitting us in different ways in different parts of the country at the same time. One of my first acts as President was to declare a state of disaster because of an unseasonal and prolonged drought. We had less than three weeks of fresh water left. At the very same time we were on high alert for widespread inundation. The drought lasted seven months and cost us nearly EUR 3.5 million. The year before that, a typhoon wiped away more than 3% of our economy and the year before, that many of our people were left homeless by a single king tide. Climate change is not a hoax. This is what the everyday struggle against climate change looks like. For us and our Pacific island cousins the ocean that has been our lifeblood risks becoming the cause of our nightmares and through no fault of ours. Unless the world keeps its promise to pursue efforts to limit global temperature rise to no more than 1.5 degrees Celsius my country and others like Tuvalu and Kiribati risk becoming completely uninhabitable before the century ends.  But the current geopolitical situation would seem to make achieving the 1.5°C limit more challenging than this time last year. In the 18 months or so since the historic Paris Agreement was reached the world seems to have been turned upside-down more than once. The leader of the world’s largest historical contributor to climate change has announced that he wants to leave the Paris Agreement. In my view, that decision was, at best, misguided. It was also disappointing and confusing for those of us that have long believed in the importance of US global leadership. This is particularly so for my country, a long-time committed ally and friend. In the coming three years before the US can legally withdraw, we all have a duty to work together to convince President Trump of the importance of climate action. We have compelling arguments and evidence to help change hearts and minds. Because of that, I am cautiously optimistic and so are my people.
