I have come here today to explain why and to ask for your help. The Paris Agreement that we all fought so hard to achieve is a balanced, fair and durable agreement. It is a ringing endorsement of multilateralism. It will stand the test of time. The Agreement gives countries flexibility to determine their own contributions towards fighting climate change in the context of collective science-based goals. The Agreement will bring countries together every five years to take stock of progress towards achieving those goals with a view to raising ambition. The Agreement provides for transparency and accountability and sets out provisions relating to means of implementation, adaptation, and loss and damage. Importantly, the Agreement recognises that the national circumstances of countries must be considered in its implementation. It took us well over 20 years to achieve the Paris Agreement. We cannot do better and we do not have the luxury of more time. The Agreement is not open to renegotiation. Almost 150 countries have now joined the Agreement; some 50, including more than a quarter of the G20 since the US election. No one else is walking away. In fact, they are doing the opposite. Some have joined in the last few days. I have been overwhelmed in recent weeks by the widespread global support and commitment to the Paris Agreement, including leaders, governments, cities, regions and business community and individuals. I commend Italy for its climate leadership in the G7 and expect no less of Germany in the G20. Such collective acts of leadership are critical and must not fall by the wayside. Apart from the moral case for climate action, the economic case is undeniable. A recent OECD report highlights in no uncertain terms that any delay in climate action is bad for the economy. Growing numbers of decision-makers at all levels see this. Real world climate action is accelerating and exceeding national targets.  Who could have predicted only a few years ago that renewable energy would increasingly be the cheapest option? Climate action simply makes sense at every level. This realisation is resulting in new countries emerging as climate champions, including India and China.  We are also seeing countries coming together to find new ways to push the boundaries of climate ambition. The High Ambition Coalition, which my country established with the European Union and others, was key to reaching the deal in Paris. That Coalition, which bridges traditional economic and geo-political divides is now working towards the full implementation of the Paris Agreement and the creation of the political space needed for deeper and faster climate action. In September next year my country will take over leadership of the Climate Vulnerable Forum – a group of 48 developing countries that has pledged to go 100% renewable by 2050. If we can do that, so can you! At the sub-national level we are seeing an unstoppable groundswell of collective commitment to climate action. Initiatives include the Under2 Coalition, the 2050 Platform, Mission 2020, the C40 Group of Cities and the We Mean Business Coalition. Statements of commitment from US states, cities and businesses in the last week is to be welcomed and so is the direct engagement of European nations with them.  As the UN Secretary-General recently said, the climate action train has truly left the station. But for a country like mine, there is an urgent time imperative. A cost effective path to achieving the 1.5°C limit requires peaking global emissions before 2020 and a rapid acceleration of climate action before 2020 so as to set the world towards net-zero emissions in the second half of this century. The International Energy Agency (IEA) has confirmed this rapid decarbonisation is possible but requires unprecedented levels of leadership. So once again the world is looking to Europe. Thankfully you have a good track record. From the Kyoto Protocol and delivering on its implementation to securing the Durban mandate that led to the Paris Agreement, and ensuring the success of Paris itself, including bringing it into force in record time, Europe has been at the centre of it all. Indeed, in Paris, it was the Marshall Islands and the European Union that marched arm-in-arm with others into the historic or final plenary. With that in mind, I pay tribute to President Juncker, Commissioner Arias Cañete and other European leaders and ministers over the years for their commitment. They are true climate warriors, as are many of you who grace this Chamber and others around the world. Domestically, Europe is demonstrating that economic growth and reducing emissions of greenhouse gases are both possible and mutually reinforcing. Your ground-breaking legislation and policies are being emulated by others around the world. Leadership must increasingly be about implementation. You are turning rhetoric into reality and beginning to put in place what is needed to deliver on your Paris promises. The EU and its Member States together provide about 40% of all global public climate finance. The EU is also the biggest provider of technical climate assistance to developing countries. An important example is the MPC partnership. In my country EU support has on its own helped solarise more than 90% of our outer islands. Every penny is being put to good use. For all of this, I say thank you for your leadership and for your example. Going forwards, what must climate leadership from Europe look like? First, Europe must urgently communicate a 2050 strategy to reduce emissions, consistent with the 1.5°C limit and net-zero emissions in the second half of this century. I have already committed my country to doing so. Second, in 2018 the world will come together to consider progress and inform countries in coming forward with new or revised Nationally Determined Contributions in 2020. The EU must approach this dialogue open to the possibility of raising its ambition as a result. We will not stay within 1.5°C unless Europe and others move before 2020 to raise ambition. So I am pleased to see President Macron has already committed France to doing even more and I welcome similar statements by Prime Minister Modi of India and others. This is exactly the race to the top we need. The 2018 dialogue, together with the climate action summit which California plans to host next September and the UN Secretary-General’s climate summit of world leaders in 2019 are the three biggest political moments we have before the end of this decade to push the cause of increased climate ambition. Europe must be at the centre of these, working with countries and others around the world to ensure further and faster climate action by all. Third, I urge you to move to five-year international targets. Ten-year targets risk lacking in low ambition and are less responsive to the latest science and technological developments.  Fourth, the European Union must continue to push ambitious climate action in all relevant fora and sectors, including on shipping emissions and ensuring environmental integrity in reducing aviation emissions. It will also be important to push for the Kigali amendment on HFCs to enter into force as soon as possible. My country has already ratified the amendment. I acknowledge the sustained leadership of the Federative States of Micronesia to this important cause. The EU must also lead the world in mainstreaming climate action to deliver the sustainable development goals including in relation to oceans. I pay tribute to our Pacific cousins from Fiji, as well as to Sweden for their leadership. All Pacific islands are also extremely proud that Fiji will represent us when it leads the world at COP 23, the first island climate summit. Finally, ongoing leadership of the EU on climate finance, in particular for the most vulnerable countries, will be critical. Support for implementation by developing countries is a crucial part of the Paris Agreement. Sadly, the US decision to stop Green Climate Fund (GCF) funding presents a problem and one we hope the EU and its allies can address.  Bilateral assistance will also continue to be viable for countries like mine. An even greater focus by the EU on the Pacific region is urgently needed.  In concluding, I note that some people, maybe even some in this room, think that it is impossible to achieve the goals we agreed in Paris; that is to say that my country cannot be saved. It is impossible to explain how it feels as the leader of my people to see reports or commentaries that apparently forecasts the oblivion of our home land, our ‘jolet jen Anij’.  I have seen and experienced the forced relocation and migration of my fellow citizens to other parts of the Marshall Islands and beyond as a consequence of the testing of nuclear weapons. So, the responsibility my generation has to leave to our children, and to their children and grandchildren, the Marshall Islands as a secure place to call home weighs heavily. Failure is not an option. As our young climate warriors eloquently put it ‘we are not drowning, we are fighting’. I think I speak for all of my Pacific sisters and brothers when I say that. By working together, the Marshall Islands, the European Union and many others have achieved the impossible before and we will achieve it again because we must. For your leadership, past, present and future, I say ‘Kommooltata’ – thank you very much! (Sustained applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The President of the Marshall Islands will stay with us because I think it is also important for her to know our position. We want to be at the centre of the debate on climate change.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the recent announcement by President Donald Trump to withdraw the United States from the Paris Agreement on climate is a highly regrettable step. The announcement is in line with previous actions on environmental regulation by the new US Administration, such as the rolling-back of existing climate programmes and the weakening of international climate commitments. The decision to withdraw has been taken in the face of many convincing arguments in support of the new international framework and its architecture that have been voiced by the international community, businesses and other stakeholders. Unfortunately, at this point the details of the US approach are still unclear.  However, what has become evident now is the fact that the US withdrawal adds to the global responsibility held by the European Union as the key supporter of a rules-based multilateral system. Let me stress here that the EU is committed to leading with ambitious climate policies and through our committed support for the poor and the vulnerable. The Paris Agreement is fit for purpose. It is ambitious, yet not prescriptive. With its flexible architecture it constitutes an international framework which encourages countries to widen the array of options contributing to the goals of preventing climate change, which threatens global development, peace and stability. Therefore the Council is committed to ensuring that the EU significantly contributes to the optimalisation of the Paris Agreement and to the design of all the elements of the Paris outcome. Our goal should be to minimise the consequences of the US decision on the effectiveness and credibility of the climate framework. The EU will also continue to support the convergence between intergovernmental negotiations and the implementation agenda. This includes conversion of countries’ Nationally Determined Contributions goals into concrete policies and actions.  The Council is continuing its work on the completion of the internal legislative and regulatory framework of the Union, which is necessary to deliver our Paris target of reducing economy—wide emissions by at least 40% by 2030. On 19 June the Environmental Council will hold an exchange of views on the effort-sharing and the land-use change and forestry emissions proposals. We hope to swiftly finalise the Council’s position and to start our interinstitutional negotiations as soon as possible. The EU position following President Trump’s decision to withdraw the US from the COP 21 climate agreement will also be discussed during the Foreign Affairs Council meeting on 19 June.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, when I addressed the Paris Conference in November 2015 I saw the world united around a simple goal: to hand over to future generations a healthier planet, more stable and fairer societies, and more prosperous and modern economies. Thanks to the negotiations, and in particular to the chief negotiator of the European Union, my good friend Miguel Cañete, a historic deal was made. The world agreed to save its one and only home. Doing justice to its traditional name, ‘gifts from God’, the Marshall Islands took action, becoming one of the first to ratify the Paris Agreement. The testimony of President Heine is a reminder of the need for action. It is a matter of survival. Here is a fact: every morning, international datelines set that the day begins at the Marshall Islands. President Heine, we will work to help your country continue to mark the beginning of our days. We will not allow the denial of the very few to be the end of the days of the Marshall Islands.  Unfortunately, not everyone in the world sees the truth of the facts. The withdrawal of the United States from the Paris Agreement is more than a sad event; it is a sign of abdication from common action in dealing with the fate of our planet. We are disappointed and we regret that decision, but the abandonment of Paris by the US Administration will not mean the end of the Agreement. I am convinced that it will make the rest of the world more united and determined to work towards the full implementation of the Paris Agreement. The European Union will not renegotiate the Paris Agreement.  (Applause) The 29 articles of the Agreement must be implemented and not renegotiated. Climate action does not need more distractions. We have spent 20 years negotiating; now is the time for action and now is the time for implementation.  I see a strengthened resolve from all those who care about the future of the planet and who see the opportunities of a modern economy. This includes partners within the United States, such as the states of California, Washington, New York, which, taken together, would be the world’s fourth economy. As the European Union, we will step up our climate diplomacy and collaboration with other partners. For example, climate action was a key topic of the EU-China Summit on 2 June. In September, Miguel Cañete will co-host a major gathering with his Chinese and Canadian counterparts to implement the Paris Agreement and accelerate the clean energy transition. We are also reaching out to our partners in the African Union and the ACP countries. We adopted joint statements expressing our common resolve and we will work hard to have a clear message coming out of the G20 Summit, or at least from 19 of its members, in July. In Paris, the world committed to helping vulnerable countries adapt to the consequences of climate change. The decision of the US to go back on its pledge to the Green Climate Fund leaves a major void. From our side, we stand firm to our commitments and we will work with third countries to mobilise the right public and private investments.  You can count on the efforts of the Commission to keep the momentum going on the implementation of the Paris Agreement. In return, we hope to count on your support to make the European Union’s commitments a reality and make swift progress on all Commission proposals related to that goal. When we ratified the Paris Agreement in record time, this House showed its commitment to climate action. We need to keep the same spirit, more than ever.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Madam President! I would first like to say that we are honored by your presence and by your speech. A warm-hearted welcome! When asked how we deal with Donald Trump's decisions, a very banal question arises, namely the question: How do we deal with facts, how do we deal with facts? The major American universities - Harvard, Stanford, Georgetown, Yale - and even 82% of American citizens say they understand that climate change is a reality. For us it is just as clear: Change is coming, it will be great, it will be dramatic, and the only question that remains is how much we can limit it with joint efforts. As Europeans, we can be proud that we were the driving force with others, that we went ahead and made the Paris Treaty possible in the first place. The Europeans will therefore not accept America's exit and will not follow it. The emotional question that arises is: How do you react to it? At first, of course, with a little frustration with developments in the United States. But then, if you think about it for a few seconds, all the more decisiveness that emerges - because of the responsibility for the following generations and also because of the knowledge that the issue of climate change will also trigger a modernization boost for our economy. Even American corporations like Exxon are in favor of not giving up the climate targets, because they recognize that there is also a great opportunity in them if we tackle the economy to initiate this change. Donald Trump negates the facts, Donald Trump decides against the will of his own US citizens, Donald Trump will not create any new jobs with these developments, with this decision. And that's why Donald Trump commits with this decision a big, historical mistake.America First is selfishness.America First is related to breaking relationships.Perhaps we should counter this with a “Europe First”."Europe First" is the approach of partnership, of togetherness, of wanting to solve problems together.In this respect, Europe needs less “America First” and more “Europe First”.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Heine, thank you first of all. The beauty and vulnerability of the Marshall Islands are the key to our planet and are the opposite directions we can go in, thanks to our choices or because of our choices. We can go towards the beauty, health and safety of the planet, but we can also go towards disaster. A tweet - he loves tweets - to Donald Trump. I didn't think there could be a worse President of the United States than George Bush, but I have to change my mind because there is never a limit to the worst. He has reached the pinnacle of the worst, I hope he doesn't get over it, and he is leading the planet to disaster, but we will stop him. We, together with the progressive forces of the world, we as European forces, but together with all the great social, political, institutional, associative and non-governmental realities, together we will stop the Trump disaster. Europe must make Europe, as he did over the years when he built the single market. It was a big goal, and today that must be the big goal. We are not naive. Trump does this not only because he is a bit like that, but because he wants to reduce the costs of American productions. This is unfair competition and we must take countermeasures, which also means thinking about tariffs. Let's think about it, but certainly, if there is unfair competition, we must know how to respond. We have a duty to preserve the prospect of life, beauty and health for our children, for our grandchildren, for the whole world.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank very much President Heine for coming here today and for her clear leadership and inspiration to the High Ambition Group.  For those of us who have struggled perhaps a little bit with how to address Donald Trump, what tone to adopt towards him – after all, he is a legitimately elected world leader – he has now solved my problem, because I am very happy to publicly and loudly say that this, and his action, is reckless. It is myopic and it is totally irresponsible.  It is made even more contemptible by the fact that we now know that he has decided that climate change is real. He has stopped his denying of it. He says it is real and indeed his ambassador to the UN, Nikki Haley, has confirmed that for us. So that makes his decision even more contemptible. He is not even pretending any more that he does not believe in climate change.  We can also see that he has a complete misunderstanding of the Paris Agreement and what the US’s obligations are under that Agreement. He seems to think that it will be giving US industry an extremely unfair position and totally ignoring the fact that actually it gives the US a huge amount of flexibility in how they deal with making sure that they stand up for their obligations.  And given the modest commitments that the US is being asked to make – let us face it, for many people what the US is being asked under Paris is actually still way underperforming Europe and many of the Member States in Europe – it seems even more the case that ‘the Donald’ should be asked exactly where he gets his information and his advice from, because with higher per capita emissions than the world average, the US has a moral duty to significantly reduce its emissions and ensure that global average temperatures remain below 2 degrees C.  Maybe we should say that the next human-caused climate disasters should be called Hurricane Donald, Super Drought Pruitt, or Tropical Cycle Bannon, because that is going to be his legacy.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, President Trump is not the only threat to our global environment and the beautiful island states such as yours, President Heine, and thank you for coming to talk to us. Climate change sceptics in the UK also threaten European global protection. The British elections delivered a disastrous result for our Prime Minister, and Ms May battles on – she has appointed a new Environment Secretary, Mr Michael Gove. Gove has a shocking record. When he was Education Secretary, Gove wanted to get climate change off the school curriculums. He voted to sell off all of England’s publicly-owned and protected forests and woodlands. He has voted 12 times against measures to prevent climate change, including opposing limits on greenhouse gas emissions. He supports fracking and he supports drilling in national parks. He has opposed refitting homes to stop carbon loss. To quote a past colleague of this House, Caroline Lucas, who is now an MP: ‘Michael Gove is an environmental disaster waiting to happen’. During the Brexit referendum campaign, Gove stated that he had enough of experts. Well, frankly, the experts and the public have had enough of him, too, just as they have had of President Trump. Colleagues, please be tough during the Brexit negotiations when it comes to the environment, as you will be with Mr Trump. Climate deniers like Gove need to know they have international treaty commitments that they cannot evade. He will try to slip and slide on environmental agreements. So, given the election results last week, it remains to be seen whether the UK will actually leave the EU. But if we do, the UK, just like the US, must fulfil its international environmental obligations. Environmental challenges do not stop at borders. Our environment, our planet, is interlinked, especially when it comes to the most vulnerable states on the planet. We must work together to protect it in the UK, in the US, and of course driven here by the European Union.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Dear colleagues and, above all, Madam President, thank you for coming to us today and thank you for your words as well. Donald Trump has decided to withdraw from the climate agreement in Paris. Apparently he would like to return to the Middle Ages, where the denial of scientifically verifiable facts was the order of the day. Unfortunately, despite all his tweets, climate change is unstoppable. As we have had the opportunity to hear today, entire nations and states are threatened by this process, which brings with it rising sea levels and a devastating drought. Man-made climate change may in the coming years cause a wave of migration of such magnitude that the current crisis will be mere banality in comparison. He didn't say what Mr. Trump wanted to do with all this. Obviously, the role of unlimited ruler of the wasteland would suit him. The situation around palm oil in Indonesia, for example, shows us today and every day how far the reckless use of resources and neglect to protect the environment leads. Today more than ever, we must show the world our unity, determination and the right path.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mister President! Thank you, Madam President, for being here today, for showing us again what it actually means, what the effects of climate change mean for the people in the most affected areas. I can only assure you that we Greens will continue to work to ensure that we do more to combat climate change, and I am delighted that many colleagues who have already spoken today have also said: Yes, they support the Parisian Deal, and they find Trump's decision wrong. But it is not enough to criticize Trump and then see ourselves on the moral high ground and say: We are better off. No! The objectives that we have set so far and that the Commission have adopted here are based on an optimistic scenario. They won't guarantee us that we won't even be two degrees. But that's not enough for islands like President Heine's. We have to stay below two degrees. We should aim for a maximum of 1.5 degrees - only then will these many islands have a chance to survive. So we have to do more now - we as Europeans. We are the third largest emitter of CO2, but we as the European Union also have the strength and the technology to do something about climate change. We are not one of the poorest nations in the world. We have the options and we must move forward. We can really show leadership here, we can move forward, and we can help ensure that the climate continues. And especially when Trump gets out, we cannot say: Well, the USA is not doing anything now, then we are not doing anything anymore, but we have to compensate for this loss by the USA. Because if we are later asked by future generations: Yes, why didn't you do more? Then we cannot say: Yes, Trump did not want to more.But we have to increase our own share - we here in Parliament, but also the governments.When I see how, for example, the federal government in Germany always poses for a family picture in front of the glacier, but at the same time accommodates the biggest polluters by issuing CO2 certificates or stands in the way of the tough CO2 standards for cars, then gojust not together.That doesn't fit with Europe's leadership role, and that doesn't fit with the fight against climate change.We really have a chance to create good new jobs with real prospects for the future with the fight, with energy efficiency and with renewable energies.It's all down to political courage - we have to muster that.The planet does not wait for us, it can also without us - but we not without it and we not without a tolerable climate.We can do it - we just have to want it, I think of that.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The President of the Marshall Islands and I are leaving the plenary. Madam President, thank you for your engagement and for your speech. Thank you for your cooperation with the European Union. The European Union and the European Parliament will support your position. (Applause)

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, according to some calculations, the US withdrawal from the Paris agreements would lead to a theoretical increase of around 1.4 million tonnes of CO2 per year until 2025 and would cause serious damage to the economy and to the agriculture. We are talking about abnormal numbers in front of which we can not pretend nothing has happened. In the era of the fourth industrial revolution of the circular economy, the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and the Paris Agreement, this is the ideal place to plan a more sustainable future. The European Union has responsibilities not only towards its own populations but also towards the least developed countries of the planet as a whole. The time has come to take back a central position in the scientific and technological scenario and to increase investments in the sector. But if this Europe is the same as Dieselgate and fossil fuel financing through the EFSI and the ECB, then it is clear that a change in the political climate is first of all necessary to change the climate.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! It is hard to believe how many noble rescuers of the global climate are here when you walk through the garage of the house and see the many six-cylinder and eight-cylinder vehicles with a correspondingly high output volume. You won't believe it either, if you look at the program of visits to the house, the European Parliament, where mandataries fly to the remotest corners of the world to discuss important issues such as gender mainstreaming and other things. But all is well and all is well when it comes to US bashing, when it comes to Trump bashing; there are no limits to hypocrisy. Let's take a closer look at this climate agreement that you are so enthusiastic about. Monsanto has sat at the negotiating table, the nuclear lobby has sat at the negotiating table. In truth, it is kneeling before the nuclear lobby. And the real goal, namely to promote renewable energies, was neglected. And so I can only appeal to you: Be honest about the issue of climate protection, nature conservation, and put an end to your hypocrisy!

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: - Madam President, President Trump’s decision to withdraw the United States from the Paris Agreement has sparked a global outcry. Even the chairman of Goldman Sachs, who was not known to be so concerned about the planet, went with his little condemnation. For my part, I will not dramatize this decision. First, because the Paris Agreement is not legally binding, regardless of what has been said, and there is nothing to force its application by its signatories. It is above all a political commitment. Then, the US withdrawal will not be effective until 2020, and many sub-federal authorities in the United States - states, big cities - have said they want to pursue policies consistent with the agreements. Finally, because Americans have business acumen: If it pays off to invest in the green economy and the economic sectors that go with it, they will. My concern is more about the prospect of a European bidding up that, under the pretext of offsetting the supposed effects of this withdrawal, we would impose on our economy. I notice that Mr. Pittella has become pro-tariff to ward off unfair competition when it comes to the United States. I hope it will be the same in other circumstances.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: - Madam President, no one today will be able to say that they knew nothing about climate change: the repetition of natural disasters, more and more violent, affecting deprived territories and therefore poor populations, by impoverishing them a little more , the rising water levels, which threaten the coasts and the islands, finally the drought, responsible for the famine in East Africa, are unfortunately a reality and risk in the long term to push to the exodus of the thousands, even millions of people, not to mention our biodiversity, also endangered. President Trump has withdrawn the United States from the Paris agreement. This is an irresponsible decision that "outdated" his own country, preventing Americans from entering modernity. The assumed protection of our environment and the technological revolution that it entails, that is modernity. Our companies have understood this issue well, they are investing to quickly access the most efficient technologies. They stand up for their jobs and they have our support. The Paris Agreement was a worldwide success. Europe is on a clear and visionary path to defend the climate. Some here in this chamber find that our legislation goes too far, but no, we are just ambitious and responsible for future generations.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: – Madam President, President Trump made his announcement to leave the Paris Agreement, ironically, in the rose garden, and the question is: how should we react? We can be very angry, we can be frustrated – but let us not be afraid, and let us stand united. We have heard many of our political leaders in Europe say that we will keep up the engagements in the Paris Agreement. It is nice to give good speeches, but the proof of the pudding is in the eating, and the first thing we need to do in Europe is implement the Paris Agreement in full. When we have a vote on the Effort Sharing, when we discuss renewable energy, when we discuss energy efficiency, let us move up and make it more ambitious. That is our goal.  Second, we always say that Europe is divided – with two speeds, or three speeds. Well, we can also say that in the United States we have more than one speed: we have the Trump administration, but we also have states, cities, mayors, companies that have said they will implement the Paris Agreement and that they will keep on track with it. Let us not turn our back on the United States and their people, but work together with these cities and states. I think that is also what the European Commission should do: to make sure that at international level we keep up with China, India, but also with the citizens of the United States. Rest assured, Trump is not the rightful representative of the people in the United States, because they do stand with the Paris Agreement and with combating climate change.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen!In his television series, the entrepreneur Trump usually said goodbye to his candidates with the sentence: "You are fired." Now he thinks he should run his country like a company.As someone who has always lived in industry, I can tell you: They don't run their country the way they should run their business.Instead of developing new products, he relies on old technology.Instead of listening to the advice of his own researchers, he relies on alternative facts.Instead of worrying about the long-term health of his company, he jeopardizes it for short-term goals.If I were the chairman of this company's board of directors, I would say to Mr. Trump tomorrow, "You are fired."

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: - Madam President, the fact that Donald Trump abandoned the Paris Agreement is bad news for all of us, but if we agree with this, we must be consistent and, therefore, I want to make an appeal here. Just a few days ago, we voted on this Parliament's position on the LULUCF dossier on the ITRE committee and won the forest business lobby. This first vote that we took in Parliament does not just call into question the Paris Agreement, but it also brings back European legislation on combating climate change. That is why I appeal to this Parliament, the European Commission and the Council, to transpose the Paris Agreement as it should be, without tricks in accounting for emissions and without hypocrisy. We cannot count only the trees that are planted and ignore those that are cut down. There is still time to amend the hand. I appeal to this Parliament, the Council and the Commission. LULUCF must be a dossier that transposes the Paris Agreement and not that it takes us back on climate change.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank everyone for these heart-breaking speeches on climate change. It is really great to hear how everyone is involved in it and concerned and, well, let us see, in half an hour you can vote and you will add loopholes to our own climate legislation watering down our targets for 2030. There might be some inconsistency with some of you guys, but I am sure you are going to work on that.  I also want to thank the Council for being here because you have been listening to the Marshall Islands. I know that you are even worse on the effort-sharing regulation. You are playing for more loopholes all over the place. I really hope when the Environment Council is meeting next week, you still have in your mind the speech by the President of the Marshall Islands, and act accordingly. I think that is important. And to the Commission I would say: one of the clear demands we got from the Marshall Islands is to come now, before 2018, with your 2050 road map. Are you going to do that? Or is this going to be for the next Commission, postponing, postponing? I shall be silent now because I am going to listen to Mr Helmer and, if I understand The Guardian correctly, you are going to step down in July; so if this is your final speech I am happy to listen to it.

name: Roger HELMER
text: – Madam President, may I, from this Hemicycle, send congratulations to President Trump for his wisdom and courage in pulling America out of the climate agreement in Paris and resisting the pressure from the green lobby, of which we have heard so much today. In fact, he has given America a huge competitive advantage in terms of industry and exports, which will be damaging to Europe if we cling to the outmoded climate passion that we have heard in this Hemicycle. Some colleagues will be familiar with the peer-reviewed paper published recently by Danish statistician Bjørn Lomborg, in which he estimates the cost of Paris at USD 100 billion by the end of the century, when the impact on climate will be 0.17 °C. In other words, an eye—watering amount of money for virtually no return. This is pure virtue signalling and gesture politics; we should be ashamed of ourselves.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Madam President, last month colleagues from across six nations this side of the House wrote to President Trump, urging him to pull out of the Paris climate agreement – and he did. He is putting American jobs first. He is fighting against global interests; he is protecting the nation state; he is trying to protect his citizens from terror. He is a president that has the guts to stand up to the global elites and their green hobbies. He puts American people first, instead of virtue signalling with other people’s money.  Trump’s policies, like Brexit, have really challenged the status quo in this place, and that is why you are all so frustrated now. So good luck, President Trump. I wish you well, along with Steve Bannon, your chief strategist. You are winning, and we are winning, despite the rhetoric that goes on – and despite Ms May really messing up. But I am sure all my colleagues across this House would like to join me in wishing President Trump a very happy birthday. (Applause from some quarters)

name: Peter LIESE
text: - Madam President! I had the great honor of taking part in the European Parliament delegation to the climate conference in Marrakech. And of course there was a shock when it became known that President Trump had won the election, because of course we had to reckon with the current developments. But it was already very clear in Marrakech: the rest of the world will not be deterred and will hold on to Paris. I thank Jean-Claude Juncker and Miguel Arias Cañete for their clear statements in this regard. And Parliament will not just speak, it will act. Bas Eickhout is just going out now. He spoke of loopholes. But he should not hide the fact that we are voting on effort sharing this afternoon, and the EPP agrees to the compromise, which envisages an ambitious implementation of Paris - realistic, but ambitious at the same time. And I am glad that, after discussions with my group, we have come to this agreement. Protecting the climate means an opportunity for the economy, and Trump will do most of the suffering to the US by missing out on the future.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: - The date of entry into force of this Regulation shall be limited to the quantities of the products listed in Annex I to this Regulation. U xi kultant nibda nisma ’d-discorsi u lanqas nemmen lil widnejja, għaliex għandna nies li lanqas biss qegħdin jirrealizzaw li, jekk l-ekosistemi tad-dinja se jmutu, l-ekonomiji se jikkollassaw għal kollox. On the other hand, the company has been notified in its entirety of the French Republic, which has been approved by the Member States. In the present case, it is possible to enter into the contract on a two-tier basis. Id-deċiżjoni tal-President Amerikan li jirtira mill-Ftehim ta ‘Pariġi, irridu nammettu, hija daqqa ta’ ħarta. Però d l l ostakolu mhux se jnaqqas mid-determinazzjoni tagħna li naġixxu. Irridu mmexxu, irridu nispiraw u rridu nempawerjaw. The name of the company is as follows: the same is true of the continent of the continent, which is described in the first half of the year. In this case, the following measures apply in particular. Qegħdin nitkellmu, kif smajna wkoll, dwar id-dritt għall-ikel, id-dritt għall-saada, id-dritt għas-saħħa, id-dritt għall-educazzjoni, id-dritt għas-sigurtà tal-bniedem. In this case, there is a risk that there is a risk of illness.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Madam President!The Paris Agreement gives each party the opportunity to use their conditions.It does not assume decarbonization, appreciates the role of forests in the balance of CO2 emissions, and focuses on sustainable development.After the US withdraws from the Paris Agreement, the EU's climate policy should be revised.However, I am warning against the thoughtless reaction of unilaterally inflating European ambitions to fill the gap left by the United States.Our solitary efforts will not save the world, on the contrary, they will make European industry even less competitive.I appeal, Commissioner, for the Paris Agreement to be the cornerstone of a European climate policy that does not involve decarbonisation, appreciates the role of forests in the balance of CO2 emissions and focuses on sustainable development.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: - Madam President, what a great unanimity in this Parliament against Donald Trump. Indeed, the decision of the American president is irresponsible and criminal. But, frankly, if the talk about climate and the environment had to save the planet, it would. The credibility of climate diplomacy, the credibility of leadership, it is the credibility of climate action that is at stake. Too often, the European Commission like the Council, like the right wing of this Parliament, by dint of listening too much to the lobbies of nuclear, oil, gas, intensive agriculture, forestry and transport fail to see all SMEs, researchers, start-ups, communities and citizens who want to do more in favor of the climate and who are today building the world of tomorrow. If there is a great project for Europe, it is to reconcile ourselves with the future, with the climate. It is to create jobs. And there we will reconcile Europeans with Europe and we will reconcile Europe with the rest of the world. So act, act, act!

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: - Madam President, in this extremely air-conditioned hemicycle filled with deputies who came by plane from the four corners of Europe, this umpteenth condemnation of the President of the United States seems to me as hypocritical as that of the Saudis denouncing Qatar's support for the movement jihadist. Yet his decision is that of a democratically elected head of state, who has never hidden his climate skepticism and who has only one goal, to protect American jobs. You better take an example, you who are unable to fight unemployment or terrorism, but who claim to act on the climate. It is urgent, however, to be concerned about the threatened jobs of our workers, those which the consequences of your policies have not yet thrown into unemployment and whose companies will now suffer a further decline in competitiveness in the face of their formidable American competitors. Mr. Trump is indeed wrong, in not pretending to want to respect an agreement, not legally binding, but on the contrary to officially affirm what he believes is good for his fellow citizens. But it's so hard for you to admit it, it's so different from the way you think and act.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: – Madam President, I think it is fair to say that there is an agreement in this House that we need to continue to fulfil our commitments to the Paris Agreement, and I hope this will be seen in the vote which is following on effort sharing, which I hope will have the support of this House. The problem still exists in the support that the Member States are giving to the Paris Agreement targets, because even if we adopt policies with ambition, then we have to have the support of the Member States – we need to implement this. This House cannot have a very good say. We need the Member States to put the money where they promised they would put the money and to implement these policies we are agreeing upon. The weakness of the agreement lies in its voluntary nature, so the implementation will depend very much on how the global economy will fare. The Paris Agreement, we need to say, makes economic sense, because it will create more jobs, more prosperity and sustainable growth in our economy. This is something President Trump needs to find out.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the European Union must give President Trump two answers.First of all, on the occasion of the COP23, which will take place in Bonn, from November 7 to 16: let us take this leadership to allow the world, behind the concrete proposals of the Union, to fight this wait-and-see attitude or this decisionridicule of the American president.Then, of course, as we know today in America, the negative reactions to Mr. Trump are significant: many businesses and cities, but also thirty out of fifty states condemn his attitude.Therefore, Commissioner, let us get in touch with these States, with these American companies and with these cities to establish cooperation with the Union in the coming months on the occasion of the COP23.

name: Ivo BELET
text: - Whatever the position of the United States, we are on the path of a low carbon and energy efficient economy and there is no going back.That is of course the right choice, also and especially because it makes us less dependent on unreliable oil and gas suppliers.So ambition, certainly also in the reform around the distribution of efforts, which we will vote on later.But also: don't be naive.Look at the reform of the ETS, in which we want measures to combat carbon leakage.And at the same time continue to work on the reform of the ETS, making that system more robust and especially linking it to systems such as in California.Because we have strong allies in the United States.Let us also continue to work on a system, on a level playing field for industrial producers who want to produce for Europe.We can also successfully use the ETS for this.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Madam President, we just had our 80th Transatlantic Legislators’ Dialogue (TLD) with our American counterparts in Congress after Trump announced his withdrawal from the Paris Agreement. I have to say with our American counterparts in Congress, it was a difficult conversation with them, but it is needed and what Trump did is actually disrespectful not only to his own people, but to people all over the world and for the 194 States that are there and committed to fighting climate change. I also have to say that this withdrawal is actually placing a lot of question marks over the US government; it has further implications for the US. Can the US be trustworthy when it has to do negotiations and new global and international deal in the future? That is a question we have to ask ourselves. It is weakening our position to take collective action on a very important issue. But as others have said, there is a coalition: cities, States, people all over the world, including in the United States, that want change and they will continue despite Trump’s decision. Let us stand together and work together and we will succeed.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: - Madam President, Commissioner. Thanks also to President Heine for her testimony and inspiration. The president of the United States, Donald Trump, has demonstrated the inability of his administration to participate in the leadership of the fight against climate change. The European Union, which had already led the previous negotiations of the Paris Agreement, must step up and take command to lead this transition to a low-carbon economy. Today, 20% of the Union's budget is allocated to actions to combat climate change. We are in the midst of updating the emissions trading market and establishing a circular economy, and we need to do even more. And we need, in turn, an industrial policy that is sustainable, with the same ambition in its three pillars: economic, job creation, social and environmental. And in this sense - and I will finish - I want to ask you, Commissioner: What measures has the Commission taken or plans to take to protect the European economy, European industry and its jobs, in the face of a more than possible environmental dumping by the United States ?

name: Jo LEINEN
text: - Madam President! Climate protection is not only a political but also a moral duty - this was shown in the speech by the President of the Marshall Islands. It would be completely irresponsible for entire states to disappear from the scene if we cannot limit global warming. Protecting the climate will be the greatest transformation of the economy since the first industrial revolution. The departure from fossil energies and towards renewable energies also creates completely new opportunities. We in Europe have to be careful that we not only buy the new products, but also manufacture them ourselves. Most of the photovoltaic systems are produced in China. Most electric cars will soon be produced in China. Green cities and buildings are produced in China. Well, Europe has to make an effort so that we don't lose touch. Commissioner, I regretted that the EU-China summit did not come up with a declaration for climate protection and mutual cooperation, because global climate protection needs leadership. And that has to be Europe in relation to China.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam President, your speech was very moving and incisive. We are all vulnerable, but above all are the Marshall Islands which are, with a thousand islands and 50 000 people, at daily risk. Despite Trump's decisions, a critical voice is growing around the world with announcements of alliances between big cities and US federal states, with statements from the rest of the world and citizens, and with Europe ready to play a leading role. The world is looking to Europe and we have already achieved important objectives, starting with the very rapid ratification of the Paris Agreement which I had the honor of leading on behalf of Parliament, but we will commit ourselves to do even more, not forgetting the need to ensure the competitiveness of our industrial world. It has now been proven that the transition to the new sustainable economy is also a winning strategy from the point of view of economic growth and the creation of new jobs, and that is the direction in which we must go. Madam President, and I think I am speaking to the great majority of us, know that the European Parliament is with you and Europe is with you.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, President Trump's decision to withdraw the United States from the Climate Change Agreement has posed a major problem for the European Union, and we must acknowledge that. One of the largest polluters on the planet, the United States, does not want to participate in environmental protection measures. Everyone here thinks we want to contribute to environmental protection. There is another major polluter, China. I believe that the European Union cannot take on the task of saving the planet alone. What will the Commission and the Council do on political and economic relations with the two major polluters? Will we continue to fill the market with products that come from a polluting environment and further deindustrialise Europe? Will we destroy jobs? Will we leave young people without jobs? I believe that the European institutions, including us, Parliament, must take responsibility for negotiating any agreement in favor of European citizens. Protecting the climate is vital for the planet and this must be used in all negotiations.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: - Madam President, the US withdrawal from the Paris Agreement should not come as a surprise. Trump has sometimes criticized the deal as a hoax aimed at weakening American industry. Of course, since Trump's neoliberal policy puts the interests of multinationals above the protection of the environment. This withdrawal should not become an excuse for non-compliance by the others. On the contrary, the disastrous course of the United States confirms that even greater action is required of us. Dramatic climate change sends out a warning signal. It is therefore not enough to condemn the withdrawal of the United States. The European Union, in cooperation with China and other countries, needs to develop initiatives to provide practical support to developing countries, and to develop a comprehensive action plan to combat climate change, to reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Unless there are immediate binding targets, we will not be able to stop the destruction of the planet.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I must say that I have very much appreciated the words that have mostly been said in this House on this debate, in particular those spoken by President Pittella regarding this infamous choice by Donald Trump toexit from the Paris Agreement.Pittella also spoke of health, he spoke of the beauty of the territories.The problem is that President Pittella plays in a party that has decided to double the oil stations in Italy, effectively devastating our territories and our seas.So I ask: how do you think global warming will stop if you are allied with oilmen?My question is: how do you plan to fight climate change, if what you say is exactly the opposite of what you do?

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, regardless of our motives and views, President Trump, to the extent of his authority, has the legal right to withdraw the United States from the Paris Agreement. The moral dimension of this decision remains, of course, doubtful. Of course, the shift to more environmentally friendly options has already taken place. But further action and regulation are needed. The changes provided for in the agreement pose both challenges and opportunities, but which are not distributed proportionally between the states. The same goes for the effects of climate change. Taking legally binding action against targets is essential, along with fostering innovation. A rule that must be taken without delay is "whoever pollutes is punished". Otherwise, the consequences of inaction will be wider than the cost of any adjustment. What is required is the survival of humanity. However, despite the urgent dimension of the issue, any selfish interest that imposes interests or undermines a state under the guise of regulatory frameworks will not be accepted.

name: Elmar BROK
text: - Madam President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen!Just two brief points - first: I believe that Mr Trump wants to build a wall there against migration to Mexico and that the number of migrants will increase by preventing the fight against climate change.For us it is also an existential question that if we want to secure the living conditions in Africa, climate change will be stopped, because otherwise there will be migration.And that's why climate change is an important question in this sense too.And the second point that I would like to mention: If you want to base your economy on coal and cement, you have to see that the innovative companies in your country are against it.That's why we should keep our nerve.American companies will not accept this backward policy in the long run.Trump is here to lead his own country into economic disaster.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: - Madam President, Trump has made good on his threat.The United States, his administration - not the country - will not be an ally in the fight against climate change, but this is not the only threat.On the one hand, the denial of people like Trump.On the other hand, the lack of ambition.I appreciate the defense made by the Commission of the Paris Accords, but good words cannot hide the lack of ambition, for example, in the clean energy package.If we want the Paris Agreement to be more than a bad memory of what could have been and was not, it is time to commit in a big way and take a giant leap in European objectives.For example, on renewable energy, increasing ambition and making targets binding on Member States.I want to see this House there, as before: with ambition, with commitment, with long lights.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. –Madam President, all the House has listened to the passionate speech of the President of the Marshall Islands calling on us for ambition and action.  The best answer we can give is, first of all, to confirm that we will not renegotiate the Paris Agreement and that we will make all the efforts needed to provide the political momentum behind the Paris implementation. The implementation of the Paris Agreement domestically requires that this House gives full support in moving ahead on making the European Union’s commitment a reality.  The European Union is showing the world the way with our cutting-edge climate policy and there is no stronger statement we can make than swift progress on the ETS, the effort-sharing regulation, the land-use legislation as well as on the Clean Energy for all European Package. When we ratified the Paris Agreement in record time this House showed its commitment to climate action and we need to provide the same spirit now, more than ever. Internationally we will have to implement the Paris Agreement by working closely with all our allies with ambition and determination. And as Ms Van Brempt and some others clearly stated, we have to keep working with the United States, which is much more than the Federal Government. In the United States the decision to withdraw also strengthened the resolve of those who care for the future of the planet and who understand the economic opportunities of a low-carbon transition. Hundreds of United States mayors, governors, state attorneys-general, CEOs and others pledged to the United Nations to achieve and eventually exceed America’s commitment to the Paris Agreement in a declaration entitled ‘We Are Still In’ and they will submit a Societal Nationally Determined Contribution to the United Nations, aggregating action by different stakeholders and building upon the Global Covenant of Mayors for Climate and Energy.  The states of California, Washington and New York founded the United States Climate Alliance, now joined by nine other states. So it is clear that we will continue to have great partners within the United States even if the Federal Government decides to stay on the side of the road. We will also step up our climate diplomacy. Climate action was a key topic of the European Union-China Summit on 2 June and our cooperation on the ground with China is stepping up a gear. In September the European Union will host a major ministerial gathering with ministers here from China and Minister McKenna from Canada to advance in the implementation of Paris and accelerate their transition. Finally, my last remark to his House is that the world’s reaction to President Trump’s action proved that the European Union is on the right side of history. Our task ahead is clear. Let’s keep our resolve.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I thank everyone for their interventions, and despite the US decision to leave, I am encouraged by their support for full implementation of the Paris Agreement and our continuous leadership at international level. We will continue our work on this and on the current climate legislative proposals. I thank you all very much.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - We Spanish socialists are in favor of reducing greenhouse gas emissions as the first urgent measure to adopt to mitigate the devastating effects of climate change. Following the announcement of the United States' withdrawal from the Paris Agreement, the European Union must lead the process and redouble its efforts as a reference region to follow. We Socialists want to prevent the increase in the global average temperature of the planet from exceeding 2 ° C with respect to pre-industrial levels and we will defend undertaking additional efforts so that global warming does not exceed 1.5 ° C. In the same way, we defend the commitment of the EU and its Member States to continue with the Paris Agreement, recognizing the need for global emissions to reach a ceiling as soon as possible and assuming that this task will take longer in developing countries. In this sense, we support contributions to the Green Climate Fund, aimed at developing countries to reduce their emissions and increase resistance to the consequences of climate change. To do this, we Socialists want to maintain the goal of mobilizing $ 100 billion a year in 2020 and extend this measure until 2025.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: written. - The political climate between the EU and the US has deteriorated since Donald Trump took office; Now the US president is also making it clear what he thinks of the global climate and its protection. Trump's announcement that he is withdrawing from the Paris climate agreement is a step backwards in international efforts to get a grip on climate change. One of the greatest challenges of our time is to hand over a clean and livable planet to future generations. In this regard, it is frightening how lightly Trump jeopardizes the hard-won Paris climate agreement. Even if Trump believes he can disregard any scientific knowledge about climate change, the decision will end up having a significant impact on the environment and international relations. It is now up to the European Union and its member states. The EU must not allow itself to be negatively influenced by the short-sighted policies of the American president. We Europeans must now lead the way with leadership. Because despite Trump, climate protection must continue to be pursued and - as far as possible - expanded with more ambitious goals. It must be clear: this announcement also means that Europe can no longer count on the unpredictable US president on such an important issue as the fight against global warming.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: written. - President Trump has opted for the US to withdraw from the Paris climate agreement. In doing so, he is maneuvering his country into the margins of climate policy. At the same time, it indirectly increases the pressure on Europe and the other signatory states to meet their obligations and to set ambitious goals in the future. As a global economic power, the EU has an obligation more than ever to take a leading role in international climate protection. For this we need a European climate diplomacy strategy. The European Parliament can and must give important impetus in drawing up this strategy. For a year now, I have been campaigning for there to be an own-initiative report on climate diplomacy in the Committee on Foreign Affairs. For example, I advocate that our parliamentary committees and delegations systematically ask their interlocutors on their worldwide travels about the implementation of the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and their national climate protection goals as part of COP21. This also applies to our EU representations around the world. The European External Action Service in Brussels must be given the financial and human resources to strengthen Europe as a central player in climate diplomacy.

text: written. - We Spanish socialists are in favor of reducing greenhouse gas emissions as the first urgent measure to adopt to mitigate the devastating effects of climate change. Following the announcement of the United States' withdrawal from the Paris Agreement, the European Union must lead the process and redouble its efforts as a reference region to follow. To do this, we Socialists want to maintain the goal of mobilizing $ 100 billion a year in 2020 and extend this measure until 2025.

To do this, we Socialists want to maintain the goal of mobilizing $ 100 billion a year in 2020 and extend this measure until 2025.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing. - The Paris Convention has been negotiated for twenty long years. Finally, a historic agreement was reached in which the international community committed itself to tackling the causes and consequences of climate change. The Paris Convention represents a strong alliance between developing and developed countries, as only two states in the world have not signed by signing it, namely Syria and Nicaragua. That is why it was shocking for all of us to announce President Trump that the United States no longer wants to remain a party to the Paris Convention. The President of the Marshall Islands, Hilda Heine, also took part in the debate, so we heard first-hand about the threats posed by climate change and the day-to-day fight against them. We are only really aware of how lucky our geographical location is when we think of the serious consequences of the 7-month drought, the overwhelming force of a typhoon, or the people left homeless by the tide. And the Marshall Islands got one of these every year. The European Union must take the lead in meeting the goals set out in the Paris Convention so that we can pass on a healthy planet to the next generation. The agreement also contributes to long-term economic development and the well-being of society. Obligations can even be seen as opportunities to encourage Member States to develop ambitious, modern technological achievements.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – Although President Trump’s decision to withdraw the United States from the COP 21 Climate agreement baffled European countries and other signatories of the agreement, I believe that in the future, when we look back, we can thank President Trump, whose actions have pushed Europe and the rest of the world more together, in order to take climate change much more seriously and to actually take concrete steps to enforce agreements. We have even seen how several US states have gone against President Trump’s decisions, by pledging to fulfil COP 21 commitments voluntarily. We welcome such action, as this is a great example of how unified work of individuals and businesses at a grass-roots level can have an effect on important matters, even if the leaders of the country think otherwise. Climate change is a global challenge, and we need to tackle it, even if we are met with resistance.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: written. - We Spanish socialists are in favor of reducing greenhouse gas emissions as the first urgent measure to adopt to mitigate the devastating effects of climate change. Following the announcement of the United States' withdrawal from the Paris Agreement, the European Union must lead the process and redouble its efforts as a reference region to follow. We Socialists want to prevent the increase in the global average temperature of the planet from exceeding 2 ° C with respect to pre-industrial levels and we will defend undertaking additional efforts so that global warming does not exceed 1.5 ° C. In the same way, we defend the commitment of the EU and its Member States to continue with the Paris Agreement, recognizing the need for global emissions to reach a ceiling as soon as possible and assuming that this task will take longer in developing countries. In this sense, we support contributions to the Green Climate Fund, aimed at developing countries to reduce their emissions and increase resistance to the consequences of climate change. To do this, we Socialists want to maintain the goal of mobilizing $ 100 billion a year in 2020 and extend this measure until 2025.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr President of the Republic, welcome to the European Parliament. It is an honor and a pleasure for me to receive you today in Strasbourg. A month ago, dear President, we received Mr. Moussa Faki Mahamat, the Chairman of the African Union Commission. Your visit is therefore part of the rapprochement and strengthening of our partnership with, on the one hand, the African Union and, on the other, the Member States that make it up. I would like to salute the extraordinary work you have done in your country: coming out of a civil war, strengthening institutions and the rule of law, straightening, energizing and diversifying the economy by creating an industrial base, and improving indicators social. The Ivory Coast ranks among the fastest growing economies in the world, with an estimate of 8% this year. It can and should serve as an example for other countries on the African continent, particularly in West Africa. However, many things remain to be done: the fight against poverty, infrastructure, education, health, access to drinking water and even electricity. Please know that we do not forget that the Ivory Coast, like Europe, has been hit by terrorist attacks, especially in Grand-Bassam. This is a scourge we cannot solve on our own. We must cooperate in this area, with the help of regional organizations, such as ECOWAS or the African Union. Europe and Africa also share the same challenge on the management of migratory flows. We must act at the root of the problem by investing more and better in the framework of real economic diplomacy to create growth and jobs. The arrival this morning of the President of the Republic of the Marshall Islands reminds us of the importance of taking action for sustainable development and the climate. Ivory Coast is also suffering the effects of climate change, with drought, floods and even coastal erosion.In addition, youth and employment, peace, security, human rights and even crisis management are concrete areas that we will no doubt be dealing with at the end of November in your country, in Abidjan., during the Africa-European Union summit.Mr. President, your presence here is very important and we look forward to having you with us today.Know, Mr. President, that we want to look at Africa with African glasses and not European ones.That is why our cooperation is and will be crucial for peace, for stability, for the commitment against terrorism, against illegal immigration and against climate change.Mr. Speaker, once again, thank you very much.(Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President of the Republic of Côte d'Ivoire. - Mr President of the European Parliament, dear Antonio Tajani, Ladies and Gentlemen of the European Parliament, first of all I would like to thank you for the opportunity you have given me to speak this morning in front of the European Parliament meeting in session plenary. It is an honor and a privilege for me, for my country, to be here because, you who are the elected representatives of more than 500 million European citizens, you constitute, because of your cultural diversity, your political commitments as well as your great experience, an exceptional and prestigious audience. I would therefore like to take this opportunity to discuss with you the major challenges that Africa must meet in the coming decades. I will then tell you about my country, Côte d'Ivoire, which is on the path to emergence, as you know. Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, on March 25, 2017, the European Union celebrated, in the Eternal City, the sixtieth anniversary of the signing of the Treaties of Rome. These treaties established the furrows of active solidarity between nations once at war. The founding fathers of the Treaty of Rome had the ingenious idea of ​​pooling resources and intelligence in the service of building an area of ​​shared peace, security and prosperity. Europe is in this a source of inspiration for the world, and more particularly for the African continent. At a time when, unfortunately, a withdrawal of identity is observed in several regions of the world, I am convinced that here, in this noble assembly, you will be able to draw from yourselves the energy necessary to pursue the spirit of solidarity, openness and peace advocated by your predecessors. This conviction is based on the fact that since its creation, the European Union has not ceased to communicate to humanity its unshakeable faith in a world of peace, stability and progress. The Nobel Peace Prize, awarded to you in 2012, is of course a remarkable illustration of this. Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, the future of humanity will depend on the policies, actions and programs that we define together, in our countries, our continents and on a global scale. In other words, the world will become what we want it to be. In this regard, I would like to address today three major challenges which will have a significant impact on the future of our planet and on relations between Europe and Africa. I know that the President of the Commission, Mr Juncker, raised the issue of peace and security with you, so I would not want to repeat it. The three challenges I would like to talk about relate to global warming, migratory flows and population expansion. I will start with global warming. On December 12, 2015, world leaders gathered in Paris to adopt a landmark climate accord. This agreement, which has been ratified by the vast majority of States, including Côte d'Ivoire (which has already deposited the instruments of ratification at the UN), constitutes for our planet a unique opportunity to contain the global warming within reasonable limits. Now more than ever, it is urgent to implement this agreement, so that the harmful effects of global warming on people and the ecosystem are contained. In this regard, Europe, as it has always been in the face of major global challenges, can show the way. Europe must, in particular, continue to mobilize the opinions, funding and technologies essential for the energy transition so that the Paris Agreement is irreversible. Yes, the Paris Agreement gave us a historic opportunity, now we have to make it happen. Today, as I speak to you, torrential rains, which are the consequences climatic disturbances are causing significant damage in several regions of my country. Likewise, many regions in Africa are facing waves of drought of unprecedented magnitude, which are causing death and desolation in several communities and causing massive displacement of populations. Ladies and Gentlemen, I would therefore like to encourage you to continue to make the climate a priority, so that the tragedies we are seeing around the world stop. There are indeed several possibilities to continue to chart paths towards green growth that uses little CO2. These possibilities include sound management of natural resources and ecosystems while harnessing their value for economic development. Together, we need to foster resilience within communities by reducing all forms of discrimination, especially against women. We must all work to put in place policies for the more efficient and fairer redistribution of wealth. Mr President, Ladies and Gentlemen, the second challenge that I would like to address and which our planet is facing is that of unregulated migratory flows and the employment of young people. At the Valletta Migration Summit in November 2015, I told the participating Heads of State that the dramatic events which are causing the deaths of thousands of people in the waters of the Mediterranean and in the Sahel require more solidarity and consultation between Europe and Africa. To do this, we must act over time and on all of the factors causing this situation. In this regard, it is urgent to restore peace and security in the Sahel-Saharan strip and to encourage a consensual political solution to the conflict in Libya. However, it must be recognized that conflicts and organized crime alone do not explain the movements migration to Europe observed in recent years. To these factors must be added poverty, I would even say misery, unemployment and the lack of democracy in many countries. This is why, on Monday June 12, 2017, during the G20 conference in Berlin on a partnership with Africa, we suggested the establishment of a plan that would aim to facilitate massive investments in Africa by with a view to creating jobs, especially for young people. This will help reduce illegal migration flows to Europe. Given the German Chancellor's commitment to this noble cause and the importance of this prospect, many of us have suggested that this plan could be called the "Merkel Plan." We have noted, however, that intra-African migratory movements are significantly higher in number than those observed between Africa and Europe. For example, the Ivory Coast hosts nearly 5.5 million foreign nationals on its territory, representing a proportion of 26% of its total population of around 24 million. Transfers from this African diaspora to its countries of origin represent nearly 1% of Côte d'Ivoire's GDP each year. This is to say how much Ivorian hospitality and generosity make a good contribution to the development of neighboring countries. (Applause) My country will continue to show solidarity with all these populations. It is therefore important that it be supported so that it continues to create jobs that allow it to remain a land of welcome and hospitality. Mr President, Ladies and Gentlemen, this African youth who are tempted by the European adventure is often the victim of mafia networks and terrorist organizations which feed on their vulnerability and their frustrations. We must therefore act towards these young people by educating them, by informing them and making them realize that they are better off in Africa than elsewhere. They must also be treated with respect for their dignity. We must keep in mind article 1 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, adopted by the United Nations General Assembly on December 10, 1948 in Paris, at the Palais de Chaillot, I quote: “All human beings are born. free and equal in dignity and rights. They are endowed with reason and conscience and must act towards one another in a spirit of brotherhood. ” It is in this spirit of openness to cooperation on many issues of global interest that Côte d'Ivoire will exercise its mandate within the United Nations Security Council for the period 2018-2019. In this regard, Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank all your countries for the massive support you have given us on the occasion of our election to the United Nations Security Council. This mandate, which will begin on January 1, will be placed under the sign of peace, which Ivorians have established as a second religion. Mr President, Ladies and Gentlemen, the last challenge I would like to mention is that of population expansion.
