According to projections by the United Nations Population Division, the world population, which is approximately 7.4 billion people today, including 1.2 billion Africans, will exceed 10 billion by 2056. In this whole Africa will experience the strongest growth, which will account for 50% of global population growth by 2050. This will allow Africa to catch up with the populations of more developed regions, such as North America and Africa. Europe. Nigeria will become, in 2050, the fifth most populous country, ahead of Brazil, the United States, Indonesia and Pakistan, and the Democratic Republic of Congo and Ethiopia will replace Russia and Mexico in the list of ten countries most populous in the world. In other words, what will be the place of these three great countries at the global level in a few decades. This strong growth will be even more pronounced for working-age populations. Indeed, the active population in sub-Saharan Africa will increase from 518 million people today to 1.3 billion in 2050. Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, Africa, cradle of humanity, will continue, paradoxically, to be the youngest region in the world until the end of this century. This observation challenges all African leaders, but also leaders around the world. Indeed, the stability of Africa, but also that of the rest of the world, will depend on how the issue of youth is dealt with in the coming decades. Taking demographic expansion into account in development programs will require special emphasis on human capital, including education, health and vocational training. Massive investments will also need to be made in infrastructure, including major sub-regional projects, transport, electricity, education and health. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would now like to tell you about the progress made by my country, Côte d'Ivoire, which, after more than a decade of crisis, is at peace today. It has also returned to economic growth. This progress is first and foremost the result of the mobilization and determination of Ivorians. They have also been made possible by the significant technical and financial contribution of our partners in the European Union, notably in the areas of governance, agriculture and energy. I would therefore like to take this opportunity to greet and warmly thank the European Union for its accompaniment and support. Partnership with the international community, and particularly the European Union, enabled Côte d'Ivoire to achieve exceptional performances. Over the past six years, the economy's average growth rate has been 9% per year. Projections for the period 2017-2020 are around 7-8% per year. The inflation rate was contained below 2% thanks to the peg to the euro, and the budget deficit was brought under control at around 3% of GDP. This year, of course, the situation is a little different, due to the drastic drop, almost 40% since the beginning of the year, in the price of cocoa, of which we are the world's largest producer. Nevertheless, we will continue to make efforts to master the macroeconomic framework. Côte d'Ivoire remains the world's largest producer of cocoa and cashew nuts. We are also the largest African producer of palm oil and rubber. Côte d'Ivoire is one of the top reformers in the World Bank's Doing Business ranking. In the energy sector, Côte d'Ivoire is on its way to becoming an energy hub in West Africa, with a capacity of 2,000 MW in 2016, which will increase to 4,000 MW in 2020. Today , Côte d'Ivoire has one of the most dense and diversified infrastructure networks in Africa, thanks to its roads, ports and airports. Finally, Côte d'Ivoire has made significant progress in the area of ​​security reform, including disarmament, demobilization and reintegration of former combatants, a program to which the European Union has successfully contributed. Recent events do not call into question this good development because, today, the safety index is at the same level as in Geneva or New York. These reforms will continue and intensify in order to provide the Ivory Coast with defense and security forces that can contribute to peacekeeping operations. Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen MEPs, a few years away from the expiry, in 2020, of the Cotonou partnership agreement and at a time when we have to reflect on a new agreement between Africa and Europe, I would like to suggest some ideas that are inspire exemplary relations that Côte d'Ivoire has maintained with the European Union. These relations must be frank, based on mutual trust and, of course, on national ownership. They should use flexible financing instruments and take into account national management and control mechanisms, which could be strengthened if necessary. Of course, we will have the opportunity to discuss these issues of great importance to my country in more depth. In conclusion, I would like to invite all the countries that you represent to take part in the next European Union-Africa summit, which will be held next November in Abidjan. This important meeting, which will take place in the pure tradition of Ivorian hospitality, will be an opportunity to discuss the international cooperation necessary to respond to the new challenges facing humanity, particularly issues related to youth and development. Mr President, I would like to thank you again. Ladies and Gentlemen, I say a big thank you, and I thank President Antonio Tajani for his invitation. I am impressed by your warm welcome and by your important participation, which gave me the opportunity to present to you the challenges we face, not only in Côte d'Ivoire, but also throughout the African continent, and of you talk about the evolution of Côte d'Ivoire. Thank you. Thank you to each and every one of you. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you very much, Mr President, for your speech.The European Parliament will be a protagonist in the dialogue with your country and with Africa.We share the same challenges: youth unemployment, the fight against terrorism, against illegal immigration and against climate change.You stressed the importance of population growth.This is why Europe needs to be much more involved with you if we are to solve our problems and help you, working together to try to reduce unemployment and give hope to all young Africans.We have a duty to prevent the dream of young Africans of living at home from being destroyed due to various issues.We want to be by all of you, and Parliament will play a very important role in this area.Thank you once again for being here with us.You have friends here, and our door will always be open to you.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: - Mister President!I am referring to Rule 31 of the Rules of Procedure.On Monday in the Bureau you discussed a report that considers the building of the Parliament in Brussels to be so dilapidated and no longer secure against terrorism that the building should possibly be demolished.This report is available to many newspapers - except us MEPs.I do not mean to say that I am against the demolition of the building, but I think that, as Members of this House, we have a right to see this report too.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is Voting Time.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: – Mr President, I would like to ask colleagues to refer the matter back to the Committee for starting the interinstitutional negotiations. This is based on Rule 59(4.4).

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Voting time is over.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, I fully support the rapporteur’s stance on amending the Commission’s proposals on climate action regulation implementing the Paris Agreement. The amended proposal focuses on long—term predictability and energy efficiency, and aims to provide sufficient flexibility for the Member States. You know that, to achieve a proper implementation of the Paris climate change agreement, it is very important to think beyond the 2030 target, which is precisely what the amended regulation proposes by setting out a long-term objective towards at least 80 % greenhouse gas emissions reductions by 2050. Although, I would be glad to see a bit more flexibility in terms of encouraging Member States’ contribution to climate action in terms of agriculture and forestry activities.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr Chairman!Well, we live in times in which, perhaps for the first time in human history, we decide not only about our own fate, but about the fate, the future of not only our children or grandchildren, but people who will live in fifty or a hundred years on Earth.Unfortunately, not all European countries share this view, and what is worse, not all countries in the world - including, we have recently known, also the United States.On the other hand, it is a country that is responsible for 15% of CO2 emissions on a global scale, and is in the second place after China, which emits 30% of CO2.So in the situation we are in, we should probably rethink our strategy to achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, I am in favour of the Paris Agreement. I cannot help noticing the sudden change in tone, though, of its other supporters. A year ago, they were telling us that it was a bare minimum, that it was inadequate, and suddenly, the moment Donald Trump pulled out, it became central to the survival of human civilization. But we will leave that to one side. It seems to me sensible to have countries working voluntarily on this kind of issue.  What is not sensible is to defend it – as so many in this House have been doing – as an economic project, the idea that it is all about creating green jobs and so on. To see what is wrong with that argument, consider Frédéric Bastiat’s example of the broken glass. If somebody went round smashing windows, that would – on exactly the same argument – create lots of jobs, because there would be lots of jobs needed for glaziers, people to drive the new glass, people to install them and all the rest of it; but of course we can all see that we would still be worse off. If we are prepared to pay an economic price, fine – that is a perfectly valid convincing argument. But for heaven’s sake, let us not insult people’s intelligence by claiming that this is somehow going to boost global growth.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, what we are talking about is the contribution that agriculture, transport and construction have to make to climate change. The issue is how much of a contribution can be made, particularly by agriculture, because the Council conclusions of 2014 recognise the low mitigation potential of the sector and, indeed, the Paris Agreement talks about the food security issue and the vulnerability of agriculture to the adverse impacts of climate change. I was concerned about the targets that Ireland, in particular, would have to reach under this agreement, but I supported the report because of the overall thrust of its direction: that all sectors have to contribute. I count on the negotiations to take out the most difficult aspects of this from an Irish point of view, so that we can keep forging ahead with a sustainable food supply chain, supplying our EU customers and global customers.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, it is important that we meet the Paris objectives, particularly in light of the statements recently by President Trump, and I do not think anybody disputes our commitment under the Paris Agreement to binding annual greenhouse gas emissions and how we are going to reduce those. As a member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, I was involved on behalf of the PPE in preparing our input into today’s important vote. But I think we should take note of the different positions that Member States have, the different structures of their economies and their varying capacity to meet those targets. I therefore supported amendments, that unfortunately were not accepted, seeking to ensure we have a more flexible and less punitive approach towards the greenhouse gas emissions reductions, and I acknowledge the many difficulties that many countries face after the financial crisis. The agricultural sector is particularly sensitive for Ireland and we have raised this objection today, but overall I support the report and its implementation as we aim to meet our Paris climate change objectives.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! I voted against the report on sectors not covered by the ETS, as the consequence of adopting the proposed regulations will deepen the development disparities between the Member States. The proposed solutions promote richer countries through an unfair allocation of annual emission allowances. Moreover, setting a benchmark for 2016-2018 is detrimental to poorer countries. In order to maintain policy continuity, it is necessary to set the emission level that will start at the end of the current period, i.e. in 2020. I also disagree with increasing the level of reduction ambitions by setting a trajectory for reducing them from 2018. As for the proposed reserve for the less prosperous member states, it will minimally compensate for their extra effort. I recommend going back to the cornerstone of climate policy, which should be the Paris Agreement.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, I must say that there are good things in the report, amendments that I have voted on, such as Article 7 on providing incentives for SMEs and small farms. I would have liked to support this report in full, but we have to be realistic: there are a lot of things in the report that will mainly affect smaller and less developed states, such as articles that provide for the introduction of additional delegated acts and we do not know what these delegated acts will contain. I think that the citizens who need support the most will suffer. Reducing gas emissions is a necessity, but the proposed targets must be rational and in line with the possibilities of each state, because we still have a job crisis, and we still have problems with regional disparities and per capita income. very different. So I have refrained and I hope that this ratio will be improved, because yes, we need a reduction in emissions, but we also need more jobs and per capita income.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, like my colleagues, I am totally in favour of the Paris Agreement and EU targets for 2030. However, we have a huge difficulty with the 2020 target setting, which was implemented here in Parliament. For that reason, I tabled a split vote on that. It means that rather than starting on actual emissions, we had to start with a target which was not reachable, was not practical and which will now probably cost the Irish taxpayer EUR 1 billion to purchase compliance. We are starting a non-compliance method. This is not fair to us, and we have to make a stand on it and ensure that this is rectified in due course. It was only in the last minute, I think, that somehow the rapporteurs etc. got this point where Ireland and other countries are concerned. Starting in a non-compliant way, like we are, is like starting a 100 metres race where one person has to start 20 metres behind. It makes no sense, it is not fair, and it has to be amended. That is our biggest issue; we want that message to get across; we are totally in favour of reaching the 2020 targets otherwise.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, it was a very difficult decision for me to abstain on this report and not to support it, because it contains many good proposals on the reduction of greenhouse gases. However, what has happened here is that we have let the best become the enemy of the good, in particular by setting a starting date of 2018 and not 2020, as proposed by the European Commission. The starting point is critical, and pushing it back to 2018 could, as my colleague Seán Kelly has said, ensure an additional liability of EUR 1 billion for Ireland, and I simply could not support that proposal, because it is a bad proposal. I think what we have done here is to run counter to the Paris Agreement and the October 2014 Agreement, which recognised the low mitigation potential of agriculture and that food production and food security are important elements in any proposal on climate change. I hope that in the negotiations the start date will be moved back to 2020 and we can get a good overall outcome.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Let me explain why, in the final vote, I supported the EP's position on the proposal for a regulation on binding annual reductions in greenhouse gas emissions.I think this is an important signal from the EP at a time when Donald Trump has announced the withdrawal of the United States from the Paris Agreement.This legislation is based mainly on the methodology and principles set by the previous Council decision and at the same time on the experience gained in the previous period.There are also some administrative simplifications and enhanced flexibility.I voted in favor of the amendment so that the starting path for reducing emissions is not 2018, which is the EP's proposal.The European Commission's original proposal was 2021. I agree with the reservations made here by my colleagues in Ireland, but this decision can be reversed by the Council, and I hope it will.

name: Peter JAHR
text: - Mister President! Of course, it is important and right for the European Parliament to commit to the Paris Agreement and the reduction of greenhouse gases - especially at this time when the United States obviously wants to move away from this agreement. Nevertheless, it was not easy for me to agree, and I have at least three wishes left unanswered. The first wish: I would ask everyone that we see European agriculture not as a problem, but as a solution to the problem. Second, I would like a global perspective in all of our decisions. There is no point in making many improvements in the European Union and then bad things happen in the rest of the world. And the third wish: Of course, with all things we do, we should make sure that it can be implemented and that it is unbureaucratic, because ultimately people and medium-sized companies must be able to apply it.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! In the European Union, women receive pensions on average 30% lower. This is due to the cumulative effect of inequalities and barriers. The barriers that women face on their professional paths. They receive lower remuneration for the same job, take part-time work much more often than men, and take holidays due to the need to combine work and family life. Women make a great social effort to look after children and family members, which, unfortunately, is not economically reflected in the benefits they receive. Women cannot be economically punished for acting as mothers. Their underappreciated contribution to society is of great value. Therefore, I agree that there is an urgent need to take priority action to close the pension gap. I believe that the report was balanced and that its scope gives a good direction for change. Unfortunately, there are several contradictory provisions in it, so I abstained from voting.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Mr Chairman! I did not vote for the report on the need for an EU strategy to eliminate the pension gap, as the European Union has no competence in national pension policy and should leave parents the freedom to choose between work and family life. However, I abstained because of a problem that affects, in particular, mothers who give birth and raise children, which affects their pensions. Hence the need to indicate the direction of exit to the Member States. Where possible, I have tabled amendments to reduce the pension inequality, which has in some way been taken into account in the report by encouraging the introduction of contributory points and survivors 'and widows' pensions as compensation for what is considered invisible as valuable and invaluable domestic work and caring for family members or for formal periods of care such as maternity leave.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: - Mr President, I have abstained from voting on this report because it is not possible to prevent and end the gender gap in pensions if the root causes that are helping to increase it are not attacked, such as the reforms that you are proposing to the Commission to weaken public pension systems compared to the second and third pillars, the increase in the retirement age and the years of contributions required, or the updating of the pension linking it to life expectancy and not to the CPI. We had a golden opportunity with this report. However, the rapporteur, Ms Le Grip, decided to reject a good part of the opinion of the Employment Committee, which referred to the structural causes of discrimination against women in employment, which multiplies its effects when they reach retirement age. On the contrary, instead of analyzing these structural causes, Ms Le Grip's report places increasing emphasis on the importance of second and third pillar pensions or makes negative references such as, for example, that women live longer and spend more , therefore, more on them. This is the reason why I have abstained and I believe that there are fundamental elements that are outside the report.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, I supported the report on the need for an EU—wide strategy to end and prevent a gender pension gap against the background that we have of an ageing population and the gap that already exists in the labour market and wages between men and women. Women do need more financial security, particularly in their later years. As we know, there is a wage gap of about 15% – or 14%, depending on the country – which manifests itself in terms of pension payments of 34%. So it needs to be addressed, and I am encouraged that the report manages to respect that there is a subsidiarity issue here but outlines a number of recommendations that need to be acted on. We need to look at statistical tools to clearly determine the reasons for the gap, focus on inequalities and the ability to make pension contributions and, of course, look at opportunities to create labour market conditions that are favourable for women to participate at work, also encouraging the Member States to look at repercussions and the way in which their pension systems are organised.  All in all, I think it is a balanced report, putting forward the need to ensure that we do have an EU strategy to address the gender pay gap.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, I supported this report. I think it is an important report and, contrary to what some colleagues said, the fact that it is subsidiarity does not mean that we should not be concerned, we at European level. The report clearly sets out the sharing of examples of good practice from other countries. There are obviously gaps between the pension systems in one country and another, but here we are talking about the fact that there is a gap between the pensions of women and men and there has been talk about the cause. For example, the fact that women are much more often forced to interrupt their service for raising children and obviously then the pension contribution is lower and the pension will be lower. I strongly believe that we need such a report, especially since the report proposes that Member States increase investment, increase investment in services for children, because, of course, if there are places in every country where children can grow up. safely, mothers can continue their careers. That is why I supported the report and I congratulate the report.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: - Mr. president.I think it is very important that we voted on this report today, because it really touches on one of the most unacceptable matters in our world of work and in our social world.That, in the 21st century, there is a 40% difference in pensions between men and women is simply indecent.But the origin of this problem is largely in wages.In other words, the serious thing is that this gap will not be resolved in a short time if wages between men and women are not equal.And, unfortunately, this is not being the case.Even today the salary difference between men and women amounts to approximately 25% on average, and this means that the contribution careers are weighed down by this difference.I think the report is fine.It could have been better.The Socialist Group has tabled more amendments.Some have not been approved.All in all, it is a step forward that we want to highlight.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: –Mr President, I, too, was happy to support this report on the gender pension gap. In particular, I support the call for the Commission to include pension reforms in the country-specific recommendations, and these reforms should include measures that relate to women’s participation in the workforce: work—life balance and the care of children and dependants, because that will help to reduce the gender pension gap. The Commission’s own proposals on work-life balance, which include a directive on carers’ leave, on parental leave, and also on flexibility in the workplace, will help to ensure work-life balance, and that in turn will help to narrow the gender pay gap and the gender pension gap, which stand at approximately 14% and 34% respectively in Ireland. Crucially, I also support the need for measures to ensure that women’s pay and entitlements, including pensions, are in line with the principle of equal pay for equal work or work of equal value for men and women. That taken with the work-life balance, I think will help to make significant inroads into the gender pension gap.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report, and we can agree that Serbia, as an aspiring country to EU membership, has been committed towards the continuous reform process necessary for successful integration. Serbia has shown progress in terms of economic reforms and institutional reforms by continuing to implement the Stabilisation and Association Agreement. However, there is still a lot to be done in terms of tackling corruption, ensuring judiciary independence and freedom of media and improving Serbia’s relations with all its neighbours, as well as establishing a properly functioning legal framework for the protection of the minorities in the country. Moreover, I fully support the call on Serbia to take serious steps to align its foreign policy to the EU line, and In have serious questions on the real aims behind the so—called Slavic Brotherhood and whom exactly this brotherhood is directed against.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - President! Dear Hungarian brothers from the south! However, some very important and positive provisions have been included in the country report for Serbia. However, I demand that the European Union constantly monitor their implementation, and of course the Hungarian government, as the motherland, and the Hungarian community in the south. What is this about? For example, and I would like these provisions and calls to be disseminated in eighty percent of Hungarian Zenta, from flyers, via Facebook, to announcers. The rights of national minorities and the protection and promotion of them are a basic precondition for joining the EU, says the EU. Reiterates its call on Serbia to ensure the consistent implementation of legislation on the protection of minorities throughout the country, paying particular attention to the non-discriminatory treatment of national minorities, Article 24. Among other things, education, language, justice ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - I did not support this report because it is an unrealistic and distorted view of what is happening in the Western Balkans and Serbia's intervention in it, and therefore I cannot agree with such an approach. First of all, I would like to note that the Serbian policy of assimilation of national communities and the attempts to influence and suppress them, including the Bulgarian recognized minority in the region of the Western Bulgarian suburbs, continues. The writing and publishing of Bulgarian textbooks under an agreement signed by Serbia continues to be delayed, and those published are full of errors and falsify historical facts. I cannot fail to note that the Serbian state continues to work for the fragmentation and division of all national communities and continues to interfere in the internal affairs of neighboring countries. The latest example is the elections in Kosovo. One hundred years have recently passed since the Serbian pogrom in the Bosilegrad region. A memorial plaque with the names of the victims was made by order of the local people in the Western Bulgarian suburbs. Authorities in Bosilegrad and Vranje did not allow it to be installed. For me, the path of the Republic of Serbia goes through clearing the country's relations and good relations in the first place with its neighbors.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - President! The Hungarian Student Association of Vojvodina has been fighting for years to allow the Faculty of Law of the University of Novi Sad to enroll in Hungarian in accordance with the current Serbian legislation. Nevertheless, the university denies this opportunity provided by law. The student union asked the competent court to declare that it was illegal to ban admission in Hungarian. The Supreme Court of Novi Sad dismissed the action in shockingly despite the regulation in force. What has happened again raises the question: to what extent is the constantly voiced claim that Serbia pursues an exemplary nationality policy true? This current, mentioned case proves that this is not true. The report should not examine the existence of the legislation needed to join the EU, but its practical application. He did not do that, so I did not support his adoption.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - I think that, in addition to criticizing Serbia, we should also appreciate its enormous efforts and progress towards democratization.We should appreciate his approach, for example, to the migration crisis, where Serbia was a valid member and did its utmost to try to provide basic health care, hygiene, housing or food for the people who flowed through it.We should also appreciate Serbia, which is trying to meet the needs of various minorities.You have already mentioned the Hungarian minority here, but I can mention the Czech minority and the Czech minority has not felt oppressed in Serbia for a long time.Serbia allows Czech radio, it allows Czech, and I think Serbia is on its way to the EU, and I believe that the EU will be very supportive of Serbia.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, Serbia’s path to the EU must be welcomed, but the problems have to be mentioned as well. Firstly, nationalism is often used for electoral purposes. Ahead of every general election, you send a train to Kosovo if it gives you votes. This practice is not unknown in other countries, but it has to stop since it obliges you to be nationalist even outside the election campaign. Secondly, Serbia wants to have two mothers: one the EU, and the other – stepmother – Russia. Therefore, the country has allowed Russia to take over an enormously large part of its energy infrastructure. The problem is, of course, that if Serbian foreign policy can be blackmailed by Russia through energy, the EU would be blackmailed as well.  I believe the enlargement is needed. I want to see Serbia in the EU, but we want a modern, non-nationalistic Serbia that does not get involved in the internal affairs of Bosnia or Kosovo, and a Serbia free to create and join EU foreign policy independent of Russia. I hope to see that Serbia joining the EU soon.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I supported this report.From my point of view, I perceive a very strong geopolitical interest in bringing Serbia closer to the EU.I am convinced that if the EU is not active towards Serbia and if we leave Serbia in the lurch, then in short, it will strengthen Russian influence in Serbia.From the point of view of the interest of the Czech Republic, which I represent here, I also consider this to be a bad procedure.That is why I supported this report.Of course, it is necessary to draw attention to the problems that exist in Serbia.Attention should be drawn to areas where Serbia is not yet ready to join the EU, but also to support structural reforms, such as judicial reform, police, greater fight against corruption, and serious forms of economic crime.These are the things that the report critically describes.In my opinion, this is so right, but we should not forget that it is in our interest for Serbia to move closer to the EU in the long term.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - President! In its report on Serbia, the issue of respect for and protection of minorities is given due importance, with particular emphasis on the action plan for the implementation of the rights of national minorities and the regulation establishing a fund to support national minorities. At the same time, it covers the use of languages, education, public administration, local and regional authorities, the media and churches. The text emphasizes the need to give due weight to the issue of national minorities and maintains the independence and multi-ethnic nature of Vojvodina. With regard to the protection of national minorities, we would welcome similar findings with regard to EU Member States, as the problems have not been resolved by accession, and moreover, national minorities living in the EU seem to receive less attention than minorities in candidate countries. We hope that, in the case of Serbia, this consistent attention will be maintained after accession. By the way, even a Member State, or a country wishing to join, when it comes to exemplary respect for the rights of minorities, there is always a problem.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr. President, I welcome the enlargement process and Kosovo’s steps towards the EU, but in order to make these steps faster, Kosovo has to solve its biggest problem, illustrated by the election this weekend that I among others have observed. The reason for this snap election was said to be coalition governmental inability to make reforms. However, none of the questions that caused stalemate were put before the voters. So there is a risk we will see a continued stalemate. This deadlock is Kosovo’s biggest problem and it is indeed caused by the difficult government coalitions and their partners’ unwillingness to put Kosovo’s best interests in front of their party’s. This has to stop; we need to see speedy reforms, primarily on the fight against corruption, and questions like the demarcation line, the Association of Serbian Municipalities, etc. should not be used for political gain since they are in interest of Kosovars. Enlargement is needed, we want it to happen, but we all have to speed up the process.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report because it presents how much progress Kosovo has made, but I also warmly welcome the EU—Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement that came into force last year, because it represents the very first step in the process of the integration of Kosovo into the EU. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement will help Kosovo to implement much—needed reforms and will create trade and investment opportunities. From this perspective, I call on the Kosovar authorities to continue to show clear political will and determination to implement the agreement, because the path towards European Union integration requires a strategic long-term vision and sustained commitment in the adoption of the necessary reforms. In conclusion, I want to focus on the recent general election in Kosovo, where the Self—Determination Movement won. The future government should not fail to close the border demarcation deal with Montenegro and further complicate relations with Serbia. All political parties in the country have to create the conditions for a fruitful solution and a result—orientated dialogue with their neighbours.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - I voted in favor of this report, but of course my position on the Kosovo government, which is very critical, continues.Unfortunately, Kosovo has failed and cannot convince us that it can fight organized crime, that freedom of expression and non-persecution of journalists is something that the local government, both past and future, sees as one of its main priorities.I think we need to be very critical of this fact from the EU.The European Commission recently said it would allow Kosovo citizens to travel to the EU without a visa.We should say yes, we will, but when the Kosovo government and Kosovo carry out some reforms.And unfortunately, that strength and willingness on the part of Kosovo is very small.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - I voted in favor of this report because I am convinced that the Western Balkans must be encouraged on their way to the European Union and NATO, and because they must be pulled out of the orbit of the influence of neighboring harmful and dangerous for this region and for all countries. - members of the European Union, forces. At the end of last week, my colleague Selimovic and I were on an observation mission in Kosovo on behalf of the European Parliament, and I assure you that the elections were conducted in a way that is probably more democratic than the elections being held in some of our countries in terms of technology. Of course, there are many problems - problems with corruption, problems with the rule of law, problems with the functioning of political parties and their funding, but they must be clearly identified and addressed one by one. I would like to draw your attention to the fact that the interests and influences of many neighboring countries collide in Kosovo. This is Russia through Serbia. This, of course, is Turkey, which also has its interests in the Balkans. We, as European countries, must make sure that Kosovo and its citizens choose their path and that it is part of the European Union.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I also supported this report, it is true what I said in the previous report.In short, the Balkan countries need to be brought closer to the EU, not a barrier.Near Kosovo, some colleagues have already described the problems that plague the country.I would add other problems to this, such as the growing Islamic radicalization.Many Kosovars are leaving the Islamic State to fight for Syria.I consider this to be another issue that needs to be mentioned here, but I am still glad that the association agreement entered into force on 1 April 2016 and that the process of rapprochement with the EU has therefore begun.We must be critical of Kosovo, as well as of other candidate countries, but constructively critical, ie.with a clear offer that if the situation improves and resolves, then EU membership will not pass the country.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, Macedonia was given EU candidate status in 2005, and it is time the country made progress on its way to the EU by implementing the needed reforms. In recent years, however, we have seen a decline in the stability of the institutions that maintain democracy: an independent media, the judiciary, the rule of law and minority rights. But the recent political crisis has only just finally come to an end. I sincerely hope that a new era in EU—Macedonia relations is about to start. I very much welcome the new government, which clearly demonstrates a pro—European orientation and commitment to the EU reform process. The EU also needs to remain a credible partner in this process. Twelve years have been lost, and the membership perspective has to remain in strong focus. I wish the new Macedonian Government the strength and decisiveness to take on the task of leading the country closer to the EU. That is why I strongly voted for this balanced report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - I supported this report because, despite the many problems in the Republic of Macedonia, this fraternal country has its place in the European family. I must emphasize that, in our view, the enlargement of the European Union to the Western Balkans must take place, but, of course, the corresponding changes are also needed. I strongly disagree with the view of Mr Khan, who criticizes Bulgaria and Greece for being against the start of the negotiation process. However, Mr. Weigl's report precisely emphasizes that the agreement on good neighborliness and friendship with Bulgaria is of great importance at the end of the negotiations. We want the hate speech of the media and institutions that are creating an artificial conflict in the Balkans to be stopped. I believe that we must support the future integration of the Republic of Macedonia into the European family and that the falsifications and thefts of history by Skopje historians must be stopped. I think that needs to change. Then, of course, the Republic of Macedonia must become part of the European Union.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: - I voted for the report because it is time for Macedonia to erase this difficult period in its history and open a new page in its democratic development. I welcome with great enthusiasm the formation of a new government in the country and the desire of the new government to work for the rapid accession to NATO and the European Union. However, we should not forget the fact that after a long period of political instability, Macedonia needs accelerated reforms to help normalize the country's political and ethnic climate. This is only possible if the new government serves the interests of the citizens and is based on the principles of transparency, equality and the rule of law. Prime Minister Zaev must show the necessary political will and responsibility to launch much-needed reforms to promote a culture of tolerance and inclusion between different ethnic, national and religious communities. Last but not least, I call on the European Union to show strong political support for Macedonia's European perspective, because only then will we be able to keep the dreams of two million citizens alive.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, I voted against the report on the accession process of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, because it is at least politically unacceptable to try to blame Greece for the fact that the Council does not set a date for the start of accession negotiations in Skopje. name dispute. The resolution does not take into account the facts that blatantly refute this claim. Today, we have a visit of the new Minister of Foreign Affairs of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in Athens. From the statements of the new government, it is obvious that it is recognized that the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has trapped itself in the intransigence and redemption cultivated by the leaderships. The issue of the name of Skopje can only be resolved within the framework of the United Nations with a mutually acceptable name with Greece, with one name for all. The European road must be opened for the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, provided that all the Copenhagen criteria are met.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - I, unlike my Greek colleague, supported this report because I see the enormous progress that this former Yugoslav Republic has made in recent years.I understand Greece's position and I understand what it has been saying for a long time, but we cannot block and continue to simply not have a dialogue that the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia should be part of the EU and that it needs to be supported in some wayits democratic process.I think that even in areas where the EU has had a relatively large number of reservations, such as migration, Macedonia has shown that it is a valid and cooperating member of the European Community.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, dear Colleague, I voted in favor of this proposed resolution on the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo because I believe that the European Union cannot fail to extend the application of sanctions against those responsible for serious human rights violations and the sabotage of the democratic process.in the Democratic Republic of Congo.The truth is that President Joseph de Kabila's inaction and silence in the face of these atrocities against his own people and the increase in kidnappings and attacks on aid workers and caravans are unacceptable.This motion for a resolution that we have just voted on today constitutes yet another strong appeal to President Kabila to, respecting the understanding reached with the mediation of the Catholic Church, call presidential elections by the end of this year, ensuring, therefore, the necessary conditionsthis electoral act is free, transparent and credible.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, I voted in favor of this resolution because I believe that the European Union, as a customer of 60% of clothing exports produced in Bangladesh, has greater responsibilities towards that country in promoting ethical production and sustainable consumption. Not forgetting that the textile sector is one of the economic and social pillars of that country, which directly employs four million workers, the European Union must call on companies to adopt codes of conduct that effectively guarantee the social and labor rights of their workers, including the right to dignified and fair remuneration and security conditions, should urge the Bangladeshi authorities to comply with their international obligations regarding freedom of association and should support all efforts by the United Nations to create a binding treaty that clarifies corporate obligations in the field of human rights. Last April 24, the fourth anniversary of Rana Plaza was celebrated, the terrible death of those 1,138 people, following the collapse of the sewing workshops in which they worked. It showed the world the hidden face of outsourcing the big Western textile brands and made it impossible for us to continue to pretend to ignore the semi-slavery conditions of the millions of Bangladeshi textile workers. I conclude, Mr. President, by saying that it is to the memory of these dead and of all those who die in similar conditions every year that we must pay tribute and act in defense of their rights.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Explanations of vote are closed.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on a topical issue (Rule 153a) entitled "Reconstructing a Europe based on values, anchored in effective democratic institutions and promoting a thriving economy in a fair and cohesive society"(2017/2706 (RSP)).I would like to let everyone know in advance that there is no catch-the-eye procedure and no blue cards in a debate under Rule 153a.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: author. – Mr President, there is a wind of change sweeping through the European Union. 2016 and 2017 will go down in the history books as the years of unprecedented turmoil and renewal, with a steep rise of nationalist forces, but no breakthrough. Instead, we see the first signs of a European spring, not summer yet, but after years marked by tensions and discontent there is a breeze of optimism, expectation and hope in the air. Who did not feel the excitement when President Macron met with Trump and Putin and represented a self-confident and proud Europe? And colleagues, who did not feel proud when we voted today on our commitment to the Paris climate agreement, making Europe the world leader where others withdraw?  Values are the key to the refoundation of the European Union. Election campaigns in recent years focused not just on traditional material issues of jobs and social security, but very much on values, culture and identity. The world order is changing at a breath-taking speed, and people are worried and anxious about loss of identity and loss of community. Nationalist parties have responded by sowing distrust, hatred and fear, or by promising to go back to an imaginary past. We reject that, but we have to recognise that our own response to the clear questions on values, identity and culture have not been adequate. The European Union is a deeply political union, but most politicians are wary of explaining this to their voters. They prefer to present the European Union as a technocratic entity that can be summed up in terms of economic benefits or costs.  If people are worried about loss of identity, abolishing roaming charges will not reassure them. If they are afraid their culture is threatened, cutting red tape will not allay their fears. If they are unsure about the shared values of our community, they will not find comfort in trade agreements, but we should not leave the monopoly of defining our shared values and our identity to the nationalists. In these current times of great uncertainty, insecurity and societal turbulence, it is not easy to defend our shared values; but we have not defined our shared values for fair-weather conditions only. It is when conditions are rough that our convictions are put to test. The European Union is not only an economic powerhouse, but it has great moral authority in the world. We can be proud. Our values have inspired many around the world, and many people dream of living in the kind of free, fair, stable and democratic society we have in Europe, so much so that others see our values as a threat, something they seek to destroy.  Populist parties worldwide have an agenda based on nationalism, xenophobia, homophobia and sexism. They agitate against secularism and parliamentary democracy and above all they reject pluralism. They claim there is one people, one voice, one truth only, but clearly recent elections have proved them wrong. Europeans will not be reduced to a one-dimensional caricature. If we wish to make Europe strong we must therefore promote the opposite and embrace European integration, diversity, equality, pluralism.  And against that backdrop, I think the tweet last week by Manfred Weber, who unfortunately is not here, was a bit misguided when he wrote that: ‘Europe’s identity is above all Christian. Anyone who denies this is denying reality’. But, dear colleague Weber, the reality is that the true soul of Europe lies in its diversity and the freedom to choose what to believe, and who you are.  Democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are not just ideals: they are essential for the functioning of the European Union in all policy areas. Social justice is a precondition for a stable climate for investment and development. Respect for fundamental rights is vital for common migration policies and police cooperation, and the rule of law is absolutely essential for the internal market and investor confidence. In short, values are the key to a strong European Union, and that is why the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe puts values first.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for the opportunity to speak today in this timely topical debate. This is indeed a time of deep reflection for all of us on the future of the EU. I am happy to be here today to listen to your views.  The title of this debate paints the picture of an EU which appeals to us all, one in which our values are placed at centre stage. One with effective and democratic institutions, one in which we pursue our genuine goal of improving the life and prosperity of our citizens, not just for the lucky few but across all of our society. This description is not such a far cry from the EU we have today and it certainly is in line with the EU’s clear ambitions. However, until only a few months ago, the EU’s efforts in this regard were largely ignored or discredited, either because the EU was perceived as doing too little or because it was seen as doing too much. But in recent months there seems to have been a shift in perception of the EU: rather than being considered as the source of many of our woes, the EU is seen as part of the solution.  We are seeing some positive signs of renewed trust and more support for the EU. This may be because as the world around us changes, the alternative options to the EU are slowly losing their shine. We may start realising that populist rhetoric oversimplifies very complex issues and is beginning to show its limitations. We may also be recognising that working together on global challenges like trade, climate and terrorism is preferable to going it alone.  Perhaps most importantly, the more we feel our values come under attack, the stronger our wish to uphold them. This should serve to fuel our prospects and indeed give us an impetus to work even more eagerly towards our goals.  However, only with a common vision of the EU’s future can we collectively pursue these common goals. In examining what future path to take, the EU cannot impose its vision on its citizens. It cannot come up with revolutionary designs if it does not have their support and backing. The EU needs to involve them in this debate. They need to feel that they are being heard and that their views matter.  That is why the Council very much welcomes the Commission’s White Paper process. It is a remarkable effort to steer an honest reflection and prompt a broad debate. I also commend you, the European Parliament, for your constant efforts to ensure that the views of citizens are safeguarded and upheld. I understand that, along with the Commission, you will be hosting a series of Future of Europe debates across Europe. As for the Council and the European Council, as you know, leaders already began an honest reflection exercise after the UK referendum vote to leave the EU. At their informal meeting in Bratislava last September, leaders set out a concrete roadmap with specific measures to address the most pressing concerns for citizens. This included tackling as a matter of urgency issues relating to migration, terrorism and economic and social insecurity. As work progressed on that front, the 60th anniversary of the Rome Treaties in March this year was another occasion to reflect on our common future. The Rome Agenda that resulted from this is a clear pledge to pursue our most important objectives over the next ten years. The European Council has since then framed its work across these main priorities. It has focused largely on delivering tangible results and delivering on its promises. Looking forward in relation to the White Paper process, the Council is taking careful note of the Commission’s follow-up papers and is ensuring that they provide a valuable contribution to our discussions. So for instance the white paper on globalisation provides perspectives for a debate on trade or on globalisation at the next European Council.  I would just like to say one word on the concrete result of this process. Reflecting on the future of Europe is a drawn-out process. It requires time and building trust, neither of which can be rapidly glossed over. We do not want to run the risk of having to offer results prematurely and thus falling short of expectations. The Council and the European Council will continue to focus on achieving concrete results, demonstrating that added value of the EU in very practical terms. In that spirit, the Future of Europe debates will provide further impetus for the Council to deliver on various key policies, rather than develop a new theoretical frame.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to use the three minutes allotted to me to reflect on what Mrs in 't Veld said in her introduction because I believe she touched upon the issue of fundamental values in a very concise and precise way. She also dismissed the solutions offered by nationalists, extremists and xenophobes, but then the question remains: why do so many Europeans still feel attracted to these political movements? I maintain that these political movements have assured quite strong support in the European Union and will probably continue to get quite strong support unless we address the reasons why they feel attracted to these movements. I believe many of our citizens are worried because they fear a loss of position. This is the first generation that fears that their children might be in a worse position than they are. They are worried because of the threat of Jihadist terrorism and see that some people want to attack our freedoms and take away our identities. They are worried because they see global developments in terms of peace and security, where they do not feel empowered enough to stand up for their values and their way of life.  So I think that, if we want to rekindle the feeling for our fundamental values, we need to do something about these fears, and the Commission’s starting point is that we can only do something about these fears if we stand together as Europeans. So rekindling our values starts with advocating European approaches to European problems, European approaches to global problems, and with making clear to our citizens that we can only do this if we stick together. This is difficult at a time where identity politics roam across Europe. This is difficult at a time when the other is presented as an adversary, and as somebody who is out there to take away what you have. If we redefine the European Union only in terms of an internal market or a common currency and present these, or the cutting of red tape or whatever you want, as the goals of our cooperation – these are important instruments, but they only have meaning if they are based on our common values, and we do not talk enough about these values.  The interesting thing is that the people who Mrs in 't Veld was, rightly, attacking because of their lack of solutions and the, to say the least, wobbly morality of their propositions, do have a moral approach to it. They start from their values. We should mirror that by starting from our values, the values that have made Europe great: democracy, the rule of law and full respect for human rights. This is the tripod upon which our European cooperation is built, and modernising that in the fourth industrial revolution to show that we can create a society where diversity creates more ambition with people, creates more opportunity for people, and recreates the economy in the fourth industrial revolution, is the way forward for Europe. But it will only happen if it is done on the basis of our values.  That is the basis for the White Paper the Commission has written. That is the basis for all the analyses we have written, and we put them on the table as a starting point for debate with Parliament, but also with the Member States in the hope that the members of the Council will use the paper to have a debate in their Member States about where Europe needs to go in the future.  Let me end on this. We have seen a sort of moment of awakening of a new generation in Europe. We saw it in the British election the other day, we have seen it in the French election in many ways, and we see it in the women’s marches in the United States and across Europe. Why? Because we understand now that, although our values are clear and eternal and cannot be questioned, they can be destroyed. The fact that we have now discovered is that, although our values are clear and are the basis of our cooperation, we now see that across the world these values are not unbreakable but need maintenance and that, if you want these values to survive, you need to stand up for them. You need to speak out for them. That is what I saw in recent elections. This is no longer about left or right. This is about whether you choose an open society with room for everyone, where no one is left behind, or you fall into the trap of thinking that your brother is your enemy. Europe should be for an open society where everybody counts and no one is left behind.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, just over sixty years ago, on March 25, 1957, Europeans signed the Treaty of Rome and planted the seed of the Union. It has undoubtedly been the stage of greatest peace, prosperity and stability by eliminating all the divisions and violence of the past. The words of Robert Schuman still remain and are in force, when he said that Europe would not be made in one go or with a joint work, but that it would be done little by little, with small achievements that would cultivate the value of solidarity . At that time, the founding fathers were clear about the objective: they did not have plans to build Europe, but they had a very powerful rear view mirror with which they showed us who the horsemen of the European apocalypse were: nationalism, genocide, racism, xenophobia, wars, totalitarianism. Today, Europe has changed; has aged. We received more people, but we also fired others. The labor market has the face of unemployment, which is very worrying. There are challenges such as immigration, security, energy, the economy, defense ... It is a complex Europe and a Europe full of contrasts; we face the challenge of what the richness of diversity entails at the same time as the challenge of social integration. And today the challenge is to be united and the challenge is that we endow the values ​​of democracy, freedom and progress with true content, that content with which the fathers of Europe endowed them. But for that you have to believe it, not just say it. It must be done with words and deeds.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - The title of today's debate is - to re-establish the European Union. Which means that we are aware that the main and basic foundation of our house, namely democracy, equality and respect, is falling apart. Dear Vice-President Timmermans, you have drawn attention to the dangerous populist rhetoric, to the general anger of our citizens. And so our spiritual building blocks are falling apart, and that means that the Union is doing very well in the event of non-compliance with the refugee distribution quota. The decisions we take at European Union level are simply not respected by some countries. That is why I also strongly welcome today's decision by the Commission to initiate legal proceedings against Member States that do not want to participate in the distribution of refugees. Yesterday we discussed the report on Serbia and Kosovo, countries in the EU waiting room. We strictly control what is happening there, we criticize compliance with the Copenhagen criteria. If the two countries do not meet, they will never be members. And that will probably be a fair punishment. However, is it still right and fair for the European Union to be judged on this, in which there are countries that no longer meet many of these criteria? And what will be their punishment? These and similar anomalies, which some calmly and even proudly indulge in, are neither democracy nor respect nor solidarity nor responsibility nor freedom but also order and justice and even less discipline. In the Socialists and Democrats, we have long ago supported the concept of building a t.i. democracy scoreboard, screen or reflection of our value indicators. I agree with the suggestions. But at the same time, I and I all know that we actually know the situation, as it has already been measured, that nothing will actually change until violators are regularly and severely punished. It's not true that we don't have mechanisms - we just don't want to use them all too often.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President. If I had read the title of today's debate, my time would be over, and seeing such a title would hardly bring citizens closer to the values ​​of the European Union. What the citizen wants to see in Poland, Hungary, Latvia, Greece is that the work of the European institutions should be understood and understood by him, so that the many European values ​​invoked do not really contradict his understanding of the values ​​of the national patriot he expects. Because in everyday life we ​​encounter flows of information that are contradictory in the human sense, which often cause confusion. So we should also rethink this review of these values ​​ourselves a little from today's understanding and much deeper before we start reforming Europe. When it comes to social cohesion, people want to compete. There can be no legislation at all times that shames many less developed Member States for engaging in social dumping.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, colleagues, Mr Timmermans, I am slightly optimistic like Mrs in 't Veld, because nationalists and populists are no longer a novelty and we are beginning to understand their vulnerabilities and the strengths of the beacon of reasonable utopia that we We build after WWII. Now, in a globalized world, in a troubled world, there is so much fog that, at times, it seems that this European lighthouse does not finish giving light. Well, it's time to make the first thing you said true: those values. And for that we have to apply them with courage, with integrity - so that citizens believe us - and with coherence between what we say and what we do. Otherwise, we will not be able to incorporate into the passion we need for Europe all those young people who are telling us that they want a future, that they want opportunities and those of us who, in recent years, have failed. We need you, we especially need young people, we need them to have jobs, equal opportunities and a passion for Europe, just like ourselves. And integrity.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Brexit was a wake-up call. The EU must reform to survive. We need a social EU based on democracy, human rights and national progressive sovereignty; but I have concerns that the powers that be are not listening. Instead we hear much talk of a multi-speed Europe, deeper integration, austerity and an EU army, and I believe that is a mistake. The last thing we need, I believe, is more integration with EU funds skewed towards military research. People do want more participation, more solidarity and more democracy, not guns and corporate bail-outs. The north of Ireland voted against Brexit, but our democratic vote has been ignored despite an international agreement, a Good Friday agreement that is lodged at the United Nations and which must be protected in all of its parts. Sinn Féin believe that Ireland, north and south, belongs in Europe, but we want a Europe of equals, a Europe that will cherish all the children of the nation equally, and where no one will be ignored. You could do yourself a great service, if many people here have not already done so, by reading and perhaps adopting the Irish Proclamation.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I would like to say to the Commissioner that you talk about a refoundation in Europe based on values anchored in effective democratic institutions which will promote a prosperous economy and a fair society. We, in the UK, will continue our journey to independence which will give us all of these. The vision of the EU is precisely the opposite. It is a vision based on opportunism, corporatism and neo-colonialism. It is anchored in institutions which are profoundly anti-democratic and which have delivered poverty, hopelessness and division in many of your constituent nations. One only has to look at the utter destruction wrought upon the economies of southern Europe. Do you think that the damage caused, such as 48% youth unemployment in Greece can be repaired by a Euro rail ticket? This is so blatantly insane. It is comparable to using a sticking plaster on a bullet wound. The only way the nations of the EU can achieve stability, growth and fairness is to follow the UK out of the European Union.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.- What European values are, the Member States and their population think very differently from Brussels.Brussels does not allow Poland to appoint critical judges, Hungary cannot stop an invasion and Slovakia cannot choose security over migration.The European Commission sees censorship as a good way to combat populism and to influence public opinion.And Brussels seems more positive about the murderous Turkey than about Great Britain now that the latter country wants to leave the EU.This cannot continue like this.It goes without saying that we need a new foundation for European cooperation.A collaboration that can only be successful if the member states regain leadership by regaining their veto and if the national parliaments are again in control.A big advantage is that the European Parliament can then be disbanded.That in turn saves half a billion in new construction costs for a Brussels palace.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, it is now necessary to convene a reform and re-establishment conference mandated by the reform of the Union and the common future of voluntarily cooperating sovereign states, with the aim of redistributing and redefining responsibilities. Until then, the decision-making process in the European Council, if no unanimity is to be provided, must be significantly strengthened on the basis of a double enhanced majority in terms of the number of Member States and the total population of the Union. In addition, as far as the Commission is concerned, the inherent democratic deficit must be addressed under the current "comitology" procedure through the participation of the relevant ministers and the publication of their positions and votes. The future Union must be functional, sustainable and democratically acceptable, not a washout of the current ineffective and opaque model. Through intergovernmental processes and taking into account the national needs of the Member States, focus on issues with a truly trans-European cross-border sign, such as climate change or preventing the movement of millions of illegal immigrants from sub-Saharan Africa and Asia to Europe.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Putin has returned to the Cold War: it poisons our public views and militarizes the border. Trump makes an unpredictable relationship unpredictable. In the face of uncertainties, populisms gained support, but were defeated: from Holland to Austria, through the firm choice of the French and even in the last British elections. It's because? As Robert Schuman, one of our founding fathers, quoted by Rosa Esterás said, Europe is about “concrete achievements”. And our Europe is more than an economic building. It is a citizenship project. Europe is the Erasmus program, whose 30 years we marked here yesterday: an entire generation that reinforced the idea of ​​its shared citizenship. Europe is the Paris Agreement, which is proof of the Union's commitment to the common future of humanity. Europe is Schengen: freedom of movement turns a patchwork of countries into a sea of ​​opportunities with hundreds of millions of people. Europe is Horizon 2020: the biggest program to support science and innovation and also the use of technology to save lives, as it does with E-call. This is the Europe I believe in: the Europe of the people, the Europe of the citizens. To defend it, we don't need refounding, but affirmation. Europe is not a choice or an alternative. Europe is our circumstance. The circumstance of our commitment to fundamental rights, peace and prosperity. A compromise that is worth debating and that is important to affirm, but, above all, that it is urgent to defend.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - President! Today, Europe seems confused, facing a number of previously unknown challenges and conflicts. Today, I think Europe, the future of us all, is at stake. After all, we must see that Europe has reached a turning point. It is the end of a Europe based on more or less homogeneous nation-states, industrial capitalism, well-divided social classes. The new industrial revolution, the fragmentation of social classes, cultural diversity, globalization have created a new world in which old answers and habits no longer help. We need to redesign, we need to re-create Europe. I believe that the new Europe must be based on progress and solidarity, freedom and security. We need to shape Europe so that there is no room for hatred, stigmatization or discrimination. We want an inclusive, open Europe, a Europe where everyone can find a home where the future is not fear but hope and chance.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: - Mr Chairman!We are politicians and we should speak in open text.What was the basis of the success of the European Coal and Steel Community and EEC?And the fact that these countries, first six, then nine, ten, twelve, fifteen, worked out a certain consensus, they agreed on a minimum and agreed and acted together - just in solidarity - but no one voted by force.Let me remind you of the famous dispute between France and the five other founders over agricultural policy, back then it was the beginning of the EEC, and finally it was decided that it would be better to act together so that no single country felt disadvantaged.Therefore, I think that the basis of the success of our joint European project will be that we will act in solidarity in the sense that it will be a consensus, and we will not vote on fundamental issues, because this is a road to nowhere, it is a sloping road.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: - Mr President! The latest EU barometer shows that there is strong support now among our citizens for EU cooperation. I am pleased that more and more people are talking well about the EU and want to see deeper and enhanced cooperation. Citizens' faith in the future, hope and inspiration is something that should be a guiding light now for us politicians in our work around this. After many fine, positive election successes, not least Macron in France, we now see how a positive, future-oriented center-right policy can grow strong. Work to develop, improve and change the Union must continue. We can not accept that we stand still. Now we must take the next step towards common contemporary solutions to the cross-border problems we see in area after area. The same study that I referred to shows that we must take joint responsibility for the migration issue, joint responsibility for the climate issue and for counter-terrorism. It is about securing the future of our citizens. We can only do that together.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: - Mr President, the Treaty establishing the European Union is based on the values ​​of freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, and its stated purpose is to promote the peace and prosperity of its peoples. In reality, however, the Union tolerates violations of the rule of law in Hungary and Poland. At the same time, the austerity policies imposed by the eurozone powers are leading to a shrinking of fundamental social rights, such as health, social security, collective bargaining, fair working conditions and family formation, especially in southern countries such as Hellas. If we want the European integration project to have a long-term perspective, we must demonstrate in practice our respect for the values ​​and goals of the Union, and we must prove it now, by changing policies before it is too late.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: - Mr President! A Europe built on values ​​is the theme of today's debate. Liability for taxpayers' money should be one of the cornerstones of this subject. We have now begun to receive signals from Parliament about the need to renovate or build something completely new in Brussels. That building was completed in 1993 at a cost of SEK 10 billion. The plenary hall of the Paul-Henri Spaak building also underwent an extensive renovation that was completed as late as 2014. This is also part, it should be remembered, of Klaus Welle's vision, which he has stated before: Making the European Parliament more like the US Congress. So is it that the condition of the building is so bad or is it a vision of the United States of Europe you want to fulfill? The estimated cost of the new construction is estimated internally to be SEK 4.3 billion. Information that leaks out at the same time indicates that there is less panic because it can end up signing a decision that in the end can turn out to be three times as expensive. Just over 13 billion Swedish kronor. Do you think this is what Europe's citizens want their tax money to be used for? Building another new palace in Brussels? That, I can promise, is the last thing they want to see their money go to, so now, for once, take a pinch of reality check. Manage tax money responsibly and stop wasting money on these insane visions. A building with 25 years on its neck, it is hardly ready to be demolished. Doing renovations and maintenance on an ongoing basis is a matter of course, but demolishing and building new is total madness and it will never be well received by the citizens of Europe.

name: Georg MAYER
text: - Mister President!European values - what exactly is that supposed to be?Who defines what European values are?Do you think we can define this here?Only the people outside in Europe can define that for themselves, and there are huge differences across Europe.And, dear colleagues, there is diversity.Appreciate this diversity instead of being afraid of it!Effective democratic institutions - yes, I can subscribe to that right away.But an effective democratic institution also requires an effective opposition.And if you've listened to my colleague in't Veld beforehand, then she's more afraid of opposition than of appreciating it.Sometimes I really get the impression here that you would all like to tell each other the same thing and applaud each other for it.Does not work like that.Do not be afraid, dear colleagues!

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - President! In her introduction, Ms In’t Veld spoke of the parties she called nationalist, claiming that there was a voice for them, a truth. Aren't you the ones for whom there is only one way for European countries? Even deeper integration? And those who want looser cooperation, are you described as anti-European, and that is the most subtle indicator? In his message, Manfred Weber, the leader of the People’s Party faction, referred to the fact that we are debating values ​​now, referring to Christian roots as the basis of values. In contrast, it is said here that diversity is needed here too. You quote the founding fathers here so many times, now I also quote two statements from Robert Schuman: 'Europe cannot be integrated by creating a common structure', which you want, and the other: 'Europe will or will not be a Christian'. This is also what Father, the founder, said, it is only you who selects among their statements.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, I am not among those who believe that we need to rebuild the European Union from the ground up. We do not need a revolution. Many of the ills attributed to the EU are either not its fault in the first place, or are exaggerated, as is the case of the famous democratic deficit issue. I can definitely say that the EU legislative process is considerably more transparent, accountable and inclusive than the one from my country. That said, there is room to be more effective, resilient and more capable of addressing citizens’ expectations. Already now, the current Treaties offer most responses to these issues, but these responses are often ignored. Considering the extent of its title, no one could call our debate unambitious.
