Allow me to insist on the ‘value’ part, as they are set out in Article 2 of the Treaty. We all know that the European Union is supposed to be founded, among other things, on the value of equality, non-discrimination and respect for diversity. Still, we have a long way to go to ensure the effective protection of these values. In the particular area of national, autochthonous or language minorities, the EU has not been able to prevent discriminative practices having a negative impact on the language and culture of persons belonging to such groups and ultimately to the intra-EU diversity we are supposed to cherish. More than 60 million citizens expect acknowledgement of their existence by the EU institutions.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: - Mister President! The EU is more than a big market. It is a political community and it is based on the values ​​of Europe that have been fought for over centuries. It is time for the EU to make the political profile more visible and presentable. And so, Mr Vice-President, it is right that we fight for these values ​​and intervene when democracy, freedom of expression or solidarity is denied. We support you when you initiate legal proceedings against member countries; it is necessary and citizens support it when some refuse while others do their job. The EU must of course help and protect, and one often had the impression that it was powerless and helpless. That applies to tax dumping, that applies to unfair competition, and that applies to cross-border crime. We have many policies that we really need to sharpen now, and I hope that the five scenarios in the White Paper will merge into a single program for the next stages of European unification at the end of the year.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: - Mister President! Rebuilding a Europe based on values, anchored in effective democratic institutions and promoting a thriving economy in a fair and cohesive society - when I read this I think of grazing unicorns and dancing elves. The very fact that we are talking here today that reconstruction should only lead to these results is an admission of failure. Important elements of the EU and the euro zone are not working; our societies are at their limit when it comes to the euro, migration and multicultural society; Breaches of law at the highest EU level are not the exception, but the rule - for example with the Dublin Treaties or the Eurosystem. Instead of pausing, many of the representatives of this EU are calling for this path that has been taken so far to be deepened - more centralization, more state economic planning, more communitisation, more authorities, more bureaucracy and paternalism; less personal responsibility, less performance orientation, less established tradition, less diversity, less creativity. Is this really the path we should be taking?

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: - Mr. president. This European Union is based on neoliberal principles, on deficit control, on the liberalization of services, with a perverse European bank, with anti-democratic institutions and, above all, it was built with a clear objective: the common market. This is not changed with four reforms, with a little makeup or with a White Paper and, even less, with the same ones that have led us to Brexit, the rise of the extreme right or that with their policies have increased inequality . The European Union of CETA, of TTIP, of the euro, of borders against migrants, of Maastricht cannot respond to the needs of the majority. But that does not mean that we want to break with Europe, rather the other way around. You want this European Union of multinationals; We want to build a Europe for the popular classes and we want to build it with the workers of Germany, France, Greece, Portugal: all together.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: - Mister President! Today's debate is called "Rebuilding a Europe built on values ​​and promoting a cohesive society". Reconstruction assumes that something has collapsed. This self-knowledge is definitely very good. We have to rebuild something. Mr Timmermans spoke of the values ​​of Europe: democracy and the rule of law. Nobody here in the house is against democracy or the rule of law. The problem is that you - exactly, now you are laughing, of course - consider those who stand up for national sovereignty to be anti-democratic and supporters of an injustice state. And that is exactly what is absurd, it is driving this country apart. And then we have to remember: democracy and the rule of law have to be filled with values ​​that stand behind them. I would remind you that the Charter of Fundamental Rights, the Constitutional Treaty and the Lisbon Treaty expressly make no reference to Europe's Christian heritage. These are the values ​​on which Europe is built. We have to become aware of this and become clear again. These are values. Democracy and the rule of law are technology; we all say yes to that. But we have to get the values ​​clear again.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the title chosen for this debate is one hundred per cent right to understand the problems we are experiencing today. First of all, the term "refoundation" is used, and it is clear that when a refoundation is requested it means that something has been destroyed. Here Europe has been destroyed by the policies imposed by the European Union. We use the term Europe and not the European Union, and it is time to make citizens understand that these are two different concepts: Europe is one thing, the European Union is another. Let's stop with this rhetoric and dismantle this "there is no alternative" rhetoric of those who want us to believe that the future of Europe can only be the European Union. Then three fundamental points are listed where the European Union has failed today: in values, because the treaties are based on completely wrong values; in guaranteeing democratic institutions, given that today most of the Union's institutions are not democratic, and the European Central Bank is an example of this; and finally in proposing a prosperous economy. It is clear that the European Union has failed in economic progress. The only way to refound Europe, in my opinion, is to abandon these treaties, which have failed, and refound Europe on egalitarian cooperation between sovereign states. This is the only way, because sooner or later the enormous conflict that exists between the social model proposed by the treaties and the social model proposed by the national constitutions will emerge. The treaties speak of competition, of the market, of profit, of commodity labor - a typical concept of the social model of the treaties which is gross German mercantilist liberalism. The Italian Constitution, for example, in the first articles, where its social model is expounded, speaks of work and job protection as a fundamental element of production. This is not happening in the European Union today. It is clear that if we want to move forward the only one the way is to dismantle this European Union because it is the culmination of two very dangerous projects: German imperialism and the discipline of markets and trade unions through the external constraint typical of the elites of peripheral countries.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I will not take the title. It is important to analyze the background. We are not honest with ourselves if we do not reconsider and reset Europe. We need to rebuild a Europe based on values, a united Europe, Commissioner. I want you to stop giving scripts and stop feeding Eurosceptics. I am pro-European and I entered politics precisely because I want everything in my country and in the European Union to be built on value. But if now, when my country has been here for ten years, it is still outside a space, we have more spaces: the Schengen area, non-Schengen, we have different rights, we citizens. Citizens need to understand that in order to be united, they also have access to the things that, the values ​​we are talking about, and I believe, Commissioner, that we need to invest more in education, so that people can understand. Political leaders are elected, and in order for citizens to be able to choose correctly, they must be educated people, have a set of values ​​to guide us when we establish our leaders. And finally, I say that both national and European leaders have a maximum responsibility now. Indeed, we would build a Europe based on values.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: - United in diversity.That is the motto of the European Union.The core of that motto is that you take each other into account, that you respect each other, that you do not make a caricature of each other, that you do not put each other away in a certain frame.Unfortunately, I see that the representatives of the ALDE group, the group that requested this debate, regularly do so.For example, if there is criticism from society of pushing for even more EU, then that criticism is often dismissed as populism, without serious consideration of whether that criticism also makes sense.Not taking that criticism seriously has partly led to Brexit.I think it's good and I need to think together about what needs to be done differently and what needs to be improved, certainly.But it is precisely from the ALDE group that I ask for understanding and respect for the views of others.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, despite the most positive news of recent times, let us have no illusions: the European project is still experiencing a serious crisis of results whose causes are well known. On the one hand, structural weaknesses in the construction of the euro and, on the other, an austerity policy that was the wrong response to the crisis. These are the root causes of the divergence that is worsening and undermining the foundations of the European project. But the crisis of the European project is essentially a crisis of values, which begins with the value of solidarity. If the value of solidarity does not hit the heart of the European ideal again, then there will be no solution to any of our problems. Citizens are telling us, in the last election, that they want to give the European project a new opportunity. For that opportunity can only be seized with a supportive response that faces our common problems and that really allows us to regain the confidence of European citizens.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! In this debate, the founding fathers return, we return to the origins of Europe, it is completely justified, and for axiological reasons and principles of integration. The Fathers of Europe felt that human rights, family rights, the common good and democracy were founded on Christian culture. Contrary to Mrs Sophia in t 'Veld, I understand Manfred Weber's entry perfectly well, it is impossible to understand European culture without a Christian identity. On the other hand, I cannot accept the treatment of religion, which has given the strength and vitality of European civilization, with shame or with its censorship. The second issue is to defend the integrity of the market - it was very much present in the thought of the founding fathers and today the enemy of market integrity is primarily protectionism, and often protectionism of rich countries represented by governments that close markets at the expense of competition and at the expense of the future of the European economy.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - President! Certain political forces in more and more parts of Europe are moving away or reinterpreting and misinterpreting our core values, such as democracy and the rule of law, while equality and solidarity are also increasingly being pushed into the background. There have been a number of elections across Europe in recent times, and without exception, we have had to squeeze every time so that extremist, anti-European forces do not emerge victorious. Fortunately, our fears did not materialize in the end, but not all Member States are so lucky. Unfortunately, Hungary is a good example of this. Waving the flag of illiberal democracy, it is moving further and further away from European values, and the lives of the Hungarian people are developing accordingly. There is a huge gap between the oligarchs of the Orbán government and the real Hungarian reality, while thanks to the growing Russian influence, the Orbán government, acting according to the Putin model, now poses a security risk. Although the EU can have some control over the situation by strictly monitoring the use of EU money, only voters can make a real difference.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am convinced that in order to think about the future of Europe we need to be very clear on the foundations of our construction. The more this construction falters, the more solid the references to our roots, which are the values ​​of democracy, peace and justice, must be. Do not think that these are archived or useless values, because democracy in Europe is all the more necessary when we have authoritarian drifts in some Member States. Peace is necessary when we see conflict outside the Union, with peaks of conflict within it as well. And social justice is all the more necessary when we see that, especially in recent years, the inequalities and difficulties of many parts of the population have increased. So they are foundations that, if they have guaranteed a successful integration, they must be strengthened in the face of a crisis situation like the one we have. In the White Paper Juncker puts us before some hypotheses, but I think that we cannot choose which Europe, perhaps in one Member State one type of Europe and in another another Europe. We don't have five alternatives, we have two: either win together or lose separately.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, just a few reflections on the basis of what I have heard in the debate. As a teenager, I went to Spain. It was coming out of dictatorship, and as a young man coming from the Netherlands I was shocked to see the abject poverty in Spanish rural areas. Not just the poverty in economic terms; also the poverty in moral terms. Domestic violence was endemic. Children did not go to school, or very badly to school. Girls especially were not even encouraged to go to school. Then look at Spain today. Look at what has been achieved. Surely I am not claiming this for the European Union – it was the Spanish people who did that. But they could not have done that, I believe, in this measure without becoming members of the family of free European nations in the European Union. As a soldier, I was trained to fight the Eastern bloc. In 1989 the Wall came down, which is without any doubt the most important political event in my lifetime. At that time, Poland was in worse economic shape than Ukraine. Look at Poland today where it is. I think the economy is five or six times bigger than the Ukrainian economy. Surely I do not claim that as a result of the European Union – it is the Polish people who did that. But I am sure the European Union helped in achieving that, especially in terms of the rule of law. It is not just about the economy: it is about the independence of courts. It is about the predictability of jurisdiction, it is about the fight against corruption. So if people today say the European Union is just a big shambles and a mess, they must have been blind over the last 40 years. Let us not lose track of our historic achievements; that would be my first point. And if you know what we can achieve coming out of this crisis, where the number of jobs in Europe now is higher than ever before – I know we still have many things to overcome – but let us have a bit more self-confidence that we can overcome this. Look at what our parents and grandparents overcame. We can do so much better and so much more. We should not talk ourselves down in this. And let me stress this one thing. The values the European Union is based upon, enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty, have been signed and ratified by every single nation member of the EU, and yes, there are cultural differences and all sorts of differences. But Article 2 is binding on every single Member State and every single actor in that Member State, and you cannot get rid of that responsibility simply by arguing along cultural lines. I believe the reason why we talk about re-foundation today is because we have understood that our Union is not unbreakable. As long as you think it cannot be broken anyway, you do not care so much about fundamental values – they will be all right. But now that we see that our fundamental values are under threat, under fire, we know that we have to stand up for them and speak up for them more than ever before. I just want to say one thing about the Christian foundations of Europe, and I say this as a Christian. Yes, of course, Christianity has a huge role in how we developed our values, but I would feel very uncomfortable as a Christian, if another Christian claimed the copyrights on European values as exclusively Christian. We would not be here without the humanists, we would not be here without the Enlightenment. It was my own church that needed to be enlightened. The Spanish Inquisition was not invented by atheists, so let us all take responsibility for what we contributed. But let us respect the diversity and the fact that the sources of our values are manifold and cannot be claimed only by one denomination or one political vision.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I thank the honourable Members for their valuable comments, of which obviously I have taken good note, and you can rest assured that reflection on the future of Europe will continue to be one of our top priorities. In exploring avenues for the EU to take in the future, we should perhaps bear in mind two things: one, that the EU cannot swiftly resolve all problems as if by magic; and two, that we have to balance our ideas with some practical constraints. These may sometimes limit us in our ambitions. So we need to be realistic about what we can and what we cannot do.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: That closes the debate.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - The need for reform of the European Union is obvious. We are all aware of this. I believe that the current model of governing Europe is wrong. If we want Europe to prosper, to be strong, then we must understand that the way to create a federal union is a mistake. The citizens of Europe show that they want change. In my opinion, the reform of Europe must be in the direction of stronger national parliaments, stronger national institutions. European citizens have shown ambiguously that they want less European bureaucracy, easier business regimes, tax competition between Member States. In my opinion, Europe must abandon the application of a common approach, because each country is different in structure, has different norms and established order. We see that there is a clear division between Germany and France, on the one hand, and the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, on the other. This division is caused by double standards and the hypocrisy of Western politicians. Europe must return to the original model of an alliance between sovereign states cooperating in a common market.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. - Today's debate has as its object the re-foundation of a Europe based on values. Well, when it comes to values, in this context, I believe that we cannot help but think of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which I believe is at the basis of the very existence of the European Union. Beyond the many beautiful and shareable declarations of intent, expressed by Parliament for the protection of fundamental rights, almost everywhere in the world, for some years we have been witnessing cases of mortification, if not systematic violation, of principles enshrined in the Charter , in some Member States. Unfortunately, however, the complaints raised several times by Parliament - I would like to recall the only fully democratic institution of the Union, as it is directly elected by the citizens - were not followed by adequate actions by the other institutions. To date, art. 7 of the Treaty has never been activated and it is not possible to understand what alternative measures may be to prevent violations of fundamental rights within the EU. From this point of view, therefore, I cannot share the optimism towards this Europe, too often stuck in an impasse, of a Council in which the selfishness of national interests seems to prevail.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – Soulsearching about European values has become a prevalent mood because, since 2008, certain basic tenets about what the EU stood for, and on which its soft power rested, have been downgraded. Among these was the belief that Europe stood for a social market system that would promote the free market while guaranteeing social rights, in the context of economic stability or growth. Today, when stability or growth are lacking or threatened, in order to reacquire competitivity and growth under existing structures of European integration, the only way out is to restrain social conditions. There has emerged a contradiction between the social rights that the EU proclaims, and the options available to it to achieve desired outcomes. Indeed, it has become questionable whether the three objectives that are fundamental to the European Union as of now, can be kept all three of them together: free market policies under conditions of increasing globalisation and oligopolisation; an ongoing commitment to further European integration; and a total commitment to safeguard and enhance existing social rights in Europe. Before this dilemma is satisfactorily addressed, a sentiment of angst about the real import of European values will prevail.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - Refound Europe, yes, but we cannot allow words to be played. You are not about to refound anything. What they propose, every other day as well, is to continue to deepen this neoliberal and insoluble European Union; with austerity policies, unemployment, impoverishment and precariousness of the working classes and the whole of the popular classes are increasing. The re-foundation of a Europe based on values ​​and based on democratic institutions means building a new Europe, starting by respecting peoples' right to decide, putting human rights before the interests of the "free market" and capital and abandoning the agenda neoliberal. For that, they must withdraw the proposals contained in the document of the "Five presidents", among them the one to move towards the Economic and Monetary Union. They must also put an end to the Defense Union projects, which will use billions of euros from the budgets of both the European Union and the States, to advance in the construction of a military apparatus to continue to impose by force the interests of this Neoliberal European Union and to the detriment of employment policies, social policies and maintenance of public services.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- The European Union has been facing unprecedented pressure from Russia over the last three years and is struggling with a migration crisis.In addition, we are witnessing the emergence of various anti-European movements, which are widely supported by so-called alternative media.The result is a decline in confidence not only in the common European project, but also in the state and its institutions.We can only restore this trust by a policy that is based on our natural values and solves the real problems of citizens.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: signed up. - In the current context, values ​​are the key to re-founding the Union, which is facing a loss of identity and community, with high social, economic, cultural, security and safety risks, with uncertainty and insecurity. We must not forget that the European Union is not just a political union, but, above all, a cultural and identity one (unity in diversity). EU values ​​are currently threatened by those who do not understand them and by those who fear them. The future of the EU depends on placing the values ​​of the Union at the heart of all European policies, actions and measures. Anchoring in democratic, efficient and effective institutions means that all European or global issues are addressed from a European perspective, a democratic perspective, the rule of law, prosperous and fair. Thus, terrorism, migration, economic, food and social insecurity can be solved. But the values ​​on which the EU is founded, in accordance with Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union (TEU), namely respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities, they must be constantly promoted, protected and supported, especially among young people.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the follow-up to the Panama Papers and the rule of law in Malta (2017/2694 (RSP)).

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, (inaudible few words) Presidency of the Council. As you know, the fight against tax evasion, fraud and avoidance is a common EU goal that has been constantly highlighted by the European Parliament, the European Council, the Council and the Commission. Our Presidency has placed this issue amongst our top priorities for the Council’s agenda. To summarise our achievements in a nutshell, let me mention the following: the Council has completed work on Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive 2, as well as on defining criteria to establish a list of non-cooperative jurisdictions. Agreement has also been reached on double taxation dispute resolution mechanisms. All these lost years represent important cornerstones of EU action in the area of fighting tax evasion, fraud and avoidance. Going into more detail as regards the particular pieces of legislation, let me stress that Anti-Tax Avoidance Directives 1 and 2 provide for a comprehensive framework of anti-abuse measures aimed at ensuring that taxation will occur where value is created. As a result, the anti-base erosion and profit-shifting measures which have also been given an impulse by the G20 and the OECD are now translated in the EU into a binding instrument. In several aspects the Council went even further than the basic OECD recommendations. Furthermore, the work of the Code of Conduct Group on business taxation is continuing at considerable pace. One of its current main tasks is to finalise the process of establishing the EU list of non-cooperative jurisdictions for tax purposes. We also reached an agreement last month on the directive on double taxation dispute resolution mechanisms, which will considerably enhanced tax certainty by making alternative dispute resolution mechanisms binding, faster and more efficient. Finally, transparency and exchange of information have also been considerably improved. Within just one year the Council revised the Directive on Administrative Cooperation twice. These revisions are aimed to ensure the obligation for multinational companies to report key tax information on the amount of revenue, on profit before income tax and on income tax paid in each country where they do business. They also now allow tax authorities to access the information in relation to money laundering. I thank you very much for your attention.

name: Joseph MUSCAT
text: Prime Minister of Malta. – Mr President, I would like to start by expressing my government’s solidarity with the British people on this morning’s fire and also our solidarity with our American colleagues following the shootings in Virginia just some time ago. Thank you for being so kind to invite me over to this debate. I will structure my intervention two-fold: I will start by, at the start of this debate, making some points on the progress on the rule of law which has been achieved in Malta over the past few years, then I will be looking forward into devoting most of the time later on into answering questions that colleagues will be putting over. Let me refer to a few points on the rule of law at the beginning of this debate. To brief you on the improvements that have been made in my country over the past few years, one of the first bills which we presented as a government was that which removed the time-barring that existed on acts of corruption by politicians and those holding public office. We were the first government in Malta that introduced such legislation, which will hold all politicians and public officers to account, not only today but throughout our whole life-time, should any shred of evidence crop up linking any politician – past, present or future – to acts of corruption. As such, no politician will be able to escape the long arm of justice throughout their life-time. I believe that is a unique piece of legislation at EU level. Another piece of legislation we put forward and enacted was the Whistleblowers Protection Act. This has been deemed by a number of Members of this House, like Benedek Jávor and Julia Reda – champions in the fight to protect whistleblowers – as a benchmark for other European Union Member States and a good basis for a future European whistleblowers directive. Since the law came into force in 2013, we had no less than 29 reports that have been lodged under the protection of the Maltese Whistleblowers Act. Also, after years of damning reports by the Council of Europe’s Group of States against Corruption (Greco) putting Malta on the blacklist of political party financing, we introduced an act regulating party financing, which was not only important but necessary and in our national interest. Our law was introduced in 2015 and led Greco to certify that Malta shifted from a country contravening the institution’s recommendations on fighting corruption to one of those in line with its main recommendations. In 2016 we also change the method of appointment of members of the judiciary, becoming the first government to forgo such powers. The executive is now bound to make appointments to the bench from a pool of lawyers that have been previously approved by a judicial appointments committee, rather than having government appoint magistrates and judges directly, without the need of any prior consultation. The judicial appointments committee is made of eminent persons, including the Chief Justice, the Attorney General and the President of the Chamber of Advocates, amongst others. Mr President, we did all this in just four years, but we intend to do even more. In fact, one of our pledges over the next five years is that of discussing the removal of any parliamentary immunity in Malta, introducing a transparency register at national level – following our work as presidency – to introduce a European Transparency Register, and the introduction of a new code of conduct for all those holding public office. As I said in the beginning, I am not going to make a long introductory speech; I am interested in listening to the criticism and the points raised by the Members of this House – my former colleagues – and then I will answer accordingly.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: member of the Commission. - Mr President, Madam President of the Council, Mr Prime Minister, Ladies and Gentlemen, Members of Parliament, a year ago, the "Panama Papers" were added to the previous scandals and confirmed the existence of a system of global offshore tax evasion. These revelations have rightly aroused public outrage and political condemnation. At the time, the Commission and I made a promise to you, which was to use the momentum created by these revelations to curb tax evasion. I kept my word, the Commission kept my word, the Council accompanied us. President Juncker pointed out to you two weeks ago that we have made unprecedented progress on this front in record time. We did it with your constant, demanding support, and so these successes are also yours. Recent revelations concerning tax systems in several Member States only confirm the absolute necessity of the action that we have taken and that we continue to take so that taxation in the European Union and in the world be more transparent, fairer, more efficient. The landscape that emerges today after two years of tax activism is fundamentally reshaped. Automatic cooperation between Member States on tax rulings and on multinational companies' tax information is now the rule. Banking secrecy has disappeared in Europe, including among our neighbors outside the European Union. We have created a safety net against tax evasion with the adoption of directives on the fight against tax evasion (ATAD 1 and ATAD 2). We now have binding measures to tackle the most common forms of aggressive tax planning and optimization, as well as a new external strategy to ensure that good tax governance is also respected beyond our single market. The road traveled, you see, is absolutely considerable. In the space of just one year, we have proposed strengthening the rules on the fight against money laundering, relaunched the project for a common consolidated corporate tax base, obtained the Council's agreement on tax dispute settlement procedures - thanks to the Maltese Presidency -, and launched the process to create a European list of tax havens - we have also worked well with Finance Minister Edward Scicluna on this. The transparency of information on beneficial owners is a crucial priority in the fight against money laundering, corruption and tax evasion. We have proposed to improve access to information on beneficial owners in Europe and we are pushing this priority internationally. With your indispensable support, Europe should also soon have a mechanism for publishing information country by country, with the idea that multinationals would make public their activities, their earnings and the taxes paid country by country, in Europe. Ladies and Gentlemen, Madam President of the Council, Prime Minister, this progress must now be consolidated and deepened. It's time to take the next step: what is it? First, I will propose to strengthen our means of defense against tax abuses: this will be the subject of my proposal on intermediaries, which I know is eagerly awaited by this assembly. Some of these intermediaries, banks, lawyers, counsels, consultants - it is not a question of accusing these professions -, in part of their activities, encourage abuses, profit from them or facilitate them. . The “Panama Papers” highlighted the central role of tax optimization. The PANA committee, which works here in the European Parliament in a remarkable, also emphasizes this point. Reducing tax evasion means shedding light on this sector. My proposal will be based on simple principles - transparency, cooperation, exchange of information - which we have mobilized in our previous proposals. You know them well now. With this initiative, cross-border tax optimization arrangements will need to be made known to member states well before they can affect their tax revenues, and thus tax administrations will be in a position to detect or block any possible abuse. On the other hand, although this is not the case for Malta, many recent scandals in tax evasion and other areas have been exposed thanks to the courage of whistleblowers. They endangered their careers, their way of life, their freedom sometimes. They must be protected. The Commission is studying possible courses of action for an initiative in this area. I know the European Parliament wants it. The second initiative I will take will tackle VAT fraud: it is a major issue. This fraud represents, for cross-border VAT, 50 billion euros of losses per year for our public treasuries. The task is not over, we have made efforts over the past two years. This Parliament is fully aware of this. A recent study by the PANA commission reveals that Europol has identified 388 files in the "Panama Papers" which are linked to VAT fraud operations. We are talking here about massive fraud, carried moreover by criminal networks and perhaps used to finance terrorism. Today, VAT fraud, so to speak, is a piece of cake, it's called carousel fraud. The flaws in the VAT system combined with the disconcerting ease of draining funds diverted to bank accounts outside the European Union make this tax resource extremely vulnerable to fraud, and this is particularly the case, as I have said, for cross-border transactions. The solution that we are going to propose is to move towards a definitive VAT regime, leaving intra-European Union transactions to be treated exactly like national transactions in the Member State of destination through a one-stop shop, which will drastically reduce cross-border fraud but also simplify VAT obligations for companies, because, of course, it is a simplification measure that allows companies to work more efficiently. In this context, I would also like to inform you that important actions are in preparation to fight against VAT fraud, therefore in the field of European criminal justice, after the finalization of the new directive on offenses against financial interests of the European Union, which also criminalizes VAT fraud. On June 8, we reached a political agreement in the Council on the creation - and this is a major one - of the European Public Prosecutor's Office in enhanced cooperation, supported by 20 Member States and which others may join later. I hope that I can once again count on the full support of the European Parliament for this initiative. I used to say that we are really on the same camp in this fight, which I know to be very broadly cross-partisan and shared on all the benches of this assembly. Indeed, these initiatives complement the instruments that we have put in place together over the past two years to curb tax fraud and tax evasion, which remains a shared objective. This will help ensure that the Union and its Member States continue to be at the forefront of this battle for fairer taxation, which is a global battle fought within the framework of the G20 and the OECD. Finally - and I will end there - it is important that the justice can do its work with confidence and independence, and you will therefore understand that I cannot comment on the investigations in progress, which are the responsibility of the justice system.This, Ladies and Gentlemen, Members, Mr President, Mr Prime Minister, Madam President of the Council, is what I wanted to tell you about our ever renewed fight against abuses of all kinds in tax matters.I thank Parliament once again for its support, which is essential to us at all times in this very difficult, but very important dossier.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I welcome you, Prime Minister Muscat, and first of all as a democrat I want to congratulate you on your re-election. There was strong, tough, democratic competition in Malta, you won, and I wish you all the best in the interest of the country and in the interest of our European Union. In the interest of the European Union you showed that you are from time to time ready for change, ready to rethink your own position. I bring to our mind again that you were not previously in favour of Malta becoming a member of the European Union. Today you know that membership is important for Malta and contributes to the interests of Malta. Malta is benefiting from this and today it is obvious that this is a success story. This example shows that you are ready to rethink your position from time to time. But in today’s debate, whose subject is the Panama papers linked to Malta, the question is not so much what we are doing against fraud and what we are doing for the rule of law; the most important question is: why is there still a minister in your cabinet, the only minister in the European Union, who is named on the Panama list? That is the substance of the debate today. That is what we want to ask you, because we have a lot of discussion points where can really work together for the future of Europe, but that is the substance of the debate. You won the election, but the questions are still on the table and what we ask from you, in your capacity as today’s President of the European Council, as the presidency of the Council of the European Union, is clarification of this open question.  You said a lot about what you did on paper on legislation to guarantee the rule of law in Malta. I was hoping that you would come back today to Strasbourg to the European Parliament and could show us what the result of this legislation is, what are you doing to create really strong and independent structures, and what the outcome of this is. Legislation, what is on paper, is one thing, but implementation is something else. What does this mean in reality? What is the outcome of these activities? I did not think that you showed a real readiness to give us an opening, an inside look into what is happening in your party, in your government. I would ask you to do so. I think that is a chance for you, in your second approach here in the Parliament, to clarify these points. Democracy means that people must have full trust in their institutions. That is the base for democracy, and that is what we fight for.  (Applause from the PPE Group)

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would first of all like to congratulate Prime Minister Muscat on his victory in the election, which was very impressive indeed.  The Panama Papers have given rise to a number of scandals in EU countries. Some are open-and-shut cases, while others are merely hearsay and conjecture. In a democratic society built on the rule of law there is only one response to such allegations: where there are allegations, there must be investigation and, where there is investigation, there must be a conclusion, a judgement and a ruling. In the specific case of Malta, so far only two of these are present: the accusations and the formal investigation, which is well underway.  This being the case, the plenary chamber of the European Parliament is not the proper forum to deal with these accusations. I ask my honourable colleagues whether they really question the very foundation of democracy in Malta, a Member State that has recently achieved a 92% voter turnout and is a sound democracy. As a co-rapporteur of the PANA Committee, I am perhaps the keenest to get to the bottom of all cases linked to the Panama Papers and I will insist on having facts, not merely accusations. I refuse to be drawn in to questioning a fundamental societal pillar, the rule of law in Malta, even before the ongoing formal investigation is completed. However, I do seriously question if the EU as a whole is capable of responding effectively to the revelations of the Panama Papers. Vital EU anti—tax evasion measures continue to be held up in the Council. If we are to make any positive difference at all in the fight against tax fraud, tax evasion and tax havens, we must channel all of our efforts into building European solutions. As such, I ask the Members of this Parliament who take the floor whether they are ready to reform the Code of Conduct Group to ensure public scrutiny. Can you help to bring your own governments to responsibility for the actions taken by this group? I think this is very important. We also need to do more at a European level. Together with my former co—rapporteur, Michael Theurer, in the TAXE 2 report, I ask for the Union Tax Policy Coherence and Coordination Centre to strengthen our fight against tax evasion and tax fraud in the EU. We also want to see a Tax Europol that can bridge the gap between national authorities in these highly complex international tax cases.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! Indeed, we have many questions about the allegations that are being made against Malta and the Maltese government. But there are also questions that we need to address to the European Parliament, such as why this debate is taking place now after the elections. The Panama Committee suggested that the Prime Minister of Malta should be invited before the elections. And what could be more democratic than giving the people, who express their political opinion in elections, the opportunity to also take note of the facts, to question the Maltese government before the people form a judgment? The question should be put to the Conference of Presidents: why was this proposal by the Panama Committee not followed up? Why, in my opinion, have we violated elementary democratic principles by only debating now after the elections have taken place? I think the example of democracy that we have given here is not a good one, and we should perhaps touch our noses in a self-critical manner.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I do not mean to import Maltese internal politics here but I was a member of the former Touch 1 and Touch 2 committees, now I am a co-rapporteur on the PANA Committee and therefore I have some issues to raise. The PANA Committee had a mission to Malta and many intermediaries named in the Panama papers are based in Malta; and also their possible ties to politically exposed persons there are very worrying. On the face of it, it seems EU law has somehow been implemented but its enforcement, strong and independent institutions including the Financial Intelligence Unit, and more generally the rule of law, are questionable.  In Brussels it seems Malta is fighting EU efforts to move towards more transparency, be it within the anti-money laundering directive, country by country reporting, or a common consolidated corporate tax base. This cannot imply anything other than it has a lot to hide.  It has nothing to do with the size of the country, but I am glad that the EU was reformed in the way that it now has a permanent president of the European Council. I am afraid that if you, Prime Minister, presided over the European Council now it would weaken the standing of the European Union.

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mister President! The government of Malta, and with it the current EU presidency, is regrettably associated with criminal energy. Cabinet members appear in the Panama Papers, EU visas are being hawked to Chinese business people, and the discount system allows companies to lower tax rates to five percent of profits. In my hometown of Hamburg, cruise ships even use the Maltese flag and German tax law to reduce taxes to zero. Malta is a paradise for money laundering by the Italian Mafia. Without diplomatic clichés: there is blood on the money that protects Malta. Nevertheless, the Maltese have confirmed the social democratic government. Not surprising; there was no realistic alternative - the conservatives in Malta also have their register of sins. Pointing the finger at Malta during the election campaign, but giving way to tax tricks and money laundering in Brussels, would be too cheap - for example conservatives and liberals, who recently used exemptions for country-by-country reporting to prevent corporations from gaps about profits and payments Taxes have to report country by country. The EU must deliver now, also against Malta. The Council and the Commission must work with us to close loopholes in the money laundering directive, for example for bogus directors of letterbox companies. The black list of tax havens must also be expanded to include EU countries such as Malta. We need withholding taxes for uncooperative states. Europe needs credibility, not bad deals with the tax mafia. And I would like to ask you, Mr Muscat: will you work to ensure that we come to the majority principle in the code-of-conduct group? And will you appear before the Panama Paper Committee of Inquiry, of which I am vice-chair? You received an invitation from the chairman. Will you make up for that?

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all, our group asked for this debate because we are seriously concerned with the state of the rule of law in Malta. We have found that the Financial Intelligence Unit has investigated several cases of serious wrong-doing in the field of money laundering, as well as in the field of bank licensing and doubtful procedures in banks. These have unfortunately not led to the opening of prosecution processes. These three known reports of the Financial Intelligence Unit have leaked to the media, but still prosecution processes seem not to be on the way and therefore, we call on the Police Commissioner to immediately open respective prosecution procedures. Secondly, for the financial institutions involved, there should be consequences. There is a financial supervisor and there is something peculiar in Malta because the head of the financial supervisor MFSA, Joseph Bannister, is at the same time the Vice President of Malta Finance. There is a strong conflict of interest between the role of supervisor and that of the Development Authority which brings financial investment to Malta. We think the supervisor should take action against Pilatus bank and next year BT, to look at their licenses after the findings in the Panama Papers as well as in the reports of the FIU.  Furthermore, we believe that the key persons who were involved in the Panama Papers, including Mr Schembri as well as Brian Tonna and Kazimi as well as Mr Zammit who was found in the Swiss Leagues, should appear before the Panama Papers committee; so far they have failed to do so. Reuters and Der Spiegel have revealed lax supervision in the online gaming sector. Lastly, it is imperative that a thorough investigation be started. We have written today to the Commission to start investigations regarding Treaty violation procedures concerning money laundering legislation and bank licensing practices. It is high time for Malta to defend its reputation. Your island needs to be based on the thorough rule of law; and you can do it, you have in your hands to really reveal to the public the truth about all these things and have fair and tough investigations. These are not replaced by elections.

name: David COBURN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, until the end of June, Malta holds the incumbent Presidency of the Council of the European Union. For many politicians, it seems to be a good moment to attack this small republic. This debate is linked to the Panama Papers committee working on tax avoidance, tax evasion and money laundering. The Maltese financial services sector has come under increasing pressure from abroad, especially after the reappointment of Keith Schembri and Konrad Mizzi in the Maltese Government – both of them appear in the Panama papers. Nevertheless, it is not the European Parliament that should interfere in the investigation of a sovereign nation state. Many MEPs in this House are exploiting this debate to push forward their agenda to ban economic competition between countries. By using outdated buzz words like ‘fair tax competition’ and talking about a ‘level playing field’, these EU federalists are trying to cover up their real aspirations – creating a big supranational taxation union. This debate shows to the people of the UK why it is so important for Britain to leave the EU by way of a hard Brexit, which means no membership of the single market, no membership of a political union, and no membership of this socialist taxation union.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, the High Presidency! 5% economic growth, 4.7% unemployment and a national debt of 58.3% last year - this has made Malta one of the top performers in the European Union, and that will probably be one of the reasons why you, Prime Minister, were confirmed again by the voters. I congratulate you on this. The Panama Papers, however, threw a spotlight on the financial center of Malta, and the Malta files round off this spotlight. However, Malta's good macroeconomic performance is primarily based on income from financial services. This also includes the considerable tax advantages that result, for example, from the six-seventh rule on the refund of profit taxes. Malta is commonly referred to as a tax haven, although Malta is neither on the blacklist of the OECD nor the FATF. The Panama Committee of Inquiry was in Malta and found that the investigation of tax evasion and money laundering is being hindered. However, during the presidency you have done a very good job on combating tax evasion, in particular on increasing transparency, and you have succeeded in signing the OECD agreement to combat tax loopholes, the BEPS agreement. Thank you for that. This is a good step and a step in the right direction.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Prime Minister, corruption is a major scourge of the European Union and, of course, it is not just about Malta. In this case, we actually have the names of two Maltese government officials in the famous "Panama papers". Initially, this proves nothing more than a possible tax evasion. Indeed, I consider it necessary for justice in Malta to investigate the case and, if it turns out to be illegal, to punish those responsible. But this is not the case of the European Parliament, which is unable to represent the judge. Especially, since many suspicions and suspicions about the management of finances concern its members. In addition, let us keep in mind that the people of Malta have re-elected the same government with a significant majority. The people are not represented by the various incited and uncontrolled Non-Governmental Organizations or the so-called civil society, but on the contrary, the people express themselves in elections. Finally, in a European Union headed by the former Prime Minister of Luxembourg, it is better not to blame others for tax evasion.

name: David CASA
text: - Aktar minn sena ilu, permezz tal-Panama Papers, inkixfu pjanijiet ta 'correlation fuq scala kbira uħasil ta' flus min-nies li jokkupaw karigi għolja fil-Gvern Malt. In Malta, Malta has a number of investment criminals. The Prime Minister of the Kingdom of Malta shall act as a millet, and shall not be affected. Imma l-vot tal-ġimgħa li għaddiet ma jaħfirx id-dnubiet tal-politikii recurrence. It will come to the attention of the Minister of Justice at the same time. Fil-kabinett tiegħu reġa 'appunta nies korotti u li jaħslu l-flus. Issa l-Prim Ministru għandu għażla: jew li jibqa 'mniżæel fl-istorja bħala l-Prim Ministru korrott ta' Malta, jew jista 'jagajæel li jirranġa t-taħwid. Jekk jagħżel dan, jien ser inkun hemm biex ngħinu. It is considered that Malta has a reputation. This is the case with financial support. The Prime Minister, the lil ħadd jattakka, pereempempju, il-whistleblower tal-FIAU. This is the case when the nitric acid is used as an opportunity. Jien inħobb lil Malta. In the case of Malta, the goods shall not be subject to any corrosion. If more than one country in Malta and the other country in Malta are present, they shall bear the right to enter into force. In the case of ministers, the Member States concerned have the right to apply this Regulation. Użaha. Ara fiex ġibt lil pajjiżna. In the case of ministers, there is a long-term correlation, but it is not very common.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Mr President, Members of this Parliament wishing to criticise the Maltese Government might say it has adopted policies with which they disagree. Yet under Dr Muscat’s administration, the Maltese economy has reached unprecedented growth rates, at the top of the EU league. It is delivering prosperity to all segments of the Maltese population; reforms have been implemented very quickly on social liberalisation, on LGBT rights, on access to education, on the reduction of poverty. Progress has been rapid. The government has declared it will correct any mistakes made. Critics of the Maltese administration have no basis to claim that the rule of law is being undermined. That rule is as alive and well in Malta as anywhere else in the EU. Currently, four magisterial inquiries are investigating allegations of improprieties in public management. They are proceeding in total independence, in accordance with the rule of law. The Maltese Prime Ministers has committed to respect their conclusions. Some might dislike the fact that Malta is excelling in financial services, yet the sector operates in full conformity with EU and OECD rules. Individual cases are being wrongly generalised by people in this Parliament. The grounds for this debate are non-existent. If they are given credence, future statements we might make about the rule of law anywhere will risk becoming undermined and devalued.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: blue-card question. – Mr Sant, over a year ago you expressed your view that Minister Mizzi should resign. How do you feel about the fact that he has been reinstated after the Maltese elections?

name: Alfred SANT
text: blue-card answer. – (inaudible) for a prime minister to respect the verdict of the people. I note that this has been done in this case as well.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: - (FI) Mr President, when a small number of researchers and civic activists spoke of tax havens, illegal tax evasion and legal but questionable tax evasion a decade ago, it was stigmatized directly as a sham. Today, no one thinks so, and that’s great. The greatest value of bodies such as the PANA Committee of Inquiry lies in the fact that they urge both the EU Commission and the Member States to improve their functioning and take more ambitious initiatives. In the PANA and TAXE committees, we have examined numerous finance ministers, other politicians and representatives of international organizations and companies, including Malta. The developments that have taken place are an example of how the world can be changed by involving the right people, adequate resources and a strong will for change. This work must also be supported in the future at all levels. I hope that the projects launched will be able to be monitored and evaluated. The work of the media, researchers and NGOs is also very valuable here.

name: Michael THEURER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Prime Minister! The TAXE reports have clearly shown that it has been known for many years where tax loopholes come from: through the combination of overly complex national tax systems. They couldn't be closed. The finance ministers and the heads of government have known about this problem for many years, but they could not come to an agreement. With Panama it is now coming to light that this may have a completely different reason: namely, because representatives of show business, also top-class athletes and, in some cases, politicians are involved in these deals. In any case, the suspicion is in the room, and therefore it does not matter what is in these Panama Papers. That is why we want to clarify this here as Parliament, because we are passing laws against tax avoidance and tax evasion and, above all, against money laundering - that is EU law. And then you get the impression that they are not being implemented. Then what does the Commission do? Well, it is addressed to the national governments. But if ministers then appear in the Panama Papers, then there is public suspicion that the government is not acting because some of the parties involved can benefit from it themselves. That is a terrible situation - it has to be cleaned up! It is as if the Beagle Boys, the tank crackers, were basically tasked with protecting against burglars. Therefore, the citizens have a right to know: Are members of the government in Malta actually affected? When will there finally be an independent investigation? Is the rule of law enforced here when the names are mentioned? What if even the Prime Minister's wife is named here in public as the last authorized person? Then it must be ensured here that either it is shown that there is nothing to the allegations - then it is it cleared up - or the rule of law must be brought into effect accordingly.And the Commission, Mr President, is called upon here, because otherwise it will become an accomplice.(The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mister President!No, I have a question for colleague Theurer.It has to do with the European Public Prosecutor.Is it true - I am now asking that as a member of the committee of inquiry - that Malta has not submitted to the European Public Prosecutor, and how do you assess that?Why is it apparently not possible for the Maltese government or why is it unwilling to provide assistance to the authorities in places where the financial interests of the European Union are being violated?Is this a serious problem and if so, what should be done?

name: Michael THEURER
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Lambsdorff!The European Parliament has been calling for a European Public Prosecutor to be set up for many years so that fraud on the part of the European Union can also be punished across borders in the Member States.There is now a first step towards closer cooperation from some Member States.According to the information available to me, Malta has not yet agreed to support the European Public Prosecutor's Office and to introduce it as well.But here the Prime Minister would have to explain why Malta does not support this European Public Prosecutor, whom the European Parliament has been calling for for many years.

name: Eva JOLY
text: - Mr President, Mr Prime Minister of Malta, you believe that you have responded to accusations of corruption hanging over those around you by calling early elections in your country. But a re-election does not remove suspicion. Only a serious investigation by the prosecuting authority can. Do you commit yourself here to guaranteeing genuine independent police investigations? Likewise, hiding behind membership of the European Union to disprove the fact that Malta can be a tax haven is not a serious answer. How then to qualify a country which loses 2 billion euros in tax revenue each year to other Member States, according to the revelations of the "Malta Files"? As long as the Member States are not taken into account in the European blacklist of tax havens, no, Mr. Muscat, being part of the European Union will not be enough to rule out the qualification of tax haven. It is time for our governments to realize the damage caused by these tax practices. The French Minister of the Economy, Bruno Le Maire, did not seem to have taken the measure either, since he considered it completely legal that Renault and PSA evade 119 million euros in taxes by installing subsidiaries in Malta. No, what some people call tax optimization is actually tax evasion through transfer pricing abuse, and therefore fraudulent.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President Muscat, I will list two or three topics that emerge from the Malta Papers: the trafficking of the 'Ndrangheta, of the Calabrian mafia, emerge the names of the biggest characters of the San Luca clan, protagonist of the traffic world of cocaine, arms trafficking emerges, a personage like Mohsen Rezaian emerges, a figure of international importance in arms trafficking, among other things affiliated with Hezbollah, with two companies, America Holding and Serafiner Trading, both of Maltese. They are not generic words. The newspapers talk about Valletta today - a city and a country that I have come to love in this semester - as a second Tripoli. This is an indictment, it is a shame, at the center of all the trafficking of arms and anything else between Italy and Libya, the worst there is. You are involved and you did not miss even the trafficking of NGOs that favor the trafficking of illegal immigrants, as recently reported even by the Libyan guard. And you come to talk generically about commitments? You should have come here and told us what you are doing against these realities, not these generic accusations, these realities, documented with names and surnames, which emerged from the investigation of these ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, the Panama Papers have given rise to many scandals and corruption, and it is quite right that we create laws to prevent such waste and deal with those scandals. So why doesn’t the Commission deal with the biggest scandals of all: the waste of the European Union of the taxpayers of Europe? Take, for example, the Parliament building in Brussels, built in 1993 for EUR 1 billion, and now we are told today that it’s potentially about to fall down and needs rebuilding for EUR 393 billion. Or the new Wilfried Martens building built for EUR 125 million – 15% more than ordinary buildings of the type would have been built. The European house of history: EUR 60 million. The parliamentary building: EUR 422 million. And now we have our own MEPs’ cocktail bar for EUR 1.9 million as well – there is the scandal, ladies and gentlemen. Thank goodness we in Britain are going to leave the European Union, so that we don’t have to deal with those costs and waste anymore.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: - Mister President! Prime Minister, you said the progress you have made in the rule of law over the past four years. What use are these advances on paper if the democratic self-cleaning process does not work in your government, if you have reappointed Mr Mizzi as minister without drawing the conclusions, without an investigation? Then I can only say: I am sorry - you, as a former colleague, are also responsible for the fact that Parliament, the committee of inquiry - I am excluding the Minister of Finance, but by the others whose names have emerged - have been extremely ignored . We did not receive an answer to our November question. We did not receive an answer to our invitation. Mr Schembri had an envelope handed over from the Prime Minister's office on the street in Malta. This is a way of dealing with parliament that I would not have thought possible from a former parliamentarian! And you are chairman of the Council this year - well, I have never seen such a Council ignorance of the freely elected European Parliament. You have to clean up your own country! We'll stay behind, we'll insist that your own case be cleared up - you can laugh at that. We will insist that it does not go through and the Panama Committee of Inquiry will - if nothing happens, if you carry on as you have done - also investigate whether votes were bought in this election, as is publicly claimed in Malta. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Nuno MELO
text: Question according to the "blue card" procedure. - My dear Deputy Langen, is chairman of the Panama Papers Commission. At my request, this commission called the Portuguese Secretary of State, Rocha Andrade, to Brussels. At that hearing, the Secretary of State did not clarify a secret agreement to remove Panama from the black list and confessed that he had not asked the tax authority for an opinion to remove the offshores, tax havens, of Jersey, Man and Uruguay from the black list. Mainly, after this omission, it was known in Portugal that there was a negative opinion regarding the removal of Uruguay from the national black list. In other words, this is a very important fact, an explanation that was not given, which was denied to the commission by the Portuguese Secretary of State, Rocha Andrade. I have already requested again that the Portuguese Secretary of State, Rocha Andrade, attend the mission to Portugal of the Panama Papers Commission. As President of the Panama Papers Commission, I ask you whether these new clarifications are important or not? Personally, I consider them to be very important.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Colleague!We also discussed the blacklist issue with the Commission President.He said: It will be presented by the end of the year, but he hopes that not a single Member State or jurisdiction within the EU will be on it.We will not accept this statement.There are 33 tax havens within the European Union.And some Member States have made it a point to be left out, and have removed other states, like Uruguay, to do so.We are going to review this system and I believe that the Malta tax refund system for foreign companies should be included on that list.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: - Interessanti kif il-Partit tal-Popolari Ewropej, li tagħhom il-Partit Nazzjonalista Maltti huwa membru, ressqu s-suġġett għad-dibattitu biex jagtutu l-impressjoni l l-prinċipju legali tad-dritt ma jeżistix f’Malta. Qed jippruvaw jitfgħu lil Malta fl-istess keffa tal-Ungeria mmexxija minn membru tal-familja politika tagħhom. Li mhux qed jgħidu huwa li l-Partit Nazzjonalista li jagħmel parti mill-Popolari magħhom. Divided the pressures on the flower and sit on the flower. It is possible to enter into an agreement with the competent authorities. Għalija, dik hija l-attitudni ta ’min ma jemminx fil-prinċipju bażiku tar-rule of law. In real terms, Gvern Laburista biex neħħa l-preskrizzjoni għall-politíi b’akkużi ta ’korruzzjoni, li introduċa l-liġi għall-finanzjament tal-partiti u li daáal lili li tipipoteġi lill-whistleblowers. Gvern li ma jħarisx il-prinċipju tad-dritt ma jdaħħalx dawn il-miżuri.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, the Panama Papers have revealed and launched a corruption scandal involving the Prime Minister of Malta, who is present here with us in the Chamber.The corruption scandal must be thoroughly investigated, as must all the corruption and tax evasion scandals that the Panama Papers have revealed.In order to fight corruption, evasion and money laundering, it is mandatory to eliminate all bearer actions in all Member States, including my country, Romania.Bearer shares are blank checks, do not contain the owner's name, do not leave traces, there is no control and they are anonymous.When the shares move from one hand to another, the owner changes, without a trace.I repeat, by money laundering, about three trillion dollars are lost every year in the world, of which only 1% are recovered.We owe it to ourselves to recover them all, for the people.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: - Mr President! During previous discussions around Malta, we have tried to also show some understanding of the country. The understanding is based on the fact that it can be quite difficult to find a functioning economy if you are a small rock in the middle of the Mediterranean and there is not a large stock of natural resources to use. At the same time, we are a little worried right now about the process we are seeing in connection with the Money Laundering Directive. In connection with the Money Laundering Directive, we have been trying to find rules that will last, and then it turns out that the Maltese Presidency is not really able to make clear and simple decisions about the real owner. The central point in our attempts to find loopholes in taxation policy is that we find the real owner. If the Maltese presidency does not dare to raise that issue, it raises suspicions - suspicions that it is not always handled in the way it should be handled. There are also other clues. Another issue that comes up in the Money Laundering Directive is about who is a politically exposed personality and that issue has not been addressed either.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: - Mr President, the European Union seeks to present itself as the Europe of values. It is just the Europe of business people. We already had Jean-Claude Juncker, the great architect of tax evasion, at the head of the Commission, we now have Malta, a tax haven, at the head of the European Council. It’s pretty tasty when you consider that, in order to restore its image, the European Parliament created a committee of inquiry into the Panama Papers scandal a year ago, on which I have the honor to sit. An investigation by an international network of journalists has revealed that Malta, a small state of less than 500,000 inhabitants, is depriving its partners in the Union of two billion euros in tax revenue per year. In the face of this scandal, the Union is doing nothing! I accuse him of deliberately allowing multinationals, banks and politicians to benefit from this tax evasion. I call on Europeans, and in particular the French, to open their eyes to the true nature of the Union.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Mr President, during our work in the committee of inquiry on the so—called Panama Papers, the word ‘Malta’ has come up very often. I would like to say to the Prime Minister that this was mostly in the context of very worrying information about high officials from his country being involved in various activities that raise suspicion of being linked to money laundering and corruption. Given this information, we decided to organise a fact—finding mission to Malta, during which we met with representatives of intermediaries as well as with journalists and some government officials. Prime Minister, unfortunately, your Chief of Staff, Mr Schembri, whose name appeared in the Panama Papers, refused to meet with us, while another member of your Cabinet, whose name was also exposed in the Panama Papers, Minister Konrad Mizzi, failed to convince us of his innocence. We find it absolutely unacceptable that a high government official from an EU Member State refuses to appear before the parliamentary committee of inquiry to testify. Moreover, we also find it very worrying that you, as Prime Minister, have not suspended both Mr Schembri and Minister Mizzi from their government duties until the legal investigation in their cases is completed.  The failure to do so, Prime Minister, has seriously undermined the credibility of your country and yourself personally at the crucial time when Malta holds the Presidency of the European Union. It has also sent a bad signal to European public opinion. I am sure you agree with me that winning elections does not allow you or your government to sweep such problems under the rug. Here in this House, we all expect that you will make sure that an honest investigation into these two cases will take place without delay.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: - Mr. president. The Panama Papers have not only questioned Malta. I want to start by remembering that there are many countries, networks, banks, tax advisers, and lawyers that are related to the Panama papers. It is important, however, for us to remember that this country, Malta, has the firm will to work for transparency and for loyal cooperation in the fight against tax evasion. This is what we think of you, Mr. Muscat. We have full confidence in your work. We respect you, we congratulate you on your success and we hope that Malta will indeed be one of the leading countries in this fight for tax justice and the fight against tax havens. But, ladies and gentlemen, we are not just talking about Malta. Because I want to recall that 40,000 people, related to the European Union, have come across the Panama Papers and OLAF has decided to investigate several people. For example, to the former Commissioner Kroes or, for example, to the current Commissioner Cañete, for his relations with the Panama Papers. Let's be clear. Let us not just accuse Malta, but let us demand exemplarity and indeed demand a full investigation of those responsible. Because, certainly, also the Commission, also the European Union have to give sufficient credibility to their work and not only accuse one country, but put us all at the forefront of a fight that we must all fight together.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - There is no doubt that the Panama files are one of the biggest scandals we have witnessed in recent years. It is impressive that it takes more than a year to clarify allegations of high-level corruption. With the accusations in April last year, mainly against you, honorable Prime Minister, as well as against your Chief of Staff, the Minister of Energy and members of your family, we notice that this important dossier has been dragging on for an extremely long time. I can also see this as a member of the Panama Dossier Committee. Moreover, your country is currently chairing the Council of Europe during the ongoing investigation. Obstruction by key state bodies in the Maltese political and law enforcement sphere is obvious and visible, as reported mainly in the local media. Just nine months after you, together with Transparency International, signed a statement on an approach to fighting corruption and zero tolerance, Transparency International stated in an official statement on 9 August 2016 that Malta must be cleared of corruption before heading to the EU Council next year. Such a case of corruption in the European Union must be clarified as soon as possible.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: - For the purposes of this Regulation, Malta may be authorized to enter into discussions. Il-Gvern seta 'evita dan kollu imma ma riedx. In the present case, the competent authorities of the Member States have indicated that they will be able to enter into the accounts. Hawn min, għaliex hekk jaqbillu biex isikkitna, jgħid li jekk tiddefendi lil pajjiżek, tkun qed tittradixxi lil Malta. Min jgħid hedge, żbaljat. Incidentally, the Kingdom of Malta has been notified for a period of time. The Kingdom of Malta and the Kingdom of Malta are listed in Annex I to this Regulation. Jien ukoll kontra min qed juża dak li ġara buala skuża biex idgħajjef is-settur tas-servizzi finanzjarji f’Malta. It is possible to enter into a financial agreement with the Member States and to finance the services. Għalhekk, jiena nappella, li fuq naħa, għandna nibqgħu impenjati li nsaħħu l-istituzzjonijiet ewlenin tagāna f'pajjiżna, inkluż dawk li jgħassu kontra attivitajiet illegali, u fuq in-naħa g-l l -Gvern bħala skuża fuq is-suċċess li kisbet Malta f'dan is-settur fis-snin li għaddew. Bil-kliem kulħadd jista ’jgħid li huwa Ewropew imma dak li għandu jiddefinixxina bħala Maltin u Ewropej huma l-valuri tagàna kif inwettquhom. In the present case, the interests of the Member States as a result of the application of the law of the Member States of the Community have been taken into account. Jien nwiegħed li, flimkien mal-kollegi tiegħi, ser nibqa ’dejjem niddefendi lil pajjiżna u lil dak li nemmnu fih, kullimkien.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: - The name of the company must be replaced by the name of the Member State of Malta. In this context, the Democratic Republic has missed its commitment to interning and the United States. Qidħdin niddiskutu wieħed mill-Istati Membri li l-aktar għamlu suċċess ekonomika, fejn id-demokrazija u r-rule of law qatt ma kieni dubjuži. Waqt li għall-Panama Papers hemm il-PANA Committee, id-dibattitu tal-lum huwa biss skuża meskina biex din il-Kamra tinkludi aġenda partiġjana ta 'nies li, kull meta tkellmu bl-iskop li jattakkaw' il-Gvern, għamlu kemm The Commission of the European Communities, the President of the Republic of Malta. Nies li stqarru li jistħu li huma Maltin. L-iskop ta ’dan id-dibattitu mhux veru biex niddiskutu r-rule of law.
