Tant hu hekk, li dawn riedu li dan id-dibattitu jsir qabel l-elezzjoni bieenerali biex b’hekk jieħdu vantaġġ politiki partiġjan. Dawn huma tattiċi tal-mistħija, tattiċi tal-bullying. Malta is a democratic, progressive country. Pajjiż żgħir imma nazzjon kbir. Tippruvawx tkunu bullies magħna għax ma nħallukomx.

name: Markus FERBER
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! After I had the special pleasure of being on TAXE-1, TAXE-2 and the Panama Committee of Inquiry, I have to say that it is very, very difficult to get into this cartel of silence that the Council unfortunately has has also built, with the support of the Commission, to shed light and gather information. Firstly, Commissioner, you wrote me a letter saying that there are no tax havens in the European Union. This letter has been given a place of honor in my office, and I always enjoy looking at it because the daily work in the committee of inquiry shows that the opposite is the case. And, Prime Minister, it is interesting that a country like yours can really bring the Who's Who of the European economy to its home without large-scale production taking place there. These are also interesting things that we have processed in TAXE-1 and TAXE-2. Panama is about how individual taxpayers keep their assets safe from taxation. And the fact that even Maltese citizens are very responsible and fear the Maltese tax rates is an eloquent example of what is happening there. The whole thing is crowned by the fact that cooperation with the Council - sorry - is under all cannon. We have now learned the possibilities of blackening documents when we wanted to look at the documents. Some blacken entire pages, some blacken paragraphs, some blacken words. But we don't get any information, we only get black pages. Dear Prime Minister, there is a lot you could have done to create more credibility in Europe. Whoever creates economic growth only on the back of other countries is not acting lawfully. (The speaker agrees to a question about the "blue card" procedure according to Answer Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- President!First of all, let me also say a word to the Prime Minister that, as a Hungarian Member of Parliament, I envy your problems.For all the accusations that have been made in the past, and you have alluded to them.I respectfully ask if you would be willing to give the same speech to Viktor Orbán, who commits a hundred times what we are now accusing the Maltese people of doing?

name: Markus FERBER
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- So, even after reading the Panama Papers intensively, the name Orbán could not be found.That's why I can't ask him the questions.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Mr President, we are having a debate and there is not a lack of opinions and even accusations, but there is a lack of facts. I have been part of the PANA delegation to Malta; we had discussions, but it was very difficult for us also by the nature of this mission to uncover this fact. I think the European Parliament, before entering this debate should get the facts, and take itself seriously by gathering facts and not just have opinions and accusations – that is not enough.  Let me talk about one topic. This is the opportunity where we do have facts and a lot of evidence – the evidence for tax competition. We now see for example that small firms pay 30% more taxes than large corporations: that is a fact. Malta has, to put it in a neutral way, a very different tax system, with the ultimate tax burden of about 5% in many cases. There is nothing wrong with being different and having a different tax system, but I would implore the Prime Minister to join the investigation into loopholes that are unintended and join international cooperation to close these loopholes. I expect that from Malta. I would also implore the Prime Minister, especially as he is from the social democratic family, that he join efforts to introduce the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base, because that is the European response for making the tax system efficient and fair and I also count on Malta on this.  As I said, there is nothing wrong with being different, but I hope the Maltese Prime Minister will join with the European Parliament and fight for fair and efficient taxation in Europe.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: - Mr President, Prime Minister, Commissioner, I think it is necessary to underline three points in this regard. The first is that it is shameful what has been going on in Malta for a long time and, therefore, in particular, the way in which this has been made public, through the Panama Papers, shows that we cannot keep this type in the European Union regulation that gives rise to less transparent maneuvers. Secondly, I must say that it is not just Malta and, therefore, we have to fight this tax competition at the level of the whole European Union and, therefore, tax harmonization is a priority because there are several other sites that lend themselves to this less transparent practices. And finally, to say here that I completely associate myself with that cry or that manifesto of my colleague Nuno Melo, when in Portugal, in a totally illegal way, the Isle of Man, Jersey and Uruguay were removed from the black list of offshores. Therefore, I would also like to note this because it must be investigated by the Panama Papers Commission.

name: Nuno MELO
text: - Mr President, it is not normal for a member of a state government to omit relevant information from a European Parliament commission of inquiry, but that is what the Portuguese Secretary of State Rocha Andrade did. He did not explain a secret agreement to remove Panama from the black list at a time when he was part of a government. He confessed that he did not ask the Portuguese Tax Authority for an opinion to remove three offshores from a black list against national legislation and omitted a negative Finance opinion that was against Uruguay's removal from the black list. For this very reason, I asked the President of the Commission of Inquiry that Mr. Secretary of State Rocha Andrade could, in the next mission to Portugal, have a new opportunity and clarify what he omitted in the European Parliament. It is important to know how, against the law, against opinions of Finance, they remove themselves from the black list offshores in Portugal. About this, I hope you will attend the next mission to Portugal.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Mr President, are you going to keep Keith Schembri and Konrad Mizzi, both exposed in the Panama Papers, in your government? If so, it will remain vulnerable, despite winning elections. And the worst thing is that it makes your country’s reputation more vulnerable, which has already been shaken because it is based on prosperity and development in financial services and eGaming industries that serve organized crime and serve corrupt people all over the world to launder capital and flee to pay taxes. Recently, the weekly Expresso, published in my country, Portugal, exposed the way in which your country is used by politically exposed people and entrepreneurs to create front companies that serve as a platform to disguise the illicit origin of the heritage and, from Malta, invest in the European financial system, benefiting from big tax benefits. The program to sell citizenship and residence to individuals or companies, which has been published in Air Malta magazine, is an illustration of the blatant scheme of tax dumping and money laundering facilitation in which, unfortunately, Malta is not alone among the Member States. European Union members. I fear that, in the report of the Commission of Inquiry on the Panama Papers, Malta does not stand out for working for European values, much less for socialist and labor values, but for looking and being a European tax haven, among others. We have to end them.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, in the jungle all animals are equal, but the lion is a little more equal. There is no one who can not complain that illegal money laundering should not be allowed, whether it refers to Malta, Cyprus or any other country. But do not "throw the baby with the bathtub". In a panel discussion on the Panama Papers, of which I am a member, it was said that a company keeps illicit money in 60 places around the world, and we found that in one place it hides 70 billion. And on average, you make 1 trillion, and nobody dealt with this issue. One trillion saves the global financial crisis and feeds the entire hungry human population. Well, let's look at Malta, let's look at other countries, let's look at Jersey and Guernsey, because isolation gives the impression that we are not clear on how we are dealing with the issue.

name: Romana TOMC
text: - We can pass a thousand laws, but we will not prevent corruption with them.We can have a thousand institutions, but they will not detect crime.It all depends on whether the laws are written for the elect, who in this way even legalize their actions.And are the institutions that are supposed to be independent really independent?The Panama Papers affair has garnered a lot of attention and we have closed quite a few loopholes for tax evasion because of this, but of course this is just the beginning.Every day a new affair arises.Only a few days ago, an affair broke out in connection with the largest Slovenian bank, which is suspected of participating in the laundering of Iranian money.We all talk about the rule of law, including Prime Minister Muscat, and we condemn corruption.It would be good, of course, not only to talk, but to stick to it as well.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Mr. president. A while ago we debated here, in this Plenary of the European Parliament, about a Europe based on values, which we miss when we see the non-compliance in immigration matters, when we see the lack of union to face the populist-in-chief Donald Trump when he withdraw from climate change with a humanitarian diplomacy that gives a humanitarian response to the crisis, but also when we fight against tax evasion and against tax fraud. Prime Minister Muscat: Of course, we welcome his commitment. But, Commissioner Moscovici: it is very important that the work of the Investigation Committee on Money Laundering and Tax Avoidance and Evasion does not focus on either Nevada or Hong Kong, but on tax inequality here, in the European Union, within the European Union. Because tax resolutions, the role of lawyers, tax advisers and banks are crying out for an effort at tax harmonization in Europe and from Europe. That is why the commission of inquiry has to pave the way for new legislation that will close the loopholes, loopholes and the many tricks that allow fraudsters to continue to get away with it.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - President! Allow me to refer back for a moment to the answer I received to my previous question. Indeed, Malta is on the stage here now, but I think this debate should still be about the European Union. The phenomena we are talking about here now are in a great many countries in Europe and are drawing astonishing billions from European development, from European taxpayers. That is why I think it is very, very important that the important lesson of this debate today is that we do not just look at one country, and then all the accusations can be made there, but the whole problem must be dealt with as a whole, because, as I said, Orbán Viktor makes a hundred times as many pigs in Hungary as we heard in the hall as an accusation here, that is a fact. For example, the citizenship program run by the Orbán government is exclusively and strictly the subject of offshore operations. Well, these are what a European community cannot leave.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I welcome the fact that the PANA inquiry committee in the European Parliament has been taking the Maltese case seriously and organised a fact-finding mission to Valletta in February 2017. It seems that on the one hand the Maltese tax system is in line with current international EU standards as regards harmful tax competition, but that, nonetheless, the system provides for advantages, making it highly attractive for business and wealthy individuals to settle there. Moreover, a high number of intermediaries from Malta were involved in the Panama papers, with some intermediaries having worked with politically-exposed persons. It is regrettable that Keith Schembri refused to appear to be before PANA, and that institutions in charge of implementing and enforcing rules as regards tax fraud and money laundering were highly politicised. This must be condemned by all means. And the other side, last but not least, allow me to praise the successful activity of Malta leading the EU Council.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: member of the Commission. - Mr President, Mr Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for inviting me and for inviting the Commission to participate in this debate, which has given me the opportunity to recall everything that the Commission and the Union have done to make taxation more transparent, more efficient and fairer in the European Union. The Commission is of course aware of the links established between the Panama Papers and Malta, which are the subject of judicial inquiries in Malta. The reason we have not spoken is very simple, and that is that the Commission cannot comment on ongoing investigations. There is a principle that exists in all our democracies: that of the separation of powers and the independence of the judiciary, which we obviously cannot question. Mr Giegold said a letter was sent to the Commission today. The latter will take note of it and respond to it. I just want to emphasize three points. The first is that many of you have explained to us that we have a restrictive view of tax havens when we consider that there are no tax havens in the European Union. This does not mean that we are unaware that there may be problems and harmful practices in the European Union, which are the subject of investigations, but a tax haven is something else, if we want to reason in all rigor. Why? A tax haven is a country that does not respect international standards and, beyond that, the rules on transparency and the fight against tax evasion which are now enshrined in European law. I spoke of European leadership because, thanks to our determined action, European law goes far beyond international standards. All European countries have adopted these rules of law. They implement them all and they show that they have the necessity and willingness to meet these commitments. There have also been several mechanisms, which I will call soft law, such as the establishment of a code of conduct on harmful tax practices. It is therefore absolutely necessary to take strong action to combat unfair tax practices in the Union. However, qualifying a particular Member State as a tax haven in itself is not, in my opinion, an intellectually satisfactory or rigorous process. Therefore, the Commission will not propose it. As regards action against money laundering, the Commission considers that transparency and access to information on beneficial owners are very important points in the fight against money laundering and against evasion. and tax evasion. The Commission defends its proposal, because we consider it to be proportionate and balanced between, on the one hand, the need to provide the authorities with the necessary instruments to combat tax fraud and money laundering and, on the other hand , efficiency, which is also essential. Finally, I respond in particular to Mr. Ferber, who posts the letters that we can address to him. I will send more to him which I hope will also be displayable and which will also be acted upon. On requests for access to documents, the Commission, through its various Directorates-General, notably DG TAXUD, DG JUST and DG FISMA, is working hard - I also say this to President Langen - to accede to the legitimate requests of the PANA commission ( commission of inquiry responsible for examining allegations of infringements and maladministration in the application of Union law on money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion) concerning access to documents. Mr. President, you can testify that we have already submitted hundreds of documents to this committee, with which I am delighted to be able to work under the best conditions. In particular, I will cite two things. At this stage, more than 850 documents have been uploaded to the open internet platform within the framework of the PANA commission. In addition, no less than 697 other confidential documents (including 375 for DG TAXUD, for which I am responsible) were provided to the PANA committee in a secure reading room. It will be understood that we must also respect a certain amount of personal information about taxpayers. In any case, it is not for us to make them public. But I want this transparency action to be carried out to the end, and you know very well - I am addressing the Members of the European Parliament here - that if there are gaps here or there, it is not the fact of the Commission, but more that of the Member States, which must also cooperate. This is what I wanted to say in this debate, which I appreciate the importance of. This debate must not avoid any situation. At the same time, it must respect the separation of powers and must do justice to the Member States and their efforts to integrate new European regulations into their own national law. It must also continue an ardent, unwavering fight against tax fraud and tax evasion. We have achieved extremely important results in recent years. Indeed, many of the cases we are talking about are cases that stem from flaws or loopholes in previous legislation. They could not happen again in the future. This is no reason not to consider that the investigations should be completed to the end, but it is a reason for the Commission to pursue its legislative action in this area to the end and to ask the Member States not to falter, not to fail and to be by our side in these advances that your Parliament, I know, supports and promotes with us, and even more ardently than us.

name: Joseph MUSCAT
text: Prime Minister of Malta. – Mr President, I expect some of you would be expecting me to be angry after this debate. Actually I am not: I am very happy to be here; I consider this as a natural second home for me, and I do understand the spirit of this debate. I do understand the political narrative of it all. So allow me to reply in kind and to be tongue and cheek in my replies and very candid and very open in the way I try to address the concerns that you have put forward. I do understand, as a politician, the timing of the debate, and I do appreciate that a majority in this House did not agree to the fact that such a debate takes place during an electoral campaign. This is a much more serene setting for such a debate. I welcome, first of all, Mr Weber’s wishes. I thank him for his contribution to our campaign back in Malta. He said that the only politicians mentioned in the Panama Papers were Maltese – I am sorry, it is not true. We have a Commissioner from the EPP family who is mentioned in those papers – his own family. No one is saying anything about that. (Mr Langen, I have not interrupted you: please listen to me, hear me out.) No one said anything about that, so I do believe that that was the first incorrect fact. But, really and truly, there are three ways in which this debate has gone: there is the debate on the Panama Papers, there is the debate on the issue of taxation, and there is then an outright lie that has been said. Let’s start with the debate on the Panama papers, with many Members asking why there is not an investigation. I think Ms Metsola said quite clearly: there are four investigations taking place in court by independent judges, and they will decide whether there is room for prosecution. There already has been a commitment that, if there is such room for prosecution, resignations would be in order. I am amazed that this basic fact was not taken into consideration. There are four independent judicial investigations taking place. That is the most basic fact that, I am sorry, quite a number of Members got wrong. I do believe the problem is that most of the time, Members and colleagues are sourcing their facts simply from the social media and not trying to dig little bit deeper to try to ascertain the veracity of fact. Secondly, I do believe, and I do bring to your attention, the fact that some of the conclusions that you were referring to were really and truly denied by the same independent institutions that are being quoted, including the Financial Intelligence Analysis Unit. I must say that I will keep on mentioning a number of facts that I think need to be ascertained. Let me start with our tax system. Malta’s imputation tax system is quite unique in Europe, that’s true. It has not been invented or put in during the past 4 or 10 years. It has been there since World War II. It has been scrutinised by the Commission prior to our joining the European Union more than 11 years ago. It is OECD-compliant. Some might not like it; some might say it is competitive. The fact is that it has undergone all levels of scrutiny by all organisations. I also believe that there are two ways in which we can go on the taxation element. On one I agree with this House, and I will show how, in practice, we as a government and also as a presidency have gone to lengths not only not to obstruct the advancement of dossiers in this area but actually to conclude dossiers that are quite thorny: ATAD II – the anti-tax avoidance directive, the second recast; BEPS – the erosion of profits, profit shifting. These are all issues that have been concluded or where progress has been achieved under the Maltese Presidency. I think that is a fact that should be taken into consideration. I must also stress the fact that our government and also as a whole, we are part of the OECD exchange of information. Some mentioned the ‘Malta files’. There is nothing secret. The people who have companies back at home are publicly available on the internet. The only exercise that was made was a consolidation of elements where, instead of searching a company, one searches a name. I invite you to take a look at the Tax Justice Network’s Financial Secrecy Index. You will find at least five Member States – and not necessarily the usual suspects – who are ranked lower than Malta when it comes to secrecy and transparency. We have done away with banking secrecy more than a decade and a half ago. We are not the last people to come to join this fight against avoidance and evasion. The point where we disagree is where Member States should not be let and left to decide their own tax levels. That is something that I totally disagree with the majority of this House about. I might remain in a minority on this, but that is something that I believe is fundamental and is also fundamental for a number of other Member States, irrespective of the composition of our economy. It is not true that our economy is dependent on financial services: that shows a lack of knowledge about the structure of the smallest Member State’s economy. Maybe it is not too much important for some of you over here, but if you look at the basic numbers, our main exports are microchips. In almost all your mobile phones, you will find a microchip proudly made in Malta. We are not a mailbox economy; we are an economy that produces value added. Trying to put a caricature of all this – I can accept it in a tabloid, but really and truly, I expect a more informed debate in such a House. Let me move on to some other issues. I said the independence of institutions, but also the way in which we source our information and the way in which we direct debates. Yes, quite a number of you relied on reports that were on media. None of you – I am surprised – referred to the Moneyval reports. I believe that we all trust Moneyval. It is an institution that is not political. It is an institution that sees each and every jurisdiction, makes recommendations and is very tough. Moneyval has a positive report about our country. FSAP – let’s refer to the facts. It is not about who tweets and who posts on the internet. It is about experts telling us what to do in the same way that Greco, the Council of Europe, told us: ‘you guys don’t have a system of party financing, we don’t know who is financing your political parties’. Guess what? We introduced the system. Guess what? We are now totally compliant with the system and we are implementing it. It is not a law just there for the sake of being there. Unfortunately the opposition does not like it, but fortunately enough we are all compliant with it. Which brings me to some other points which I would like to make, which is really the third point, which some of you have referred to. I am really sorry that Mr Langen is no longer here, or at least I do not see him. Some people in this House have referred to a story – a totally outright lie – that has been directed against me, my wife and my family, namely that I have some sort of structure – account, funds – that I took from some contract: this is an outright lie. Whenever I ask someone to tell me the source of all this, everyone points at the same blog and report, which is unsubstantiated. And you know what? We respect so much the rule of law that, as Prime Minister, I went to court and I asked the court – an independent institution, where I have already as Prime Minister divested myself of the right enjoyed by my predecessors to nominate people to the bench (but now people come to the bench after being vetted by independent lawyers and prosecutors) – to appoint a magistrate to investigate these allegations. I said more than that; I said that, not only if there is some evidence that is put forward but if there is a shred of truth, I will immediately resign. I put myself on the line, for the simple reason I know it is totally untrue. Those who made the allegations, I asked them: ‘would you want to pledge your political career if what you are saying is false?’ No, they did not take up the challenge. Maltese people judged also based on this fact. What politician would pledge his whole career totally on one statement, on one assertion? I do not even bat an eyelid doing that, because I know I am saying the truth. I marvel at the idea that some extremely knowledgeable Members of this House have taken this thing, this fake news, and repeated it here just like that. So my point to Mr Langen and to some colleagues is: why aren’t you coming to the PANA Committee?’ I said about a month, a month and a half ago, I am coming to the PANA Committee. If you do not get this basic fact right, I am sorry, please check your press reviews or fire the people who are making them for you. I said I would be coming. I said I would be coming once the judge comes out with the independent investigation – one of the four independent investigations – to be able to present to the PANA Committee not what the Prime Minister of Malta is saying, but facts ascertained by the judiciary. And I am amazed that such a basic fact has been overlooked when there is such – what I deem to be – a serious debate, or which should have been a serious debate. I will conclude, Mr President. The second part of the topic for discussion is the rule of law. Let me take some time to say what we do back at home about the rule of law. May I remind you, The Economist classifies Malta as one of the few countries which is a full democracy. Some other Member States are not full democracies, but I will not judge them. What have we done? First of all, we have a totally independent National Audit Office that criticises government whenever it deems needs to criticise the government; a government that, when it has reports, takes corrective action. We have an ombudsman, who is critical of all institutions and of all governments, irrespective of which party forms that government; a Public Service Commission that is made up of representatives from all sides of the House. We have an independent judiciary which, even during the last legislature, decided that the opposition should have two extra seats; we disagreed with that ruling, but we said: yes, we will implement that ruling, because we observe the rule of law. We have an Attorney General, who was not changed after the election. We kept the same Attorney General who was nominated by the previous government, and now this person of high integrity gets attacked because some people in the opposition do not like the way in which he is giving advice. We have the Chair of our Financial Services Regulatory Authority, who was appointed by the previous administration. We kept him in office. We have removed time-barring on issues of corruption. I mentioned a number of other facts, such as the removal of parliamentary immunity, and very soon the implementation of a commissioner for public standards. We will be having, for the first time, hearings in our Parliament for appointing regulators. We have enacted a Freedom of Information Act. We have relaxed media laws in a way that now they are one of the most, if not the most, liberal in Europe. Not only did we not put constraints on journalists, we have even relaxed the way in which journalists are required to put forward issues related to sources. And we have removed criminal libels in order to prevent journalists from being put in prison – laws that have been there even after we joined the European Union, and we managed to remove them. In doing all this, then, we managed to achieve success, and I do believe that there might be some people who are not too keen on our economic success and social success. We not only have the best-performing economy in the Eurozone – and that is not because of financial services and gaming alone, it is about tourism, manufacturing, the services industry; it is about the honest, busy people that go to work each and every day. We have increased our pensions; we have increased the minimum wage; we have introduced universal free childcare; we have put Malta from number 20-whatever on the ILGA list for LGBTIQ rights to number one in Europe. This is prosperity with a purpose; this is the sort of debate I would love to have in this House. I do not have a problem in having the debate that we just had. I do hope that, when I appear in front of the PANA Committee with the facts – and I assure Mr Langen that I will appear in front of the Committee; I am not a Volkswagen that says one thing but does another – I keep my word. I will be here to present facts, and those facts, hopefully, will show how misguided some colleagues, unfortunately, have been. Having said that, I love this institution and I will continue to stick up for this institution.

name: Joseph MUSCAT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I mentioned earlier the ongoing efforts in the Council on the different files in the area of the fight against tax evasion, fraud and avoidance, and I can assure you that in the weeks before the end of our presidency we will do our utmost to achieve all the progress possible on these files. I am also confident that our Estonian colleagues will pursue this work in the coming months in this area, which is a priority for the Council.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulations)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - The so-called Panama Papers have highlighted, on the one hand, that European standards, however demanding they may be, are not enough without the cooperation of third countries, specifically due to the full adoption of stronger standards within the OECD framework, and another is the existence of complex schemes of aggressive tax planning and avoidance in which third-party jurisdictions, such as Panama, and certain member states, such as the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Malta, participate alike. Thus, it is typical to create a company with no real economic activity in Panama, Gibraltar or a similar country, and then open the bank account where the assets of said company are located in Luxembourg. The automatic exchange of information, and company registries with identification of the final beneficiaries are fundamental instruments in the fight against circumvention, but we also need rules that control intermediaries, an issue on which the Commission is working, and put an end to aggressive tax planning on the demand side, that is, the so-called specialization of certain jurisdictions, including Member States, in the creation and registration of companies and in the management of large fortunes.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - For years, the EU has always turned a blind eye to the presence of tax havens within it, into which huge resources have been transferred, to the detriment of other European countries, often the same ones, on which a harsh austerity regime was imposed. Between 2012 and 2015, Malta would have subtracted around EUR 14 billion in lost tax revenue from other EU countries, thanks to a distortive tax system, based on an effective tax rate on corporate profits of 5% and the absence of taxation on interest and royalties. The Panama Papers had revealed links between personalities in the Maltese Prime Minister's office, still in office, and some of Mossak Fonseca's client companies. Yet, the EU continues to hinder the adoption of ambitious measures of transparency and contrast to harmful tax practices, starting with the indispensable black list of tax havens within the Union, in order to achieve real cooperation to combat the great international avoidance and financial crime. From the "Malta Files" now further critical issues emerge, linked to the laundering of dirty money, coming from mafia activities, carried out through some companies registered on the island; as well as Malta's role as a crossroads for illegal arms trafficking. A scandal linked to the persistent gaps in anti-money laundering legislation, on which the Commission and especially the Council do not intend to take concrete steps forward.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- Today's debate could be titled: "Panama Papers and the Rule of Law in Spain", since Panama is one of the favorite tax havens of the Spanish right.Ministers and former ministers of the PP, such as Messrs. Rato and Soria, appear in the Papers.Even the Chief Anticorruption Prosecutor, favorite of the current Minister of Justice, had to resign when the press revealed his Panamanian companies.According to Gestha, the negligence of the Treasury allows three out of every four tax crimes to go uninvestigated.And given the ties of the current PP Government with corrupt and corrupters, nothing will change if the EU does not take action on the matter.The EU loses up to 237 billion a year due to tax evasion to Panama, 3.4% of its public spending, of the money for hospitals, schools and housing that the rich flee from the working class.That is why I ask you not to be an accomplice and to act once and for all to classify Panama as a tax haven.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: written. - The Panama Papers uncovered a lot: mailbox companies, secrecy and profit shifting via questionable company structures. In the committee of inquiry, however, we also learned above all that we don't even have to leave Europe to find offshore structures, letterbox companies, money laundering and the most aggressive tax planning. So before we take a look at Panama, we urgently need to clean up ourselves. Proposals for fair taxation are already on the table, such as the public reporting of multinationals by country. Instead of learning the lessons from Panama, the Conservatives would rather cover Panama again. On Monday, the conservative forces watered down the proposal for Public CBCR, i.e. real tax transparency, with their Emmentaler Amendments. ECR, ALDE and the EPP are protectionists of the global multinationals. However, the fight for real tax transparency continues and I expect support from the plenary and the Council. It can't be all about Panama & amp; Co-act, but don't act when specific suggestions are on the table.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by José Manuel Fernandes, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, and by Udo Bullmann, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the implementation of the European Fund forStrategic Investments (2016/2064 (INI)).

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: reporter. - Mr President, I would like to greet the Dear Colleagues and the Dear Colleagues who are here, also the Commission, and say that the EFSI, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, is meeting the objectives in the investment and innovation window. It is in line with the plan outlined in the window of small and medium-sized companies. It even goes there with the best predictions. The proof is that over € 190,000,000 has already been mobilized in the European Union and over 420,000 small and medium-sized enterprises have been supported. It is in this way, by promoting investment, that we get more jobs, that, at the same time, we also get more competitiveness for our economy, without ever forgetting social, economic and territorial cohesion. However, the European Fund for Strategic Investments does not have the visibility it deserved in view of the results it has produced. It is necessary to improve communication, it is also necessary to improve the visibility of this Fund. The proof of success is that, today, we are already negotiating the extension of the European Strategic Investment Fund to 500 million euros and its extension until 2020. This does not mean that this fund, its execution and, in particular, the execution by an essential actor, the European Investment Bank, cannot and should not be improved. First of all, knowing the projects that are not pre-selected, and here there is an attitude that can be discriminatory in law, but an attitude that is in the power of the European Investment Bank. It is important to be aware, at a minimum, of projects that have not been introduced in the system, of projects that have not been pre-selected. It is also important and essential to have a better geographical distribution, a better geographical balance, with regard to projects. It is also important that there is sectorial diversification. Small projects cannot be excluded from this fund, which requires pro-active territories and the implementation of investment platforms. it is essential for this purpose, to be able to encompass small projects. The need for platforms for cross-border projects is also something that needs to be addressed. The digital union is important, the union of energy is essential and also in this way, in addition to promoting the internal market, in addition to promoting interconnectivity and efficiency, we would be contributing to objectives across the European Union. This fund is an additional fund, it is also a complementary fund, but it is important and platforms are a means where this can be achieved, so that it can be better used, together with the Structural Funds, the funds, namely, of policy of cohesion. It is important that the additional aspect is reinforced and respected. It is also essential that less developed regions and regions that are, for example, in difficulty can take their economic situation into account when selecting projects. Finally, the advisory hub is essential to promote better projects to help structure investment platforms. I would like to end by thanking all political groups, all shadow rapporteurs for the work that has been done and, in a special way, the correlator Udo Bullmann. We have done work to promote growth, to promote and improve the competitiveness of the European Union and to give citizens a better quality of life. And we will continue with this goal in mind.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I can return this thanks to José Manuel Fernandes, my co-rapporteur, to all shadow rapporteurs, as well as to the many hardworking hands and minds in the staff who are involved in our work. We passed the EFSI legislation very quickly. We are now engaged in legislative deliberations on the Commission's new proposal - we will do that too efficiently and quickly. But of course we also have to take this opportunity to deal with a résumé, with a conclusion: What have we achieved? What is still to be achieved? First of all, why this fund for strategic investments at all? The Commission tells us: € 200 to 300 billion a year is missing from European investment policy. We have an investment gap especially in transportation, especially in broadband networks and renewable energies. We, the European Parliament, the political groups that are behind this decision, which we have taken, do not want to come to terms with it. We believe in the future of the European economy. We want to give the young people, who are unemployed far too often and far too often in many countries, a chance. There has to be sustainable growth. We want to create the conversion into the future of the economy. That is why we have to close these investment gaps. Yes, we stand by this program. Yes, we support the program. But let's see: Where are deficits still to be eliminated? Where can improvements be made? We have to ask ourselves: what has been achieved? Yes, the volumes are flowing, the numbers are good. But are we really funding the projects we want to fund? Or is there not too often a situation in which projects are financed that receive capital anyway - be it private or public financiers behind it? Why are there still too few partnerships - partnerships that support small and medium-sized projects, partnerships with regional promotional banks, with national promotional banks that have the know-how that we urgently need? Does the money really get to the regions where we need it most? Or are those regions not preferred that already have an intact infrastructure - an infrastructure for consulting, an infrastructure for project planning - and are therefore perhaps less dependent on our money? Is the positive dynamic we want in the modernization sectors already emerging? Or do we give priority to spending money so that money is spent? These are critical questions that we must not ignore, and that is why our report highlights the merits, what has been achieved. But it also makes it clear where the deficits are. We want to get a clearer definition of additionality. We want the instruments for selecting projects to be sharpened and, if you please, also to be used as they are anchored in the first legislative act. We want more transparency. We want more cooperation. And we feel that the weight of the European Parliament is necessary in order to better achieve these goals. We are counting on cooperation, of course in particular with the Commission, which we support, but also with our preferred partner, the European Investment Bank - here too we want to make cooperation even better. And we want to convince the Council that important steps must be taken towards this.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: Rapporteur for opinion Opinion Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. - Madam President, as has been said, EFSI 2 is currently being negotiated. I think this extension is positive, but I believe that our colleagues who are currently negotiating must take into account the conclusions of this implementation report. These are really good results, but we must still take into account some things: the amounts presented as realized do not include reality, ie the money that reached the beneficiaries. The credit ceilings given to banks do not think that they have reached the beneficiaries yet and this must be taken into account: only 60% of the money is private money. So there needs to be more transparency about these amounts, as to the reasons for refusal. EFSI must not replace grants, EFSI must, together with the Structural Funds, contribute to investment and much more promotion of EFSI is needed in all Member States.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. -  Madam president. The truth is, it has been difficult to assess EFSI 1 after just a year and a half. Even so, with all the studies and evaluations, we have seen that although the quantitative results were, in principle, positive, there were nonetheless substantial shortcomings in the quality of the projects, in the unclear evidence of additionality of the same, in their geographic concentration, in the lack of certain sectors or even in the lack of transparency in the selection. In the case of transport, we have encountered a rather cruel paradox, since 2.2 billion were taken from the Connecting Europe Facility - that is, more than 25% of what EFSI 1 was - and yet in Of the projects that have been achieved, we have only found 13% of projects for transport. And what is worse: in the EFSI 2 proposal it turns out that the Commission - and it is not you, Mr Moscovici, I know - arrives with a 'no roads at all'. Therefore, we would like the EFSI 2 to take into account that if money is still required from transport, there is of course a specific interest for the additionality of CEF projects.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. - Madam President, of course we have supported the initiative of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), and we can see that this initiative is generally a success. It’s a perfect hit in small and medium sized businesses for the European Investment Fund (EIF). It is also a quantitative success, but we have a few remarks and, under the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN), as my colleague has just said, some disappointments. In fact, transport was considered, for the infrastructure part, as an essential element, with a minimum percentage. Then, we considered that qualitatively, these projects should have added European value. However, we can see that both the quantity and the quality are not there and that as such, the transport is all the more frustrated that it has been the subject of a puncture, that comes to be told, on a fund mechanism which itself works perfectly, which is moreover already exhausted by its success, namely the mechanism for interconnection in Europe. I don't want to believe that we will go so far as to puncture him a second time. I want to conclude by saying that the European Investment Bank (EIB) is not a bank. The EIB is first and foremost an institution of the Union, and as such, additionality, the guarantee of first losses and support for European policies must be reconsidered; this will be - I think - the subject of the EFSI 2 regulation, which carries our hopes.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: member of the Commission. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear rapporteurs, exactly one year ago the Commission was here to discuss with you the mid-term review of the European Investment Plan, the Juncker Plan, and for also announce its intention to extend this European Fund for Strategic Investments. At that time, we found that we had around 65 projects: infrastructure projects and industrial investment projects that had already secured funding from EFSI. In addition to these, and even more importantly, 185 agreements have been concluded between the European Investment Fund and intermediary banks, between this Fund and private banks, all to finance small and medium-sized enterprises. Today, we can say that we are going much further, with 224 projects and 275 agreements with intermediaries. Also, I am proud to say, on behalf of Jyrki Katainen, that the EFSI is now well on track to fulfill its investment promises, because it is about closing the investment gap in Europe. There is, I believe, a very broad consensus on the success and usefulness of EFSI. Over the past two years, it has shown itself to be a powerful instrument to support investment in the European Union. 194 billion euros have already been mobilized in total investment in the Member States, which benefits 420,000 small and medium-sized enterprises or start-ups. The EIB Group, which I want to salute, has supported projects and small businesses in many sectors and many regions in, of course, all the countries of the Union; all for the benefit of growth and jobs in Europe. I am also pleased to inform you that some of the shortcomings or imbalances rightly singled out in your report have in the meantime been reduced. EFSI now covers - that was of course of high importance - all EU 28 Member States. Compared to GDP, the investment mobilized currently is highest in Estonia, Spain, Bulgaria, Portugal and Finland, which balances the initial geographic concentration. Investment platforms are developing, even if in the beginning slower than we would have hoped for. But of course, more needs to be done, and we are determined to make EFSI a success for everyone and everywhere. In your report you point to a potential contradiction between the quantitative and the qualitative goals of EFSI. Here, let me again refer to the statement the Commission made in this Chamber last year that demonstrates how much we are in the same logic and how much we share the same concerns. The main issue in this is to focus on addressing market failure. The main issue is not to make it larger. One thing on which we have to be very careful is to provide financing for new innovations which will strengthen sustainable development of our economies in social and environmental terms, for instance financing through investments which will promote the circular economy. Here I quote the speech of last year: ‘Honorable Members, dear colleagues, three main issues are identified as falling short of expectations in your implementing report: additionality, transparency and geographical diversification’. These are precisely the items we decided to address through the EFSI 2.0 Regulation. I am therefore pleased to perceive a large convergence of views between the Commission and the European Parliament on the areas for improvement. Though divergences appear in the means put forward to overcome EFSI's initial weaknesses or defects, most of them relate to the level of ambition for EFSI 2.0. The Commission does not believe that this is the time for a complete overhaul, because it would cost time and also damage investor confidence - but we are not looking for a quick fix either. You can be assured that the Commission does not put quantity over quality - I insist on that - and is as vigilant regarding the appropriate use of the EU guarantee as the European Parliament. We share the same view. It is precisely because we consider the improvements in terms of additionality and transparency so important that we want them to be implemented as quickly as possible. While we might disagree on some proposals for the immediate way forward, let me underline that the Commission looks with great interest at some of the medium-term reflections you formulate for a potential EFSI 3.0. The Commission welcomes Parliament’s call for further proposals to see how we can permanently support investment in Europe, relaunch, boost and strengthen it. All this shows that the European Parliament has an ambition, a commitment for this investment plan, the Juncker plan. I want to assure you all that your reflections, your reports will be a source of reflections, a source of actions, a source of thoughts within the framework of our own thoughts and reflections on the future multiannual financial framework, which will be our very important task. In my opinion and in the opinion of the Commission, it is absolutely crucial that the next budget of the European Union be above all an investment-focused budget, because investment is the key to innovation and innovation is also the key to our common future.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. - Madam President, Commissioner Moscovici has just said, there may be disagreements between us, differences of appreciation, but I think that at this stage, everyone agrees first to recognize the merits a major investment plan in a European Union which continues to suffer from a chronic deficit of public and private investment. I remind you that we are 15% below the 2008 level. It is true that we would like to enrich the EFSI. There is of course the intensification of thematic diversity (I am thinking in particular of the questions of ecological transition) and there is the regional dimension of the funded projects: I continue to believe that it is abnormal that Greece still has only 'limited access to this fund. On behalf of the Committee on International Trade (INTA), of which I was draftsman, I would like to underline two points. The first concerns small and medium-sized enterprises. It is true that the part of the fund devoted to financing SMEs has worked well, but we would also like there to be a mission to help internationalize small and medium-sized enterprises. The second point concerns tax conditionality, and I thank the rapporteurs for being sensitive to it. A number of promoters have been linked to tax havens, which, in my opinion, goes against the Union's external tax doctrine. It would be appropriate to remedy this.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. - Mr President, it is very good that this EFSI program has started. But just as has emerged here, this program needs to be intensified. We have had some shortage of investment. It is precisely this regionalization that is very important. It must be borne in mind that the purpose of this program is to add value and, in a way, to close the gaps that have now arisen through other programs, that is to say, to create added value and thereby increase European know-how and innovation. The internationalization aspect is very important here. When it comes to quantity and quality here, then of course we have to go quality first. But, as I said, I hope that this quality will not only focus somewhere in Europe, but could serve a wide area of ​​the whole of the European Union. It is very important that these investments bring new added value to the whole European field in the long and medium term.

name: Romana TOMC
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.- On the preparation of the opinion in the Employment Committee, we focused mainly on the impact of the EFSI on job creation, which is particularly important for regions where employment is low and where depopulation is high.We also emphasized the importance of making the EFSI accessible to small and medium-sized enterprises, and we must, of course, ensure that they have easier access to financial support.Not only that, the consulting environment is also important, especially in technical terms.We also emphasized that the regional or sectoral approach is not at the forefront when it comes to the EFSI, and suggested enhanced cooperation with the Structural Funds.It is also important that we have data on the success of the implementation of the EFSI at all times, because only through evaluation can further improvements be made.Finally, let me say or emphasize that no effort at EU level will be enough if the Member States do not do everything in their power at national level.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the European Fund for Strategic Investments is certainly one of the political initiatives that have most characterized the current Commission. We can say that the Fund was successfully launched and has achieved concrete results, contributing to the relaunch of investments in Europe in a particularly difficult phase. The Internal Market Committee stressed the importance of the Fund guaranteeing greater additionality, being suited to supporting projects with high levels of risk and guaranteeing effective coordination with the other funds. The Fund can be an important tool for the better functioning of the single market and hence we underline the need to strengthen the third pillar to make the regulatory environment of the European Union more certain, homogeneous and favorable to investments. Projects in infrastructure, broadband, high-speed and digital platforms will have to be central to growing our economy and completing the single market.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the REGI commission believes that there are many positive aspects of EFSI, including the immobilized resources, the concrete support for many businesses and citizens in the territories, the reactivation of financing channels that had suffered the crisis causing the collapse investments in many parts of Europe. We have also put forward some proposals to improve it and to improve its impact on the real economy, for example through better synergy and more effective coordination with the Structural Funds. We believe that cohesion policy remains the main source of European investment and that it must be preserved and updated. However, cohesion policy works by programs, while EFSI works by projects. Therefore we believe that both will be able to achieve even more important results if it is done in such a way that they can work coherently together also through integrated plans, covering the whole European territory better. It is also important to remember the positive work of national investment banks which have greatly helped small and medium-sized enterprises, especially in technical and administrative support.

name: Jill EVANS
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – Madam President, the lack of awareness of EFSI is a problem. I know this very well from my constituency in Wales. It is a particular issue in the cultural sector, a sector which makes an increasing contribution to the economy. This report recognises that sectors such as social infrastructure, health and education are under-represented, receiving only 4% of approved EFSI financing. Culture and education represent a tiny percentage of that 4%. I am pleased that the Commission has already announced that it is frontloading the Creative Europe Guarantee Facility through EFSI. But concern was expressed in the Committee on Culture and Education that funding had been diverted away from the Horizon 2020 budget and, despite being assured that the money would still reach the university sector through EFSI, this has not happened. So that must be put right and the funding restored.

name: Brian HAYES
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mme President, today in Ireland a new Irish taoiseach was elected, Leo Varadka, and I want to wish him every success. One of the key issues he has highlighted for Ireland is this investment gap, which is so evident across many Member States but especially in Member States that have gone through a financial crisis – a gap of about 20% in Ireland. I want to agree with Commissioner Moscovici when he said very clearly that EFSI must be a success for every Member State in every part of our European Union, and we must do much more to promote the opportunities that EFSI can advance in economies right the way across the European Union. In Ireland, because of this investment gap, we need to do much more in drawing down funds and lending opportunities from EFSI. Last year about EUR 800 million was lent by the EIB to Ireland, but only a small percentage of that was in EFSI. I believe the Irish government should set a very clear target of being able to get lending opportunities of over EUR 5 billion over the course of the EFSI plan for new lending opportunities in Ireland, and I also think we should look again at how we use the pillar banks to obtain lending opportunities to small businesses, especially in Ireland. The key aspect of EFSI, its genius, is the idea that we can underscore and underwrite the risk factor that frequently does not allow investment to go into new business and to new lending opportunities. That is what makes EFSIs so useful, and that’s what we need to continue to support for jobs, investment and growth.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, it has been a year and a half since we approved this investment plan and I think it is a good time to take stock and, above all, to learn for the future and improve that second part of the plan, which we already have on top of the table. It cannot be denied that the plan is working and that 195 billion euros have been mobilized to date. But we cannot be dazzled by the quantity, but the quality is also important. And, in this case, there are many things that can be improved. For example, the true additionality of the projects, because, in certain cases, it is not entirely clear that this criterion has been fulfilled and we have seen some projects with the FEIE seal that leave us many doubts as to whether they could not have been financed in the markets. Complementarity with other funds must also be improved and we also have to clearly define the objectives so that there is no competition or duplication with other items such as Horizon 2020 or COSME. We also need greater transparency in the evaluation of projects, because sometimes we do not know why or why a project has not been financed. And this transparency would also allow us to assess the true additionality of the projects. It is also necessary to improve the geographical distribution and, above all, the sectoral distribution, promoting investments in social infrastructure. We have to ensure a better participation of national and regional promotion banks, because their knowledge on the ground is essential. We also have to adapt financial instruments to the needs of projects with higher risk financial products, such as subordinated financing or capital market instruments. And finally, the counseling center must be fully developed, because it is one of the pillars of the plan. You have to be proactive, you have to go out to find promoters and you have to influence in the sectors and in the countries where the use of this investment plan is really needed the most.In short, for the future, more, yes, but better, too.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President. I am pleased with the European Parliament's assessment of EFSI I, which is not only a success story, but also an indication of the shortcomings that have already been mentioned here. This geographical imbalance is obvious. The Commissioner mentioned that this situation has just changed and that the geographical imbalance is disappearing, but if we look at the projects recently approved by the EIB, especially in the field of infrastructure, you basically see in Eastern and Central Europe that public money replaces 100% of private money is meant, especially for transport projects, because there is not a single euro of private money coming into these projects - it is municipal money directly or indirectly. And finally, if we too idealize this EFSI approach in my opinion and try to replace the Cohesion Fund principle, the grant principle, with this EFSI principle in the next seven-year multiannual budget, we will make huge differences in the future of the European Union - bigger than they are now.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: for the ALDE Group. - Madam President! The common European cultural treasure includes the collection of stories known as A Thousand and One Nights, and it is available in all conceivable European languages. In that collection of fairy tales, we also find the magic formula "sesame open you". It was probably the intention that the EFSI Fund would appear as a "sesame open you" to remedy the investment deficit that has hit Europe. Now we do not really know; we see that the economy is going up, but we do not really know how it is connected, if it was EFSI that opened here or if it was something else. Here we would really need a more decent assessment. What bothers us a bit in this context is also the decision-making process. If you have a decision-making process that requires unanimity, you run the risk that the dumbest, most ignorant or laziest in the management team dictates the decisions. Therefore, I do not think that the decision-making process as it was designed was good. The second issue we have encountered is about risk assessment. Here, I think that part of the management team also ended up on bad roads. We know that German motorways can be very risky, but the riskiness does not depend on the investments but on how you drive there. But once again back to the story of A Thousand and One Nights. The story where the magic words "sesame open you" are, it is the story of Ali Baba and the 40 robbers, but now it is in the way that the number of robbers is not 40, the number of robbers is 28. Throughout this process, the member states have shown total inability to really understand how this is done. If they read the European cultural treasure, they would have a slightly better chance.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, cé go gcuirim fáilte roimh infheistíocht chun fostaíocht a chruthú, táim buartha go bhfuil an baol ann go mbeidh EFSI 2 chomh lochtach leis an gcéad cheann.  Anois agus sinn ag lorg geallúint ar tuairim is 10 mbilliún breise as an mbuiséad, cé hiad na daoine is mó a bhainfidh buntáiste as so? Cinnte tá na focail chearta á n-usáid: infheistíocht níos mó i dtíortha go bhfuil geárchéim eacnamaíochta acu, an plean a bheith trédhearcach, díriú ar na gnéithe sóisialta. Ach an bhfuil an baol ann nach bhfuil iontu ach focail? Cá bhfuil an luach sóisialta? Bhí deis againn difríocht a dhéanamh anso ach tá ag teip orainn an difríocht sin a dhéanamh.  Ag sodar i ndiaidh na hinfheistíochta príobháidí, ag freastal ar thíortha go bhfuil na hacmhainní acu chun an ciste a riaradh agus gan ach 4% don chiste ag dul i dtreo gnéithe sóisialta. Má táimid dáiríre i dtaobh aghaidh a thabhairt ar fhadbanna dífhostaíochta, éagothromaíocht shóisialta, géarchéimeanna tithíochta agus aire a thabhairt don ghlúin óg, caithfear treo nua ar fad a chur i bhfeidhm.  Ní féidir bheith ag díriú ar son an mhionlaigh amháin, beidh buiséad laghdaithe againn gan dabht tar éis Brexit agus an baol ann nach mbeidh sé inbhuanaithe. Tugadh gealltanas sa chéad EFSI go mbeadh infhestíocht ar fáil do chomharchumainn shóisialta; bhí sé seo mar aidhm agus do theip glan air.  Níl sé seo sásúil. Ní haon ionadh is dócha nach bhfuil aon mhuinín ag an pobal insan Eoraip seo ná i gcóras na mbanc.  Brabús do na bodairí móra agus an tsochaí ag díol go daor as.  Mar sin, cathain a bheidh Eoraip shóisialta á cruthú againn? Is é an nualiobrálachas atá i réim go soléir anso agus táim anois ag glaoch ar thacaíocht do na comharchumainn shóisialta sin arís.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, it is great to see that everyone now agrees that Europe has an investment gap and that we need an investment programme to work on that. That is very good. I am also happy that the Commission changed to a more realistic tone when we discussed the Juncker investment plan. A year ago it seemed that the Commission was selling it as a success, no matter what. It is good to see that there are still some issues that we need to solve, because if you look at the additionality, is EFSI really supporting those projects that otherwise would not have happened? If you look at the geographical imbalance, is it really going to those regions where there is an investment gap? If you look at the scoreboard use, is it really that those projects that score well on sustainability and jobs get the higher scores? It has all been very unclear until now. That is why we are now also working on improvement to the legislation: it is great to have a nice initiative report where the text is good, but in the end it is the legislation that counts, and we are in the trialogues. We are not there yet, so let us change it: EFSI is important, but needs to deliver better.

name: Marco VALLI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the EFSI program, on the other hand, has failed to fill the investment gap of the European Union, precisely because there is a very strong crisis in demand and this is linked to the constraints that have been introduced in our treaties, which should be revised. By the way, shortly there will be a discussion on the introduction, in the EU regulation, of the Fiscal Compact, and we should go against this introduction, precisely because it would encourage depressive austerity policies for the economy and depressive for investments. We need more public investment. Specifically, on the Juncker Plan, we analyze how many of the projects have had little impact from an environmental, economic and social point of view. I'm sorry, there is no additionality that the Commission has promised because, by going to the EFSI site, we see how many of the projects are in high carbon impact infrastructures, therefore refineries, gases and highways, and therefore I also wonder how the Greens can support this kind of projects.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, Commissioner, when we launched this project, in 2012, of an investment agency, we were concerned with solving the problem of the North-South disparity by creating money. Not through recession and unemployment, but by injecting real money into profitable projects. Allow the South to create more wealth so that it is not forced to restore its accounts by recession and unemployment. So, it will still be necessary to explain to me how, with 21 billion, we make 315 billion and how we solved the problem, which is absolutely essential today, of the growth of activity and employment in France, Spain, Italy, but also to what extent there has been a positive result? You have to set up an investment agency, you have to invest real money. So the $ 1.4 trillion with which we bought treasury bills should have been invested in the real economy instead.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: - Madam President, I think that congratulations are due today to two dear and distinguished colleagues, my friend José Manuel Fernandes and Mr Udo Bullmann, who I Mr Juncker, they can also be considered pillars of this important European Union investment venture, which I consider to be the largest investment venture since the founding of the European Union. For those who have doubts about this plan, I have one thing to say: the numbers are staggering. 190 billion, today, investments with a prospect of 500 billion in 2020, already 420,000 small and medium-sized enterprises with all that entails employment, growth, creating perspective and dynamism for the economy and many other positive actions that essentially embrace the dynamics that we were all looking for. I would expect the critics to hear another, different proposal. What is the other, different, envisioned investment plan for the European Union? I believe that this investment plan, at the moment, serves the goals and objectives set by the European Union as priorities. However, in the face of these numbers, I must also express my regret, because there was no opportunity and the possibility for all these millions to reach my small homeland, Cyprus, not a single euro. That is why we will invite the Commissioner, Mr. Moscovici, together with Mr. Katainen, to visit Cyprus and give the message that this investment plan will reach my homeland as well. They will be able to make investments there, which are so much needed.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the European Strategic Investment Fund has undoubtedly made a positive contribution to overcoming the serious investment deficit in the European economy. The socialist group that claimed this instrument naturally sees the progress made with satisfaction. But, at the end of the year and a half, it must be recognized that the Juncker Plan, despite recent improvements, is still far from needs and, above all, has been very poorly distributed. The available data also reveal a very high geographical concentration that benefits the most powerful economies and is further aggravating the divergence within the European Union. This is particularly true for infrastructure investment and innovation projects, which concentrate almost two thirds of investment support in three Member States. This is a very serious problem, which needs to be corrected by reviewing the rules, criteria and procedures. The Juncker Plan will only be a truly European project if it becomes an instrument in favor of convergence in Europe and, for that, much remains to be changed.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: - Madam President!One and a half years after the introduction of the EFSI, it can be said that the results of its operation are quite satisfactory.However, not quite so.Much greater emphasis should be placed on its complementarity with other European funds.This complementarity will give a chance for greater economic growth.It was also rightly pointed out in the motion for a resolution that the EFSI support is not uniform, therefore measures should be taken to eliminate these negative phenomena.This is especially important for less developed countries.I want to believe that in the countries of the so-called new Union, the EFSI will really help to implement projects with a higher degree of risk and will strengthen the EU cohesion policy and the process of equalizing economic opportunities between our countries and regions, which, after all, has been one of the priorities of the social and economic policy of the Union for years..

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the two rapporteurs, Mr Bullmann and Mr Fernandes, for the huge amount of work they have done. I hope we will be able to finish it in the next few weeks. I hope that the new EFSI projects will be chosen more on their merits than on their proximity to political power because we have had some experience in some countries where this was the case. We should not repeat this mistake as there is the possibility that EFSI will have a real impact on the economy. I am also happy to see that we are going into a more decentralised form of EFSI. I hope that we will continue the path of new associations in this spirit. I will conclude by saying that taking decisions closer to the people and the real economy seems to be the best way to make a real success of EFSI.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: - Madam President, the European Fund for Strategic Investments today represents the mirror of the contradictions within the European Union: a contradiction between the major objectives proclaimed by the European Commission and the Council and the lack of financial means to promote economic recovery and territorial cohesion. Thus, instead of a broad public investment plan designed to stimulate private investment, the Juncker Plan has moved forward, which does not respond to the real challenges of the present and the future. Nothing moves us against private investment. What we criticize is the promiscuity of these public-private partnerships where the private invests and keeps the profits, while the public assumes the eventual risks and losses. This plan is just over a year old. The available evaluations confirm the criticisms we made, either in the additional aspect or in the automatic geographical distribution. We are, therefore, facing an operation of direct transfer of public funds to the private sector, without any democratic control and whose repercussion on the investment deficit remains to be proven. In Portugal, in addition to the EIB loan of EUR 50 000 000 to the Lisbon Chamber, we have nothing tangible on the ground. To extend this plan and extend its scope to other areas such as defense is to repeat the same mistake. The problem will not be resolved by implementing yet another tight central direction in the choices of private investment. Rather, put our knowledge and experience at the service of a public investment plan, at the service of cohesion, development and the quality of life of the populations.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: - Madam President, the European Fund for Strategic Investments is a good idea whose implementation needs to be improved. In the report, which I think is a good report, we have indicated in what aspects, and one of them is the selection of projects, because we have come across some surprises, and I will give a concrete example. Bankia was chosen in October of last year to carry out a project to improve its digital platform for 50 million euros. Bankia, a financial entity that was chaired by former Minister Rato - for whom the Prosecutor's Office requested five years in prison yesterday for having hidden the bankruptcy of the entity from investors - which was rescued with public money at an estimated cost of 12 billion of euros, marked by the scandal of the «black» cards - with which its directors appropriated up to 2.7 million euros -, which has been condemned for the sale of preferential cards to an elderly woman with Alzheimer's. Do you think that an entity with such a recent past deserves the confidence of the EIB and the Commission? What deserves more public support? This is not the way to generate trust between European institutions and a citizenry that has seen how some banks, managed ineptly and even illegally, the crisis has been very cheap.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: - Madam President, the EFSI is the central element of the Commission's investment plan and although it is almost two years old and is bearing fruit, we should not be satisfied. I am confident that the targets set by the Commission - ambitious targets, without a doubt - will be met and that the € 500 billion planned in additional investment in the real economy will be mobilized by 2020. Until today, all kinds of projects have been financed - energy, transport, digital, agriculture, environment, energy efficiency, R & D & i, infrastructure ... - but I would like to highlight one of them. I am talking about the Canary Islands, an outermost region of Europe that needs all our support and also needs the FEIE to be able to adapt to its peculiarities, and I am talking about a project: the bus line - "guaguas" we say - of Las Palmas, a project approved and signed, it will create over a thousand jobs during the construction phase before it goes live in 2021. I think that is good news. All initiatives aimed at improving the impact of the EFSI, its transparency and complementarity with other European funds are welcome, but what is important is also its impact on SMEs, which are the main economic engine of the Union. On the other hand, I want to emphasize that, in order to fully exploit the potential of the EFSI Guarantee and avoid distortions in the markets, it is imperative that the EIB works actively and loyally with national promotional banks and private investors. Only in this way will the EFSI instrument serve as a true crowding instrument and thus avoid the phenomena of mere substitution of sources of financing in projects in favor of the EIB.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
