text: - Madam President, launched in 2016, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which we called for, aimed to mobilize up to 315 billion euros of investment in Europe by mid-2018. It is clear that, despite significant figures, the EFSI has not provided proof of its additionality. The nature of the projects supported calls out to the choices made and the windfall effect that a number of national authorities have been able to grasp. How to explain that Europe must invest more in order to restore confidence by supporting the sectors of the future? The needs are numerous: infrastructure, in particular broadband, the "carbon-free" economy, support for SMEs, support for research, the fight against youth unemployment, etc. So, let's go further and support these future projects with public investments. At the very least, let us ask the EIB to make an effort on the rates and loan conditions so that the EFSI labeled projects can be distinguished more, more clearly in any case, from the traditional actions of the EIB.

name: Sander LOONES
text: - The old continent, as the European Union is known, while we have everything in house to be at the top internationally. But for that we will have to reform more, save more, so that we can make sensible, smart investments with that money saved. I sincerely think that the European EFSI fund can help. The ambition is very high: 315 billion euros in additional investments in innovation, in infrastructure and in SMEs over three years. Today we are evaluating the first phase of that EFSI fund. And what is the conclusion? We get our grades. This is a good business. On the other hand, we note that the quality of the investments must be improved. Because EFSI should not do what the ordinary bank or an ordinary investment fund can do. We can expect more from EFSI, so that we can invest in more innovation, in quality projects, in more risky projects. That should be our priority: investing in excellence, putting Europe back on the map, not opting for leveling down, but opting for real progress.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: - Madam President, the European Strategic Investment Fund, with its efficient operation and its time extension, contributes to the coverage of the investment deficit at European level but also to Greece, which has the biggest problem. Investments in Greece accounted for 11.4% of Gross Domestic Product in 2016, while in the euro area countries the corresponding percentage was on average 20.1% of Gross Domestic Product. This means that, in order for the level of investment in Greece to rise to the level of the euro area average, they must increase by 15-16 billion euros per year. Until this deficit is covered, the views of the International Monetary Fund will prevail, according to which the Greek economy is almost doomed and the European partners will never get back the money they lent to the Greek State. So instead of wondering who will ultimately owe the debt of the Greek State, we would do well to turn to the search for a comprehensive investment strategy that will free the productive forces of Greece from over-taxation and mobilize foreign investment and additional European funding in its favor. Greek economy. It is the safest way to achieve stable and dynamic growth, quality jobs and debt sustainability of the Greek State.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, you said that EFSI is a project that has had some success, especially in terms of the number of projects that Europe has been able to support. But it is a stimulus package that falls far short of all of our expectations. The quality of the projects selected shows significant shortcomings and shortcomings. I think in particular that we must move in the direction of a better geographical distribution of projects, their sectoral diversification, a strengthening of the transparency of the selection procedure and own financing, without drawing on the budgets of other initiatives. I would like, Commissioner, to really stress the importance of public, productive investments directed towards the real economy. I think that it is really a necessity for the authorities, in particular the local authorities, to be able to invest in projects which are productive, such as insulation works of public buildings, because the consequences are positive for the economy, generating local jobs which cannot be relocated and in line with environmental criteria. Commissioner, I would like to remind you forcefully that the golden rule is not a social project, it is a working method. As the treaties provide, I think it is high time to rework on the flexibility of accounting for our public investments if we want to recreate growth and jobs.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! In the debate on the implementation of EFSI after one and a half years of its operation, it should be emphasized that the estimated amount of investments to be launched is around EUR 160 billion, i.e. over 50% of the total amount of investments to be launched by 2018. Unfortunately, the distribution of investments financed under the EFSI. By the end of 2016, as much as 90% of the funds were allocated to the old "fifteen", and only 10% to the thirteen new member states. For example, in the area of ​​infrastructure and innovation, three countries, Great Britain, Italy and Spain, were even monopolists in using EFSI funds, receiving nearly 65% ​​of them. In turn, in the area of ​​small and medium-sized enterprises, Italy, France and Germany received over 36% of the funds. Realizing that wealthier Member States are more easily accessed from market-based funds such as the EFSI, I want to emphasize that in the coming years this proportion of EFSI use must be sharply shifted to the thirteen new Member States.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, EFSI is without any doubt a successful programme. It is on track to achieve its ambitious target of generating an additional EUR 315 billion of investment in the EU Member States. But now let us use this debate also to reflect on what we can improve and how we can make EFSI even better in the future. One element which we can improve is the geographical distribution. We said at the very beginning that we do not want to allocate certain quotas to Member States and I think that that was the correct approach. We should not change that but should continue to finance the best projects irrespective of the country they come from. However, we are seeing that 73% of the projects are concentrated in five Member States, particularly countries in which the investment gap is below average. So what we should do is advise: use the advisor we have to help assist those countries that have not yet benefited from EFSI and use this advisor we have to help those countries in particular which do not have developed financial markets to create a level playing field so that all 28 Member States can benefit equally from this project. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- Madam President, Mr President!Indeed, you have already pointed out before you that there is a geographical inequality in this whole division, and I also agree with you that we need efficiency and good projects.But do you also notice that disparities are not only at the east-west, north-south level, but also between rural and urban areas, and that rural areas have virtually fallen out of it?

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: blue-card answer. – So what we should do to help these countries and these regions is promote EFSI, not only in the urban areas but also in the rural areas. Encourage the advisor we have, the EIB, to provide assistance to people who want to write projects, and create also a level playing field in terms of financial market developments, particularly to assist the countries which do not have promotional banks in the establishment of promotional banks. This will help create a level playing field and give all beneficiaries equal opportunities and equal chances vis à vis EFSI.

name: Eva KAILI
text: – Madam President, EFSI was primarily designed to help us bridge the investment gap of Europe, but it has not worked as expected. Being a supply side instrument, we understand that it’s difficult to create its own demand, especially in the structure and innovation window because it was not included in incentives like that for the creation of this demand and the facts are clear: very few of the projects were additional; the diverse risk premium—the pricing of the programme caused more disincentives than incentives to apply for it; and lack of institutional framework to enable blending with other EU financial resources made it more difficult for the Member States that need it more. Now we are looking forward to address and fix this problem with the trialogues of EFSI 2, but the ambitious elements that could incentivise the creation of demand are still not enough: 91% of VS 9, 15 Member States VS 13. It doesn’t seem that it will change dramatically. I do believe that there is urgent need for economic relevance in the EU and EFSIs are potentially headed toward the correct direction. But its structure as designed does not address the realities and the lesson is that for EFSI 1 supply side mechanisms with weak demand will not produce significant results.  Congratulations to Mr Bullmann and Mr Fernandes for the efforts made to change this Direction.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! We have to say that the EFSI is one and a half years old. And in these one and a half years, he has pushed 194 billion euros in investments, from which 425,000 and more small and medium-sized companies benefit. We evaluated it after these one and a half years and said: We have to extend it to 2020, and we need more money, more investment that is being initiated, and we are increasing it to 500 billion. And we recognized the weaknesses and said: The EFSI has to enter the high-risk Champions League. He must expand the promotional banks of the other Member States. Everything that is said here is part of our trialogue. Today we are discussing the own-initiative report in response to the evaluation, but we also have a legislative report, which is our work program for the negotiations, where we can improve it. We do not say: more of the same, but longer, but rather: improve, but also extend, because it has done good. But the EFSI is not there alone to fill the investment gap. We have to continue structural reforms. We have to strengthen the internal market. We need to deepen economic and monetary union. We need a stronger investment climate in Europe and we need innovation because we have not yet closed the gap - but we are on the right track.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, EFSI, the Juncker Plan, entered into force in 2015, by the end of 2016 it had already granted guarantees for € 21.5 billion and in May this year it has already reached 200 billion euros. It is not just cold figures but infrastructure, modern railway networks, fiber optics in our homes, more environmentally friendly buildings, new technologies. We have done a lot, but it is still not enough. With the renewal of the Plan we must commit ourselves even more. We must ensure real additionality, making sure that the eligibility criteria of projects are truly geared towards the riskiest but useful investments for citizens, facilitating access to EFSI tools for small and medium-sized enterprises in particular, in particular by supporting the he excellent work that has been done up to now by national promotional banks and, finally, also allowing third countries to intervene, if there are clear advantages in terms of efficiency or economy of scale. In closing, allow me a note of merit to my country, Italy, which with 3.7 billion investment is the first beneficiary country of the EFSI guarantee, naturally a pride but also a responsibility for our government.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: – Madam President, I think that the EFSI and the whole Juncker Plan came at the right moment and that we are seeing good results. Money is needed in the real economy. Let me make three remarks. First, we should have a better guarantee and a better look at the additionality. Financing roads in France, Germany or the Netherlands is not high risk, so what are we doing? Second, on the geographical balance: of course, it cannot be Europe that is standing on one leg in the more developed country; the winner takes all. There we have to support these countries so they have a better capacity to take it up, quality to make projects and investment banks, as my colleague has said.  Third, as the coordinator of the regional committee in the PPE Group, I think we should move much more to combining the funds from the regional funds, the structural investment funds, and the EFSI. This would not mean blending, putting them all together in a big blender, but having these shared management funds in the Member States to give them – this is already possible in the regulations – the possibility of having a higher risk and more loans and guarantees in the real economy. We now have the Omnibus. We come with this simplification and I see a big future for the EFSI Fund. It is a compliment to the rapporteurs and also to the Commission.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Madam President, the Fernandes-Bullmann report highlights major concerns that EFSI does not provide complementary financing for high-risk projects and that small projects are deterred from applying for EFSI financing. There is no procedure for tackling conflicts of interest, while there are cases where the EIB has been pushing to support projects structured using firms in tax havens! No wonder then that the EU 15 have received 91% of EFSI support while the EU 13 only 9%.  Article 7(2) of the EFSI Regulation stipulates that it is the steering board that shall determine the strategic orientation of EFSI, its operating policy, procedures and rules and the risk profile of EFSI. Under the same Article, three out of the four board members are appointed by the Commission. Therefore, what are the urgent and specific measures that the Commission shall undertake in order to gain the trust of Parliament and the Council to grant authorisation for EFSI 2?

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - The European Fund for Strategic Investments has been in existence for 1.5 years and yet can be said to be successful in at least some regional areas.It can be said that we already see its shortcomings.Predecessors listed here a number of concrete proposals for its improvement.I would like to remind you of the need for greater transparency, better targeting of the fund and also better management.There are some doubts about conflicts of interest in the governing bodies, and that is very bad.There has been a lot of talk about regional disproportion.I would even say that this is a marginalization, if 13 countries draw only 9% of the total fund, then I would say that it is directly a marginalization of certain areas.I deliberately looked at what it looks like in the Czech Republic, where it is about extending the guarantees of two banks for small and medium-sized enterprises.I think the conclusion is clear.It is good not only to continue, but to improve.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the EFSI has been active for a year and a half, sufficient time for a first assessment and to take the indications recorded so far in order to improve the methods of implementing the Plan. The main problems appear to be the differentiation of EFSI's funding objectives and conditions from other similar funding sources, which effectively leads to competition with other funds. There is real added value to the complementary use of EFSI and ESI Funds, but regulatory issues complicate this complementarity. The geographical distribution of the projects presents limits of uniformity, which must be remedied. Likewise, the serious difficulty in creating investment platforms must be overcome, where the need to finance smaller projects does not receive adequate responses. Finally, efforts in the context of the European Investment Advisory Hub should be stepped up to provide adequate technical assistance and to strengthen EFSI communication so that cooperation can also be improved.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Dear President, the primary purpose of the European Fund for Strategic Investments was to guarantee additionality by responding to market failures or insufficient levels of investment. I must admit that it has not been clear to me from day one how the Commission intends to ensure that public investment enhances the impact of private if it has not previously provided a more favorable climate for private investment. As is usually the case when a large injection of taxpayers' money into the economy is planned, it has happened that many projects could have been financed without Union guarantees and that decision-making is rather non-transparent. The geographical distribution of investments is also worrying, as by the end of June 2016, as much as 91% of funds had been allocated to EU-15 countries. Such things undermine the credibility of the Union and its programs because they create the impression that some members profit at the expense of others. If we intend to avoid such interpretations and raise the reputation of the European Union, the implementation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments must be much better.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, the infamous € 315 billion three-year plan lacks transparency. There is a lack of accountability, it is inefficient, it does not cover investment gaps. The European Investment Bank does not provide adequate access to information on this project. There is a complete lack of statistical data and comparable amounts of financial efficiency of all projects that have been funded so far. The risk of overestimating the multiplier effect is not just visible, but proves to be real. It is pointed out by the Court of Auditors itself, which emphasizes that the stated objectives and results are projections that have not been confirmed by tangible, specific, clear and up-to-date data. The Union's top five economies have basically benefited from this plan, thus creating further disparities and inequalities between Member States. In conclusion, this is not an investment plan, it is a plan to deceive and manipulate European citizens.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Madam President! The European Fund for Strategic Investments is undoubtedly a very important tool that has a real impact on increasing investments in Europe. Although its effectiveness cannot be fully assessed yet, the current data allows for optimism while showing areas for improvement. First, it is important that this fund is used by all Member States. Therefore, it is necessary to consider how to support countries that have not used it so far or have used it to a small extent. Secondly, it is important that this fund works in synergy with the European Structural and Investment Funds to ensure financing facilitation. Third, it should be remembered that the aim of the Juncker Fund is to support risk investments that would not be possible without this funding. Therefore, one should avoid supporting projects which, by their nature, should receive support from other EU programs and funds.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Ms. President!Dear Commissioner,Here in the debate, we can hear different figures on how the utilization is distributed in terms of the strategic development fund, and I have already mentioned in a question that rural, rural areas are indeed at a disadvantage, they are not very caught up in this opportunity.At the same time, I would like to draw attention to this aspect once again because, just today, the European Parliament has once again voted in favor of a number of austerity restrictions, which are otherwise justified from an environmental point of view, which will put rural, agricultural areas in an even more difficult regulatory environment.I think this EFSI is supposed to offset this.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Madam President, EFSI is fulfilling its goal, which is to raise the level of investment.However, we want more than that.We want growth, development and high growth and development rates in the European Union and new jobs.For that, we need two other pillars of the investment plan for Europe.The first pillar is to identify good and quality projects that are innovative and risky.Are we funding such projects at the moment and have we found just those for EFSI funding?And the second pillar that still remains is strengthening the single market and creating a favorable environment for our entrepreneurs and investors.There is no way the European Commission can do it alone.This requires coordination and work with the Member States, and I therefore call on the Commission to strengthen its ties and links with the Member States in order to make the investment plan for Europe a reality.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs from the outset. They made an exact x-ray of what happened to EFSI 1 and I want to remind you here, as Mr Bullmann said, that it was not good enough, I said from the beginning, the criterion "first come, first served". Let's be very clear, let's not steal our hats: rural areas, poorer areas, do not have the administrative capacity to write projects and will never be the first. I believe that we must use other criteria if we really want this strategic investment fund to lead to social cohesion and the development of poorer areas. That is why I think the rapporteurs have done very well. SMEs are not enough, especially small businesses. I lead the intergroup and I find that SMEs complain because they have no guarantee that they can reach this fund. I think that EFSI 2 has the advantage that it has the experience of EFSI 1 and we can correct and I rely a lot on rapporteurs and the Commission, obviously, for the correction (the chairman interrupted the speaker).

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, thank you for the numerous comments, questions and remarks. EFSI might not be perfect. It certainly is not a magical weapon that can, on its own, close the investment gap we suffer from: create growth and jobs and put our economy on a sustainable and inclusive track. But our debate and the reports prove that it is a valuable instrument in pursuit of this aim. I hear all the expectations in terms of job creation, ambition as regards macroeconomic impact, vigilance in the face of potential crowding out of other investors and fears of cannibalisations of other EU instruments. I understand them all and I share this impatience. But let us discuss on the basis of actual results, and focus on positive messages. EFSI delivers, and we are in the midst of negotiations to extend it and also to make it better. In this regard, I would like to answer a few questions or remarks. I was asked if EFSI was supposed to replace cohesion funds. The answer is no. We attach great importance to cohesion policy. EFSI and Cohesion Policy can coexist and can be mutually reinforcing. Both share a goal, which is to increase the level of investment for the benefit of growth and jobs. It is about developing synergies between EFSI and the cohesion funds, in no way opposing or excluding them. Several remarks were made on this or that country and on the way in which they are served by the cohesion funds. In this regard, of course, we have statistics. I will simply mention two countries. First, Cyprus. It is true that for a long time there were no projects, but an agreement was signed in December 2016 on the SME component between the European Investment Fund and the RCB bank. With regard to Greece, there were several interventions. For a long time, it is true that there was no project in Greece. A hub team has been sent to assist in structuring projects and today Greece, listen up, is the eighth country to benefit from EFSI funds. Therefore, there has been more than a catch-up in this matter. I take this opportunity to say how much I hope that, tomorrow, at the Eurogroup to be held in Luxembourg, an agreement will be found for Greece which will make it possible to disburse the funds provided for under the third program and to draw up the parameters for measuring medium-term debts, all of this against the backdrop of a policy that should favor growth and employment in this country. Because after the crisis, after the efforts, it is time for the Greek people to see the result of everything they have agreed to. My colleague from the Commission, Valdis Dombrovskis, made this presentation alongside me yesterday at the College, and the Commission knows that it has already done a lot for growth and jobs in Greece. We also want to do more through EFSI. More must be done. This is fundamental. My colleague Katainen and I are ready to come back to this Parliament in perhaps a month, before the summer break, to discuss the outcome of the trilogues. President Juncker introduced EFSI 2 in his State of the Union address in September 2016. You can be sure that in one year we have already delivered results in this direction for the benefit of our European citizens. Therefore, my message is simple: the EFSI is an instrument which can be improved, criticized, like any instrument, but which is also remarkable. So let's perfect it together. That’s what we can do, and it’s all the usefulness of our discussions today.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: reporter. - Madam President, Commissioner, Dear Colleagues, it is clear that the European Fund for Strategic Investments will not, cannot, replace cohesion policy and therefore has no geographic quotas. The European Fund for Strategic Investments requires proactivity from its beneficiaries and proactivity from the territories. This does not mean that one should not look for territorial cohesion, geographic cohesion, the distribution of projects. It should be looked for. And, therefore, Parliament insists on the advisory hub, on the advisory platform to help the structuring of projects and higher quality projects, to help the creation of platforms, to also contribute to complementarity, which we want to exist and which between this Fund and the cohesion policy funds. We insist on the advisory hub, on this advisory platform so that this objective is achieved. It is clear that this European Strategic Investment Fund has contributed to employment; it has also contributed to companies and, above all, small and medium-sized companies, and also to entrepreneurship, to innovation, to the strengthening of the European Union's competitiveness. It is also clear that the additional aspect needs to be reinforced and the selection of projects must also take into account the place where the project will be carried out. The same project does not have the same economic impact in terms of job creation in a less developed or more developed region. That is why it is necessary for less developed regions to pay special attention, although, I insist, this Fund can never be confused with cohesion policy.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President! I would like to thank my colleagues for what I think was an extremely committed discussion. The rapporteurs have listened; we take the suggestions with us. But I can also say: We feel confirmed in the direction in which we want to move forward in order to make EFSI better. I ask the Commission - which I perceive that it does not really see the problems any differently than we do - to understand. I ask - I turn to the Council - to understand that we praise EFSI where good has been achieved, but that we also identify the problems where we see them. And one more thing: Of course, we don't just want to name the problems, we want to fix them. And that's why we rely on the good cooperation with both institutions so that we can quickly come to an end with the current legislation in order to make EFSI-2 even better. I would like to turn to the Council again because that is one of the issues we are debating at the moment. I believe that Commissioner Moscovici is absolutely right when he speaks of EFSI-3 - the great challenge we are facing now to think beyond the phase we are currently planning. It is of course an ongoing task to make ourselves internationally competitive in terms of a sustainable economy. Still, we have to argue about this thought. And I would ask you to take a very close look - to name just one major competitor - what the Chinese sovereign wealth funds are doing in the Mediterranean region or what they are doing with their major Silk Road project. Is it really the case - and I am addressing the Council - that our Member States do not understand what the hour has come and that we must finally come to an agreement, particularly with regard to medium-term financial planning, that we are setting the course now? I hope we find the strength for it. The European Parliament will do whatever it takes to go in that direction.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 15 June 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. - The European Fund for Strategic Investments is at the heart of the Investment Plan for Europe, as one of the instruments designed to deal with the consequences of the economic crisis. One of its manifestations was a significant decrease in the rate of investment, which was the so-called Juncker package to prevent. The original intention was that it should help mainly projects with great innovation potential, which, however, are still relatively risky for investment. It was also to focus in particular on small and medium-sized enterprises as a driving force in the European economy. The result was to be a restoration of confidence in the market and a consequent multiplication of the funds thus invested. After a year and a half of operation, it turns out that there is considerable interest in this money. However, they do not always focus on strictly innovation-oriented projects that respond to the future development needs of the European economy. In addition, the distribution of these resources within the European Union is relatively uneven. The vast majority of them have so far headed to the so-called old Member States. In the future, these Member States will have to be much more active in order to obtain the funding in question. Support for small and medium-sized enterprises is vital for the advancement and competitiveness of the European economy, especially in the face of ever-increasing levels of international competition.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: in writing. - The priority of our work in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee on the opinion on the European Fund for Strategic Investments was that the co-financed projects should generate new jobs. For this purpose, we applied for appropriate monitoring of the impact on the labor market. Unfortunately, despite the fact that one and a half years have passed since the project was launched, we do not have any information on how many new jobs have been created as a result of investments supported by its funds. The European Commission did not provide this information in its report, as it does not collect such data at all. Of course, this does not mean that new jobs are not being created. The very fact that a significant part of the funds from the fund is directed to the sector of small and medium-sized enterprises allows us to assume that they contribute to the creation of new jobs. Nevertheless, it is currently difficult to estimate the impact of the Fund on employment in Europe. Therefore, I appeal to the European Commission to collect such data! I would also like to highlight another important point. When analyzing the use of the Fund, we can see a clear geographic concentration of investments. Half of the Member States received more than 90% of the money invested. It is worth considering and analyzing whether the money actually goes where it is most needed.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: in writing. - The performance of the EFSI is satisfactory. However, we must ensure that we can take full advantage of this instrument and improve its operation. For better use of the EFSI, I believe that great emphasis must be placed on its complementarity both with the European Structural and Investment Funds and with other EU funds. Such synergy would allow for more efficient development of sustainable economic growth. I would also like to highlight the high territorial concentration of funds disbursed so far. We should understand the reasons for this allocation and make it possible for less developed regions to be better able to use EFSI funds in the future. Therefore, efforts should be made to increase the expertise and technical assistance for these regions. In particular, emphasis must be placed on the efficient operation of the European Investment Advisory Centers, which should also benefit from local knowledge through cooperation with relevant national institutions. I am of the opinion that the above-mentioned issues will help to use funds more efficiently, and will also help to introduce both high-risk and innovative projects in countries that have so far used less EFSI funds. Such activities will also help to achieve one of the overarching goals of the EU policy, which is equalization of economic opportunities between countries.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: In written form. - In the first almost 2 years of its establishment, the European Fund for Strategic Investments has achieved tangible results, but the geographical distribution of projects remains a cause for serious concern. Due to their less developed financial markets, lack of administrative capacity, and experience in implementing financial instruments, some countries continue to face difficulties in participating in the EFSI. Only about 10% of the investments mobilized under the fund are in Central and Eastern Europe. This is particularly worrying, given that most less developed regions are located in this part of the EU. It is therefore crucial that, in the continuation of the EFSI, measures are taken to geographically diversify projects so as to ensure complementarity with traditional cohesion policy instruments. The EFSI must help to overcome regional disparities and not run counter to the efforts of some countries to catch up. In this regard, it is the right step to change the eligibility criteria so that even smaller projects can benefit from funding. Opportunities to provide technical assistance and advisory services in project preparation and structuring also need to be improved, especially in countries with less developed financial markets.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - I invite my colleagues, I invite you to vote in favor of this report, which calls for a Commission initiative to control, at European Union level, foreign investments in strategic European sectors, all the more so when the countries from which these investments originate limit or prevent access to their market for European investors. In my view, it is essential for the European Union to identify the key sectors and industries that it must protect and for which it must, if necessary, prevent targeted acquisitions by foreign investors. At present, and I have often relayed it, there is an obvious problem of reciprocity (especially with China) and major risks for Europe, because strategic sectors such as robotics, defense, high technologies and the airport sector are targeted. The risk is the transfer of technology to a third country which ultimately threatens European interests. More than ever, we need a strategic industrial policy: we must protect our key industries.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: written. - The report is exaggerated in considering the EFSI to be a success, as the evidence is mainly the use of money. The report shows that the EFSI is crowding out other sources of EU funding because it is more favorable to companies. The report suggests that classification as a specific activity of the European Investment Bank would guarantee additionality. At the same time, however, the report states that not all projects have been, at least in part, genuinely complementary. Assessing the effects on employment and economic growth is generally difficult, as they require information on complementarity and externalities. In the future, the EFSI will not compete but co-operate with other EU funding sources. As a result, it is even more difficult to assess the impact on economic and employment growth, as the potential impact of individual funds cannot be targeted. In this way, we cannot see a possible success or that the same results could have been achieved with existing financial instruments.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: in writing. - The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) was established to mobilize EUR 315 billion in investments in the European Union, including by providing guarantees for financing - economically and socially important - projects carried out mainly by the private sector. After one and a half years of operation of the Fund, its activity is generally assessed well, although there are also opinions that instead of promoting innovative projects, EU guarantees were used to promote also those projects for which there are doubts as to their compliance with the established selection criteria. Bearing this in mind, I believe that in the future more care should be taken to ensure that investments made with the support of the Fund lead to employment growth, as well as generate sustainable economic growth and contribute to the deepening of economic, territorial and social cohesion. Moreover, attaching great importance to the development of investments within the European Union - I believe that regardless of how high the EU budget will be in the 2021-2027 perspective, strategic investments should be particularly protected.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the debate on Council and Commission statements on foreign investments in strategic sectors (EU actions) (2017/2730 (RSP)).

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, my intervention will be brief, given that the subject of foreign investment in strategic sectors has not been discussed as such in the Council yet. Consequently, there is no Council position. Indeed, there is not even a Commission proposal on the table. That being said, I would like to underline that Europe is open for business and that foreign investment remains a key principle for the EU. We need investment as an engine for growth and job creation. We encourage others to invest in the European Union and our investors are very successful abroad. But clearly in the last year some reasons for concern have emerged and these are related to the sharp increase in foreign acquisitions of significant value in key EU economic sectors. I am thinking of industrial machinery and equipment, ICT, utilities, infrastructure or energy. The surge in foreign investment appears less as a result of market forces and more as a consequence of strategic industrial policies by other states. This could compromise fair competitive conditions across the EU and put into question our access to technological know—how. As such, these acquisitions could be deemed not to be in the EU’s long-term interest. In this regard, we welcome the debate launched in February by the Economic Ministers of Germany, France and Italy, who in their joint letter to EU Commissioner for trade, Cecilia Malmström, outlined their concern that partner countries do not match the EU level of market openness when it comes to investment and public procurement. They pointed out that the EU was losing its advantage in technological expertise due to mass acquisitions from non-EU investors. The three countries asked for more scope to investigate individual takeovers and, where applicable, to block them. We have also noted with interest the proposal for a Union act on the screening of foreign investment in strategic sectors, which was tabled by Mr Weber, Mr Caspary and eight other EPP Members in March this year, calling for intervention at EU level when direct investments by third countries do not comply with market rules or are facilitated by state subsidies, resulting in a likely market disturbance.  Finally, the Commission, in its reflection paper on harnessing globalisation, also noted the concerns recently voiced about foreign investors, notably state-owned enterprises, taking over European companies with key technologies for strategic reasons. In its reflection paper the Commission further underscored that EU investors often do not enjoy the same rights to invest in the country from which the investment originated. It is very clear that the way we address investments in strategic sectors will require necessary attention in the future. In the Council we will follow the developments on this subject with interest and remain ready to carefully examine any proposal the Commission puts on the table.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start by stating the obvious: investment is a major source of growth in the EU and a contributor to economic and social prosperity. We have always welcomed foreign direct investment and openness to investment has always been a key principle of our trade policy. As a consequence, the US is the most favourable framework for investment in the world and is a major promoter of open, transparent and predictable conditions for investment worldwide. This policy has positioned the EU as the biggest source destination of foreign direct investment in the world.  The Commission however, is also well aware of the growing concerns regarding the perceived rapid increase of acquisitions of European strategic and high-tech companies by companies originating from countries that do not share the same open framework for investments as we do, which maintain important restrictions on foreign investment. The Commission in its recent reflection paper that you mentioned, Madam President, on harnessing globalisation, noted that concerns have recently been voiced about foreign investors, notably state-owned enterprises, taking over European companies with key technologies for strategic reasons. EU investors often do not enjoy the same rights to invest in the country from which the investment originates. These concerns need careful analysis and appropriate action.  We are therefore assessing the real scope of this phenomenon, and trying to be clear about what the real issues are. This may represent a new challenge to EU policy and we need to assess whether we have the appropriate tools to respond to it. This may be particularly relevant at a time when the Commission is proposing a reflection on foreign investment in sensitive defence-related technologies and the opportunity to introduce some control.  The Commission is convinced that an important part of the solution to some of the concerns related to the lack of a level playing field for EU investments abroad should come from our trade agenda, which aims at securing the best possible market access and transparent and non-discriminatory conditions for new investors operating in third countries; but the nature of the concerns requires also to look wider and deeper. Therefore, we are currently analysing the effectiveness of EU policies on foreign direct investment in close coordination with Member States, which are maintaining their own foreign investments screening measures to see if the current framework provides sufficient flexibility to respond to the challenges we are facing. In taking this word forward, we should avoid as much as possible to introduce unnecessary barriers to trade and investment, bearing in mind that the EU economy continues to need more investment, both domestic—that’s the previous debate—and foreign. The Commission is ready to engage in further discussions with Parliament on these important issues. It goes without saying that such a discussion will need to take due account of the legal framework established under the EU Treaties and under the EU and Member State international commitments.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! "China wants to keep its door wide open and not close it," said Chinese President Xi Jinping in Davos earlier this year. Unfortunately, the reality is different. European investments in China are falling - from ten billion euros in 2015 to just eight billion euros in 2016. We have big problems there. And China is investing more and more in the European Union - last year 35 billion euros, almost half of which in our key technologies. And they are mercilessly implementing their “China manufacturing 2025” strategy. On the other hand, there are many problems for European investors in China: Restricted, to name just a few examples, is the question of the production of automobiles and motorcycles, valuable metals, banks, insurance companies, telecommunications; Investments in rare earths, in publishing, etc. are prohibited. We want to change that, and we have to play harder there. We are convinced that open markets are needed, but they also need clear rules. Through our initiative, which we introduced, we hope that we as the European Union will identify key industries in which we want to protect ourselves, and that we will then have a way of preventing targeted acquisitions there. We have to give our industry a chance for the future, which is why I appeal to the Chinese President: create fair conditions, otherwise we have to act! And so that he can understand it, in Chinese: [Chinese language recorded on tape].

name: Bernd LANGE
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, to the Presidency! Yes, we do indeed need investments in Europe - we just discussed this in the previous item on the agenda - and of course investments from all possible partner countries on earth - just as we invest in other countries. And that's why we have to emphasize the principle of reciprocity, the equivalence of conditions, in our negotiations. I have absolutely no problem in saying that if there are restrictions on our investments in a country, then we will also tackle the same restrictions in Europe. But I cannot imagine that we are going in the direction of protectionism and generally questioning investment activities because it ultimately depends on how investors behave. Do they adhere to reasonable terms? Do you comply with employee rights? Do you adhere to environmental standards? That must be the criterion as to whether we can approve investments or not. In this respect, I assume that we should be guided by the principle of equivalence of the rules and that we should be able to respond to restrictions on our investments abroad with the same restrictions so that we have a fair playing field here without going in a direction of protection from the outset .

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, mar thoradh ar Bhreatamach, is léir go bhfuil tréimhse neamhchinnteachta maidir leis an ngeilleagar i ngach Ballstát os ár gcomhair amach.  Tá sé ríthabhachtach dúinn ar fad a chinntiú go bhfuil cobhsaíocht neartaithe maidir leis an ngeilleagar go háirithe sa mheántéarma. Cé nach mbeinnse ná mo pháirtí sásta, bearta eacnamíochta cosantach a chur chun cinn, tá sé tábhachtach go mbeadh grinnscrúdú fairsing deánta ar aon mholadh chun infheistíocht eachtrach a chur i gcrích. Caithfidh sé bheith mar aidhm na hinfheistíochtaí seo a bheith réadúil le buntaistí tugtha don earnáil phoiblí agus nach mbeadh stát coigríche ábalta a straitéisí cosantacha a chur i bhfeidhm anseo.  Caithfidh tionscail straitéiseacha, cumhacht an eolais agus leibhéil oideachais fhorbartha fanacht faoi smacht na mBallstát. Caithfidh siad fanacht faoi smacht na mBallstát tríd an earnáil straitéiseach atá ann faoi láthair chun cinntiú a dhéanamh ar fhorbairt  teicneolaíochta, fás inár ngeilleagair agus, mar thoradh air sin, níos mó poist mhaithe a chruthú.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, dear colleagues! Let me start with the facts. The fact is that foreign state corporations are investing in strategically interesting industries here in Europe because they are fed with subsidies at home to an extent that is illegal for European companies here in Europe. The fact is that our open investment landscapes are used by countries that are increasingly sealing off certain markets at home from European investments. The fact is, we don't look closely enough when buying up crown jewels of European high-tech development, developed with research money from tax revenues, and the fact is that many of these investments are far less economic than geostrategic. That is why we need a European strategic industrial policy that says: We want to protect European industry without practicing protectionism. And for that we need a plan from the Commission by the end of this year. Mr Moscovici, it is not enough if you are ready to discuss - you have to be ready to act!

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: - Madam President, Europe has become a vast investment supermarket, where our companies, strategic and others, are self-service for predatory foreign interests. At the request of certain Member States, the Commission is preparing measures to control these investments, possibly blocking them on the grounds of economic security or damage to economic prosperity. Unfortunately, it is not certain that the treaties allow it to do so, since they leave it to States, fortunately, to define and defend their essential interests. Moreover, assuming that these concepts can be defined at European level, should the Commission be entrusted with the monitoring of these investments, which is incapable, in particular vis-à-vis China, of guaranteeing reciprocity, to denounce the unfair competition of ultra-subsidized companies or even to quickly take strong commercial protection measures? I have no more confidence, it must be said and admitted, in my country, where Mr. Macron calls for new skills, but when he was Minister of the Economy, he never used the possibilities of the Montebourg decree. . He let General Electric take over Alstom and Finnish Nokia from Alcatel-Lucent.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: - Madam President, Madam Minister, Commissioner, foreign investments contribute to our growth and we must continue to attract them. But, conversely, in some third countries, our entrepreneurs regularly encounter obstacles that prevent them from developing. This is why it is crucial that reciprocity finally becomes the backbone of European Union investment policy. We must get our foreign partners to open up their market to us as well. Finally, we must above all respond to a worrying situation: certain foreign investors may, by entering the European market, take control of strategic sectors, in particular security or energy. Europe must quickly equip itself with effective tools in order to be able to control this type of investment. It is respect for fair rules by all that will allow fair and fair trade. We therefore call on the Commission to act and make a proposal quickly.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: - Madam President, this debate is absolutely fundamental, and we are obliged, as has just been done just now, to start with concrete examples. Concretely, in four years, Chinese investments in Europe have multiplied by five and, at the same time, the Chinese authorities are imposing increasingly strict conditions to prevent European operators from entering their market. Yes, of course, there is a problem of reciprocity and major risks for Europe, because our strategic sectors, such as robotics, defense, high technologies and the airport sector, are targeted. The risk is the transfer of technology to a foreign state which, in the long term, obviously threatens our European interests. Some Member States have taken action. I am thinking in particular of France, but I am of the opinion that the entire European Union would have an interest in doing so, especially since, in this area of ​​foreign investment, as in the area of ​​access to public procurement, the other industrialized states are defending themselves. Look at what Canada is doing, what Japan is doing, what the US is doing, what Australia is doing. In short, we cannot stand idly by and explain that all investors are welcome, without ever defending our companies and our Member States. I would remind you, however, that the Obama administration decided arbitrarily, and without the possibility of legal recourse, to reject all foreign investment projects that were deemed to be contrary to American interests. I think that Europe must act and be inspired by these firm policies both on public markets and on foreign investments. I therefore call on the Commission to act.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I am delighted that we have the opportunity to speak on this matter this evening and I am extremely grateful to Mr Caspary and to the other colleagues for taking the initiative, here in plenary with the Commission, on this important issue to speak. I think I first have to point out that the topic goes far beyond China. It is a fundamental question how we succeed in the long term in actually bringing our companies in the European internal market into a uniform situation that investments in this internal market must follow the same rules as we are already doing today within the European Union via European state aid law, about European competition law and many other rules. We are currently creating an unequal competitive situation for companies from Europe who want to buy companies from Europe in relation to companies from outside. That cannot be in our interest. We want to ensure that the internal market grows together, that companies in Europe unite in order to be competitive with one another on a global level, and that third parties from outside do not make difficult decisions against our interests. The question remains, however: can the Commission in the near future come up with a definition of what we so commonly define as the “European crown jewels” without knowing exactly what is meant by that? Because it is often the case that one country defines a crown jewel very differently than another. That will not work if we want a uniform European approach. And that's what we need. I would therefore ask you, dear Commissioner, that the Commission actually come around the corner with specific proposals.

name: Franck PROUST
text: - Madam President, can the investments of our companies be strategic? Of course. Can foreign investments in Europe be strategic? Of course. Is there a threat to our industrial know-how today due to the takeover of strategic European companies? Of course. Does the lack of reciprocity in investments create a distortion of competition? Of course. Do some Member States, like France, protect themselves from investments they consider hostile? Of course. Is there a risk of not having the same level of protection if there is no coordination between the Member States? Of course. As you can see, Commissioner, I do not need to ask you whether the Commission needs to deal with the coordination and protection of our companies in the face of hostile foreign investment. Of course we have to, and time is running out because we are no longer in the anticipation phase, we are already suffering the consequences.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: member of the Commission. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this is above all a very constructive first exchange on this absolutely decisive issue. It will be necessary to provide precise answers to each other's questions, in particular within the framework of the Committee on International Trade (INTA). The European Union needs policies which allow us to measure what is positive and what is less positive about globalization, and thus respond to the concerns of our citizens. The Commission is analyzing the challenges linked to acquisitions by foreign companies of European companies, themselves operating in strategic sectors linked to industrial policy considerations. We must also be particularly vigilant when it comes from countries which apply restrictions on direct investment - this is the principle of reciprocity - and when there is just no level playing field for our own investors. I would like to assure you that all concerns related to such investments will be scrupulously and carefully analyzed and that we will discuss with you the definition of all the possible instruments to remedy these situations. The Commission is, of course, ready to work closely with Parliament and with the other institutions to develop and implement policies which will address all the risks that may affect sustainability and prosperity in the Union. We must be an open space, of course, but without naivety and with the concern for reciprocity.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, it has been a pleasure to participate in this plenary debate regarding the formulation of an EU approach on foreign investments in strategic sectors—a topic which will be of growing relevance in the coming months.  It is vital to regularly reassess whether we have all the tools to respond to the changing landscape of globalisation. In this context, the EPP proposal and a letter by the three Member States are an important contribution to the discussion. The Council is of course prepared to act once a proposal has been tabled by the Commission.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the debate on Council and Commission statements on child poverty (2017/2731 (RSP)).

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank Members for the opportunity to speak on the topic of child poverty. It is a very wide-ranging issue that must remain on our European agenda. The challenges are common to all Member States. However, their extent, dimension and context differ from one Member State to another. This is why the actions to be taken at national and local level vary accordingly. The most recent Eurostat data from 2015 speaks for itself. Children are most disproportionately affected by poverty. They are the age group at the highest risk of poverty or social exclusion. An estimated 27% of children in the EU 28 are concerned, as compared to about 25% of adults and around 17% of the elderly. The causes of child poverty are diverse and often multiple. The five main factors are: type of household, monetary poverty, the level of education, a migrant background, and living conditions.  But, despite Member States’ commitment to the Europe 2020 poverty reduction target and despite steps being taken to fulfil this target, two further drivers have triggered a general increase in poverty and social exclusion. I am referring to the economic crisis and the phenomenon of inherited poverty. Therefore the fight against child poverty needs to be tackled in its largest possible scope. This means combating exclusion and fighting inequalities in the spirit of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.  What measures have been, and should be, taken? Let me first state what is self—evident: no child deserves to be left behind. In our actions we should be led by the overarching concept of investing in children. Our responses need to be multidimensional. In December 2015, this House adopted the written declaration on investing in children and, in February 2016, you followed up on this initiative with a stocktaking exercise. In this context, the Council adopted a set of conclusions on an integrated approach for combating poverty and social exclusion including child poverty. Furthermore, the new Commission initiative on the European Pillar of Social Rights encourages us to further reflect on the provision which sets out a right for children to be protected from poverty.  These issues are very much on the agenda in the Council and will be discussed tomorrow in the Council’s Youth Working Party. The Council is also looking forward to the launch and implementation of a preparatory action on a child guarantee as announced in the Social Pillar framework. In this context, I would like to thank Parliament for its continuous commitment to maintaining the issue of child poverty on the agenda.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I share your concerns about child poverty, even though since 2010 the proportion of children at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the EU has decreased slightly from 27.5% in 2010 to 26.9% in 2015. However these figures remain worrying, I would say, unacceptable.  That means that more than a quarter of all children in the EU, around 25 million, are growing up in a household which either earns less than 60% of the median income, suffers from material deprivation or is a quasi-jobless household. Child poverty is a multi-faceted issue that demands an integrated and, to the extent possible, preventive approach looking at both the employment situation of the household and the rights of the child. As you know, fighting child poverty is primarily the responsibility of the Member States. However, the Commission and my colleague Marianne Thyssen support their efforts through all the instruments that are at our disposal. First, policy guidance, including through the European Semester’s country-specific recommendations, and second, our EU financial instruments; the European Social Fund (ESF), the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), and the Fund for European Aid to the Most Deprived (FEAD). Of the latter, the funding possibilities for children in the existing EU financial instruments have been significantly strengthened. For the current programming period, approximately EUR 21.2 billion of the total ESF allocation was earmarked for social inclusion measures, of which EUR 3.9 billion has been set aside for access to services, including childcare and EUR 8 billion was earmarked for measures to prevent early school leaving.  Moreover, around EUR 11 billion of ERDF funding is planned for measures promoting social inclusion and combating poverty, while around EUR 6 billion are planned for investment in educational infrastructure. The EU funds are also supporting healthy nutrition for children with the EU School Fruit Scheme: EUR 150 million to ensure the distribution of fruits and vegetables in schools in 2015 and 2016.  All these financial interventions are extremely important for preventing and breaking inter-generational transmission of poverty and social inclusion, which is of course the major factor. Moreover, the newly adopted European Pillar of Social Rights puts children at the forefront of social Europe. It acknowledges the need to improve children’s life chances and to enhance children’s rights in the European Union. Principle 11 of the Pillar recalls that children have the right to protection from poverty and that children from disadvantaged backgrounds have the right to specific measures to enhance equal opportunities. It also recognises that children have the right to affordable early childhood education and care of good quality. The Commission trusts that Parliament will join together with the Council in the proclamation of the Pillar by the end of this year. This builds upon many of the policy instruments’ elements contained in the 2013 ‘Recommendation on investing in children: breaking the cycle of disadvantage’, in particular those on parents’ access to adequate resources, activation and quality services On 26 April the Commission published a Staff Working Document to take stock of the progress achieved by Member States in implementing this Recommendation. The experiences collected throughout the last four years show the areas in which good progress has been made and those where there is still room for improvement. Therefore, it should provide a useful guidance for further action at local, national and EU level in the field.  Moreover, underpinning the relevant principles of the Pillar, the Commission has adopted an initiative on work-life balance, which should contribute to a larger and fairer participation of women in the labour market, which is also a key factor since, ultimately, the employment status of parents is one of the key determinants of child poverty. This initiative will continue to reduce the number of children who live in households at risk of poverty.  One last word about the preparatory action for a child guarantee proposed by this Parliament. We will launch a study that should initially analyse the possibilities of such an action to improve the situation of particularly vulnerable children in the European Union, i.e. children in institutions, children left behind by parents working in another EU country, disabled children and children of migrants and refugees.  Let me once again assure you in conclusion that this Commission is committed to addressing child poverty across the EU by restoring economic growth and upward social convergence, fostering job creation and ensuring social fairness. For the 40% of children in some of our Member States that live in households at risk of poverty, we need to come with effective solutions to foster employment of their parents and to ensure their full participation in society. Child poverty and social exclusion not only have a negative imprint on a child’s future but are also a huge waste of potential that our ageing societies cannot afford. We must on the contrary build on our children.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, all the reports show that since 2008 the level of child poverty has increased in a large part of the Member States. In my country, Belgium, which is far from being the most affected, it is indeed 25% of young people who are on the verge of poverty. This is unacceptable. Furthermore, it is not possible to isolate situations of child poverty from the more general level of poverty. The fight against poverty must be and must remain a priority for the European Union. This poverty which affects children is all the more unacceptable as it will strike them permanently. The repercussions are dramatic in terms of health, education and integration, they will mark the child and put him on a journey that will handicap him throughout his adult life. Fighting child poverty, intervening quickly to break this negative spiral, is to avoid, later, having to devote significant resources to integration policies, but above all it is to allow each human being to live in dignity, that dignity which must be that of our entire society.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. - And it is no coincidence that the issue of child poverty is on the agenda of our plenary today. I listened intently to both the Presidency and Commissioner Moscovici, and indeed I understood from your speeches that both the Council and the Commission are well aware that child poverty is a major problem in the European Union, at 27%. children in the European Union. And what can we say about what we did? Is the situation improving? No, the situation is not improving. Consequently, the measures used by the Member States, those which are at European level, are insufficient. Our S&D Group has repeatedly called on the Commission to provide a European guarantee for children, and that would certainly be a concrete measure with specific funding. Yes, there are many European foundations, millions can be named, but do they reach children? Has the situation changed since then? No, the situation hasn’t really changed, it’s even getting worse. Consequently, I really welcome the fact that the Maltese Presidency has said that the pillar of social rights is a child guarantee, a European child guarantee. Or will the Commission actually make a concrete proposal? That children have direct access to health care, adequate housing, adequate nutrition, adequate education. Because look, we already have a European Youth Guarantee, but isn't that the same vicious circle? It is not enough for us to start investing later. We need to invest in children from the outset so that they do not live, do not fall into that vicious circle of poverty. I am asking with all my heart, people are tired of speeches, we need action, we need a European guarantee for children.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- Madam President!According to Eurostat, in 2015 more than a quarter of children in the European Union were at risk of poverty or social exclusion.The most difficult situation is in single-parent families, where almost half of the children are exposed to poverty;The situation in large families is also very difficult.These data clearly show that the weakening of the family institution has a particularly negative impact on the financial situation of children.Therefore, our priority should be to strengthen the family.The experience of my homeland, Poland shows that investments in the family bring tangible benefits.In 2016, we launched the Family 500 plus program, which covered 55% of children.Thanks to this program, poverty was reduced by 48% and extreme child poverty by as much as 94%.Therefore, in order to effectively eliminate poverty and social exclusion among children, it is necessary to support the family and adequate social assistance.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, as a member of the ALDE Group and as an economist, I do not like very much that poverty is divided or fragmented. That if it is energetic, that if it is rural, and that of the children. But, having said that, and having said that probably the vast majority of poor children are poor because they are in a poor family, that will have to be solved. It is true that, as a liberal and as a human being, the poverty of children annoys me much more, in the sense that it definitively breaks - said Bernie Sanders «condemns children to death from poverty from the beginning» - and on the whole fundamental principle of our liberal democracies, which is equal opportunity. And, in that sense, I do believe that an extra effort must be made for the tragedy of child poverty. And that overexertion is justified all the more as it must be admitted that it is a European problem and in need of European impulse and in need of European solidarity. Because just as there are different banking areas with different levels of crisis, or different rural areas, poverty also affects different areas of Europe, but in the end it is a European problem and a tragedy for Europe, unacceptable in such a rich area. Therefore, the Commission has the power and the moral duty to organize not only benchmarking and to make proposals to the Member States. Let's not talk about the principle of subsidiarity. Let's talk about effectiveness in conjunction with concrete and advised measures, to really see the effects on reducing child poverty.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, a recent study by Unicef ​​stated that social inequalities have deepened with the crisis and with austerity policies and have particularly affected children. In 2015, in the EU — 28, 27% of children and young people, 25.3 million, live in poverty. EU austerity policies have forced Member States to cut support and social benefits and income-substituting benefits when needed most. Right-wing and austerity policies that imposed cuts in health, education and other public services, while imposing cuts in wages, unemployment, degradation of labor relations, increasing inequalities and poverty. It is your policies of exploitation and misery that feed the reality that today cannot be hidden in countless countries: thousands of children flagged in hungry schools, basic needs, such as clothing, housing and health care to be provided, children victims of abandonment and school failure, child labor, begging, youth prostitution, abandonment. Child poverty requires multidimensional responses, only possible in the context of a break with European Union policies: among others, increasing employment, combating precariousness, increasing wages and redistributing wealth, protecting family income, strengthening the social functions of the State and social benefits, the guarantee of free and quality public services, such as health, education, but also public networks of daycare centers and preschoolers.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would agree with much of what our colleague there has just said: that if we look at the UK, for example – and this is supposed to be one of the world’s strongest economies at the moment – we have 30% of children classified as poor, and two-thirds of them are in working households. So there’s something to be said about the wage level which is not actually allowing families to live and children to be properly cared for. So when we’re looking at the Commission’s recommendation and the Council’s buy-in, we know that they recognised – as Parliament does; we see it in our development aid policies – that those first thousand days of life are critical. And yet we look at some of the measures we take, and the Fundamental Rights Agency has reported more than once that the link between national child poverty rates, the country—specific recommendations formulated and the measures suggested in the national reform programmes are not always clear. So can we join up our thinking to make sure we have the effect that we want?

name: Laura AGEA
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. –Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the effects of the economic crisis that has been raging in Europe for ten years have a silent victim: children. Innocent victims grow up in contexts of marginalization, in families that do not have the means to satisfy their essential needs, in the shadow of societies where values ​​have been turned upside down and overturned and where certain abominations are simply classified as collateral damage. There are more than 20 million poor children in this inert Europe who, instead of taking care of their happiness, satisfies quite other interests. The children of today will be the adults of tomorrow, sold in the name of austere policies that rob them of dreams, hopes and prospects. And while our role as the voice of the least is lost in the noise of nowhere, their laughter dies down. Every moment we lose, every opportunity we miss to defend them makes us complicit in having departed from our most important task, that of taking care of our children, not only those who wait for us at home in the comfort of a safe life, but much of more than those for which our action can lead to survival or condemnation. Colleagues, let us remember that the world changes with our example and with our work, not with our talk, and perhaps it would be useful to go to school of poverty to contain the disaster that wealth is producing.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - One third of children in Europe are at risk of poverty. How does child poverty actually arise? It is mostly poor children who become poor parents, so the cure for this reproduction of poverty is, above all, affordable and quality education for all children, as well as support for their families. It is the Member States that have to decide. We in the EP can call on them, and it is also right that the EU is calling on the Member States to do something about child poverty. It is in their interest to support families with children, especially employment, wage growth, decent housing, tax incentives and rewards for parents who care for children. Ladies and gentlemen, let us not forget that poverty is not only material poverty, but also emotional poverty. I know children who are poor but happy with their parents, who take loving care of them. I know children who, despite their wealth, are unhappy and unsuccessful. Without the loving and wise upbringing of parents, children will not be happy.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: - Madam President, it is a personal experience. I am a councilor of my city council and a few years ago we visited the houses of some neighbors. We knocked on a door and a mother who had two children, ages five and seven, opened it for us. The youngest, when he saw a loaf of bread that the councilor who accompanied me was carrying, he rushed to take the loaf of bread because he had been eating only water and sugar for several days. The mother, crying, asked us: What kind of state guarantees a desk in a school for my son and does not guarantee a loaf of bread? And he is right. I think we have to be clear that the decent society that we have built in Europe with the welfare state has to guarantee the most basic, and the most basic is not guaranteed by making complaints, like the one we are making today, it is done with policies. We believe in politics. And, therefore, what I ask of the European Commission is that, to combat child poverty, bet on and support a directive on minimum incomes so that the member states are obliged to put public money so that families with basic needs they can satisfy those of their children and end, once and for all, with something that does not define us as a society.

name: Margot PARKER
text: – Madam President, according to statistics released in March 2017, child poverty in the UK has risen by over 400 000 since the Conservatives took power. Twenty-nine per cent of children in my own constituency of the East Midlands live under these conditions. The situation is similar throughout Europe, and indeed is even worse in many places. What are we doing? How can any child in Europe be left behind so badly? For all the hot air of politicians throughout this continent and all the failed policies, we continue to fail our young people. It is simply not good enough. GDP growth and statistics mean nothing if children have nothing on the dinner table. We cannot go on like this, and we must ensure real change before we fail an entire generation.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe, as we continue to imagine it, cannot fail to take charge of the most precious human capital, our children, in fact. The numbers are dramatically true. But what and how many faces does poverty have? Guaranteeing the wealth of opportunities means offering useful tools to defeat it. It is not enough to take refuge in the comfortable reading of the responsibilities linked to the crisis and its repercussions, in particular to the contraction of public spending and the labor crisis, in a time when fears extinguish hopes and cancel the future. This is the time when politics must take full responsibility for giving back opportunities. Resources are needed, of course, but these must be aimed at promoting a new feeling of community, of social cohesion. In short, investing having a clear idea of ​​promoting a model of an educating community, which links the public supply chain to the actors of the territory to rethink the places of life and educational and training models and to respond to the demand for accessibility and opportunities for a new agenda rights.

name: Julie WARD
