text: – Madam President, the Commission has already acknowledged that austerity has increased inequalities, social injustice and poverty in Europe. Children are among the most impacted and remain the group at the highest risk of poverty and social exclusion. We need, therefore, to have decisive political action so as not to exclude a great part of the next generation. As a member of the Intergroup on Children’s Rights, I am proud that my political group is pushing hard for the creation of a child guarantee, in line with the Investing in Children Recommendations, ensuring that every child in Europe at risk of poverty – including refugees – has access to free healthcare, free education, free childcare, decent housing and adequate nutrition. Children must also play a role in decision—making that concerns them, and the Children’s Commission on Poverty in the UK involves young people investigating peer poverty and making concrete policy recommendations at all levels. The NUJ and the Church Action on Poverty have also worked with young people to produce excellent guidelines, which will end the demonisation of the poor by the right—wing media.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the recent economic crisis and the consequent austerity have penalized families with children, especially the most numerous, single parents and immigrants, and have hit children hard. Between 2008 and 2014, child poverty increased in two thirds of European countries, reaching the highest poverty rate of all age groups. In the European Union, one in four children is at risk of poverty or social exclusion. In my country, Portugal, in 2015, one year after the end of the economic and financial assistance program, 536 thousand children, almost 30%, were at risk. These children who grow up in poverty and in conditions of social exclusion are children amputated for their rights. They are less likely to succeed at school, to enjoy good health or to get a job in adults, thus perpetuating a cycle of social exclusion across generations and making poverty a structural problem. If the Europe 2020 strategy aims to lift at least 20 million people out of high-risk poverty, the fight against child poverty must be the number one priority of all European social policies. Yesterday we celebrated in this House the 30th anniversary of the success of the generation ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, poverty and social exclusion are two words that must be spoken together. The prolonged recession has widened the number of families in poverty and has increased the range of inequalities in our society. It is mainly children who suffer from conditions of poverty. In 2015, more than 400 MEPs signed the written declaration "Investing in Children" in which, among other things, we called for the inclusion of a specific and binding indicator on the number of children at risk of poverty or social exclusion and underlined the '' need to invest at European level in childhood and not only in economic terms, but also through access to care and participation in social life and education, in order to offer all children, in all countries, the same opportunity. Now more than ever a social dimension of Europe is needed. From the new social pillar, Commissioner, we expect a lot to overcome inequalities and to ensure decent living conditions for all children.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Madam President! Child poverty is parental poverty. Children are the future of society. But while the pension was socialized, the costs of bringing up children are largely borne by the parents alone. This results in disadvantages for parents from the time they raise their children up to retirement age, especially mothers. Raising children and caring for children is family work - work that equates to work in professional life. The solution is to pay a parenting salary that is subject to tax and social security contributions. We not only need a pension fund, we also need a family fund, where the money is charged as a percentage of the salary. The level of the education salary was based in 28 countries on salaries for crèches and kindergartens and children's homes as a recommendation. This would give us more children, women and single parents are financially secure, no child in poverty, social systems remain affordable, and we would not have an abortion for social reasons. Malta, I would like to take another step forward against parental poverty.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Madam President, boys and girls have the right to protection against child poverty, according to the European social pillar. A fundamental right, when one in four European children and one in three Spanish children live below the poverty line. Child poverty is due to insufficient parental income, precariousness, unemployment, and lack of social protection coverage. Therefore, fighting against child poverty is fighting against social inequality. The European Social Charter tells us what minimum social standards are necessary. A SMI at 60% of the median salary and a guaranteed income at 60% of the median income for children and adults with lower incomes. Issues to be developed through legislative instruments such as a framework directive. Hypocritical recommendations in instruments such as the European Semester are not enough, since it is incompatible to strengthen social protection and demand, at the same time, cuts in public spending. Make a bet much more ambitious than the one you have made so far.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, according to a UNICEF report, by 2030, 167 million children will be living in poverty. Unfortunately, this unacceptable situation also applies to the children of Greece, which has been financially damaged by the memoranda imposed on it. 25% of the country's workforce is unemployed, leaving 686,000 children malnourished and even facing starvation. This, as you realize, is unacceptable. Fortunately, family ties in Greece are still strong and so this situation is partially addressed with the meager pension of grandparents. But painless lenders, including the European Union, are pushing for a reduction in these low pensions. Thus, a generation of young children in Greece is threatened with genocide. The European Union leadership must immediately end this unacceptable situation and stop shedding hypocritical tears over child poverty around the world.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, children are one of those vulnerable groups that a mature society must take special care of. According to Eurostat data from December 2016, every fourth child is at risk of poverty or social marginalization. The survey of child poverty and strategies for dealing with household poverty in Croatia shows that the relative poverty rate of children in our country is about 7% higher than the European Union average. The data are alarming, but we must not allow them to direct us to the adoption of new expensive social policies, but we must primarily ensure that we create the preconditions for employment and the creation of well-paid jobs, in order to achieve higher employment of parents and increase their salaries. This is impossible with the great tax pressure needed to fund costly social policies and that is why we must be careful not to fall into this trap. Children can live with dignity only if their parents earn a decent income from their work.

name: Romana TOMC
text: - Poverty in general is unacceptable in today's developed Europe, but of course child poverty is even less acceptable.Although the economic situation is improving, it is clear that our efforts to reduce poverty are not yielding results or are yielding them very slowly.So we should ask ourselves what we are doing wrong after all.Certainly, the social transfers we give at European level or in each individual Member State are important, but money is not everything.Education, however, is certainly one of those factors that provides a very good basis for children from poor families to break out of this grip of poverty.That is why I think it is very important that we pay more attention to ensuring that all children have the same opportunity to attend school and thus increase their chances for a better economic and more independent life.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, millions of children around the world are deprived of their childhood and their right to grow, learn and play. According to a recent report by Save the Children, more than 16,000 children under the age of five die every day from easily treatable diseases, 156 million children suffer from growth problems due to malnutrition, 168 million are involved in child labor and 28 millions flee from wars and persecutions. They are unjustifiable data. In Europe too, there are still many children at risk of poverty or social exclusion. The percentage of minors who cannot afford to eat meat or fish for two consecutive days has dramatically doubled since 2008. Europe and the Member States must make a concrete commitment to tackle child poverty by increasing the effectiveness of social support. The children of today are the men of tomorrow. Einstein, who understood progress, said: there is no great discovery or progress in this world that holds, as long as there is even a single sad child.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, the European Union is all about peace and prosperity, and we have thankfully had peace on the continent for 60 years now. Prosperity has come in fits and starts: the recession obviously meant that an awful lot of people went below the poverty threshold. It is very sad for that to happen, especially in relation to young people.  As has been pointed out, the consequences of child poverty is that a child does not get the opportunity to reach their potential. All of us here have had the opportunity to reach our potential; many, many children in Europe, and indeed across the world, do not have that opportunity. So it is incumbent on us – and it is good that we are debating this tonight – to ensure that we can do whatever we can to give them that opportunity. Maybe, in 30 years’ time, when we have another display out here on Erasmus, many of the children who are in poverty now might be lifted out of it and benefit from the Erasmus programme as well.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: - Unfortunately, those most at risk of poverty are those who can have the least influence on their position - children and adolescents. If a child is born into an environment where he often does not even have the basic conditions for living, let alone learning, he will find it much harder to achieve better results at school, continue his studies and perhaps get a better paid job. It is the education of parents and their situation on the labor market that is one of the main causes of child poverty. The result is a vicious circle where poverty is unfortunately inherited and very difficult to break out of it. We should therefore not only take measures to reduce child poverty, but also focus on the situation of their parents. It is very important to support the education of children, but it is equally important to support the employment of their parents, I add, for decent wages. There are many families where falling into poverty can only cause one unexpected increase in family spending. Improving the living conditions of entire families can thus reduce the number of children at risk of poverty.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: member of the Commission. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as I said in my initial speech, child poverty is a phenomenon with multiple causes which the Commission and the Member States are trying to address. We have, I believe, the appropriate financial instruments and tools at European level and our responsibility is to act together at local, regional, national and, of course, European level. Earlier I mentioned the basis of European social rights. There is an ambition which proves that this Commission puts the future of children at the heart of its priorities. I have heard your concerns. I have also heard a shared sensitivity across all ranks of this chamber, and I can assure you that we take everything that has been said here seriously. I said that we want to be concerned about the future of children, and this is for a simple reason: it is because children are, by definition, the future of Europe and we cannot , today less than ever, create discrimination or leave it aside. We have no right to indifference. We all have the duties of mobilization.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me just recall the conclusions adopted by the Council in March: reducing child poverty and breaking the cycle of poverty and social exclusion across generations require integrated strategies that combine prevention and support. These strategies should aim at supporting parents’ access to the labour market and enhancing preventive approaches through early intervention and increased support to families.  Thank you once more for this debate; it has shown again the multifaceted and persistent nature of this problem. Further efforts are evidently needed from all sides involved.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Article 162)

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - In a time when scientific and technological development reaches unprecedented levels, child poverty is one of the most revolting expressions of the inability of the dominant global economic and social formation - capitalism - to satisfy the most basic human needs, despite the means at your service. A recent UNICEF study stated that social inequalities deepened with the crisis and particularly affected children, concluding that there is an absolute need to protect family income through social policies. In 2015, in the EU28, 25.3 million children and young people lived in poverty. EU policies have imposed on Member States cuts in support and social benefits for families and children and in substitutive income from work, when they were most needed. Cuts in health, education, and other public services. Cuts in wages, unemployment, degradation of labor relations, increasing inequality and poverty. The result: hunger in schools, basic needs, such as clothing, housing and health care, to be provided, children victims of school abandonment and failure, child labor, begging, youth prostitution. Responses are needed that imply a break with EU policies. Combating precariousness, increasing wages, redistributing wealth, strengthening the social functions of the State, free and quality public services.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - President! In early 2006, the Spring European Council committed itself to "taking the necessary measures to rapidly and significantly reduce child poverty, ensuring equal opportunities for all children, regardless of their social background." Nevertheless, to this day, one in four children in the EU is at risk of poverty. This problem needs to be addressed seriously, and we can only hope for a solution from specific programs. Be it local initiatives from social cohesion, such as "Let all children live well!" or government programs. I believe that Hungary is at the forefront in this area. School meals are no longer only available during the school year, but children from disadvantaged families can get hot food during all four school holidays, including summer holidays. Since 2015, 208,000 disadvantaged and multiple disadvantaged children across the country have received free hot food once a day. I think it is important that these important, exemplary programs are also mentioned here in the European Parliament.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - Hungary is interested in supporting and strengthening families. Going its own way, Hungary has continuously spent more and more (more than 4.5% of GDP in 2018) on family support, which is almost twice the OECD average. According to surveys based on the EUROSTAT methodology, the proportion of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion has been improving since 2012. This improvement affected the largest proportion just under the age of 18, more than 40,000 children. In the fight against child poverty, not only the most disadvantaged children in Hungary, but all disadvantaged children are important, and they receive support through child opportunity programs. The number of Safe Start Orphanages - where children and parents receive services together in disadvantaged settlements - is already well over a hundred nationwide (more than doubling since 2012). Hungary is also at the forefront of compulsory kindergarten attendance, as children attend kindergarten from the age of 3, almost twice the EU average. The Hungarian state has been spending 250% more on children's meals since 2010, and already during school (mid-year) breaks they provide one hot meal a day for disadvantaged children. In three counties (Szabolcs-Szatmár-Bereg, Hajdú-Bihar and Borsod-Abaúj-Zemplén), the three-year-olds under the age of three also receive a food package from a specially targeted EU source. It helps 12,000 disadvantaged children.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: in writing. - I welcomed the fact that the European Commission and the Council of the EU took up the subject of child poverty. Although the causes of the poverty of the youngest are varied - resulting not only from the financial problems of the family, but also the level of education, living conditions or migration past - challenges in this area are common to all Member States and should be addressed not only at national but also at European level. The latest Eurostat data from 2015 are alarming - they show that in almost all EU countries poverty affects children more than the general population. It is estimated that about 27% of the youngest are affected by this problem, compared to 25% of adults and 17% of the elderly. It should be remembered that poverty of households in a particular way affects the children growing up in them, because it threatens their health, proper development and socialization, and makes it difficult to obtain education, which obviously translates into later difficulties on the labor market and overcoming poverty in adults. life. Therefore, the disadvantageous situation of children in Europe should be reflected in increased activities for them. The problem requires a multi-track approach, investments are needed in the labor market, which is not efficient enough to fully protect families from poverty, in the education system to facilitate access to education for children from poor families, and in the social welfare system to support more effectively families at risk of social exclusion.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: written. - One in five of Europeans affected by poverty and social exclusion is a child. 25 million. A figure that threatens the model of solidarity and economic and social convergence on which the EU is based. It is important that the EU shows sincere support and supports local and national actions to end child poverty, counting on the support and advice of specialized NGOs and the organizations of people living in poverty themselves. For this reason, I consider it important to act with a strategy based on a dual approach: - in the short term, through measures of social and labor inclusion and mitigation of existing poverty, for example through the ESF, the FEAD, responding to deprivation needs material. - in the long term and to fight against this intergenerational component and its consequent vicious circle, we must end the existing stereotypes towards the most disadvantaged communities, guarantee affordable and quality public services and above all through education and training , avoiding early school leaving, since without training it is difficult to find a quality job and therefore to get out of poverty.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: in writing. - One of the goals of the EU's Europe 2020 strategy is to reduce the number of people affected by poverty by at least 20 million by 2020. However, rarely in this context is there any mention of specific groups of people that need special attention. Child poverty is not only a short-term social problem, but also a factor that affects their entire lives and the future of their families. It should be noted that children from low-work-intensity households are 56.7% more likely to be at risk of poverty or social exclusion. Nevertheless, the risk of child poverty also persists in families with high work intensity, incl. in countries such as Romania, Lithuania, Portugal, Spain and Greece. In addition, women are at greater risk of poverty than men, and fighting female poverty is also essential in efforts to reduce child poverty. More and more children suffer from malnutrition, leading to the increasing emergence of diseases that have been largely eradicated in the EU, such as rickets. In some countries, the proportion of children who cannot afford the recommended amounts of certain foods is increasing.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. - Tackling child poverty is a key issue in catching up with disadvantaged groups. Among children growing up in social exclusion and with severe deprivation, the phenomenon of early school leaving is much higher, in general they are capable of significantly worse school performance, so their placement in the labor market is more difficult and the circle closes. The most serious problem in the Roma communities of the Central and Eastern European states is child poverty, without which the catching-up programs are much less likely to try to change today's frustrating situation. In particular, we need to see more accurately the accompanying phenomena of child poverty, school drop-out, domestic violence, housing problems in order to identify effective areas and methods of intervention. It is much more difficult to set up and run self-sustaining programs in the field than at the planning table, so it would be important to exchange good practice and, of course, courage on the part of Member States and local authorities, as they have the opportunity to intervene.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Every child in Europe deserves to live free from poverty. Nevertheless, one in four children in the EU is at risk of poverty or social exclusion. As a member of the Socialists and Democrats Group in the European Parliament, I strongly support creating a European Child Guarantee that protects every child in the EU. Fighting the root causes of child poverty should become a top priority for the European institutions. In the EU, only five EU Member States, including Romania, have seen a slight reduction in the number of children at risk of poverty and social exclusion. I am proud to see my country on the right track, but a lot needs to be done still. The only way to ensure stable societies and prosperous economies is by investing in education and reducing inequality. If we do not act as soon as possible so that every child can have access to free healthcare, free education, free childcare, decent housing and adequate nutrition, we run the risk of losing a whole generation of children in Europe.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written. - The European Union lives in a permanent contradiction. On the one hand, it has been instituted as a principle to combat social exclusion and poverty, while promoting measures within the framework of the European Semester that are aimed at reducing public spending as a way to economic recovery. Economic recovery impossible if the public administrations are deprived of resources to implement correct public policies that provide the population with quality public education, or accessible health for all. Finally, let us remember that time is running out and the indicator of poverty reduction, especially child poverty, set within the Europe 2020 objectives, not only does not reduce what is wanted, but increases, reaching 25.3 million of poor minors. In short, without a drastic change in economic and financial policies, any statement from the European Commission or the Council is absolutely unnecessary and empty.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for a joint discussion on the digital economy with the report by Nicola Danti, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the European agenda for the collaborative economy (2017/2003(INI) (A8-0195 / 2017) and the report by Henna Virkkunen and Philippe Juvin, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on online platforms and the digital single market (2016/2276 (INI) (A8-0204 / 2017).

name: Nicola DANTI
text: speaker. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, today it is still difficult to define the collaborative economy. Yet it moves, grows, transforms our society, our ways of living and working. It builds extraordinary opportunities and, at the same time, risks undermining established legal and social categories. Thanks to the digital revolution and online platforms, with one click we can rent a room anywhere in the world, share a car trip with someone, buy a meal from a neighbor, find a gardener to cut the hedge. Opportunities that consumers increasingly appreciate and use. The collaborative economy arises, on the one hand, from technological innovation, but, on the other, from the increasingly widespread need for a better use of resources, with the effect of stimulating the biodiversity of the economic forms of society. A mosaic of different experiences that see large platforms as protagonists, now real multinationals, and small start-ups strongly rooted in the territory and in the reference communities. In recent years, the collaborative economy has developed in Europe more with the judgments of the courts and with national and regional regulations, often contradictory, than on the basis of a shared strategy, giving us a fragmented market and provisions that are difficult to interpret by operators. . For this reason, the Commission's attempt to define a common approach with its communication is to be welcomed. Our report has the ambition to go further, considering a European strategy to be indispensable. First of all, we invite the Commission to examine the existing legal framework, evaluating the advisability of introducing general principles and specific rules that can favor harmonious development. The goal must be to avoid that different rules apply to similar services between traditional and collaborative economy, both for how much it concerns access to the market as well as with regard to taxation, thus ensuring fair competition between online and offline operators as well as between these and the so-called prosumers. The distinction between professional and non-professional is an essential point for defining fair and balanced rules. Evaluating the market access criteria can represent an extraordinary opportunity to simplify the rules even for operators of traditional services. Furthermore, we believe that a common legal framework can foster the growth of European platforms, which today see uncertainty and fragmentation of rules and the unavailability of risk capital as the main obstacles to growth on a global scale. This is demonstrated by the fact that among the top ten platforms producing economic value in Europe only one is European. Online platforms, the engine of the collaborative economy, cannot ignore the assumption of greater responsibility towards consumers, through clear information, towards service providers, guaranteeing the reliability of ratings, and towards public authorities through fair tax cooperation. Finally, the collaborative economy can represent a stimulus towards new employment, in particular for the population groups with a lower rate of employability. However, it is not conceivable that in this sector workers, whether they are employed or self-employed, have fewer rights and protections than everyone else. Allow me to conclude by thanking all the shadow rapporteurs, the draftsmen of the opinion committees, for the excellent cooperation they have had in recent months, not without also a frank and in-depth debate, which I believe has been fruitful for the drafting of this final report.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: demonstrator. - (FI) Mr President, the platform economy is now growing really fast in the world, but the challenge for us Europeans is that Europe's share of the market value of online platforms is really small. The most important thing now is to create a region of Europe that encourages companies to innovate and invest in Europe and to grow and develop their business here. We had a very broad consensus with the shadow rapporteurs and the various groups that we need to create fair competition and a fair, encouraging market environment throughout Europe. We know that the platform economy has benefited a great deal, both consumers and businesses. It has brought a whole new marketplace for goods, services and digital content. The role of platforms today is also very central in the distribution of news, advertising and cultural content, and of course in social interaction between people. For small businesses and startups, online platforms have brought a whole new marketplace where they can offer their own products and services around the world. They have brought a lot of new business models to us as well. In the same way, they have brought new jobs and thus been able to promote the formation of new businesses. For consumers, the digital platform economy has brought more choice, price competition and comparability. We have a great many positive opportunities ahead of us. But on the other hand, we also have big challenges in how to develop Europe precisely as a place where it is worth growing its own business and where thriving online platforms also emerge. The key here is now to be able to create a more level playing field across Europe, increase fair competition and transparency, and an innovation-friendly environment that encourages brainstorming. Of course, our decision-makers need to make sure we have a good digital infrastructure that takes this into account now future requirements and how much demand for online services is constantly growing. The big challenge is to remove barriers to the internal market, both in technical and economic terms, that still limit pan-European activity. We know that there are still big differences between Member States. The current challenges and difficult issues that we discussed very much with various representatives and groups during the preparation of the report relate precisely to the need for separate regulation of platforms or whether sectoral legislation is sufficient and a better option, and whether the e-commerce directive and competition law are sufficiently appropriate. also in today’s digital world and what is the responsibility of intermediaries for the content and services that are shared on these platforms. Personally, in terms of regulation, I think it is important that we do not succumb to over-regulation in Europe. It is better to approach online platforms on a sector-by-sector basis and to go in the same way here in the online world as in the offline world, specifically by sector, to look at legislation and operating conditions. A great deal of legislation is currently being examined to see how well the law fits into today's digital world. This must now be encouraged by all the Member States and also by the Commission. We often know that we already have legislation, but it has not been implemented well enough. Here we have efficiency across Europe. As far as the liability of intermediaries is concerned, we have the e-commerce directive and the intermediary limited liability systems for illegal content, and they work very well when it comes to trade in goods. But we also have a lot of new challenging phenomena, such as hate speech and false news, that have brought new challenges. Here, new guidance is now needed from the Commission to make platforms more aware of how notification and removal procedures should apply.They also need to learn more about voluntary means of tackling illegal and inappropriate content.It is clear that the platforms cannot and do not want to take on the role of the Truth Commission, but the right balance must be struck between how we prevent lawlessness and at the same time safeguard freedom of expression.Here, it is important that the platforms work closely with legislators so that we find a good balance.I believe that consumer confidence is even the cornerstone of a thriving platform economy.I would like to warmly thank all my colleagues and all the shadow rapporteurs for their good cooperation in this very challenging cooperation between the two committees, and I would also like to thank the Commission for its good cooperation and the proposals you have already made and are preparing.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: protractor. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, there has been a lot of talk so far in this debate about platforms and the digital economy. I obviously share all the elements that have been said. The question regarding platforms is both simple and complicated. Platforms are the key to the modern economy. They have huge benefits for consumers who can compare, who can buy, and who have a freedom that they did not have before. They are an extraordinary opportunity for education and access to knowledge. We remember when we were students, when we didn't have these platforms and we had to spend hours in the library. All of that is over. Our whole society is evolving thanks to platforms. They are a positive and wonderful tool. At the same time, the question we are asking both Parliament and the European Commission is whether these platforms should be the subject of a certain number of common rules in all the States of the European Union. . The first question is that of the homogenization of European rules. It is obvious that if we want a digital single market, we will have to have common rules and definitions in all the States of the Union. We have to talk about the same thing everywhere. If we do not make this effort to homogenize European law, including on definitions, we either submit to a fragmentation of the law and therefore to a weakening of platforms and the European economy, or we submit to the right will of the judge who, through case law, will make the law evolve, which we do not want. The second point, which is a key point, is the question of the responsibility of the platforms. You know that today, platforms see their responsibility engaged according to rules that were enacted more than fifteen years ago. The world has changed in fifteen years. Back in the day, we used to talk about an active host and an inactive host. Very clearly, this distinction no longer reflects reality. There are now many platforms that no longer just store data but select it, recommend it, reference it and monetize it. Our old rules are no longer appropriate, we must change the platform liability rules. The third point is the question of the protection of the users of these online platforms. It is essential to gain the trust of these users, that is to say, there must be transparency, a level playing field and a high level of data protection. We remember the case of the blacklisting, by a large host, of a British company, which could no longer be visible on the market because this large host, which is a platform, had decided to promote their own business, which had the same economic activity. There must be transparency and the rules must be fair and shared. The fourth point concerns the issue of platform taxation. It’s something fundamental. To move quickly into a complex subject, we want it to be simple - and Parliament, I hope, will support this proposal tomorrow through its vote on our report. Platforms have to pay taxes in Europe, where they have their customers or users. Then, of course, the question of VAT arises. VAT is a very smart old tax, except that it is totally unsuited to the digital economy, and in particular to the platform economy. We need to invent a new tax system that will boost this new economy. Finally, there is the issue of B2B relationships. We can clearly see that everything must be done to prevent the platforms that dominate very often concentrated markets from imposing unfair to entering companies.We want to avoid this.The market cannot regulate everything and we are waiting for the Commission to make proposals to us.As you have understood, my dear colleagues, the real question we are asking ourselves, with Henna Virkkunen, is whether we want a digital single market, if we want real European digital sovereignty, if we want to see the emergence ofEuropean champions, if we simply want to participate in the development of a new economy through new definitions and new rules for platforms.

name: Joachim SCHUSTER
text: Draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear Commissioner! Online platforms hold great economic potential and are growing dynamically. They offer opportunities for new jobs, and that is precisely why we must ensure that the competitive advantages of the platform economy over the traditional economy are not based on wage or social dumping. We must ensure that the minimum wage and collective bargaining agreements also apply here and that online workers are included in the social security systems. Clarifications at European level are necessary for this. All work in the platform economy is carried out either by employees or by the self-employed. And whether they are dependent employees must be determined on the basis of facts. On this basis, the same social and labor rights must then apply as in the traditional economy. We also need greater efforts to combat bogus self-employment, and the self-employed in the platform economy must continue to be given the opportunity to organize themselves and conclude collective agreements. The Commission is called upon to take initiatives to this end.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the rapporteur and colleagues because the text being voted on is excellent and includes many messages from the opinion of the ITRE committee which I followed as rapporteur. Among these is the recognition of the growing role of the collaborative economy in the self-production, self-consumption and distribution of renewable energy at the local level, by the prosumers of the local energy communities, as well as the potential of distributed ledger technologies that enable and certify energy exchanges between peers without intermediaries. It is important that the Commission makes the most of this intersection between the collaborative economy, the digital economy and new energy models, so that the citizen is truly at the center of the energy union and is enabled to actively contribute to the transition towards a more energy system. sustainable, democratic and resilient. Finally, I underline the importance of the role that open software, open hardware and Creative Commons have had and will have in the development of the collaborative economy, as expressed by a large majority by the ITRE commission. That is why I invite colleagues to consider the amendments tabled by my committee.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the digital economy and society of today is marked by a revolutionary set-up, new services which have changed everyone’s life. Almost every part of our lives has been transformed by these new technologies: the way we communicate, access information and media, the way we book a hotel, navigate around a city or order our dinner. Almost exactly one year ago, the Commission set out its thoughts on online platforms in general and on the collaborative economy more specifically. I welcome the opportunity given today to respond to Parliament’s report by MEPs Mr Danti, Mr Juvin and Ms Virkkunen in response to our communications shaping the debate at EU level.  First on a collaborative economy: the Commission welcomes MEP Danti’s report. It provides a balanced view on current developments in the collaborative economy. We agree with Mr Danti that to facilitate the development of the collaborative economy, we need legal clarity and we should avoid regulatory fermentation in the single market. We need to ensure that the collaborative economy is not unduly restricted. I would like also to recall that the Commission adopted a Communication in June 2016 providing legal guidance and policy recommendations on how to ensure the balanced development of the collaborative economy. The Commission will continue working with Member States and stakeholders on this matter. We also agree with you that peers offering services on a private and occasional basis are different from professional services providers’ thresholds, although precisely defining them is difficult. Identifying peers can contribute to establishing a clear and proportionate regulatory framework. The Commission takes note of your call for a level playing field. We think that it is for consumers, not regulators, to choose which service they prefer. EU law requires that national regulation is justified and proportionate. This means taking into consideration the specificities of the collaborative economy whilst not favouring one business model over another. I want to acknowledge the need to ensure social protection for the self-employed, as you do, under the European pillar of social rights. This topic will be subject to consultation with social partners. Finally, I wish to call upon Parliament, Member States and stakeholders to work together to enable users and consumers to choose the service they want and to seize the opportunities that the collaborative economy offers. Secondly, on platforms. The platform economy is now a major feature of the digital transformation across the entire world. More than two billion people are using social networks, a number expected to reach three billion by 2020. The report by MEPs Mr Juvin and Ms Virkkunen rightly acknowledges the positive impact of online platforms and reaffirms the need to further promote the emergence of new online platforms in Europe. The report supports the Commission approach – that is how I read it – of first looking at better enforcement of existing instruments before resorting to designing new rules, which should be targeted to specific problems.  As part of the digital single market strategy, the Commission undertook to carry out an in-depth assessment of the role of online platforms. The Commission’s Communication on the digital single market mid-term review, adopted recently on 10 May, announces a number of actions that will tackle some of the main issues raised in your report. We need to safeguard a fair, predictable, trusted business environment in the online economy. Sellers should benefit fully from platforms and at the same time, platform businesses should be able to start up and grow in Europe. This is why I warmly welcome your strong support for the Commission’s ongoing work on platform-to-business (‘PtoB’) trading practices, impact assessment for action still to be proposed in 2017 and intermediary liability. The Commission will make sure that any possible policy intervention is first targeted, i.e. specific to online platform ecosystems; secondly, problem—driven, that means addressing clearly identified problems; and thirdly, with a light touch i.e. without laying down detailed sector-specific rules in EU legislation. Finally, the Commission can echo your conclusion that the intermediary liability regime is a crucial pillar for the EU’s digital economy. The Commission remains committed to keeping a balanced and predictable liability regime and it is currently working on guidance to eliminate certain flaws in its enforcement, including to allow online platforms to comply with their responsibilities, and the rules on liability enhance legal certainty and increase user confidence.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. - Madam President, to understand the transformations in the world of work in the 21st century we have to distinguish between the collaborative economy, which includes solidarity and altruistic forms, and online service platforms, which is a business sector like any other. I think this distinction is not clear enough in the report and we run the risk of camouflaging one thing as the other. From the European Union we have to influence the need for a regulatory framework with guarantees that puts an end to violations within a sector that, with great growth prospects, what it is doing is camouflaging precarious employment and unprotected employment in a kind of opportunities youth work or entrepreneurship. Offering low-cost services, saving labor costs and promoting precariousness and unfair competition, is not a good strategy, nor does it offer guarantees to the consumer or whoever works. Online platforms must adhere to the same labor rules as traditional competitors. Asking for this, requesting a labor regulation, I consider that it is not asking for heaven, it is asking for equality, security and rights.

name: Axel VOSS
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. – Madam President, I am speaking on behalf of Ms Constance Le Grip, who was the rapporteur for the opinion in the Committee on Legal Affairs for online platforms.  Online platforms are key players for the future of the global economy. They offer great opportunities by fostering access and relationships, but pose a lot of economic and legal challenges as well. As rapporteur for the opinion, Constance Le Grip welcomes the result of the report voted in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and the fact that the contribution from the opinion on the Committee on Legal Affairs was very much valued within the text, which will be voted in plenary tomorrow.  The report states key aspects fully in line with our opinion about the way Europe should deal with platforms: clarify platforms’ responsibility so that no regulatory frameworks are bypassed because of the digital nature of their activities, and further enforce and protect copyright and intellectual property rights online. This should be translated in encouraging the transfer of value towards rights holders for the exploitation of the works online, and in proceeding to a revision of the Intellectual Property Rights Enforcement (IPRE) Directive to strengthen the fight against counterfeiting online, ensure fair competition and practices in the platform economy, both for B2B and B2C, and promote the emergence of European players in the field.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, the shared economy offers endless opportunities for everyone to enter the labour market. Breaking traditional schemes, it provides flexible forms of employment and empowers consumers. The collaborative economy goes hand—in—hand with the circular economy, creating sustainable ways of using goods and services and allowing a better allocation of resources. We are moving towards a society where fewer people own what they use and more people share what they need, creating communities. Online platforms, with their feedback system, offer increased traceability of transactions, strengthening both consumer protection and the fight against illegality. Trust is the new currency of the digital single market, and it is smart, creating entrepreneurs that are in the driving seat – not politicians. We need to be humble to keep up with digital innovation, and overregulation is not a solution. We should instead be enablers and help to boost cross—border growth and facilitate our start—ups to become global champions.  At EU level, we need to overcome fragmentation, removing hurdles and hindrance to free movement to create a level playing field. At this stage, we do not need new EU legislation, but rather the full enforcement of existing rules. The important issues of tax and labour compliance and liability are instead better dealt with at national level. In any case, rules should be clear, technology—neutral and future—proof. I understand that there is concern, but protectionism can never be a solution. We should embrace innovation.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, the digital economy obliges us to public powers to four things: to regulate to avoid unfair competition between operators that provide the same service, regardless of whether they do so through digital media or through the traditional economy ; to train, so that inequalities do not occur from the point of view of equal opportunities; to invest to reduce existing digital gaps; and, above all and also, to support the sectors that may be affected in this digital transition in which we live. But we have to regulate precisely to avoid a double legal reality in the digital world with respect to the traditional world. Those who seek a parallel job market, protected by the digital economy, are deeply mistaken: digitization cannot come hand in hand with a greater precariousness of employment. And, for that, we have to ensure that people who work through online platforms have the same wages, the same social protection, the same social security and the same coverage as workers in traditional media. We have to guarantee taxation, because it is the sustenance of the welfare state in an increasingly growing economy, and online platforms have to pay their taxes wherever they generate economic activity. We also have to guarantee consumer protection, data security protection, and also clarify the responsibility of the platforms, which are not mere intermediaries, but are active agents in the economy and in society. Therefore, it is necessary to regulate to avoid those gray areas that leave workers and all citizens unprotected against the challenges of the digital economy.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the rapporteur has tried very hard, but for us the platform report is far too restrictive, so we have tabled an alternative motion giving our more open, flexible vision. Let us remember that the aim of the Digital Single Market is to help European companies to scale up in the same way that American companies do: an innovation—friendly environment. For that, there cannot be a one—size—fits—all approach to the sharing economy – especially for platforms. No two platforms are the same. You would not regulate banks and gardening centres in the same way, so why are we doing that with platforms?  Platforms are disruptive, but that is good. They offer new flexible employment options and better choice for consumers. The sharing economy matches unmet demand with unused resources; it is an economist’s dream. We want European platforms, but consumers do not care where the platform comes from. They want a good service, and the sharing economy empowers consumers in a way that has never been seen before. It also empowers workers. If platforms lose trust, they lose business and they lose their workers, so we need to be very careful in how we go forward with this. We have got a huge opportunity to shape a new vision, and we should get on with it and not restrict it.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the collaborative economy is a good thing. It is good for consumers, it is good for growth and jobs, and it is good for the environment. The collaborative economy will be worth more than EUR 85 billion to Europe by 2025: this is only eight years away. This is to prove that, if we empower consumers, it is to benefit all of us. I believe this is a message supported by the majority in this House, but for this to work, we need to focus on removing hurdles and creating a business-friendly environment.  My Group has great concerns about the lack of clarity about applicable rules, but we are even more worried by the risk of market fragmentation when we see protectionist measures and anti-single market policies adopted in some Member States and by some individual cities. So we call on the Commission to ensure that both the Member States and regional and local authorities respect the rules set down in the Service Directive, including market access rules. The time has come to embrace the digital revolution. We should not attempt to protect traditional service providers from this transformation, and instead should let competition force them to modernise. If we do not embrace this fact, not only will we be holding back Europe, we will be keeping our citizens from a world of better service, lower prices and more choice. So let us have the courage to give consumers what they want, and say ‘no’ to those self-interested groups that try to stand in the way.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group.- Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we all know that the platform revolution has taken place in recent years within an old and inadequate framework of rules.An opportunity for growth for all has thus been reduced to a business for the few.In this wild West the result is an unfair market, where few players concentrate resources, damaging the pluralism of the media, production sectors and consumer rights.This text has the undoubted merit of photographing this situation and pointing out the distortions of the market, but it seems to me too weak in suggesting solutions.We need to ask more forcefully for the protection of consumers, especially minors, and the protection of workers, and to demand full editorial responsibility for online platforms.To do this, we need to put our hand to an e-commerce directive, which is now seventeen years old and therefore completely outdated.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - So, when we talk about digital platforms and the collaborative economy, we are of course entering a path of certain unpredictability, although of course this form of economy is becoming a reality. And precisely because it is a kind of sui generis phenomenon as well, it needs to be addressed through many of its influences. Impacts on competitiveness, of course, also on the so-called fair and unfair competition, impact on the environment, impact also on social and labor rights. There is, of course, also consumer protection and the issue of liability. So, of course, I think that this system also needs to be properly regulated to protect all these phenomena that can be affected by this system of digital platforms and the collaborative economy. It is clear, however, that if the development of this collaborative economy is not followed by development and adjustment in the field of labor and social rights, then of course everything will turn into complete precariousness, which reduces legal flexibility and social security of labor rights. I think, of course, that this is why it is necessary to define that even in these relations of the collaborative economy, the relationship between those who give, offer the possibility of action, and those who receive, must not act as a service, but above all as a working relationship.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group.- Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the vision of society that we have puts the whole citizen at the center and therefore those online collaborative economy platforms that do the same must be supported.This is why we need a regulatory framework that does not generalize but can adapt to the various sectoral categories.It is also essential to distinguish between commercial and non-commercial activities. Making your apartment available a few days a year is very different from making it available systematically throughout the year or making more apartments available.Therefore, the conditions must be created to help the local economy, avoiding abuses and unfair competition.It is this type of economy and this type of service that should be favored.And this means putting the citizen at the center, supported by a healthy economy.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, the collaborative economy and the use of digital platforms are a real revolution for many economic sectors that are already severely destabilized. A balanced and non-partisan analysis should have taken stock of the opportunities offered by this new economic model, but above all should have paid special attention to the immense risks it poses to millions of people. The concerns of the rapporteurs are front. They are primarily concerned only with the fragmentation of the single market, which they believe is threatened by uncoordinated legal responses by Member States to try to regulate the sector. The collaborative economy is first and foremost the result of organized economic deregulation, a contraction of the real economy and wages, the explosion of unemployment and tax hype. Monetizing private goods is not a choice, but most of the time becomes an economic necessity. The solutions put forward will therefore be of no use other than political. They thus tend to guarantee only one thing: compliance with the European Commission timetable on the digital single market. The real basic issues are forgotten: digital independence and network security, the stability of the real economy and the labor market, the protection of consumers and businesses, and the fight against tax dumping.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Madam President, the mockery and exploitation of the unemployed to survive is working models, such as the digital, co-operative or solidarity economy, social co-operatives and other auspicious but very dangerous anti-labor promoted by the European Union. They cover up unemployment, generalize flexible employment without rights, such as insurance, with starvation wages or not at all, since workers are considered entrepreneurs, shareholders or volunteers in companies destined to close or be absorbed by bigger fish. It is a Trojan horse for privatizations in health, welfare, education, water supply, energy, etc. A tool of deception of employees, such as the company ENKLO in Greece that a for-profit fund, in order to reopen it, blackmails the fired people that they will rot in unemployment if they do not forget their claims from accrued and compensations, turning them into shares of a bankrupt company and former owners. The workers should not be divided but should overthrow the barbarism by claiming their modern needs with their united class struggle.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I would like to thank everyone who was involved in drawing up these reports, because the result of this cooperation that goes beyond the boundaries of the committees is very satisfactory. Firstly, it has to be said that we are experiencing massive changes that we all understand only very incompletely, and that we agree that the digital possibilities have already changed our habits considerably and have simplified our lives overall in many places. Second, however, many rules that have been created for analog markets are not all so suitable to achieve the desired effects in the digital area in the same way. I would like to focus my speech here primarily on those platforms that have a so-called gatekeeper function and are therefore a mandatory requirement for all companies as a barrier to entry into this internal market. However, these gatekeeper platforms have so far only obeyed their own rules and self-imposed principles, which makes it difficult for many start-ups in Europe to grow to the extent that they could grow, to use the innovations as they invented them. That is why we urgently need to readjust from the point of view of competition law, because we have to ensure that the principles of the social market economy also apply in the digital age as they did in the analogue age.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: - Madam President, the digital economy offers great possibilities for Europe: there we risk our future. If we want a prosperous digital economy, we must establish a clear regulatory framework, which provides security and certainty to citizens and companies, which generates quality employment and not precariousness. The key is in training, in the continuous and constant improvement of the digital skills of present and future workers to avoid exclusion. The key is in a clear regulatory framework and in its compliance, closing the cracks through which those who claim to come to modernize the economy sneak in and only come to violate the failures in their regulations without adding value. The key is in a social and labor protection regime that protects workers alike, that avoids old forms of exploitation in new clothes. The key is that taxes are paid, as has been said, where the benefits are generated. The key, therefore, is to make the online economy an economy to move towards a more just society and without new or old exclusions.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: - Dear colleagues, tomorrow we will vote on two reports related to the digital economy, which offers many opportunities, both for consumers and for businesses. Our job is to solve problems where they arise. Sometimes, however, I think the pendulum here in this hemisphere tends to swing a bit to the other side. Sometimes we create new problems for new initiatives and innovation. The reason why many large platforms come from outside the European Union is not because of a lack of rules, but because of too many of them. That is why I think that similar online and offline services, as has already been mentioned here, should simply be subject to the same rules. On liability and consumer rights, I am very pleased to see that the Commission is organizing a series of workshops with Member States and with the industry, and I think it would be good to involve the European Parliament in this as well. Then colleagues might see that some of the rules that are before us are redundant.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: – Madam President, many colleagues talk about the collaborative economy, but I will focus on the online platforms. It has become quite trendy that, when something bad happens in society or the economy, the online platforms are blamed. When there is a terrorist attack, then the circus starts: we blame the internet; governments ask for action and require companies to remove content faster. When do we stop? At what point do we understand that you can take down content, but it will reappear somewhere else – that no filtering technology is able to make moral judgment of what is right and what is wrong? Maybe sometimes it is better that the private companies – especially not European – take a bit more time to decide how to silence free speech. The European Commission is to be criticised for not proposing anything in the past 15 years on the notice and takedown procedure, but any colleague who thinks that they have found a perfect scapegoat in the internet needs to think more about what is right or what is wrong.

name: Michel REIMON
text: - Madam President! There seems to be a broad consensus that we want to promote online platforms, the digital economy. But sometimes I have the impression that the ends and means are getting mixed up. The goal, the public interest that we are pursuing with it can be multiple. We want high-quality jobs in Europe, we want data and data protection in Europe, and of course we also want sales, profits and tax payments in Europe - these are public interests. And this is how we should shape the promotion of the digital economy. Sometimes I have the impression that the promotion of the digital economy itself - the main thing is that these companies are here, even if the jobs are bad, even if they no longer pay taxes, even if we give in on data protection - is already a goal in itself . Then we would do more harm than good with deregulation. I am advocating a very balanced approach here. I do not believe that this is the case with all amendments. I even see motions that go in the direction of, yes, censorship, surveillance and so on and allow the only cuts there. This is going in the wrong direction. We will look closely at how the votes go.

name: Petr MACH
text: - I must say that I am very concerned about the coming censorship on the Internet.In this report on the digital market, Facebook wants to step up the fight against harmful content.The EU wants to take action against the spread of false news.It is intended to combat the online spread of hate speech.You recently prosecuted Marine Le Pen for allegedly perpetrating her alleged crime for sharing photos of Islamic State crimes on Facebook, and today prosecuted her father for saying on the radio that90% of crime is committed by migrants or descendants of migrants.Please remember Voltaire, who said, "I do not agree with what you are saying, but until death I will defend your right to say so."Don't take people's freedom of speech, don't try to regulate the internet.It is a place where, at least in my country in the Czech Republic, opinions are still allowed to be expressed freely.

name: Anne SANDER
text: - Madam President, the collaborative economy has enormous potential, and Europe has the assets to become a leader in this area.This new digital economy indeed allows many retirees, young people, unemployed, students or precarious employees to find a job and supplement their income.Our entrepreneurs are inventing new services every day and we must encourage the development of these start-ups.However, the question of the law applicable to these platforms needs to be clarified.The adjective collaborative cannot be a marketing slogan that, in reality, hides a massive circumvention of social rules, unfair competition for our artisans and SMEs, consumer deception and tax avoidance.A fair framework is therefore necessary, and we look forward to the concrete measures that the Commission will propose in this regard.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Madam President! Today's discussion is an important prerequisite for the success of the digital single market - one of the most important and ambitious projects of the current Commission, the implementation of which will be decisive for Europe's economic future. The collaborative economy is a driving force behind this. Nicola Danti has presented a comprehensive and well-founded report. For us Social Democrats, the following points are particularly important: We need a legal framework that promotes the development of this sector and that deserves consumer confidence. This applies equally to all areas of application - regardless of whether I reserve a room, book a car trip or download a text. But the collaborative economy is not just a business opportunity; rather, it could also be understood as an opportunity for a renaissance of the economy for the common good. Above all, however, it must be developed in accordance with the legitimate protection needs of employees and ensure fair remuneration.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: - Madam President, Commissioner. Today is the last day of roaming. I refer to this because progress in the integration of the telecommunications market is a path that runs parallel to the digital single market. They are facts that intertwine us more as Europeans, that make the European project closer and more palpable. The Digital Single Market is certainly an opportunity for business innovation in Europe. But, for this, it must be accompanied by a legislative body that provides the same standards for all. Our small companies, medium-sized companies, our freelancers, are all they ask of us: legal security and a framework of fair and fair competition. Digitization and new technologies will continue to transform forms of communication, access to information and the behavior of citizens and companies, and both traditional business models and those based on new online platforms must pay attention not only to technological demands but to all the new demands of European citizens.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the collaborative economy, if promoted and developed in a responsible way, can create new opportunities for consumers and entrepreneurs and contribute significantly to the economic growth of the European Union. In recent years, this phenomenon has experienced rapid growth in terms of users, transactions and revenues, redefining the way products and services are provided in many sectors. There are various business models operating in this market, allowing the exchange of goods or services all over the world. Unfortunately, the legislation in this area is still fragmented and very often the regulations of collaborative platforms depend on local and national regulations. It is therefore necessary to develop a European strategy on the collaborative economy to define a legal framework that is clear and harmonized and to ensure compliance with tax obligations. Finally, it will be very important to develop stricter international standards on social protection and privacy.

name: Michał BONI
text: – Madam President, I would first like to thank the rapporteurs very much. For some, online platforms represent one of the biggest regulatory challenges. They fall under existing EU regulations such as consumer protection, competition, data protection and e-commerce. I believe this is sufficient. We do not need one—size—fits—all solutions, because online platforms take various forms: internet search engines, purchasing platforms, platforms for cooperation or sharing of certain goods and services, social media sites. The key issues for the report are transparency, the use of information, the relation between platforms and their suppliers, the conditions of switching between comparable services offered by platforms, and a model of the liability of online intermediaries, including ways to tackle illegal content. But be careful about redundant expectations. Companies cannot play the role previously held by national courts and legislators in judging what is or is not illegal or bad. In a digitally changing world the functions of platforms can be changed every day, so we have to monitor the current situation, checking whether any new rules are needed or not.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: - Madam President! Yes, the platform economy has a huge potential both in terms of consumers, for the utilization of resources, which are good for the environment, and for companies. And in our report from Danti, we also highlight the many opportunities that the digital economy offers us. But we Social Democrats have also ensured that in the report we also address the pitfalls of the digital economy. The digital economy must not become an eldorado for companies that do not want to pay taxes. Platform economy must not become a scapegoat for those companies that want to avoid protecting consumers and workers. Proper working conditions, fair competition and tax payment are something we will have to regulate in the digital economy. We have done this in the analogue, therefore we must also do it in the digital one. So we call on the Commission and the Member States to dare to address this. Regulation is the only way to ensure that the digital economy is good for everyone.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - The regulation of online platforms of private companies with global coverage and economic and political influence is an extremely complex problem that our society will face for years to come, as the report by colleagues Virkkunen and Juvin makes it clear. The dissemination of false news and hate speech, the development of digital propaganda and, at the same time, the economic loss of journalists and other creators of cultural and creative content show that we need to address these issues. I therefore welcome the proposal for a directive on audiovisual services, which also covers shared video platforms, which requires the rapid removal of harmful content on platforms. Today, young people watch half as much time on television as their parents. Therefore, the requirements that apply to traditional television broadcasting need to be extended to digital platforms. In the future, I would also welcome the European Commission to draw up specific guidelines for identifying and removing harmful content.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, on the day when we see the end of roaming, it is good to be discussing the digital economy and the next steps forward to make Europe the world leader into the future in this whole area. Having been involved as a rapporteur for the Data Protection Regulation, I am slightly worried that we might go too far and not get the balance right. I am just looking at some of the proposals in the Privacy Directive, and I think they are gold—plating some of the balanced proposals we had in the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). The same goes for platforms: we have got to get this right so that the economy can grow and so that consumers are protected, and all the other things mentioned by colleagues, like paying tax, B2B, etc., all have to be done properly, because the Digital Single Market is our way forward in Europe. If we can get it right, maybe the United Kingdom might want to stay, or at least come back in again.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the sharing economy is a rapidly growing reality which can now be seen as a driving force for a competitive European economy and which, applied to products and services, can offer undoubted opportunities for consumers, workers and businesses. Opportunities which, however, are accompanied by a series of challenges and criticalities which must be faced. In fact, as often happens in the face of new phenomena, the reaction was individual rather than collective. Some states, unlike others, have tried to regulate the phenomenon at regional or local level, but this regulatory fragmentation risks producing potential distortions and unfair competition in the European single market. There is therefore a clear need for a coherent legal framework, defining minimum standards for the defense of competition, the protection of consumers and workers' rights, taxation and corporate social responsibility. Clear common rules will allow the collaborative economy to grow and bear fruit on an employment and social level.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I agree with what has been said here in the area of ​​the digital economy that this is a huge opportunity for the future. An opportunity for our businesses and for consumers as well, but I do not agree that over-regulation of this environment should be prepared, because it carries a lot of risks. I know that one part of that legislation is actually two decades behind, so it's quite old in the digital age, it's like 200 years. On the other hand, I am afraid that we will really carefully consider what specific regulations we will try to incorporate into that legislation, ie. what specific obligations. With regard to copyright, I would like to emphasize that we should focus primarily on the possibility of settling rights for the entire internal market, but we should not interfere too much in our own content. With digital media, printed matter is actually impossible. I am strongly opposed to the same obligations being the same as those of the terrestrial media, for example.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs on achieving a consistent and balanced text. There is already a consensus that the collaborative economy brings benefits related to both the diversification of services and the flexibility of the labor market. In transport, the collaborative economy has had a positive effect on decongestion and lower tariffs, and tourism has experienced a real revolution, especially by increasing the number of transactions brokered by online platforms. However, there are still some issues that require rapid intervention at European level. I am a great supporter of all the opportunities brought to the European business environment by the collaborative economy, but also a supporter of a fair competitive environment. Thus, the collaborative economy needs to be used as a way to avoid tax obligations. There is a need for transparency and collaboration between competent authorities and collaborative platforms on compliance with tax provisions and tax collection. Also, new professional opportunities should not lead to the erosion of social issues, and the European legislative framework must provide adequate protection for all those working in the collaborative economy, regardless of their status.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: - Mr Danti's report is a first step towards a comprehensive and balanced EU strategy on the sharing economy.The responsible development of a shared economy can bring many benefits to citizens and consumers.At the same time, however, there is no doubt that the sharing economy can have a significant impact on established business models in many sectors, such as transport or regulated accommodation.Businesses, consumers and even supervisors today often do not know how to apply existing legislation in some areas.It is therefore necessary to address gray areas in the field of regulation, to avoid tax evasion and to ensure a high level of consumer protection.I also support proposals to strengthen aspects of social issues, including the protection of workers, social security or the call for closer involvement of the social partners.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission welcomes the Parliament’s own—initiative reports on the collaborative economy and platforms debated today under the digital economy. This debate, as you know, is only a first step in what should be a continuous and joint effort between the institutions to credibly respond to the many and decisive emerging and future challenges that the rise of the platform—intermediated economy will raise. Having said that, we cannot forget that platforms do not operate in a legal vacuum, and that an effective enforcement of existing legal instruments should be the default course of action. An innovation—friendly approach is clearly in the interests of existing as well as new platform firms. Consumer protection, competition, law and data protection legislation are particularly important in this regard. This is why I welcome your timely deliberations, exchanges and reports.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: speaker. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thanks to the colleagues who have spoken, thanks to the Commissioner for the attention the Commission has shown, but above all for a point that he said and which I would like to emphasize. Well, let's start working on a specific issue, on an important issue, that of the definition and clear distinction between professional and non-professional operators. It is a first issue on which we could immediately work and find guidelines that serve to orient the debate, to juridically orient the European framework. I think we must avoid a debate between who is over-regulated and who thinks that the free market can just guarantee.
