I think we must instead work on a European framework because, if the rules we have today had been sufficient, we would not have found ourselves today with 28 national legislations, with 100 regional legislations, with each city deciding as it sees fit with respect to the issues and challenges that the collaborative economy, in some sectors in particular, highlights. So I think we should think about this, about how we can help the collaborative economy to be a strength of the European Union's development. We have peculiarities in our collaborative economy, we have small platforms very rooted in the territory. Let's make this a strength, give it the strength to be able to develop. This certainly passes from a more homogeneous regulatory framework and also passes from resources and risk capital that we will have to put in place. This is the challenge we have. It is a difficult challenge. European platforms lack neither intelligence, nor creativity, nor innovation, nor technological capabilities. We need the trust of the European institutions, we need a stimulus to do better and to establish ourselves throughout the world.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: demonstrator. - Mr President, I would like to thank all my colleagues and committee representatives and, of course, the co-rapporteur, Mr Juvin, for this work and a good debate. Here, quite a few people in their speeches called for and demanded new legislation. It is quite clear that the digital economy brings us new types of challenges, but it may not always be the right solution to increase legislation, but it is important to evaluate our existing legislation and ensure that it is properly implemented in the various Member States. For example, competition law is a very important tool when it comes to large online platforms, but its implementation needs to be speeded up and the resolution of these cases needs to be speeded up in the digital world. Here the Commission has gone in the right direction. Another very important directive for us is the e-commerce directive, which already makes it clear that if content is illegal, platforms must remove it. It must now be borne in mind that, in different Member States, slightly different things have been defined as illegal. For example, at the moment, the big challenge we have is hate speech. Its definition in the various Member States has proved to be very different, and even platforms have a very demanding task within a few hours of deciding what is hate speech and what is not. Here we need to find the right balance so that we do not jeopardize freedom of expression, but nevertheless ensure reliable and correct content. Here, too, platforms can take on a lot of responsibility and evaluate their own practices. It is clear that consumers need to be properly protected, but I believe that, above all, we need to invest in ensuring that citizens are also well placed to act in the digital world. It means that our education must be of a good standard, so that people have the ability to appreciate the products and services that are offered to them in the digital world and beyond, and that they have the opportunity to make a real choice and make solutions.Of course, the own transparency of online platforms also plays an important role here.It is important that we find a good balance between where legislation is needed and what can be resolved through good cooperation with online platforms.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: protractor. - Madam President, Commissioner, in 1911, in Paris, there was a cab driver strike. They went on strike because they saw car taxis hit the market. They said the world was falling apart, because it was going to ruin everyone. Well no! Today there is an automobile industry in Europe. The cab drivers were wrong. When I heard Mrs. Troszczynski, a member of the National Front, who left - she came for 60 seconds today and she has already left, but I am going to answer her anyway - explain to us that the Google or Facebook platforms, it is barbarism - this is the name that was used by another of her colleagues - and that it can no longer work that way, she did not understand anything. Sorry, but platforms are the key to the modern economy. The fact remains that our role today is to make sure there are rules. Commissioner, allow me to disagree with you. It's true, you are right when you say that there is no legal vacuum, there are laws, fortunately, but it seems to me that a number of these laws, today, do not work. not. Today, if you type Dar al-Islam on Google, on the front page you have the Daesh newspaper explaining to you how to kill someone, how to carry out an attack, etc. In October, I wrote to Google asking them to remove this page - forgive me, it's not censorship - and the page still exists. Therefore, I think there is a problem and we have to find solutions. These solutions, I do not know them, but, as Henna Virkkunen said, we must at least assess the effectiveness of our current laws. Most are unsuitable. We don't necessarily want to legislate, but we want rules. It may be self-regulation, but it will take some smart thing.I also share everyone's concerns.Mr. Kelly was right earlier when he said, "Above all, no over-regulation".We must not move from a system with inadequate legislation to a system that creates gas factories.He is right.We must not over-regulate, but we must find sometimes legislative solutions to issues that are fundamental.If we don't do this, we will not have a European digital single market, we will have missed a stage in Europe, we will not have European champions.That is simply the purpose of this report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 15 June 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - The concept of "collaborative economy" is extremely multifaceted and changeable, although it is based on two well-known fundamental criteria: the free exchange of goods and services and the use of the Internet. But this economic model, in the forms of the sharing economy on demand, of collaborative consumption and capitalism based on crowdfunding, being inextricably linked to the exchange economy and technology, now puts supply and demand in communication more than real time and facilitates yes. transactions, but remains influenced by their strengths and weaknesses inherent in these instruments. Indeed, it is indubitable that we are moving towards a model of predictive economy, in which the final consumer is called - I would say by necessity - to adopt collaboration systems, in which he believes he can find a sense of greater confidence in access to the financial and fiscal market. . Once again, therefore, these new economic phenomena, which will soon go to the most extreme barter trading, denote rejection and distrust of the Banking Union, which has not yet solved the crucial challenges of security, data privacy, consumer protection and fair competition.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. – I support the enhancement of the collaborative economy, as it provides citizens with further possibilities for flexible working arrangements and additional sources of income, which are very important mainly for young people, part-time workers, seniors and other workers threatened by exclusion. However, the business models of collaborative platforms must be unquestioningly in compliance with the existing legal framework. Although I see a rapid growth and increasing importance of the collaborative economy, I am not convinced our legislation entirely responds to the challenges of this sector. Therefore I call for further optimisation of the legislation, in order to maintain the high level of protection of all stakeholders involved. Moreover, we need a clear system of rules that would prevent risks of tax avoidance and unfair competition towards traditional sectors and incumbent actors.  On the other hand, in order to fully benefit from the potential of the collaborative economy, the EU should promote a culture of sharing and assist providers of collaborative platforms to gain the trust of mass markets. The collaborative economy leads to more effective usage of resources. For example, shared car rides do not just help to reduce traffic jams and tackle the problem with parking in cities, but are also more eco-friendly.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - There is no doubt that in recent years there has been an extremely dynamic development of the sharing economy, which has led to a significant change in the way products and services are delivered. This type of economy offers many opportunities for European consumers who benefit from more competition, more tailored services, more choice and lower prices. At the same time, however, so-called co-consumption has challenged well-established economic models in many sectors such as transport, accommodation, catering, services, retail and finance. Accordingly, there have been demands for detailed regulation of the collaborative economy to be developed as soon as possible. In my opinion, however, it is primarily necessary to reflect on how, on the one hand, to maintain fair competition conditions for all entities on the free market, and on the other hand, not to limit or even eliminate co-consumption. It is also worth remembering that the sharing economy in Europe has a number of specific features, including with a European business structure made up largely of micro-enterprises and SMEs. That is why I warn against the consequences of too strict regulation of new business models, which would be extremely difficult for smaller entities to bear.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. - The rapid development of the collaborative economy, also known as the community economy or community consumption, has changed the way the market functions in terms of delivering products and services. The concept of the social economy is very broad and covers a range of activities based on various business models based on cooperation, also on non-commercial principles. The result is a blurring of the traditional boundaries between the consumer and supplier, employee and self-employed person, as well as professional and unprofessional service provision. This presents a challenge to EU legislation in many respects. One of the positive effects of the collaborative economy is environmentally and socially sustainable economic development. To maintain such development, it is necessary to ensure consumer protection independent of the level of professionalisation of the service provider. It is equally important to protect employees of enterprises who, due to the atypical legal nature of their activity, may not yet be subject to appropriate labor laws. Uniform tax law standards should be established to avoid the possibility of an enlargement of the shadow economy and unfair competition with legal entities operating on the market. Responsible development of the social economy can bring many benefits to consumers, who will benefit from increased competition, as well as to employees from the creation of new jobs. It is therefore important to ensure that this sector is able to access the capital it needs for development and cross-border competition.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the taxation of ports (2017/2704(RSP)).

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: member of the Commission. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission agrees with Parliament that investment in ports is crucial for our economy. State aid rules facilitate this process more than they oppose it. First of all, I want to clarify an important point, which is that the rules on state aid apply to aid which distorts competition. Therefore, the control exercised by the Commission is limited to the economic activity of the ports. The Commission has neither the power nor the intention to prevent Member States from compensating ports for the cost of tasks falling under the prerogatives of the public authorities. This applies for example to security or - this is in the sense of my portfolio - to activities related to customs controls or the police. Such compensation is simply not state aid. However, even when the aid relates to economic activities, the rules on state aid help to facilitate investment. Recently, the Commission defined clear criteria in the General Block Exemption Regulation which allow Member States to support the realization of certain investments in ports without requesting prior authorization from the Commission. The new regulations apply equally to all ports, whether they are under the control of private or public shareholders. It is based on the well-established decision-making practice of the Commission on aid for investment in ports. In all of the cases it has dealt with to date, the Commission has approved state aid, after verifying that it was limited to what is strictly necessary to generate the investment. The new regulation now gives Member States more clarity and also more flexibility when granting aid to ports. Member States may carry out public investment of up to 150 million euros in seaports and up to 50 million euros in inland ports, with full legal certainty now. Public authorities can also finance dredging costs, as well as access waterways. The regulation on port services, which entered into force on March 24, introduced, moreover, a requirement of financial transparency, which facilitated the inclusion of port investments in the general block exemption regulation that I mentioned. . As you can see, the Commission has therefore recently made it a lot easier to invest in ports under state aid rules, but, you know, it is in its role when it ensures a level playing field. fair, fair competition, in this economic sector which is quite significant. This is why the Commission is taking a closer look at corporate tax exemptions for public and private ports. These exemptions are very different from the investment aid that the Commission facilitates. Indeed, they are not targeted on the financing of certain investments, certain costs. They are not transparent, nor do they pursue an objective of general interest, such as the promotion of mobility or multimodal transport. In fact, tax savings - and that's the point - can be used for any type of business. These exemptions, in our view, are also not fit for purpose, as they are not limited to what is necessary to make the investment which, again, is the virtuous aspect of port economy. On the contrary, corporate tax exemptions are proportional to profits. This has a completely paradoxical effect, which is that the small loss-making ports, those ports which have arguably the most in need of support, are deprived of any benefit, while the larger ports, which are the most profitable, derive the greatest benefit. It's a bit of the world upside down, and it doesn't seem justified or fair. As guardian of the Treaties, the Commission must precisely guarantee a level playing field in the internal market. That’s why we’re looking at the corporate tax exemptions for ports in more detail. Of course, the Commission treats all Member States on an equal footing when applying state aid rules. The surveys, which started in 2013, showed that most Member States subject the economic activities of their ports to the normal corporate tax regime. The Commission is currently studying the tax regime in several Member States where this is not the case. These investigations are not all at the same stage. The reason is that the Commission was not informed at the same time about the tax measures in the different Member States. For example, she became aware of the tax provisions in the Netherlands during a larger investigation into the tax exemption for public enterprises, a few years before she learned of similar measures taking place. applying to ports in other Member States. The Commission has also focused its action on Member States where competition concerns warranted swift action. It has made good progress in its investigations into French and Belgian ports. It has also made progress in examining possible tax advantages for ports in other Member States. No final decision has yet been adopted in these cases. I am fully aware, as well as my colleague Margrethe Vestager, whom I represent here, of the demands of this Parliament calling on the Commission to disclose Member States' responses to our questions on ports and taxation. I would like to stress that the information Member States provide to the Commission during state aid investigations is protected and confidential, in particular as long as the Commission has not brought such investigations to an end. Of course, the Commission remains committed to explaining its approach to ports to this Parliament, as I am doing today. It will inform the European Parliament as soon as it has completed the additional inquiries into tax exemptions for ports. She also stands ready to explain to you how she facilitates investments in ports, as she has done in the General Block Exemption Regulation, as well as in many state aid cases. That is why I thank you for raising this question, which, I think, allows to bring all the useful clarifications, in any case all those that are possible at this stage, and I wait of course with a lot of interest the debate which will follow.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - The day is coming to an end, but we still have to deal with a tough bit of food at the moment. I would like to thank the Commissioner for his interim answer - that is how I would describe it - because I understand that we are getting further information. Still, I am a bit confused. On the one hand, he says: we are not ready, but we have already started proceedings against the Netherlands, Belgium and France. On what grounds did that happen? We do not know the results of the 2013 survey, they are also confidential. I understand that to a certain extent, although it is then very difficult for Parliament to judge exactly what is happening. And, Mr President, I understand that state aid to ports is a sensitive subject. We have actually been working on this for decades now: what is allowed and what is not allowed? As the EPP Group, we are pleased that the general exception has been increased, so that there is less of a question of state aid, but I do have a great need for a comprehensive overview and therefore again my question: why have already started three procedures, while the research in its entirety is not yet finished? Thank you very much.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Commissioner, first of all, thank you for your answer, although I am still sitting on my ... a bit. The landscape of the ports in Europe is very diverse. You have large ports, you have small ports, you also have large ports in small Member States, you also have small ports in large Member States. You have ports in the hands of the public, so of the government, private ports, and everything in between, and also many different tax systems. That is the diversity of our port landscape and I fully understand the Commission, which absolutely has to fulfill its task of ensuring that there is no improper state aid, that there is a level playing field, but then you really have to apply it. Today, as my colleague said, an infringement procedure against France, Belgium and the Netherlands, which is not based on a level playing field and a good discussion of what really matters, and that is not okay. So I think it's important that the questionnaire launched by the European Commission leads to a very broad survey, and that we have a real discussion about how we want to run our ports. I think it is incredibly important that we do not focus on a few Member States, but that we treat all ports on the same level and that we make sure that other criteria are in place, especially environmental, social criteria, ensure that we have a very good logistics system. I think that the Commission should look at the infringement procedure against those three Member States in a different way and now ensure a really level playing field in the debate.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Thank you, Mr Moscovici, I have listened very carefully to you, but I must largely agree with the previous speakers. The Commission, headed by Mr Vestager, has always been a staunch defender of a free market with fair competition. Like a true “Iron Lady of Danmark”, Mrs. Verstager fought with multinationals, with cartels, with dishonest companies. But today, in this file, I note that her zeal has the opposite effect. In proceedings against three Member States, she believes that Member States should tax the port institutions as if they were purely commercial companies. That is a bad decision that cripples employment, growth and investments in our Flemish and European ports. And I wonder whether this is a covert strategy to get involved in the taxation of the Member States or whether the real aim is to underpin our ports. Our port companies do perform public tasks and therefore the state aid rules cannot be applied without further ado. With that attitude, you jeopardize the international competitiveness of our ports in favor of Shanghai, Singapore, Hong Kong, etc. And penalizing three countries for a practice applied across the EU is selective and anti-European.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President! Commissioner, thank you very much for your introduction. It really is like this: What takes a long time will finally be good. We talked for a long time, for several years about the service package for the ports in Europe and about the so-called port package 3, which we recently concluded. Indeed, it was a condition of Parliament that we said: the block exemption regulation must please come. The ports must be released - anything else would be bad for our competitiveness. Incidentally, this concerns all European ports, not just Dutch ones. After the first three speakers, all of whom come from the Netherlands, you could almost think that this is only about the Netherlands, which of course has many ports - but we have in Germany too. I think that what has happened now has turned out very well - I am deliberately not talking about taxes now, but about the block exemption regulation, which we are really striving for. I think it's good that we now know exactly what the public sector can invest in infrastructure and how much without having to obtain any concessions, and that is fixed: that can be 150 million euros per year in seaports and 50 million euros in inland ports - they are also recorded, that makes things a lot easier and is really a piece of bureaucracy reduction. I also think it's good that there was no longer any distinction between initial dredging and maintenance dredging. Of course, it also plays a major role - or is important and welcomed - that there is no longer any punishment and that it is cleared when waterways are dredged into or from the ports, as well as investments in the beginning of the port-hinterland connection, namely for example rails and highways that lead directly out of the ports. I also think so too It is welcomed that in this case the infrastructure for alternative fuels and investments that one wants to make there for ships, for shore power for example or also for LNG, is also covered by the exemption.What I think is a shame is that in this case there has still not been any distinction made between public and general infrastructure in terms of aid.That is still unclear, it would make things even easier.But overall, the competitiveness of our ports has been significantly strengthened.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, it is in the name of the miraculous competition and the liberalization of the single market that the Commission takes an interventionist role in decisions that only the States are responsible for, in defining what their sovereign development policies should be. More than the discussion of those decisions, what should motivate the debate are the consequences and losses for the States that result from the privatization of a strategic sector for the economy, the port activity, or the harmful consequences of this competition in the national context, or the assault that you are promoting the working conditions of port workers, namely stowage, imposing precariousness, stealing rights and wages, while the companies that operate there accumulate profits for shareholders, who are not reinvested in the development of the parents. The Commission may well want to assume itself as a champion of justice: we know the responsibilities it has in imposing austerity policies, privatizations, the destruction of countries 'productive apparatus and the assault on workers' rights.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, Mr Moscovici is gone, I hope you take note, because what I am going to say is important. The Commission criticizes the Netherlands, Belgium and France for having too favorable a tax regime for their ports, since these three countries exempt them from corporate tax. Until then - I am speaking to the Commission - you are doing your job: applying European legislation, so be it! But you had sent questionnaires to the Member States to establish, for each of them, an inventory concerning the submission of ports to corporate tax. This is where the problem begins. Why refuse at all costs to communicate the results? We are Parliament. Why such a lack of transparency? This silence is not without consequence, as it stirs up suspicion. Why start with the Netherlands, then Belgium, then France and not the others? Above all, why not opt ​​for a more political approach by bringing all the Member States concerned around the table in order to reflect together on what the taxation of ports should be? Quite simply because, Gentlemen, I tell you, ports are quite simply not businesses like any other.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, at least at ten in the evening I hope that this House can make simple things simple and not always make them complicated. To respect the historical, mercantile and economic value of ports, concrete actions are obviously needed. I try to name three. Surely it is necessary to defend our ports, that is to say stop using our Italian ports as a reception door to clandestinity. It is also necessary to open an investigation by virtue of what the European Court of Auditors has attested to the port of Rotterdam; I would like to recall the 2016 audit 23 which says that the necessary checks on incoming goods are not applied in the port of Rotterdam, and therefore we need to open an investigation on this, I say the Commission. The other theme is: leave taxes to whom? Obviously leave the ports taxes at the port for the services of that port. It is unthinkable to squeeze, plunder the virtuosity, for example of the port of Genoa, to the detriment of the port to distribute to other less effective, less capable ports.

name: Ivo BELET
text: - I'm going to speak in Dutch. I've lost - no, only - five seconds. Hereby. We think that the Commissioner, ports and port companies are not economic players like other companies and they do have a broader remit. They are public companies whose purpose is to promote the general interest, without making a profit. I think we should do everything in our power to make our European ports - large and small, also in the Netherlands and France and also in Belgium - even stronger. In the meantime, I think, if I may just mention that, that we should also be aware of other developments in the port domain that are currently underway. Look, Commissioner, what is happening in Greece with the port of Piraeus: more than half of it was recently taken over by a Chinese public company. It would therefore be a good thing for the Commission to tackle such issues as well, and to concentrate on such situations where vital public infrastructure in Europe, in European transport companies, falls into the hands of non-European governments. In the recent European Commission policy paper on globalization, the Commission announces measures to this effect. We would like, Commissioner, that the Commission should also concentrate on this, that, as he himself said, it should show the necessary flexibility and that it would do everything in its power to ensure that our ports are as strong as possible internationally.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! I am not Dutch, and I will not particularly regret that there is an ongoing investigation into Dutch, Belgian or French ports. On the other hand, there will undoubtedly be less interest in the methodology used by the Commission, how the investigation works, what needs to be determined, what the findings will be, why. I agree with my fellow speakers here that a seaport is not pure business. These are services, this is an object that represents the general economic interest. Second, it is a component of the transport system, and we want to develop sea-land transport chains; moreover, we would like to move part of this system to the sea via the motorways of the sea. Therefore, investments in a seaport interest me primarily from the point of view of infrastructure. Infrastructure is not the most ideal factor that brings great profits, infrastructure is to be available at a reasonable price, as it serves to increase the competitiveness of the economy. After all, this is the mission of transport: to increase the competitiveness of the European Union's economy. I would also like our tax policy to pay attention to geographic balance and the needs of weaker regions.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ports - as you know, all this has been said on all these banks - are not businesses like any other. In reality, they are not companies. Due to their strategic location, the French port authorities support public service missions by fulfilling crucial sovereign missions. In this hemicycle, moreover, everyone agrees: regional planning, navigation police, fight against terrorism, guarantee of access for transport operators, via dredging, in particular. All these activities specific to public authority cannot be carried out by companies. This is why the co-signatories, of which I am a member, along with the French, Belgians and Dutch, tabled an oral question on the taxation of ports on March 13. Today we are awaiting a response from you that works in our direction and, unfortunately, it is not. For us, the corporate tax exemptions enjoyed by European ports are legitimate and desirable. On the working method of the Commission, as on the substance, everything needs to be reviewed. Commissioner, why not publish the results of the questionnaires sent to the French, Belgian and Dutch tax authorities? Why focus only on the fate of three of the twenty-eight Member States, without further justification? Tomorrow will be the turn of Spain, then Italy? Here is my answer: of the four largest ports, three, which alone represent 72% of the market share, are concerned by the investigation. Only one state emerges from this story unscathed. Which? Germany, with the port of Hamburg. President Juncker announced at the start of his term that the Commission would be more political and more pragmatic. Indeed, I note that the Commission has just taken an eminently political decision, based on a technostructure at the service of Germany.You have investigated the charges, and I ask you to review your copy.I have, moreover, just referred the matter to the President of the French Republic and the ministers concerned, one of whom is a co-signatory of this oral question.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I come from the island of Ireland, and we have many great ports in my own constituency. We have ports like Rosslare, Waterford, Cork and Shannon Foynes, which is one of the most naturally deep-water ports in the world. Our ports have a huge role to play as our economy develops into the future, and also indeed in even tackling climate change, where you should utilise them more to carry cargo and get it off the roads. I think the Commissioner has some worries about taxation and some ports across Europe. I was pleased to hear him say that the information he has gathered so far is confidential – that is the way it should be. It is very important that this will be broadened, that there will be discussion with the Member States involved and that all ports across Europe may be looked at so that we establish a level playing field and that one does not feel discriminated against the other – that is a very important issue. Gathering all the information across Europe and then making it available would be the best way to progress.

name: Franck PROUST
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to welcome recent advances in state aid for ports and airports. I would like to remind you, for example, that one euro invested in an airport is 20 euros in benefits for the territory. Public aid for investment is therefore not in vain. This evening we are talking about ports, the tools necessary for trade between Europe and the world. After questioning Member States on the tax regimes of port systems in July 2013, the Commission launched proceedings against France, Belgium and the Netherlands, without any real transparency. According to the Commission, the exemption from corporation tax is state aid. However, it must be understood, as my colleague Renaud Muselier and other colleagues have just said, that ports are not businesses like any other, because they also perform sovereign public service missions. Following our question with a request for an oral answer, supported by many French, Belgian and Dutch parliamentarians, we have come together, not to give or receive lessons, but to propose solutions. To promote realism, we therefore propose that the Commission suspend its procedures and bring together the port States and their players in the sector, so that listening, understanding the issues and above all the search for sustainable solutions are finally in the foreground. .

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I would like to support my colleagues in calling for the interruption of the Commission's proceedings. It is, I would say, beyond any doubt, that, in the context of transparency, it would be appropriate to first work with data that is comprehensive, as my predecessor said. I would also like to draw our attention to the importance of that inland waterway, because that has not been talked about here. I believe that the importance of those national or inland ports should not be overlooked. I know that there is a limit of EUR 50 million to support them. In my opinion, this limit is insufficient. It was he who was to contribute to shifting the cargo to waterways where it was expedient. Therefore, I would argue that we could still move with that limit and, secondly, that we should also contribute to environmental aspects and our responsibility for climate change in promoting the inland waterway.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: member of the Commission. - Madam President, I would like to thank Parliament for this debate. Basically, it is clear that we agree that ports are of crucial importance in the European Union. The Commission will continue to do what is necessary to facilitate investment and to ensure fair and transparent competition in this sector. As I said earlier, the Commission is committed to informing Parliament as soon as it has completed the ongoing investigations into the area of ​​corporate tax exemptions for ports. She also pledged to explain to Parliament how she facilitates investment in ports, as she has done in the general block exemption regulation in many state aid cases. I think you will recognize that there is substantial progress there. I have heard your various comments, of course. I want to assure you that the Commission is not in the pay of anyone and that it does its job with complete independence. Regarding transparency, you can request information from states. It turns out that the interinstitutional agreement between the European Parliament and the Commission covers the situation, but there is a question of trust between the States and the Commission. Therefore, I think you can address them directly. There is a second question that has been asked, it is the hiatus between, on the one hand, France and Belgium and, on the other hand, the Netherlands, which is due to the fact, as I tried to explain, that the information was not available at the same time. They were available well in advance in the Netherlands, namely from the 2000s. Finally, the question of sovereign missions was raised. I want there to be no ambiguity on this point. In this regard, states do what they want: sovereign missions are not subject to state aid. I think anyway that we must continue to dialogue to shed light on this subject, within the limits of the contract of trust that I mentioned a moment ago and which is also part of our rules and our operating methods.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on statute and funding of European political parties and foundations (2017/2733(RSP)).

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: member of the Commission. - Madam President, I welcome once again this opportunity which is afforded us today to debate the issue of European political parties and foundations. The Commission has taken due note of the points raised during the debate we had on this subject in March. At the time, we expressed our willingness to work with you to see how the new rules worked in practice. As we underlined then, the 2014 regulation makes use of important innovations, in particular reinforced guarantees aimed at ensuring respect for fundamental European values ​​by all parties registered in the system. But even good rules can be improved. The Commission has taken due note of the suggestions for new modifications which could be made to the rules, formulated by some of the existing parties, by certain foundations and by this assembly. She understands that the experience of the operation of the current system in recent months requires further improvements even before the next elections in 2019. This is an ambitious goal, which can only be achieved if changes are made. carefully targeted and if the political ground is well prepared to garner sufficient support, both from your assembly and from the Council. Some of the changes we are discussing today, such as the reduction in the co-financing rate, have been presented by the Commission in the past but have not won the support of the Member States. It will be important, for all those who advocate change, to also defend it in national capitals, because that is where, you know, lies the key to many decisions or decision blockages. Today's debate and the resolution you plan to adopt as a result will be a useful source of food for the Commission. This The latter would appreciate any possibility offered by the European Parliament to continue to seek the views of external experts, in particular through hearings.I cannot prejudge today what decision the College might take on specific change proposals, but I can assure you that we are actively engaged in addressing these issues.As the Commission has already expressed its position on your specific suggestions during the plenary in March, I would just like to reiterate that it is a strong supporter of strong and dynamic political parties, representative at European level, and that itis actively working to examine the best options to continue to further refine the system, to give it more means to meet the fervor of citizens.I look forward to the vote on your resolution in the same spirit.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! In my country, the parties are reimbursed for election campaign costs based on their success in elections. And when parties get donations, the state adds something. The Federal Constitutional Court said: Yes, functioning democracies also need functioning parties. But there are narrow limits for this. And they were set in my country, which does not mean that they are not violated occasionally. But it is then also punished severely. We need European parties and we are glad that a first step has been taken through the existing regulations. But we have seen that these regulations are not enough. Obviously, we couldn't imagine the energy with which some look for loopholes. We think it is a mistake that MPs who have been elected on lists of parties that do not have a European party family set up individual structures, apply for funds, then obviously spend them incorrectly, and if we check and claim the funds back, then the parties are insolvent or no longer there. We need to put a stop to these practices. I also want to say explicitly that I have nothing against not only having to compensate for the damage, but that fines are also established. In any case, we have to close loopholes and not take the time until 2018 that we originally wanted to take, but rather act now.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Madam President, Commissioner, I believe that we all agree that European democracy needs democrats in order to make it truly live. It is therefore obvious that we must find the means to help our democracy to develop. As you said, political parties and foundations play an essential role. We have a responsibility to supervise them, to help them in their development, but also to ensure that their actions correspond to the fundamental principles of the Union, in particular the transparency of their funding, but also the questions that my colleague Wieland recalled. . The resolution that the four political groups co-signed goes in this direction and asks the Commission to take up the subject, by addressing issues such as the level of co-financing, the multi-party system of MEPs, possible abuses relating to the use of way contrary to the fundamental rules of European democracy. We know that you have initiated a reflection and we suggest that you propose changes as soon as possible to meet the demands of European citizens and European democracy. We ask you to act quickly, because the elections are fast approaching.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I speak as a leader of one of those European political parties, the Alliance of European Conservatives and Reformists, whose group here in the European Parliament is the third largest, the ECR Group. I can say that we support some of the new provisions being debated, for instance a reduction in the 15% co-financing obligation, or limiting contributions, or raising the requirement to be represented by three or five MEPs. However, there is one concern, namely that closer scrutiny, to determine whether European political parties respect the fundamental values of the EU, might be misused for a political fight and possibly to make an argument against those parties that do not share the federalist orthodoxy. I can tell you that we have very recently experienced some strange behaviour from the EP administration which might strengthen that feeling. I hope that this will not happen and that, once the provision has been adopted,  everything will be OK, transparent, objective and fair.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! We had this debate three months ago and there have been no new developments since then. So the only intention that remains is to keep the pressure on the Commission. I can therefore repeat what has already been said: In 2014 we passed a regulation that addresses the changed responsibility for the European political parties and represents and defines improved regulations. We have given the parties a clear legal status, defined their rights and obligations and created significantly better financial framework conditions. The question arises as to why MPs from some parties have been pushing for months to revise this regulation, because the regulation itself has not yet been fully implemented. And it was precisely these parties that determined their current specific direction at the time. At the same time, the public is not told what it is about. Why should the prohibition of profit purposes suddenly be softened by definition? If one calls for less own resources to be made available, this means less overall resources as a consequence. Why not say how you want to compensate for this resulting gap? And we are in favor of implementing it first and, from mid-2018 - that is, almost tomorrow - to take a closer look at what may not be sustainable in the long term, including the loopholes.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, our Group is clearly committed to transparency and accountability, especially in the use of public funds. But we are also committed to the idea of a pluralist democracy. Some Groups defended in the past the need to increase the threshold to have access to European funds. They said, and I quote: ‘One should reflect if a one-man party really contributes to expressing the political will of citizens of the Union’.  A party represented by one MEP still needs to be represented in at least a quarter of the Member States in order to be registered. And secondly, no democratic system cuts the funds to a party that has parliamentary representation just because it is represented by one Member. This dangerously undermines a pluralist legitimate debate. Therefore, we welcome the good cooperation at this stage in finding a solution that does not harm the essential dimensions of every functioning democratic society.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, when you state subsidise something, you encourage more of it. Farmers set aside land more regularly, because the European Union pays them to do so. We pay child benefit because it is socially desirable to encourage people to have children. This debate concerns European political parties. You will, I am sure, recall the old joke suggesting that the word ‘politics’ derives from the Greek ‘poly’, meaning ‘many’, and ‘ticks’, meaning ‘blood sucking insects’. The irony of an MEP saying this is not lost on me, but we are subsidising politicians.  European political parties do not appear on ballot papers; they do not form governments; they do not even correspond to the political groups in this place. They exist because we subsidise them. If we actually needed them, they would exist without subsidy. Let us save the taxpayers’ money and find out whether or not we really need them, shall we?

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: - I will talk above all about the proportion of funds that political parties are obliged to generate and thus contribute to the financing of their budget.When it comes to the effective functioning of European political parties and increasing their ability to contribute to the promotion of European values, we should think realistically and halve the current commitment of 15%.7.5% is a realistic figure that will make it possible to address really important aspects of the activities of political parties in public space.I consider the proposal to increase the number of MEPs that a political party must have in order to be financed from the EU budget to be similarly crucial.Unfortunately, the danger of abusing the current regulation, which speaks of only one Member, is too great today, and we should react to it and, as a result, protect European taxpayers' money.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I have repeatedly called on the European Commission to come up with a revision of the Rules governing the status and functioning of parties and the financing of political parties. With this resolution, we draw attention to the fact that there are a number of shortcomings and shortcomings in the current regulation that can have a negative impact on democracy at European level. Unfortunately, the unresolved issues of the past resonate until now and can affect the future of European construction. For several years, extremist parties have infiltrated the European Parliament's political groups and jeopardized the institution's credibility and European values ​​as a whole. That is why we need to make sure that we have the necessary democratic tools at our disposal and that they work to strengthen the European approach. Issues related to the co-financing of the activities of European parties and the criteria for membership of several parties are key elements that need to be reviewed as soon as possible in order to prevent populist scenarios. By amending the problematic provisions of this regulation, I believe that we can achieve a truly European political scene and a European Parliament that represents the interests of the Union and its citizens in a responsible and committed way.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: – Madam President, we can start from the basic proposition that there does indeed exist a European level of politics: the institutions of the European Union, the Member States and the citizens interact in a variety of ways to make this European political system operative. Let me make it clear that, in many ways, this political system is quite different from what is to be found in a Member State. Then there is the question of European—level political parties and their role in the system, and, in this connection, how these parties should be financed. This financing raises a number of issues. First of all, do they exist, these parties? Well, obviously, the answer is yes, they do. Secondly, should they exist? Well, if we have European—level elections for the European Parliament – as we do – then logic dictates the answer: yes. Thirdly, if these European political parties exist, then can they function in any way that makes sense without adequate finance? Again, logic says that they need financing.  At the same time, the system as it exists – and others have referred to this – can be gamed. Virtual parties, cross—party memberships, ad—hoc groups, etc., have been known to gain access to financing. The regulation should ensure that this practice comes to an end. Both these issues should be resolved in the regulation, and resolved speedily.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I would like to say the following on this subject. In my opinion, it is too late for drastic changes, but I will be happy to be wrong. I would like to draw attention to two aspects which, in my opinion, are very important. Mrs Bresso said here what I really like, that European democracy needs democrats. Sometimes it is not enough to stare a little over what militant speeches are made here against the EU, against women. Of course, full value sharing cannot be prescribed, but I find it completely absurd that EU money is used to pay for parties that aim to break up the EU. I really can't understand that or explain it to my constituents. The second thing when it comes to funding national political parties. There is the greatest darkness under the candlestick, and it is quite clear to many, perhaps dozens of parties, that they are being paid from Russian sources, and we are ignoring this matter, the funding of the national political parties that send their representatives here. In my opinion, this is reprehensible.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, European political parties are political bodies whose existence helps to express the will of the people of Europe and to shape the European conscience. These parties, many of which have been supported by millions of voters, are by far the best expression of participatory and representative democracy. For these reasons, they must be funded by European Union funds so that they can operate smoothly and not seek funders outside the European Union. Also, various pretexts should not be invented in order to limit the funding of these parties according to some desires, which we want to set and which we should not serve.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: member of the Commission.- Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for this interesting debate.I have taken careful note of the views that were expressed.The Commission, I repeat, believes very strongly in the need for the presence of political parties which are active and strong at European level and we are fully prepared to cooperate with you to this end.Many suggestions, remarks and proposals have been made which point in this direction.The resolution that your assembly plans to adopt tomorrow will be an important and very welcome contribution to our reflection on the best options to further refine the framework governing political parties at European level.Therefore, I think this debate is going in the same direction that we want.This is the right direction for European democracy.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 15 June 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I support the resolution because I am in favor of a revision of the regulation on the statute and funding of European political parties and European political foundations.Opportunities for abuse and influence must be eliminated and replaced by a transparent process.
